Stomach

- Arterial supply: 5 arteries (resistant to ischaemia) - **need to know!** - Lesser curve: left gastric artery, right gastric artery (HAP CHA) - Greater curve: right gastroepiploic artery (← GDA CHA), left
  gastroepiploic artery (← splenic a.), short gastric artery (← splenic a.)
- Venous drainage
  - Lesser curve: into portal vein
    - Coronary vein: markedly dilated in portal HT, embolized in TIPSS
  - Greater curve: into splenic vein
- Lymphatic drainage (important for CA stomach) - Lesser curve: gastric, suprapyloric → para-aortic nodes around celiac axis - Greater curve: gastroepiploic, subpyloric superior mesenteric nodes
  around SMA
- Innervation - Sympathetic: T5-T12 (vasoconstriction, inhibit gastric motility, pylorus
  constriction) - Parasympathetic: **ant. vagal trunk** from left vagus n., **post. vagal trunk** from
  right vagus n. (secretomotor, pylorus
  relaxation, afferent fibers for sensation)
  Functional anatomy
- Fundus/body: - Parietal cells (80%): intrinsic factor (bind B12
  for absorption at ileum), HCl - Chief cells: pepsin
- Antrum: - Parietal cells (20%) - Mucus cell - G cell: gastrin - D cell: somatostatin - ECL cell: histamine, serotonin
  [Image of a diagram of the upper gastrointestinal tract, with labels pointing to the hepatic portal vein, the head of the pancreas, the portal triad, the hepatic artery proper, the common bile duct, the right free margin of the lesser omentum, the spleen, the suprarenal gland, the pylorus, the kidney, the transverse mesocolon, and its cut edges, the right colic flexure, the ascending colon, the fundus, the right gastro-omental artery, the corpus, the suprarenal gland, the transverse mesocolon and its cut edges, the splenic flexure, and the duodenum]

Duodenum

- Approximately 25cm long: most is **retroperitoneal**
  (except proximal 2.5cm of D1)
- Shortest, widest and most predictably placed part of
  small bowel (L1-L3)
- 4 parts

[Image of a diagram of the duodenum showing the superior, descending, inferior and ascending parts and the root of mesentery]

| Features       | Important relations                                             |
| -------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| D1: superior   | Most mobile: proximal 2.5cm is **intraperitoneal**              | Posterior: **GDA** (PPU may erode into it), CBD, PV Anterior: quadrate lobe of liver                                                                      |
| D2: descending | Ampulla of Vater at posteromedial wall of D2 (8cm from pylorus) | Anterior: gallbladder, R lobe of liver, **transverse colon** Posterior: hilum of R kidney. R renal vessels, psoas major Medial: **head of pancreas**, CBD |
| D3: horizontal | Clamped between SMA and abdominal aorta                         | Posterior: **IVC, aorta**, R ureter, R psoas major, gonadal vessels                                                                                       |
| D4: ascending  | Suspended by ligament of Treitz                                 | Posterior to DJ flexure: **IMV**                                                                                                                          |

- Arterial supply: gastroduodenal a., superior (D1-2) & inferior (D2-3) pancreaticoduodenal a., jejunal a. branches
  (D4)

# 3.2 Dysphagia

Definitions

- Dysphagia: difficulty in swallowing
- Odynophagia: pain on swallowing
- Globus: sensation of having a lump in the throat without true dysphagia; benign

Classical presentations

- Painless progressive dysphagia (over weeks) is malignancy until proven otherwise
- Painful non-progressive dysphagia points to functional causes

Terminology

- Vomiting: forceful expulsion of contents after reaching stomach
- Reflux: backward flow of contents from stomach
- Regurgitation: backward flow of contents (undigested food) from oesophagus

Differential diagnosis

| Functional                                                             | Structural                                                                                                            |
| ---------------------------------------------------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Achalasia                                                              | Intraluminal: foreign body                                                                                            |
| Diffuse esophageal spasm                                               | Intramural: CA esophagus, stricture (e.g. GERD, corrosive injury), esophagitis, esophageal rings / webs               |
| Neurological e.g. stroke, MND, Parkinson's disease, MS, MG, myopathies | Extramural (4T): tumour/ LN (e.g. CA lung, lymphoma), thyroid (retrosternal goitre), thymus, thoracic aortic aneurysm |
| Systemic diseases e.g. scleroderma, Sjogren's syndrome                 |                                                                                                                       |

History taking

|                       | Functional                                                                                           | Structural                                                                                           |
| --------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Onset                 | Acute (stroke) or Slowly progressive (achalasia, MS, PD) or Intermittent (diffuse oesophageal spasm) | Rapidly progressive                                                                                  |
| Type of food          | Fluid > solid                                                                                        | Solid > fluid                                                                                        |
| Difficulty initiating | Yes                                                                                                  | No                                                                                                   |
| Hold-up sensation     | Higher: usually oropharyngeal in origin (lower in achalasia)                                         | Lower: usually oesophageal in origin                                                                 |
| Associated symptoms   | Immediate choking, coughing, nasal regurgitation Neuro symptoms (e.g. dysarthria, weakness)          | Regurgitation Chest discomfort Alarm symptoms: HOV (RLN invasion), bleeding, constitutional symptoms |

- Associated symptoms:
  - GI:
    - Odynophagia (oesophagitis)
    - Chest pain (oesophageal motility disorders)
    - Heart burn, acid sensation, acid reflux, choking (GERD → adenoCA)
  - Neurological
    - Tremor (PD)
    - Ptosis, intermittent weakness (MG)
    - Weakness, dysarthria (stroke)
  - Others
    - Neck swelling (goitre)
    - Cough, hemoptysis, HoV (CA lung)
- Severity: weight loss (overlap with constitutional symptoms), malnutrition, aspiration pneumonia
- PMH: GERD / reflux (stricture), any previous OGD / investigations
- FHx: malignancy
- DH: CCB, nitrates (reflux)
- SH: smoking, alcohol, hot tea

Physical exam

- Functional causes likely:
  - CNS: speech, cognition, CN9-12
  - PNS: limb weakness (stroke), Parkinsonism (PD), fatigability (MG)
  - Skin: scleroderma
- Structural causes likely:
  - HEENT: radiation mark
  - Thyroid: goitre, thyroid status
  - Lymph node (Virchow's node)
  - Abdomen: epigastric mass, hepatomegaly
- Complications - Nutritional status - Respiratory exam: signs of aspiration pneumonia
  Investigations
- Suspect structural causes: OGD - diagnostic and therapeutic
- Suspect functional causes:
  - Barium swallow: can visualize obstructive lesions, less invasive
    - **Gastrografin** contrast: safe for suspected perforation, but may cause **chemical pneumonitis** if aspirated
      - If high risk of aspiration: use **Omnipaque** (water-soluble contrast medium: lower osmolarity and thus lower risk of pulmonary oedema c.f. gastrografin)
  - Video-fluoroscopic swallowing study (VFSS)
  - **Manometry** (achalasia)

# 3.3 UGIB

Definitions

- Upper GI bleeding: bleeding from oesophagus to ligament of Treitz (DJ flexure)
- Lower GI bleeding: bleeding from ligament of Treitz to rectum
- GI bleeding of obscured origin: bleeding of unknown origin with negative top & tail; most found in small bowel eventually
  - Obscured overt GI bleeding: with obvious GI bleeding symptoms (UGIB/LGIB)
  - Obscured occult GI bleeding: with IDA and FOBT positive

Differential diagnosis

- Oesophagus: oesophagitis, oesophageal varices, Mallory-Weiss syndrome, malignancy
- Stomach: gastritis, PUD (MC), Dieulafoy's lesion, portal hypertensive gastropathy, gastric varices, malignancy
- Duodenum: duodenitis, ulcer, malignancy, haemobilia (cholangiocarcinoma)
- Aortic-enteric fistula (after aortic repair with grafts)
- Any site: AV malformation

Important questions

- Vomitus: amount, character (hematemesis [fast rate of bleeding], coffee ground [small amount/ slow rate that is altered in stomach], haemoptysis)
- Stool: melena (slow bleeding that is altered through digestion in GIT), haematochezia (fresh PR bleeding that is profuse & fast)
  - Melena: fresh (jet-black tarry stool) vs stale (black-grey dull, mixed with normal stool)
- Severity: for emergency OGD
  - Volume loss: syncope, postural hypotension, palpitation
  - Rate of bleeding: massive haematemesis + fresh PR bleed
  - Anaemic symptoms: UNCOMMON (both plasma & blood cells are lost)
- Associated symptoms:
  - Preceding forceful vomiting (Mallory-Weiss syndrome)
  - Epigastric pain associated with meal (PUD)
  - Jaundice, easy bruising, distended abdomen, peripheral oedema (liver failure)
  - Constitutional symptoms (malignancy), dysphagia (CA oesophagus), persistent epigastric pain (CA stomach)
- Risk factors: drug (antiplatelet/ anticoagulant, NSAID, steroid), H pylori, liver disease

Initial management: resuscitation, localisation of bleeding, haemostasis

- Resuscitation:
  - Airway: cuffed ET tube + NG tube if massive haematemesis / IO
  - Breathing: O2
  - Circulation:
    - Closely monitor pulse, BP, I/O
    - (ATLS classification of haemorrhagic shock - **important!**)
    - NPO, 2 large bore IV cannula
    - IV NS 2L FR to maintain BP/P + urine output
    - Blood transfusion if Hb < 7 or massive\*
    - Withhold anticoagulants and antiplatelets (balance thrombotic risk when considering reversal)

[Image of a table with the following columns: BloodLoss (ml), %, HR, BP, PP, RR, UOP, CNS. The table has four classes (I, II, III, IV) with corresponding values for each parameter.]

- Pre-endoscopy management:
  - Bloods: CBC (baseline Hb), clotting, X-match, LRFT, VBG (acidosis)
  - RFT: elevated urea:Cr ratio (>100:1) because Hb digestion + reduced renal perfusion
  - CXR (pneumoperitoneum caused by PPU, left-sided pleural effusion by Boerhaave's perforation)
  - CT aortogram if Hx aortic graft (aorto-enteric fistula)

52

- Pre-endoscopic PPI (IV esomeprazole 80mg stat → 8mg/h until OGD) (HO handbook: only if early endoscopy cannot be arranged)
- Risk stratification:

Good prognosis if < 3, high mortality if > 8
Better at predicting rebleeding/ mortality within 30 days

- For cirrhotic patients (suspected esophageal varices): - IV antibiotics (SBP prophylaxis): IV ceftriaxone 1g daily for 7 days / augmentin / levofloxacin - IV vitamin K1 - Vasoactive drug: either one - IV octreotide: somatostatin analogue with increased half-life; inhibit vasodilator hormone (e.g. glucagon) + direct splanchnic vasoconstriction - IV terlipressin: V1 agonist for non-specific arteriole vasoconstriction (caution if CV risk, e.g. IHD, stroke)
  OGD
- Indications
  - Emergency: unstable haemodynamics despite resuscitation, massive haematemesis, suspected variceal bleeding
  - Elective (NPO 6h before OGD): all other cases
  - 2nd look OGD: if GU (6-8 weeks) or large/ complicated DU
- Contraindications: suspected perforation, unstable cardiac/ pulmonary status
- Diagnostic: **Forrest classification** (endoscopic stigmata of recent haemorrhage) - **important!**

|                              | Forrest | Risk of re-bleeding if untreated | Management                    |
| ---------------------------- | ------- | -------------------------------- | ----------------------------- |
| Acute spurter                | Ia      | ~ 100%                           | Endoscopic therapy, then      |
| Acute oozing                 | Ib      | 10-27%                           | IV PPI bolus + infusion x 72h |
| Non-bleeding visible vessel  | IIa     | 50%                              |                               |
| Non-bleeding adherent clot\* | IIb     | 30-35%                           |                               |
| Flat spot                    | IIc     | 5-8%                             | Oral PPI                      |
| Clean base                   | III     | <3%                              |                               |

[Image of Endoscopy of a bleeding ulcer, the ulcer has stopped bleeding. A white arrow is pointing towards the scar of the bleeding ulcer.]

[Image of Endoscopy of a bleeding ulcer, the ulcer is bleeding actively. A white arrow is pointing towards the bleeding ulcer.]

[Image of Endoscopy of a bleeding ulcer, the ulcer has stopped bleeding and is covered by a blood clot. A white arrow is pointing towards the blood clot covering the ulcer.]

\*Need to remove by vigorous flushing to reveal underlying vessels

- Therapeutic (**need to know!**)
  - Bleeding ulcer: **dual therapy**, i.e. adrenaline + heater probe or clips (more prolonged action)
    - Injection therapy: **adrenaline 1:10000** (**tamponade** + **vasoconstriction** + **platelet aggregation**)
    - Thermal therapy: **heater probe** (coaptive effect: pressure + heat)
    - Mechanical therapy: **haemospray** "雲南白藥"(mechanical barrier + absorbent), clips (for large area ulcer)
  - Variceal bleeding
    - **Endoscopic band ligation** (EBL): 1st line for _oesophageal_ varices
    - **Histoacryl glue** (sclerosant)
      - 1st line for _gastric_ varices (EBL cannot catch the thick gastric wall)
      - Complications: ulceration, stricture, mediastinitis, obviate use of subsequent EBL
    - Persistent/ recurrent bleeding
      - Sengstaken-Blakemore tube
      - Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunts (TIPSS )
      - Surgical shunts
- Post-OGD PPI infusion: pantoprazole/esomeprazole 80mg stat, then 8mg/h for 72h (higher pH stabilises clot since platelet function depends on normal pH)
  - Indicated for endoscopic treatment for Forrest Class Ia, Ib, IIa, IIb _ulcer bleeding_
  - _NOT_ efficacious for _variceal_ bleeding: only give oral PPI to _reduce post-banding ulcers_
- Principles of antithrombotic management
  - Withhold all stat +/- reversal agents
  - Resume aspirin after OGD, clopidogrel 5-7 days later
- Alternative investigations in inconclusive OGD (refer to LGIB section)

[Image of the number 53 in the top right corner of the page.]

3.4 Benign diseases of esophagus
Achalasia
Definition

- Most common esophageal motility disorder: loss of receptive relaxation of LES
- Characterised by a triad of:

1.  Aperistalsis with uncoordinated contraction
2.  Increased LES tone at rest
3.  Poor LES relaxation in response to swallowing

DDx:

- Pseudo-achalasia (paraneoplastic: CA cardia invades esophageal neural plexus) - differentiate by OGD + EUS
- Other esophageal motility disorders - differentiate by esophageal manometry (normal LES pressure)

Pathophysiology

- Causes: primary, secondary (e.g. Chagas disease: degeneration of myenteric plexus due to Trypanosoma cruzi
  infection)
- Degeneration of inhibitory neurons (NO/VIP) in myenteric (Auerbach's) plexus → unopposed activity of
  excitatory neurons (Ach): Initially presented with uncoordinated peristalsis → aperistalsis

Clinical features

- Age: MC 35-45, but actually any age group
- Progressive dysphagia (solid + liquid)
- Regurgitation after meal → acidic smell (fermentation of food)
- Chest pain (food stasis in lower oesophagus)
- Recurrent aspiration pneumonia, weight loss

Investigations

- High-resolution oesophageal manometry (HRM): for definitive diagnosis (triad of high resting LES pressure,
  failure to relax upon swallowing, abnormal peristalsis) and Chicago classification (based on esophageal
  pressure topography, see fig.)
- Type I: achalasia with minimal oesophageal pressurisation
- Type II: achalasia with oesophageal compression (pan-
  esophageal pressurisation)
- Type III: achalasia with esophageal spasm
- OGD: to assess complications (e.g. oesophagitis, SCC
  oesophagus) & rule out mechanical causes (e.g. malignancy,
  stricture)
- Typical finding: tight cardia and food residue in
  esophagus
- Barium swallow (fig.): usually not done now
- Bird's beak sign (early): hold up of contrast with tapering stricture in distal
  esophagus and proximal dilation
- Sigmoid-like appearance due to massive oesophageal dilatation (late)
- Any shouldering/ heaping should lead to suspicion of pseudo-achalasia (due to
  extramural obstruction, e.g. OGJ tumour)
- Barium vs gastrografin
- Barium: avoid if risk of perforation - barium peritonitis
- Gastrografin: avoid if risk of aspiration - chemical pneumonitis
- CXR: widening of mediastinum, absent gastric bubble, air-fluid level behind heart,
  double right heart border

[Image: Three line graphs labeled as 'A: Type I', 'B: Type II', and 'C: Type III', each representing esophageal pressure over time. The y-axis shows Length along the esophagus (cm) going from 5 to 35, and the x-axis shows Time (s). The graphs display different patterns of pressure, with 'Type III' exhibiting the most pronounced pressure spikes.]

[Image: An x-ray image displaying the esophagus, which appears to be significantly dilated. The lower part of the esophagus shows a tapered stricture, creating a narrow point just before the stomach. The overall appearance suggests a "bird's beak" shape.]

Complications

- Stasis of food: erosions, candida esophagitis
- Lower esophageal diverticula
- Aspiration pneumonia
- Esophageal SCC
  54

Management

- Pharmacotherapy (CCB, nitrates): transient symptomatic relief only
- Endoscopic treatment - to abolish LES
  - Graded pneumatic balloon dilation of LES → disrupt muscles
    - Curative in 65-85% of patients
    - Complications: perforation, GERD
  - Endoscopic injection of Botox (block ACh release from nerve terminals)
  - Per-oral endoscopic myotomy (POEM): creation of a submucosal tunnel at mid-oesophagus, allow long myotomy
    - Complications: reflux (no fundoplication done → PPI), mediastinitis, surgical emphysema
- Surgical treatment: laparoscopic Heller's myotomy
  - Indication: failed endoscopic Tx
  - With partial anterior fundoplication (180°) to prevent post-op GERD (Heller-Dor operation)
  - Successful in ≥ 90% cases
  - Complications: perforation, dysphagia (due to fundoplication)
- Comparison of treatment
  - Myotomy (endoscopic/lap) most effective
  - POEM has fewer hospital stay, but more reflux as no fundoplication done
  - Lap Heller's myotomy has more dysphagia

Other esophageal motility disorders

- Diffuse (Distal) esophageal spasm: uncoordinated simultaneous / premature contractions in distal esophagus
  - S/S: severe retrosternal chest pain + dysphagia / GERD
  - Barium swallow: cockscrew esophagus
- Hypercontractile esophagus (jackhammer / nutcracker esophagus): high pressure but normal coordinated contractions
  - S/S: odynophagia
- Absent esophageal peristalsis due to systemic sclerosis (SSC)
  [Image: Two anatomical illustrations side by side, labeled A and B. Both depict the junction between the esophagus and the stomach. In illustration A, labeled "Trapped food," the esophagus narrows sharply near the stomach, creating a pocket where food is lodged. A small, horizontal cut is shown on the esophagus. Illustration B, labeled "Split muscle," shows a similar junction, but the esophagus is wider, with a surgical cut separating the muscle fibers.]
  [Image: X-ray of the esophagus showing a narrowing in the middle portion, with the shape of the esophagus resembling a corkscrew]

# Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)

(Refer to [MED] for clinical features and medical treatments)
Relationship with hiatus hernia and oesophagitis

- Inter-related, although they can occur independently
- Oesophagitis: can develop into ulcer → stricture → Barrett's oesophagus (10%) → metaplasia → adenoCa (7% of Barrett's)
  Surgical treatment

[Diagram illustrating the relationships between GERD, Hiatus Hernia and Oesophagitis.
GERD is in the center.
A double headed arrow points from GERD to Hiatus Hernia.
A double headed arrow points from GERD to Oesophagitis.]

- Pre-op: esophageal manometry, 24h ambulatory pH monitoring, OGD x biopsy (refer to [MED])
- Indications
  - Young and fit PPI-dependent patients (so as to avoid long term use of PPI)
  - GERD / Complications unresponsive to medical treatment (very rare: consider alternative diagnosis)
- Contraindications: aperistalsis → risk of dysphagia
- Laparoscopic fundoplication
  - Goal:
    - Close the hiatal defect
    - Restore the pressure around LES and angle of His
    - Lengthen the intra-abdominal part of oesophagus
  - Types:
    - Total (Nissen): 360° → more durable, but more dysphagia
    - Partial (e.g. Toupet, Lind, Dor): preferred in Chinese - less dysphagia
      - Toupet: posterior 270°
      - Dor / Watson: anterior 90 or 180°) - in Heller's myotomy
  - Specific complications:
    - Improved anti-reflux mechanism: **gas bloat syndrome** (90%) esp. in Nissen (inability to burp or vomit, flatus; self-limiting in 4 weeks)
    - Too tight: dysphagia (50% in early post-op, 10% long-term)
      - Ix: **Water-soluble contrast swallow**
      - Tx: endoscopic Bougie balloon dilation / revise fundoplication
    - Too loose: recurrence of reflux
    - Surgical emphysema (gas absorbed in mediastinum)
    - Perforation → mediastinitis
    - Slipped Nissen: wrap slides down, GEJ retracts into chest
  - Efficacy: PPI independence rate ~60%
- Endoscopic treatment (emerging treatment option):
  - Target LES: RFA (by inducing LES hypertrophy)
  - Target EGJ: Transoral incisionless fundoplication

[Image depicting three different surgical fundoplication techniques. From left to right they are Nissen, Dor and Toupet.
Nissen shows the Normal Stomach with a blue box around the gastroesophageal junction. Next to it, an illustration shows the sutured fundus wrapped completely around the esophagus.
Dor shows the Normal Stomach with a blue box around the gastroesophageal junction. Next to it, an illustration shows the sutured fundus wrapped partially around the anterior part of the esophagus.
Toupet shows the Normal Stomach with a blue box around the gastroesophageal junction. Next to it, an illustration shows the sutured fundus wrapped partially around the posterior part of the esophagus.]

[Image illustrating Laparoscope cannula sites for laparoscopic fundoplication.
A torso is shown with five red dots representing the laparoscopic cannula sites.]

# Barrett's oesophagus

- Definition: **intestinal metaplasia** of oesophageal stratified squamous epithelium to **columnar epithelium** (with mucus-secreting goblet cells) as an adaptation mechanism to long-term acid reflux
- Clinical features: Long-standing GERD, dysphagia, heartburn, UGIB
  - H. pylori infection is a protective factor due to parietal cell atrophy
- Classification: Classic (≥ 3cm columnar epithelium) vs Short- segment (<3cm columnar epithelium)
  - Prague's classification (fig.): C = circumferential extent, M = maximal extent
- Investigations: OGD with biopsy +/- chromoendoscopy (e.g. NBI, Lugol's iodine) for higher sensitivity
  - "Seattle protocol": biopsy every 1-2cm in 4 quadrants
- Diagnostic:
  - Proximal migration of squamocolumnar junction (Z- line) >1cm
  - Salmon-pink epithelium in distal oesophagus
- Detect complications: Barrett's ulcers, strictures, dysplasia, adenocarcinoma (↑risk 0.5%/year)

[Diagram of the distal esophagus and gastric cardia in Barrett's oesophagus.
The esophagus is shaped like a tube with a narrowing at the bottom. The distal esophagus is orange colored, and the proximal margin of the Barrett's tongue is shown at the top. The gastric cardia at the bottom of the esophagus is red colored, and the proximal margin of the cardiac folds is shown at the bottom.
Arrows point vertically from the Proximal margin of the longest Barrett's tongue to the Proximal margin of the cardiac folds. A bracket on the arrow indicates this length is M (maximal extent).
Shorter Arrows point vertically from the Proximal margin of the circumferential Barrett's segment to the Proximal margin of the cardiac folds. A bracket on the arrow indicates this length is C (circumferential extent).]

57

- Management:
  - Treat underlying GERD: high-dose PPI for life
  - Endoscopic surveillance:
    - No dysplasia: OGD + biopsy Q3y (>3cm) or Q5y (<3cm)
    - Low-grade dysplasia: OGD at 6 months x 2 then Q1y if negative, or endoscopic treatment
    - High-grade dysplasia: intense surveillance (Q3mo), or endoscopic treatment (e.g. EMR) (advised)

[Image Description: A flowchart titled "Summary of updated British Society of Gastroenterology guidelines for surveillance of BO.1" showing pathways for managing Non-dysplastic Barrett's Esophagus (BO), Low-Grade Dysplasia (LGD), and High-Grade Dysplasia (HGD). The Non-dysplastic BO branch splits based on length (<3cm or >=3cm). The LGD branch involves repeat OGD in 6 months. The HGD branch involves MDT referral. Hiatal hernia
Definitions: protrusion of an organ from abdominal cavity into thorax via oesophageal hiatus of diaphragm
Classification
Sliding (Type 1) vs Para-esophageal (Types 2-4)
| I | Sliding: Herniation of OGJ above diaphragm (MC) |
| II | Rolling: Herniation of fundus, but fixed OGJ |
| III | Mixed: Herniation of both OGJ and fundus |
| IV | Herniation of organs other than stomach |

[Image Description: Four cartoon diagrams depicting different types of hiatal hernia: Type I (Sliding), Type II (Rolling), Type III (Mixed), and Type IV (Herniation of organs other than stomach). Each diagram shows the relative positions of the stomach, esophagus, and diaphragm, illustrating the varying degrees and manners in which the stomach protrudes into the chest cavity.]

Risk factors

- Age: loss of diaphragmatic tone, increased diaphragmatic diameter
- Increased intra-abdominal pressure: pregnancy, obesity, ascites
- Previous surgery around hiatus: anti-reflux surgery, Heller's myotomy, partial gastrectomy
  Clinical features
- Asymptomatic (MC)
- GERD symptoms
  - Anti-reflux eliminated in hiatus hernia: intra-abdominal part of oesophagus, angle of His, mucosal fold
  - Bleeding (oesophageal ulceration)
- Chest pain, hiccups, palpitations (irritation of diaphragm/pericardial sac)
- Dysphagia (oesophageal stricture/ incarceration of hernia)
- Complications: surgical emergency (Mx: NG tube decompression + EOT)
  - Gastric volvulus (only in rolling type)
  - Strangulation
  - Gastric perforation
  - Gangrene
    Investigations
- CXR: gastric bubble in retrocardiac area
- CT thorax with oral contrast: diagnostic
- OGD: upward displacement of Z-line (fig.) – Hill classification

[Image Description: Two X-ray images of a chest, side by side. In the left image, the lungs and heart are visible in grayscale. In the right image, the same anatomy is present, but the esophagus is highlighted in blue and the stomach is highlighted in green, showing their position in relation to the diaphragm.]

[Image Description: Four sets of three images. The first image in each set shows the type of hiatal hernia (Type I to Type IV). The second image is an endoscopic view of the lower esophagus with a hiatal hernia. The third image in each set is a schematic illustration of the hernia.]

Management

- Conservative: indicated if sliding hernia (Type 1)
  - Weight loss, smoking cessation, reduce alcohol intake
  - Treat GERD: PPI
- Surgical (hernia repair + Nissen fundoplication): indicated in
  - Symptomatic despite max medical treatment
  - Rolling type: Increased risk of gastric volvulus

Oesophageal varices
Refer to [MED]

Esophageal perforation
Clinical features

- Cervical: neck pain, surgical emphysema, dysphagia, odynophagia
- Thoracic: retrosternal chest pain, SOB, cyanosis
- Abdominal: acute abdomen
  Causes
- Iatrogenic (MC): therapeutic OGD, transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE), NG tube insertion
- Foreign body (e.g. fish bone, corrosives)
- Boerhaave's syndrome (violent vomiting) → Barotrauma
- Penetrating injuries
  Investigations
- Erect CXR: surgical emphysema
- CT with contrast swallow: localize site of esophageal defect
  Treatment
- Conservative - Cameron's criteria
  - NPO, IV fluids, broad spectrum antibiotics
  - Nutritional support (TPN, feeding jejunostomy, NJ tube)
  - Drainage
- Surgical:
  - Early presentation within 4-6h: direct repair
  - Late presentation: external fistula (T-tube), Endo-vac therapy, esophagectomy +/- delayed reconstruction
    - May require flaps: e.g. intercostal, latissimus dorsi, diaphragm

[Image Description: Illustration depicting surgical management of esophageal perforation. The drawing shows a section of the esophagus with a surgical drain inserted through a perforation, positioned within the mediastinum. Adjacent anatomical structures such as the trachea and surrounding tissues are also visible.]

[Image Description: Coronal CT image showing iatrogenic pharyngeal perforation.]

Cameron's criteria

- Minimal S/S: low-grade fever, leucocytosis, mild pain controllable by opioids
- Absence of shock / sepsis
- Contained leakage within neck / mediastinum with good drainage into esophagus
- Absence of distal obstruction and malignancy

Mallory-Weiss syndrome and Boerhaave's syndrome

|                   | Mallory-Weiss syndrome                                                                                                                                                                                       | Boerhaave's syndrome                                                                                                                                                                                                     |
| :---------------- | :----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | :----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Definition        | Longitudinal mucosal (superficial) tears of distal oesophagus                                                                                                                                                | Full-thickness rupture of oesophagus (MC at left posterolateral aspect of distal esophagus)                                                                                                                              |
| Pathogenesis      | Excessive alcohol intake → severe retching                                                                                                                                                                   | - Failed relaxation of glottis when vomiting → Pressure goes down to lower esophagus - Oesophagus has no serosa → susceptible to perforation                                                                             |
| Risk factors      | Chronic alcoholism, chemotherapy, sudden increase in abdominal pressure                                                                                                                                      |                                                                                                                                                                                                                          |
| Clinical features | UGIB (Haematemesis +/- melena) classically after retching                                                                                                                                                    | - Mackler's triad: vomiting, excruciating chest pain, surgical emphysema - Left pneumothorax, left pleural effusion - Hamman's sign (mediastinal clicking sound synchronous with heartbeat due to mediastinal emphysema) |
| Investigations    | CXR: pneumomediastinum, pleural effusion, hemothorax CT with contrast                                                                                                                                        |                                                                                                                                                                                                                          |
| Management        | 90% bleeding stops spontaneously Resuscitation, NPO, IV fluids Active bleeding: OGD for adrenaline + clipping Failed endoscopic Tx: on-table endoscopy + surgery (longitudinal gastrotomy and locate defect) | Resuscitation, NPO, IV fluids NG decompression IV broad-spectrum antibiotics Urgent OT for decontamination + repair                                                                                                      |

# Zenker's diverticulum

Anatomy: Killian's dehiscence

- At the midline of the posterior wall of pharynx between the 2 parts of inf. constrictor (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus)
  Pathogenesis
- Hypertonic cricopharyngeus
- High intrabolus pressure during swallowing
  Clinical features
- Dysphagia, with gurgling in throat, food regurgitation into mouth
- Foul breath
- Aspiration
- Risk of malignant transformation
  Diagnosis: barium swallow
  Management:
- Observe: if small & asymptomatic
- Surgical: open/ endoscopic cricopharyngeal myotomy + diverticulectomy

# Corrosive esophagitis

Type of agent

- Alkali: more likely to be ingested in large volume, cause liquefaction necrosis (_transmural damage_)
- Acid: cause coagulative necrosis with eschar formation (_limited penetration to deeper layers_), but more damage to stomach due to pooling in antrum due to pylorospasm
  Immediate management
- Drink water to dilute the agent
- OGD under GA
- NPO, IV fluids, antibiotics
- +/- tracheostomy to secure away
- +/- OGD balloon dilation of strictures

60 3. 5 CA esophagus
Epidemiology

- Common in male of 60-70, M:F = 3:1
- SCC most common in HK (90%) c.f. Western countries
- Prognosis poor: > 50% metastasis at presentation, 5-year survival is just 5-10%

| Risk factors                                                                                      | Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)                                                                  | Adenocarcinoma (ADC)                |
| :------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ | :--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | :---------------------------------- |
|                                                                                                   | Lifestyle: **smoking, alcohol, hot drink, nitrosamine**, betel nut, corrosive / caustic injury | GERD                                |
|                                                                                                   | **Oesophageal disorders:** achalasia, Plummer-Vinson syndrome^, long-standing esophagitis      | Barrett oesophagus                  |
|                                                                                                   | Genetics: tylosis^                                                                             |                                     |
| Site                                                                                              | Mostly in upper 2/3                                                                            | Mostly in lower 1/3                 |
| Morphology                                                                                        | Fungating > ulcerative > infiltrative                                                          |                                     |
| Tumor spread                                                                                      | Direct extension (e.g. tracheo-esophageal fistula)                                             |                                     |
|                                                                                                   | Vascular and lymphatics                                                                        |                                     |
| Management                                                                                        | More sensitive to chemoRT                                                                      | Less sensitive to chemoRT → surgery |
| Other possible pathology: neuroendocrine tumor, leiomyoma, GIST, lymphoma                         |                                                                                                |
| ^PVS: triad of post-cricoid dysphagia, IDA, oesophageal web; unknown pathophysiology              |                                                                                                |
| ^Tylosis: AD genetic disorder characterised by hyperkeratosis of palms & soles + oral leukoplakia |                                                                                                |

Clinical features

- **Painless progressive dysphagia (MC)**: ≥75% stenosis
- Odynophagia: usually due to extra-esophageal involvement
- UGIB: haematemesis, coffee ground vomiting, tarry stool, anemic symptoms
- Regurgitation/choking/ aspiration pneumonia: due to esophageal obstruction
- Signs suggestive of locally advanced disease:
  - Stridor / **hoarseness of voice**: vocal cord paralysis (usually left RLN palsy)
  - Horner's syndrome
  - Respiratory symptoms: tracheo-esophageal fistula
  - Hypercalcaemia: HHM - PTHrP (10%)
  - Distant metastasis: Virchow's node, liver (hepatomegaly + ascites), lung (hemoptysis, PE), bone

Investigations

- Diagnosis: **OGD + biopsy**: confirmatory _histological_ diagnosis and pre-op assessment
  - Proximal margin (distance from incisor)
  - Span of tumor
  - % involvement of luminal circumference
  - Whether scope can pass through
- Staging work-up: **EUS + PET-CT (neck + thorax + abdomen)**
  - **Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS)**: best for T & N staging → determine need of neoadjuvant chemoRT
    - T: Assess depth of wall invasion: important to distinguish T1a vs T1b (need open surgery)
    - N: EUS-guided FNAC of suspicious LN (hypoechoic, >1cm, spherical, homogenous)
    - Can also implant metallic markers for delineation of RT
  - **CT whole body with contrast**: for locoregional involvement (T3/4) and distant metastasis (M)
  - **PET-CT**: similar sensitivity as CT for distant metastasis (M)
    - Can also assess the metabolic activity after neoadjuvant chemoRT / detect recurrence
    - May pick up additional signals (e.g. reactive hilar LN due to smoking)
  - - USG neck
  - - Diagnostic laparoscopy: recommended for OGJ tumors (adenoCA) for hepatic / peritoneal seeding
  - - Bronchoscopy: for cervical / upper thoracic tumors to detect **tracheal invasion** → may require stenting before RT to prevent iatrogenic tracheo-esophageal fistula
- Others:
  - CBC, LRFT, clotting
  - Lung function (CXR, ABG, lung function test) for pre-op assessment
  - Laryngoscopy: baseline vocal cord status

Staging of CA esophagus

| :--- | :------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| TX   | ➡ Primary tumour cannot be assessed                                                                |
| TO   | ➡ No evidence of primary tumour                                                                    |
| Tis  | ➡ High-grade dysplasia                                                                             |
| T1 a | ➡ Tumour invades lamina propria or muscularis mucosae                                              |
| T1 b | ➡ Tumour invades submucosa                                                                         |
| T2   | ➡ Tumour invades muscularis propria                                                                |
| T3   | ➡ Tumour invades adventitia                                                                        |
| T4   | ➡ Resectable tumour invading pleural, pericardium or diaphragm                                     |
|      | ➡ Unresectable tumour invading other adjacent structures such as aorta, trachea and vertebral body |

|     | Regional lymph node (N)                        |

| NX  | ➡ Regional lymph node cannot be assessed       |

61

Management:

- Tumor factor (staging): size and location of tumor, location of anastomosis, regional invasion, LN
  - Resectable: pleura, pericardium, diaphragm
  - Unresectable: aorta, trachea, vertebral body
- Patient factor: age, smoker, comorbidities, lung function (FEV1 > 1.5L), exercise tolerance (> 2 flight of stairs)
- Organ factor: method of reconstructing esophagus

| Stage | TNM staging      | Treatment                                                         |
| :---- | :--------------- | :---------------------------------------------------------------- |
| 0     | Tis, N0, M0      | Tis/T1a (confined to mucosa): EMR / ESD                           |
| 1     | T1, N0, M0       | T1b (invades submucosa): esophagectomy                            |
| 2     | T2-3, N0, M0     | Operable SCC: neoadjuvant chemoRT + esophagectomy                 |
|       | T1-2, N1, M0     | Inoperable SCC: upfront chemoRT +/- esophagectomy (if downstaged) |
| 3     | T3, any N, M0    | Operable ADC: esophagectomy                                       |
|       |                  | Inoperable ADC: chemoRT                                           |
| 4     | any T, any N, M1 | Esophageal balloon dilation +/- stenting                          |
|       |                  | Palliative chemoRT                                                |

Endoscopic therapy: Endoscopic mucosal resection (EMR) / Endoscopic submucosal dissection (ESD)

- Only for T1a cancers (limited to mucosa)
- Preserves esophagus, less invasive, safe and highly effective (90% survival)
  - ESD has higher en-bloc resection rate
- Procedure: using hyaluronic acid + saline to elevate the lesion → snare and remove

[Detailed illustration of EMR (left) and ESD (right) procedures. The left side shows the steps involved in EMR: 1. Careful marking around the tumor using endoscopic marking. 2. Inject saline solution underneath the affected area to raise it. 3. Cut along the markings using an insulated tip knife. 4. Remove the cancerous tissue. The right side illustrates ESD: 5. Snare advanced toward the lesion after submucosal dissection is precisely tuned so that only cancerous tissue is snared. 6. Snare ready to coagulate.]

Esophagectomy

- Ultra-major surgery: 1-3% mortality, 30-40% morbidity
- Only 1/3 tumour resectable at presentation: advanced stage at presentation + comorbidities
- Prerequisites:
  - Good pulmonary function (FEV1 > 1.5L) and good physiological function (ET > 2 FOS)
  - Stage 2 or 3 tumors
  - No invasion to trachea, aorta, RLN
  - No extra-regional LN
  - No distant metastasis
- Principles:
  - Complete resection (R0): Proximal and distal margins of 5cm, adventitial margins, radical
    lymphadenectomy (R1: microscopic residual disease, R2: macroscopic residual disease)
  - For OGJ tumour, partial gastrectomy may be required
  - Maintenance of GIT continuity: stomach transposition + pyloroplasty, colonic interposition, etc.
- Approach:

| Site of tumour |              Two-stage (Ivor-Lewis)              |    Three-stage (McKeown) - preferred for SCC     |
| -------------- | :----------------------------------------------: | :----------------------------------------------: |
| Incisions      |                    Mid/lower                     |             All (including proximal)             |
|                |                   2 incisions                    |                   3 incisions                    |
|                |        - Upper midline abdominal incision        |        - Upper midline abdominal incision        |
|                |     - **Right** thoracotomy (above 5th rib)      |             - **Right** thoracotomy              |
|                | [Image of a human torso with surgical incisions] |            - **Left** neck incisions             |
|                |                                                  | [Image of a human torso with surgical incisions] |

| Anastomosis |                                   Thorax                                    |                                              Neck                                               |
| ----------- | :-------------------------------------------------------------------------: | :---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------: |
| Stages\*    |            1. **Abdominal**: gastric mobilization + pyloroplasty            |                    1. **Thoracic**: mobilization and dissection of esophagus                    |
|             | 2. **Thoracic**: mobilization and transection of esophagus, O-G anastomosis |                      2. **Abdominal**: gastric mobilization + pyloroplasty                      |
|             |                                                                             |        3. **Cervical**: mobilization and transection of upper esophagus, O-G anastomosis        |
| Pros        |                               Reduced OT time                               |    **Less severe consequence of anastomotic leak →** can control by lay-open cervical wound     |
|             |                       Lower risk of anastomotic leak                        |                                                                                                 |
| Cons        | Severe consequence of anastomotic leak: **mediastinitis → high mortality**  |                                 Higher risk of left RLN injury                                  |
|             |                       Not suitable for higher tumour                        | Higher risk of anastomotic leak (10%): gastric conduit has more tension and poorer blood supply |

- \*Details of procedure:
  - Gastric mobilisation
    - Ligate left-sided blood supply: short gastric a., left gastric a., left gastroepiploic a.
    - Bring gastric conduit up thorax via native tract of esophagus (lowest tension, best blood supply) or other routes if re-operate (e.g. retrosternal, subcutaneous)
  - Pyloroplasty: improve gastric emptying post-op
    - Insert feeding jejunostomy tube
    - Alternative: colonic interposition (e.g. prev. gastrectomy, post-leakage) - need bowel prep & ABx
  - Lymphadenectomy
    - Extent: 10cm proximal and 5cm distal to macroscopic tumor
    - 2-field dissection: Field 1 & 2 for upper 1/3, Field 2 & 3 for lower 1/3
- Other approaches of esophagectomy
  - Transhiatal esophagectomy: unsuitable for SCC, usually for palliation, rarely done now
    - Complete mediastinal lymphadenectomy is difficult → increased risk of recurrence
    - Advantages: reduced risk of pneumonia, suitable for poor lung function
  - Thoraco-abdominal approach: for very distal tumour (approach limited by arch of aorta → only for tumours below)
  - Pharyngo-laryngo-oesophagectomy (PLO): for very proximal tumour, rarely done
    - Require permanent tracheostomy and voice rehab → primary chemoRT is preferred now

Fields of LN dissection:

1. Cervical LN
2. Mediastinal LN
3. Intra-abdominal
   (celiac) LN

#

Neoadjuvant therapy (CROSS 2012 trial)

- Indication: locally advanced SCC-**T2N1, T3N0, T3N1**
- Regimen: 5-fluorouracil + cisplatin + 40 Gy RT
  - 6-8 weeks for 2 courses → wait 4 weeks and repeat PET-CT + OGD → wait 4 weeks for surgery
- S/E: RT-induced fibrosis, worsened dysphagia

Complications of esophagectomy
Early complications

- Post-op pneumonia (20%): due to smoker status, thoracotomy, one-lung ventilation, vocal cord palsy
- Reactional bleeding: transection of azygos vein / aortic branches to esophagus
- Conduit related:
  - Anastomotic leak (10%) – _DDx_: conduit ischemia
    - Risk factors: poor blood supply of oesophagus, tension of conduit, absence of serosa, use of neoadjuvant RT, surgeon technique
    - Management:
      - NPO, IV fluids, TPN, antibiotics, monitor drain output
      - Conservative: lay open for drainage (three-stage only)
      - Endoscopic: stenting, endoscopic vacuum therapy (e.g. EndoSpong)
  - Conduit ischaemia
    - Suspect if sepsis or metabolic acidosis within first 24h
    - Prevention: intra-op ICG
    - Investigations: CT thorax + abdomen with contrast, OGD
    - Management:
      - Conservative if mild (Types 1 / 2)
      - Take down anastomosis if severe (Type 3): cervical esophagostomy + resection of ischemic conduit
- Injury to neighbouring structures - RLN injury (20%) during LN dissection - Vagus nerve injury: delayed gastric emptying → routine pyloroplasty - Thoracic duct injury: chylothorax - Diagnosis: ↑drain output (milky appearance), TG >110 or chylomicrons in pleural fluid - Management - Monitor: clinical (SOB), CXR, drain output - Determine drain output: low volume (<1L/day) vs high volume (>1L/day) - Diet: NPO + ΤΡΝ - Octreotide - Re-operation (Suture ligation of thoracic duct stump) if output >1L/day - Other organs: descending aorta, pulmonary vein, trachea/bronchus, heart - GA complications: e.g. atelectasis – one lung ventilation during surgery
  Late complications
- Anastomotic stricture: require endoscopic dilation
- Post-op GERD: PPI, motility agents
- Biliary reflux
- Delayed gastric emptying

[Image of a black cylindrical sponge-like medical device, attached to a clear plastic tube. This is an EndoSponge. Below, there is a table with two columns and three rows. The first column is labeled "Type" and the second is labeled "Anatomy." The first row depicts a "Simple Anastomotic Leak" with an illustration of a tube inserted into a cavity. The second row shows "Conduit Tip Necrosis" with arrows pointing towards a narrowed part of the tube. The third row illustrates "Complete Conduit Ischaemia" with a completely blocked tube.]

Primary chemoRT

- Indication: inoperable SCC, not fit (e.g. poor lung function)
- Regimen: cisplatin + 5-fluorouracil + >50 Gy RT
  Palliative treatments
- Endoscopic stenting: SEMS with silicon coating to palliate significant dysphagia, unable to go RT after this
- Endoscopic local ablation (e.g. argon plasma coagulation, laser ablation): open esophageal lumen / unblock stent
- Nutritional support: NG tube / PEG tube / open gastrostomy / jejunostomy
- External radiotherapy / brachytherapy (intraluminal RT)

# 3.6 Benign diseases of stomach

Peptic ulcer disease
Refer to [MED-GI] for medical treatments
Modified Johnson's classification for GU
| Type | Location | Acid secretion |
|---|---|---|
| I | Gastric body / Lesser curvature (58%) | N / ↓ |
| II | Simultaneous gastric body + DU (22%) | ↑↑ |
| III | Prepyloric (20%) | ↑↑ |
| IV | High lesser curvature (rare) | ↓↓ |

Surgical management - Rarely required now

- Indications:
  - Uncomplicated ulcers refractory to medical treatment
  - Complicated ulcers - hemorrhage, perforation, GOO
  - Risk of malignancy: non-healing GU > 3months
  - Surgical options

| DU: Jacid   |                                                                                                |
| ----------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
|             | - Highly selective vagotomy: nerve of Latarjet preserved, but technically difficult            |
|             | - Truncal vagotomy + drainage (pyloroplasty / gastrojejunostomy): nerve of Latarjet sacrificed |
|             | - Gastrectomy (antrectomy / distal gastrectomy) + reconstruction (Billroth II > Roux-en-Y)     |
| GU: prevent | Type I: distal gastrectomy + Billroth II                                                       |
|             | Type II / III: truncal vagotomy + antrectomy + Billroth II                                     |
| malignancy  | Type IV: subtotal gastrectomy (extending to ulcer) + Billroth I / II / Roux-en-Y               |

PUD complication #1: hemorrhage
Clinical features

- DU: usually posterior wall → GDA involvement → coffee ground vomiting or melena
- Leading cause of death of peptic ulcer
  Management
- Resuscitation
- Endoscopy: adrenaline + heater probe / haemospray / clip
  - Limitation: massive bleeding obscuring view, large bleeding artery (>3.2mm)/ ulcer (>2cm)
- Surgical vs IR: indicated if failed endoscopic haemostasis, rebleeding failing re-scope, ongoing infusion
  - Surgical
    - DU: suture ligation of bleeding vessels → partial gastrectomy
    - GU: partial gastrectomy (risk of malignant ulcer)
  - IR: transcatheter arterial embolisation (TAE) - if unfit for surgery

PUD complication #2: perforation
MC site: anterior wall of D1
S/S:

- Sudden onset severe generalized abdominal pain (able to pinpoint exact onset time)
- +/- RLQ pain (Valentino's sign): GI contents track down right paracolic gutter
- Board-like rigidity with patient lying still
- Shock → fever (chemical peritonitis in first 4-6h → bacterial peritonitis after 6h)
  DDx: perforated appendicitis, acute cholecystitis, acute pancreatitis, MI
  Ix:
- Erect CXR: free gas under diaphragm in 60-70% cases (require sitting upright for 10min)
- CT thorax + abdomen with contrast: rule out other DDx
- CBC (Hb for GIB, WBC), LRFT, T&S, clotting, amylase (↑ due to pancreas irritation, more in acute pancr.)
- Do NOT attempt OGD: may convert sealed-off perforation to real perforation
  Mx:
- Resuscitation: NPO, IVF, NG tube decompression (may have co-existing GOO)
- IV broad-spectrum antibiotics e.g. Augmentin
- IV PPI / H2 blocker (suppress acid production)

[Image: Two diagrams illustrating ulcers associated with relatively high and low acid levels. Diagram A depicts a prepyloric, type III gastric ulcer in relation to the duodenum and gastric body. A duodenal ulcer is also present. Diagram B shows a high lesser curve, type IV gastric ulcer, as well as a gastric body, lesser curve, type I gastric ulcer.]

- Treatment options: HP eradication + surgery + peritoneal lavage (>6L NS) after repair
  - Small DU/GU (<2cm): lap/open (Graham) omental patch repair
    - Alternatives if omentum N/A: falciform lig., jejunal serosal patch
  - Large DU: distal gastrectomy + Billroth II reconstruction +/- controlled duodenostomy (esp. if difficult stump)
    - Billroth II preferred: less anastomoses than Roux-en-Y
    - Controlled duodenostomy: divert bile to consequence of duodenal stump leakage (but does not leakage rate)
  - Large GU: wedge excision / partial gastrectomy + Billroth II reconstruction
- Convert to open if:
  - Hemodynamically unstable: shorter operative time
  - Large defect (e.g. >1cm): difficult laparoscopic suture
  - Gross contamination: limited lap. peritoneal lavage
- Biopsy ulcer edge for ALL gastric ulcers to rule out malignancy

Prognosis: Boey's score (3 points)
Post-op Mx

- NPO until no signs of leakage and return of bowel function
- Complete full course of antibiotics
- Continue PPI until OGD
- FU: OGD 6-8 weeks after surgery for healing + HP status

[A drawing depicts a cross-section of the abdomen, focusing on the stomach and duodenum. The stomach leads into the duodenum, which is partially obscured by the omentum, a fatty tissue layer. A small perforation is indicated on the duodenal wall, where digestive contents leak out. Labels point to the stomach, duodenum, and omentum, highlighting the anatomical context of a perforated duodenal ulcer.]

| Risk factors                                                                      | Points |
| --------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------ |
| Time from perforation to admission >24 hours.                                     | 1      |
| Pre-op SBP <100 mmHg.                                                             | 1      |
| Any one or more systemic illness: heart disease, liver disease, renal disease, DM | 1      |
| Mortality : Score 0 = 0%, 1 = 10%, 2 = 45.5%, 3 = 100%                            |        |

Gastric outlet obstruction
Definition: clinical syndrome characterised by epigastric pain & post-prandial vomiting due to mechanical obstruction
Etiology: malignant until proven otherwise
| Benign (20%) | Malignant (80%) |
| --- | --- |
| - PUD-related pyloric stenosis (2nd MC) | - Gastric cancer (MC), lymphoma |
| - Gastric volvulus (e.g. rolling hiatal hernia) | - Extra-luminal compression: CA ampulla, CA head of pancreas, transverse colon / hepatic flexure, locally advanced cholangioCA / CA gallbladder |
| - SMA syndrome | |
| - Intraluminal obstruction: foreign body, bezoar, Bouveret syndrome (big gallstones in duodenum) | |
| - Chronic pancreatitis (inflammatory exudates from pancreas) | |
| - Gastric TB | |
| - Crohn's disease | |

Clinical features

- Waxing-and-waning epigastric pain
- Repeated non-bilious projectile vomiting of undigested food
- Early satiety
- Weight loss
- Signs: succussion splash

Initial work-up

- ABG & electrolytes - less pronounced in malignant GOO
  - HypoCl hypok metabolic alkalosis +/- paradoxical aciduria
    - Repeated vomiting of HCl
    - Paradoxical aciduria due to secondary hyperaldosteronism
    - Transcellular shift of H & K trying to compensate the hypok
  - HypoK: muscle weakness
  - HypoCa: tetany
- Erect AXR: hourglass stomach (enlarged gastric bubble, dilated proximal duodenum, lack of air in SB); calcified mass in RUQ (Bouveret syndrome), pancreatic calcifications (chronic pancreatitis)
- CT abdomen + pelvis with contrast: better for some malignancy (e.g. CA HoP)
- OGD + biopsy: rule out gastric malignancy (after ensuring adequate decompression)

[A flowchart illustrates the process of vomiting and its metabolic consequences. Starting with vomiting, the chart branches into "Loss of Gastric HCl," "Volume depletion," and "Loss of fluid rich in K+." The "Loss of Gastric HCl" branch leads to metabolic alkalosis and then to alkalosis induced hypokalemia. The "Volume depletion" branch leads to increased aldosterone and then to hypokalemia. The "Loss of fluid rich in K+" branch leads directly to hypokalemia. Finally, hypokalemia is linked to hypochloremia. The flowchart suggests a series of interconnected physiological responses and electrolyte imbalances resulting from vomiting.]

- +/- Water-soluble contrast meal
  Management
- Drip and suck: NPO, IV fluid (+K), NG / OG tube decompression
- IV PPI: to reduce gastric secretion
- Biopsy of pylorus to exclude malignancy
- Specific management:
  - Malignant GOO:
    - Curative intent: treat underlying CA
    - Palliative intent: surgical bypass (GJ) or endoscopic
      stent placement (SEMS - self-expandable metal stent)
  - Non-malignant GOO: depend on underlying cause, but in
    general include - Medical therapy e.g. PPI, triple therapy - Endoscopic balloon dilatation +/- duodenal stenting - Surgical: bypass (GJ), pyloroplasty + GD

Dieulafoy's lesion

- Gastric arterio-venous malformation (AVM)
  - Idiopathic dilated aberrant submucosal vessels eroding overlying normal mucosa
  - MC site: gastric fundus
  - Management: endoscopic therapy (e.g. sclerosant, endoscopic clip)

[Image Description: Four different diagrammatic illustrations of a stomach. Each of the illustrations is labeled with the letters a, b, c, and d. The letters a and b are in the upper half, while c and d are on the lower half of the image. Each of the stomach diagrams is in different positions. Black dotted lines are placed over the stomach in each diagram with written texts to clarify what they are illustrating.]

[Image Description: A photograph of a gastric dieulafoy's lesion. The image shows a bright red spot on the surface of the stomach lining, surrounded by slightly raised and irregular tissue.]

Gastric volvulus
Definition: abnormal rotation of stomach >180° → Closed loop obstruction +/- incarceration
or strangulation

- Usually 2º to diaphragmatic / hiatal hernia (rolling-type)
- Types: organo-axial (MC), mesentro-axial, combined

Clinical presentation: Borchardt's triad

- Severe epigastric pain
- Retching without vomiting
- Inability to pass NG tube below diaphragm

Investigations: erect CXR (retrocardiac gastric bubble), CT thorax + abdomen, water-
soluble contrast meal
Management

- NPO, NG decompression
- Diagnostic OGD if no signs of perforation: assess viability of stomach +/- endoscopic decompression /
  derotation (if viable)
- If strangulated / failed reduction:
  - Viable stomach: reduction + gastropexy +/- repair hiatal hernia
  - Ischemic stomach: wedge excision / gastrectomy

[Image Description: X-ray of a human chest. The image shows the rib cage, lungs, heart, and diaphragm. The lungs appear dark and filled with air, while the heart and diaphragm are more opaque.]

Gastroparesis
Definitions: delayed gastric emptying without mechanical obstruction
Aetiology

- DM neuropathy
- Drugs, e.g. CCB, DA agonist, GLP-1 agonist
- Post-op (e.g. gastrectomy, Whipple's)
- Scleroderma
  Clinical features
- N/V
- Abdominal pain
- Early satiety, post-prandial fullness
- Bloating
  66

Investigations

- Exclude mechanical obstruction: CXR/ AXR, CT abdomen, OGD
- Scintigraphic gastric emptying: low fat egg-white meal (fat slows gastric emptying)
- Investigations for underlying cause: HbA1c, ANA, etc

Management

- Dietary modification: low fat diet
- Optimise glycemic control
- Prokinetics, e.g. metoclopramide

Portal hypertensive gastropathy

- Common in liver cirrhosis
- Usually cause minor bleeds (if major bleed, consider variceal bleeding)
- Endoscopic appearance: gastric mucosa with mosaic snakeskin appearance
- Treatment: medical (beta blockers, octreotide, vasopressin) + endoscopic Tx

SMA syndrome
Also known as Wilkie syndrome / "cast syndrome"

- Decreased aorto-mesenteric angle (<20°) compressing on D3,
  due to e.g. - Acute weight loss - Prolonged bedbound - Spinal disease, deformity, trauma (e.g. use of body cast in scoliosis)

Clinical features

- Abdominal distension, early satiety, GOO
- Repeated bile stained vomiting
- Nutcracker syndrome: SMA compressing on left renal vein, causing haematuria & varicocele

[Diagram of the Superior Mesenteric Artery (SMA) and its relationship to the Duodenum and Aorta. Two images are presented, the first showing the relative position of the aorta, stomach, duodenum, ligament of treitz, and jejunum. Labels indicating the 1st portion, 2nd portion, and 3rd portion of duodenum are also shown. An arrow indicates the aorto-mesenteric angle. The second image is a magnified view of the aorto-mesenteric angle, showing the aorta, renal vein, superior mesenteric artery (SMA) and the 3rd portion of duodenum, along with a labelled line indicating the aorto-mesenteric angle.]

Investigations: exclude other causes of D3 obstruction (e.g. tumor, stricture)

- AXR / contrast meal: dilated stomach and duodenum
- OGD: slit-like lumen at D3, exclude intraluminal malignancy
- USG/ CT: decreased aorto-mesenteric angle

Management

- Conservative: NG tube for decompression + NJ tube (Entriflex) for feeding
- Surgery (if failed > 3mo of conservative): enteric bypass - DJ (1st line) or GJ (2nd line)
- “Strong procedure” (obsolete): relieve ligament of Treitz → DJ flexure moves to right and no longer under SMA

67

3.7 CA stomach
Gastric polyps
Approach to gastric polyps

- Polypectomy indicated if: known **neoplastic** polyps / polyps ≥ 1cm in diameter
- Multiple polyps: excise the largest polyp, obtain biopsies from other polyps
- Sample normal-looking mucosa to rule out dysplasia (total 7-12, e.g. 4-quadrant Bx from antrum)

| Pathology                                                                     | Management                                  |
| :---------------------------------------------------------------------------- | :------------------------------------------ |
| **Non-neoplastic** (90%) Hyperplastic polyp (MC): a/w H.pylori                | Resect if >0.5cm                            |
|                                                                               | Treat H. pylori if +ve                      |
|                                                                               | FU OGD at 3-6 months to confirm eradication |
| - Have malignant potential (correlate with size)                              |                                             |
| Fundic gland polyp: a/w PPI use and hypergastrinemia, syndromes e.g. FAP, MAP | Resect if ≥1cm / located in antrum          |
| - 100% benign, may regress after stop PPI                                     | Consider colonoscopy if ≥20 polyps          |
| Inflammatory polyp                                                            |                                             |
| **Neoplastic** (10%) Adenomatous polyp: usually in antrum                     | Resect **ALL** adenomas                     |
| - 4 types: intestinal, foveolar, pyloric gland, oxyntic                       | Examine for synchronous CA                  |
|                                                                               | FU OGD                                      |

Gastric cancer
Epidemiology

- Incidence: ↓ trend (6th incidence, 4th mortality), but ↑ in Asia (Japan: diet-related)
- Cell type: adenocarcinoma (90%) > lymphoma (5%) > GIST, metastasis
- Site: distal stomach (antrum / pylorus) > cardia (↑ trend) > OGJ

Risk factors

- Compensatory epithelial cell proliferation:
  - H. pylori: → chronic atrophic gastritis → intestinal metaplasia → body/distal CA (intestinal type)
  - Chronic gastric reflux (e.g. Barrett's esophagus): proximal CA
  - Hx of gastric resection: bile reflux (e.g. Billroth II)
  - Chronic atrophic gastritis: a/w pernicious anemia and Menetrier's disease
- Environmental factors: smoking, smoked / pickled food, nitrosamines, alcohol
- Host factors: hereditary diffuse gastric carcinoma (HDGC: E-cadherin mutation), HNPCC, FAP, P-J syndrome

Classification of CA stomach

- Histological (Lauren classification)

| Intestinal type - well-differentiated, better Px | Diffuse type - undifferentiated, poorer Px         |
| :----------------------------------------------- | :------------------------------------------------- |
| Risk factors as above, except FHx and HDGC       | Risk factors: HDGC                                 |
| HER2 +ve in 15%                                  | HER2 -ve, signet ring cell +ve                     |
| Hematogenous spread                              | Transmural (linitis plastica) and lymphatic spread |
| Elderly male, distal stomach                     | Young female, proximal stomach                     |

- Endoscopic (Borrmann classification) - _no implication in staging_
  - Type 1: polypoid - uncommon
  - Type 2: fungating
  - Type 3: ulcerated - common - dyspepsia as the MC presentation
  - Type 4: diffuse infiltrative (linitis plastica) - difficult to detect (OGD: difficult to inflate)
- By disease extent:
  - Early gastric cancer (EGC): confined to mucosa or submucosa (i.e. T1) - 5-year OS 95%
    - Further classified into elevated / depressed / combined based on OGD
  - Advanced gastric cancer (AGC): muscularis propria (i.e. ≥ T2) - 5-year OS 50%
  - Siewert's classification of OGJ adenocarcinoma\* (fig.)
    - Type I: distal esophagus (-5 to -1cm) - behave like CA oesophagus
    - Type II: true cardia (-1 to +2cm) - behave like CA oesophagus or CA stomach
    - Type III: subcardial (+2 to +5cm) - behave like CA stomach

[Image Description: A diagram showing the different tumor types in relation to the esophagus and stomach. The image illustrates three distinct regions: Adono-Ca of the distal esophagus, True-Ca cardia, and Subcardial Ca. Each region is labeled with an arrow pointing to the corresponding area on a simplified anatomical sketch of the lower esophagus and upper stomach. The diagram is designed to visually represent the location and extent of different types of tumors in the gastroesophageal junction.]

Clinical features

- Local: dyspepsia, early satiety, bloating, n/v, constitutional symptoms
- Complications: obstruction (dysphagia if proximal, GOO if distal), UGIB, perforation
- 4 routes of metastasis:
  - Local spread: pancreas, transverse colon, liver, duodenum
  - Lymphatic spread: peri-gastric / para-aortic nodes, Virchow's node, Sister Mary Joseph nodule (periumbilical node), Irish node (left axillary node)
  - Haematogenous spread via portal venous circulation: liver (hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice) → lung, bone and brain
  - Transcoelomic spread: ascites, ovaries (Krukenberg's tumors), pouch of Douglas (Blumer's shelf)
- Paraneoplastic for GI adenoCA (e.g. gastric, pancreatic):
  - Trousseau's sign of malignancy (migratory thrombophlebitis)
  - Leser-Trelat sign: seborrheic keratosis
  - Acanthosis nigricans

Staging of CA stomach

- T2: muscularis propria
- T3: subserosal connective tissues (e.g. gastrocolic / gastrohepatic lig., greater or lesser omentum)
- T4: serosa

Investigations

- Diagnostic: OGD + biopsy
  - Obtain tissue diagnosis and evaluate extent of primary tumor
  - Alternative: barium swallow (limited diagnostic value except for linitis plastica)
- Staging (TNM): most important prognostic factor is depth of tumor invasion
  - CT abdomen + pelvis +/- thorax with contrast (thorax if proximal tumor e.g. cardia)
    - Mandatory for M staging but not accurate for T & N
    - Alternative: PET-CT - not too sensitive for CA stomach
  - Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS): NOT mandatory for CA stomach (upfront surgery is advocated)
    - More sensitive in T staging (e.g. differentiating T4a vs T4b) & N staging (e.g. perigastric LN)
    - More operator-dependent and more invasive c.f. CT
  - Staging laparoscopy + peritoneal lavage (routine)
    - More accurate for peritoneal and liver metastasis c.f. CT
    - Direct visualization +/- biopsy of suspicious lesions for frozen section
    - Peritoneal washing for cytology to detect microscopic peritoneal metastasis
- CXR
- Tumor markers: CEA, CA125, CA19-9 - for monitoring recurrence and response to chemotherapy
- Pre-op bloods: CBC, LRFT, clotting

Management
Endoscopic treatment: potentially curative

- Indications: early gastric CA confined to mucosa (T1a) -diagnosed by endoscopic white light picture (not EUS!)
- Options:
  - EMR: only resect lesion < 2cm, by injecting fluid beneath mucosa raising the lesion followed by snare
  - ESD: can resect lesion >2cm, more complications (bleeding, perforation, stricture)
- Histology to determine margin (lateral & deep) - consider curative if clear, salvage gastrectomy if T1b+
- Endoscopic surveillance annually
  [Image of primary tumor (T) table, regional lymph node (N) table, distant metastasis (M) table, and staging system (clinical staging) table. The primary tumor (T) table lists TX as "Primary tumour cannot be assessed", T0 as "No evidence of primary tumour", Tis as "Carcinoma-in-situ: Intraepithelial tumour without invasion of lamina propria, high-grade dysplasia", T1 as "Tumour invades lamina propria, muscularis mucosae or submucosa", T1a as "Tumour invades lamina propria or muscularis mucosae", T1b as "Tumour invades submucosa", T2 as "Tumour invades muscularis propria", T3 as "Tumour penetrates the subserosal connective tissue without invasion of the visceral peritoneum or adjacent structures", T4 as "Tumour invades the serosa (visceral peritoneum) or adjacent structures", T4a as "Tumour invades the serosa (visceral peritoneum)", and T4b as "Tumour invades adjacent structures or organs". The regional lymph node (N) table lists NX as "Regional lymph node cannot be assessed", N0 as "No regional lymph node metastasis", N1 as "Metastasis in 1 - 2 regional lymph nodes", N2 as "Metastasis in 3 - 6 regional lymph nodes", N3 as "Metastasis in ≥ 7 regional lymph nodes", N3a as "Metastasis in 7 - 15 regional lymph nodes", and N3b as "Metastasis in ≥ 16 regional lymph nodes". The distant metastasis (M) table lists M0 as "No distant metastasis" and M1 as "Distant metastasis". The staging system (clinical staging) table correlates stage, T, N, and M. Stage 0 is Tis, N0, M0. Stage I is T1, N0, M0. Stage II A is T2, N0, M0 or T1, N1/N2/N3, M0. Stage II B is T3, N0, M0 or T2, N1/N2/N3, M0. Stage III is T3, N1/N2/N3, M0 or T4a, N0, M0. Stage IV A is T4a, N1/N2/N3, M0 or T4b, N0, M0 or Any T, Any N, M1. Stage IV B is Any T, Any N, M1.]

Gastrectomy
Refer to later pages for resectability

| Resection margin            | 5cm (proximal margin: may need lower esophagectomy; distal: down to D1/2) |
| --------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------ | ------------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Extent of gastric resection | Type                                                                      | Indications                                            | Transected arteries | Remarks                                                                          |
|                             | Partial                                                                   | Rare                                                   | RGA, RGEA           |                                                                                  |
|                             | Distal subtotal                                                           | Antral/Middle tumor 25cm from OGJ                      | + LGA, LGEA         | Better functional outcome GJ has lower risk of anastomotic leak (eso: no serosa) |
|                             | Total                                                                     | Proximal/Middle tumor <5cm from OGJ Diffuse-type tumor | + short gastric a.  | Better resection margins Roux-en-Y is only option of reconstruction              |

Early stage: lap / robotic
Advanced: open (esp if N+)

| Anastomosis (restore GI continuity) | Type                  | Remarks                                                                                                                                                                             |
| ----------------------------------- | --------------------- | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
|                                     | Roux-en-Y (preferred) | EJ / GJ + end-to-side JJ + duodenal stump Roux limb should be at least 40cm Prevent bile reflux (GERD, remnant CA) Less dumping, no tension ERCP not possible, Roux stasis syndrome |
|                                     | Billroth I            | End-to-end GD Only possible if low tension (e.g. antrectomy) Seldom used in HK: High risk of bile reflux                                                                            |
|                                     | Billroth II           | End-to-side GJ + duodenal stump Suitable for emergency case: fast, low tension ERCP still possible Afferent loop syndrome                                                           |
