The right illustration labels lymph node stations 12 to 16 along major blood vessels in the abdomen. Each illustration is intended to guide surgeons in identifying and removing these nodes during surgery for accurate staging and treatment planning.]

- Young and fit patients with locally advanced cancer and small peritoneal metastases: consider salvage therapy – radical gastrectomy + peritonectomy + LND + hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (HiPEC)

Post-gastrectomy complications

General

- Immediate: bleeding, injury to nearby organs (e.g. pancreas, duodenum)
- Early: wound infection, chest infection, post-op ileus
- Late: recurrence (usually at gastric bed)

Specific

Related to
anastomosis

- Anastomotic leak (OJ > GJ/JJ): Usually on post-op Day 7-10
  - Duodenal stump blowout, chyle leak, pancreatic fistula
  - Mx: NPO, IV fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics +/- exploration and revision
    - Consider tube duodenostomy if duodenal stump leak
- Obstruction:
  - Intestinal obstruction: Fiber-rich food (冬菇), adhesion
  - Afferent loop syndrome: usually in Billroth II or Roux- en-Y (rare)
    - Emergency: closed loop obstruction → risk of duodenal stump blowout, obstructive jaundice, ascending cholangitis / pancreatitis
    - Acute S/S - severe epigastric pain, non-bilious vomiting, dLFT & amylase
    - Chronic S/S - postprandial pain, intermittent bilious vomiting
    - Usually due to excessive length of afferent loop
    - Dx: CT abdomen (dilated afferent loop)
    - Mx: revise GJ/ convert to Roux-en-Y (left fig.) / Braun's enteroenterostomy (right fig.)

[Image of four anatomical diagrams showing complications after gastric surgery. The first diagram shows kinking and angulation. The second shows an internal herniation behind the efferent limb. The third shows stenosis of the gastrojejunal anastomosis. The fourth shows a redundant twisted afferent limb, also known as volvulus.]

- Efferent loop syndrome: GOO
- Jejuno-gastric intussusception: GOO
- Internal hernia (via Petersen's defect, fig.)

[Image of an anatomical diagram showing adhesions involving both the afferent limb and the efferent limb.]

Related to
motility
("post-
gastrectomy
syndromes")

- Small stomach syndrome: early satiety
- Rapid transit: dumping syndrome (Loss of pylorus → Rapid gastric emptying of hyperosmolar carbohydrates → Draw fluid into intestine lumen and release vasoactive gut hormones)
  - Clinical features
    - Early (15-30min): abdo pain, n/v/d, vasomotor S/S (e.g. sweating, flushing)
    - Late (2-3h): post-prandial hyperinsulinaemic hypoglycaemia (PHH)
    - Management: small frequent meals, avoid simple carbs, octreotide
- Slow transit: Mx with prokinetics (e.g. metoclopramide, erythromycin)
  - Gastric stasis: impaired gastric emptying (post-op atony / vagal denervation)
  - Alkaline reflux gastritis
  - Roux stasis: bloating, n/v, heartburn, delayed regurgitation (ectopic pacemakers in Roux limb → net propulsive activity proximal towards stomach)

Nutritional
deficiency

- B12 deficiency anemia: ↓gastric acid & ↓intrinsic factor, Mx: IM B12 Q3months
- Iron & Ca deficiency: ↓gastric acid required to cleave iron from food and better absorption of Ca - anaemia (iron), osteoporosis (Ca)
- Fat-soluble vitamins (e.g. vit D): loss of duodenal continuity
- Steatorrhea

Non-surgical treatments in CA stomach

- Neoadjuvant chemotherapy: downstage the tumor to improve resectability rate
  - HK: Upfront surgery is preferred - only consider if T3+/ N+
  - Regimen: FLOT (fluorouracil + leucovorin (folinic acid) + oxaliplatin + docetaxel) / Xelox if less fit
- Adjuvant chemotherapy: eradicate micro-metastasis
  - Consider if T3+/ N+
  - Regimen: 5-fluorouracil (or: capecitabine) +/- oxaliplatin (i.e. Xelox) or TS-1

Palliative care

- Tumors considered unresectable if:
  - Distal metastasis (e.g. multiple liver metastasis, peritoneal nodules, pelvic deposits, Virchow's nodes)
  - Extensive nodal involvement (D3)
  - Invasion of major vessel, e.g. aorta, hepatic artery, coeliac axis, proximal splenic artery (not distal)
  - Distal splenic a.: borderline resectable with LUQ exenteration
- Principles: relieve pain, nutrition, bleeding, obstruction, perforation
- Supportive treatments: transfusion, PPI, Fe supplement
- Endoscopic treatments
  - Ethanol injection, adrenaline, clipping: for bleeding
  - Metallic stenting: bypass obstructing tumor, but risk of re-stenosis by tumour ingrowth
- Palliative surgery
  - Palliative resection: relieve bleeding / obstruction
  - Palliative bypass (gastrojejunostomy / gastroenterostomy): more durable than stenting, but possible impaired gastric emptying / bile reflux
- Palliative chemo +/- HER-2 inhibitor (if HER2 +ve) +/- ramucirumab (VEGFR2 antagonist)
- External beam radiotherapy (EBRT) for painful bone metastases

Key anatomical features are labeled, including the small gastric pouch syndrome at the top, followed by the stomach body leading into the duodenum. Pathological conditions are highlighted along the stomach and duodenum, such as a marginal ulcer, afferent loop syndrome, chronic gastroparesis, alkaline reflux gastritis, efferent loop obstruction, early dumping syndrome, duodenal stump leak and postvagotomy diarrhoea. These labels indicate potential sites of complications or disease within the gastrointestinal system.]

Gastric lymphoma

- 5% of gastric cancers
- Usually arise from mucosa-associated lymphoid tissues (MALT)
  - Low-grade: remain in stomach for long time before LN involvement
- Clinical features: similar to gastric adenoCA
- Investigations: OGD + biopsy, CT scan + bone marrow exam for staging
- Treatment:
  - H. pylori eradication: cause regression in 80% of cases
  - Localized disease - surgery
  - Systemic disease - chemotherapy

# Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST)

Pathology: originate from muscularis propria (interstitial cells of
Cajal - GI pacemaker cells)

- Molecular pathogenesis:
  - Activating mutation in c-KIT gene causing
    overproduction of CD117 (95%),
  - PDGFRA mutation
- All GIST should be regarded as **potentially malignant**
- Occur throughout GI tract: 50% in stomach (MC proximal
  stomach) > SB > LB
- Metastasis: liver (MC), peritoneum
- Familial syndrome: Carney's syndrome\*, NF1

Clinical features: usually incidental finding on OGD / CT

- GI bleed (occult/ overt): ulceration of _overlying mucosa_
- Abdominal pain
- Abdominal mass

Types of GIT stromal (soft tissue) tumours

- **GIST (MC)**
  - Lipoma/ liposarcoma
  - Leiomyoma/ leiomyosarcoma
  - Desmoid tumour
  - Schwannoma/ peripheral nerve
    sheath tumour

Differential diagnosis of gastric mass

- Mucosa: adenocarcinoma,
  gastrinoma
- Submucosa: NET, lymphoma
- Muscularis propria: GIST,
  leiomyoma, desmoid tumour
- Adventitia

Investigations

- OGD: mass with smooth margins and normal overlying mucosa (endoscopic Bx typically cannot establish Dx)
- **Endoscopic ultrasound + fine needle aspiration (FNA)**
  - EUS: hypoechoic, homogenous lesions arising from 2nd-4th layer of Gl wall
  - Combined cytologic (histology: _spindle cells_) and IHC (CD117 + c-KIT mutation)
  - Not mandatory - indicated if:
    - Consider use of imatinib for unresectable / metastatic disease
    - Consider neoadjuvant imatinib for large GIST
    - GIST 1-2cm: obtain mitotic index risk stratification
- Percutaneous biopsy is NOT preferred: risk of tumour capsule rupture with peritoneal spread
- Staging: CT with contrast (MRI if at rectum or liver)

Management

- Surgical resection: negative margins are adequate
  - Indications: all GIST ≥ 2cm
  - Approach: segmental resection (regional lymphadenectomy not required - rarely metastasized to LN)
    - Explore abdomen during laparotomy to exclude liver / peritoneal metastases
    - Avoid perforating capsule: chemo may be needed
- **Tyrosine kinase inhibitor** (first line: **imatinib** → acquired resistance: sunitinib)
  - Adjuvant: in all high-risk cases e.g. perforated capsule
  - Neoadjuvant: 3-6 month therapy for locally advanced/ metastatic (liver or peritoneal mets) **potentially**
    resectable tumours (Įsize & vascularity of tumors → forgan preservation)
  - Palliative: first-line treatment for metastatic GIST

Malignant potential of GIST depends
on AFIP prognostic model:

- Location (SB most likely
  malignant)
- Size
- Mitotic index
- Tumor rupture

The table is divided into columns for mitotic index (<=5 per 50 hpf and >5 per 50 hpf), size (<=2 cm, >2 and <= 5 cm, >5 and <= 10 cm, > 10 cm), and risk of progressive disease in different locations (gastric, duodenum, small bowel, large bowel). The cells contain descriptors like Very low, Low, Moderate and High for the risk.]

\*Carney triad: GIST, pulmonary chondroma, extra-adrenal paraganglioma

# 3.8 Bariatric surgery

Effect on metabolic syndrome: may achieve DM remission due to change in gut hormone levels (GLP-1)

- ABCD score: age, BMI, C-peptide, duration of DM
- Total score = 10; score > 6 predict DM remission after bariatric surgery

Indications for bariatric surgery in Asians: failed medical treatment +

- BMI ≥ 35
- BMI ≥30 with T2DM

C/I: reversible causes (e.g. endocrine), psychiatric disorders, active substance abuse, non-compliance to medical care

| Malabsorption                                                                                            | Biliopancreatic diversion (BPD) +/- duodenal switch [Diagram illustrating Biliopancreatic diversion (BPD) and BPD with duodenal switch variant. In BPD, a large portion of the stomach is removed, and the small intestine is connected to the remaining stomach. In BPD with duodenal switch, a sleeve gastrectomy is performed, and the small intestine is rerouted to separate the flow of food and bile/pancreatic juices.]                                                                                                         | Anastomotic leak Intra-abdominal bleed                         | Malnutrition Weight regain                                                   |

Follow-up nutritional monitoring:

- After banding: CBC, RFT, HbA1c, FBG, lipids
- After bypass / sleeve gastrectomy: above + LFT, B12/folate, Fe profile, bone profile (CaPO4, vitD, PTH), Zn, Cu

# 4 Lower GI surgery

## 4.1 Anatomy

### Vasculature

Superior mesenteric artery

- First branch of SMA is inferior pancreatoduodenal artery (inferior PDA)
- Other branches: jejunal and ileal a., ileocolic a., right colic a., middle colic a.

Inferior mesenteric artery

- Main branches: left colic artery, sigmoid arteries, superior rectal artery

[Anatomical drawing comparing the arterial blood supply to the colon. On the left side, there is a representation of the superior mesenteric artery and its branches. Key anatomical features such as the "Middle colic artery," "Right colic artery," "Ileocolic arteries," and "Jejunal and Ileal arteries" are labeled. The right side of the image depicts the inferior mesenteric artery and its branches. Labels include "Left colic artery" and "Sigmoid arteries." These labels indicate the major vascular pathways supplying the colon. ]

Important collaterals between SMA and IMA

- Marginal artery of Drummond: contributed by right, middle and left colic a., supplying colon via vasa recta
- Meandering mesenteric artery of Moskowitz (arc of Riolan): inconstant communication

Large bowel vs small bowel

| Large bowel                                                          | Small bowel                      |
| -------------------------------------------------------------------- | -------------------------------- |
| Shorter (1.5m) & wider calibre                                       | Longer (6m) and narrower calibre |
| More part is fixed, e.g. ascending & descending colon                | More part is mobile              |
| Appendices epiploicae (fat tag, except caecum)                       | Valvulae conniventes             |
| Taenia coli (3 narrow bands of longitudinal muscles)                 | Villi                            |
| Haustra (folds in wall due to shorter taenia coli compared to colon) |                                  |

Important relations of LB - protect at surgery

- Caecum & ascending colon: right ureter, right gonadal vessels, duodenum (posterior)
- Descending colon: left ureter, left gonadal vessels, tail of pancreas (posterior)

The rectum

- Definitions:
  - Anatomical definition:
    - Upper border: at the level of sacral promontory - where taenia coli joins to form a continuous outer longitudinal muscle layer (+ lack of the 2 other features of LB)
    - Lower border: anorectal junction (defined by puborectalis)
  - Endoscopic definition: up to 15cm from anal verge
  - Peritoneal covering:
    - Upper 1/3: mobile, peritoneum covering anteriorly and laterally
    - Middle 1/3: peritoneum covers only anteriorly
    - Lowest 1/3: no peritoneum covering

[A detailed anatomical illustration of the rectum and surrounding structures. The illustration shows a sagittal section, providing a view from the side. Several key features are labeled with measurements indicating distances from the anal verge. "Upper rectum - 15 cm", "Middle rectum - 8 cm", "Distal rectum - 4 cm", and "Anal canal" are clearly marked. Additional labels point out the "Sigmoid colon" connecting to the upper rectum, as well as the "Dentate line" and "Anal verge" at the lower end of the anal canal. The illustration also depicts surrounding musculature and tissues, providing context to the anatomical relationships in this region.]

- AP flexures x2: dorsal bend (concavity of sacrum), ventral bend (puborectalis sling)
- **Lateral curvatures x3:** Upper and lower convex to right, middle convex to left
  - Lumen side: Houston's valves (semi-circular folds) - strongest is the middle one (aka Kohlrausch's valve)

- Fascial layer (**"Holy plane"**): barriers to malignant invasion, part of mesorectal fascia (implicated in TME) (fig.)
  - Denonvilliers' fascia: anterior to lower 1/3 of rectum
  - Waldeyer's fascia: posterior to lower 1/3 of rectum
- Vascular supply:
  - Superior rectal artery (**major** supply, from IMA) → superior rectal vein (to portal venous system)
  - Middle rectal artery (from IIA) → middle rectal vein (to systemic venous system)
  - Inferior rectal artery (from internal pudendal artery, in pudendal canal) → inferior rectal vein (to systemic venous system)
- Lymphatic drainage: Inferior mesenteric node, internal iliac nodes

Anal canal
[Anatomical drawing of the anal canal showcasing different parts like Rectum, Anal column, Anal sinus, Anal valve, Levator ani, Illiococcygeus, Puborectalis, Internal anal sphincter (smooth muscle), Pectinate line, Anocutaneous line ("white line"), Anal pecten, Anal aperture, Deep, Superficial, Subcutaneous, External anal sphincter (skeletal muscle).]

[Diagram showing the deposition of the puborectalis muscle, with a side view of the rectum and anus, showing how it maintains the anorectal angle.]

Extent: from anorectal ring (puborectalis) to anal verge

- Puborectalis: part of levator ani, helps maintain anorectal angle to be ~120°, important in continence
- Anorectal ring: fusion of puborectalis, highest part of IAS & deep EAS - palpable on PR exam
- Internal anal sphincter: formed by thickening of involuntary circular smooth muscle, innervated by autonomic nervous system
- External anal sphincter: innervated by pudendal n. (somatic nervous system)
  - 3 parts: subcutaneous, superficial, deep (blend with puborectalis)

Internal structure
[Image of the internal structure of anal canal. The image depicts the anal valve, anal column and pectinate line.]

- Anal valves: contain anal sinuses that secrete mucus
- Dentate line (pectinate line): divide anal canal into upper 2/3 and lower 1/3

|                      | Above dentate line (Upper 2/3)                                                             | Below dentate line (Lower 1/3)                                                           |
| :------------------- | :----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | :--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Embryological origin | Endoderm (hindgut)                                                                         | Ectoderm                                                                                 |
| Epithelium           | Columnar epithelium                                                                        | Stratified squamous epithelium                                                           |
| Arterial supply      | Superior rectal artery (← inferior mesenteric) Anastomosing branches from middle rectal a. | Inferior rectal artery (← internal pudendal) Anastomosing branches from middle rectal a. |
| Nerve                | Visceral innervation (inf. hypogastric plexus)                                             | Somatic innervation (inf. rectal n. ← pudendal n.), sensitive to pain                    |
| Lymphatics           | Internal iliac and inf. mesenteric nodes                                                   | Superficial inguinal nodes                                                               |

[An illustration of the blood vessels supplying the rectum. The illustration displays Inferior mesenteric artery, Middle iliac artery, Superior rectal artery, Middle rectal artery, Inferior rectal artery, and Levator ani muscle.]

4.2 LGIB
Definition: bleeding distal to ligament of Treitz

History taking

- Bleeding: nature (PR bleed vs melena), frequency, amount, colour
- Severity: anemic symptoms (SOB, palpitation, tremor, fatigue, dizziness / LOC)
- Relationship of blood with stool
  Ο Melena: UGIT
  Ο Mixed with stool: LGIT proximal to sigmoid colon
  Ο Separate from stool: outlet-type bleeding
  - Immediately after stool: anorectal
  - Blood on its own: diverticular disease, angiodysplasia, IBD, bleeding CA
  - Cyclic manner: GI endometriosis
- Stool: bowel habits, stool calibre, mucus

DDx

|                                         | Features for history taking                                                                                                                                                                                                                                |
| :-------------------------------------- | :--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| **Colorectal carcinoma (CRC)**          | Constitutional symptoms, change in bowel habits (e.g. alternating diarrhea and constipation), **change in stool calibre, tenesmus, IO symptoms**, metastatic symptoms (e.g. jaundice, SOB, bone pain), **FHx**, previous colonoscopy / FOBT, diet, smoking |
| **Diverticular disease 憩室病**         | Painless profuse hematochezia                                                                                                                                                                                                                              |
| **Hemorrhoids**                         | Fresh outlet-type bleed, **perianal mass / pain**, constipation, risk factors (e.g. pregnancy)                                                                                                                                                             |
| **IBD**                                 | Joint, liver, eye, skin manifestations                                                                                                                                                                                                                     |
| **Ischemic colitis**                    | CVS risk factors, thromboembolic risk factors (e.g. OCP), previous AMI / stroke / DVT                                                                                                                                                                      |
| **Infective colitis**                   | Fever, night sweats, chills/rigors, recent antibiotic usage (C. diff), TB exposure, TOCC                                                                                                                                                                   |
| **Anal fissure**                        | Hx of constipation, sharp pain a/w start of defaecation                                                                                                                                                                                                    |
| **Angiodysplasia 血管異常增生**         | Usually just anemic symptoms, a/w vascular malformations and aortic stenosis                                                                                                                                                                               |
| **Coagulopathy**                        | FHx, DHx (anticoagulants, antiplatelets)                                                                                                                                                                                                                   |
| **UGIB**\* (e.g. PUD, Dieulafoy lesion) | Melena, coffee ground vomiting, hematemesis                                                                                                                                                                                                                |
| **Procedural-related**                  | Hx of recent anastomosis (esp. stapled), polypectomy, ESD, biopsy, etc.                                                                                                                                                                                    |

Other DDx: Meckel's diverticulum, other neoplasms (e.g. GIST, lymphoma), drug (NSAID enteropathy)
\*10-15% of severe hematochezia is from brisk UGIB.

Acute management of LGIB
[Image of a flowchart titled "Acute lower GI bleed". The flowchart shows a decision-making process for managing lower gastrointestinal bleeding (LGIB). It starts with assessing the patient's hemodynamic stability. If hemodynamically stable, the next step is a colonoscopy, considering sigmoidoscopy if less than 40 years old. This leads to "Source Identified" or "Source Not Identified" options. If the patient is hemodynamically unstable, the flowchart leads to "Concern for upper GI source" and "Upper GI source unlikely". The first leads to Upper Endoscopy, while the second leads to "Angiography, surgery consultation". Both "Source Identified" and "Source Not Identified" can lead to either "Bleeding (overt) persists" or "Bleeding stops". If bleeding persists, treatment is considered. If bleeding stops and a source is identified, treatment is considered. The flowchart includes notes about nuclear scans and angiography detecting bleeding at different rates, and suggests considering EGD or capsule endoscopy.]

- NPO, monitor vitals
- Resuscitate (ABC): Set up 2 large-bore IV access and give 2L IV NS full rate
- Stop all anticoagulants
- Physical examination: GCS, hydration status, abdominal exam (peritoneal signs), PR exam for blood +/- proctoscopy
- Immediate Ix: CBC, clotting, T&S, X-match, LRFT, lactate, ABG

Further investigations

- If outlet type bleeding: proctoscopy + rigid sigmoidoscopy, proceed to colonoscopy if causes not found
- If unstable haemodynamics: early surgery consultation, rule out upper GI bleed by OGD

Role of colonoscopy: Low diagnostic field in massive bleeding (poor visualization)

- Endoscopic hemostasis - Indication: stigmata of recent hemorrhage (active bleeding, non-bleeding vessel, adherent clot) - Options: - Epinephrine injection (1:10000) – not used alone - Thermal energy e.g. argon plasma coagulation (APC) - usually for angiodysplasia - Endoscopic clip / band ligation - usually for diverticular bleeding - Scope clipping device (Ovesco): can even treat GI perforation / leakage / fistula
  Options if inconclusive top & tail
- Active bleeding: mesenteric angiogram / CT angiogram
- Intermittent bleeding: common causes include angiodysplasia, Dieulafoy lesion
  - Double balloon enteroscopy (DBE): scope with 2 inflated balloons, advance into SB from mouth or anus
  - Wireless capsule endoscopy: C/I IO → do CT/ MR enterography beforehand
  - CT/ MR enterography
  - Enteroclysis: intubation of DJ flexure under fluoroscopy → injection of barium, methylcellulose and water (double contrast) → identify small bowel neoplasm
  - Meckel's scan (for young patients)
- Emergency laparotomy may be required for life-threatening bleeding: segmental bowel resection
  - Pre-op localization (e.g. OGD, colonoscopy) preferred
  - If N/A, consider on-table enteroscopy or repeat OGD/colonoscopy

| Approach      | CT angiogram                                                           | Mesenteric angiogram                                                                                                                        | Red cell scan                                                                  |
| ------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
|               | CT abdomen + pelvis with contrast (arterial and portovenous phase)     | Femoral artery puncture → look for contrast extravasation (usually SMA)                                                                     | Technetium-99m labelled RBC remain circulation for 24 hours                    |
| Bleeding rate | 0.3-0.5 ml/min                                                         | 0.5-1 ml/min                                                                                                                                | ≥0.1 ml/min                                                                    |
| Role          | Diagnostic only For active bleed only                                  | Diagnostic + therapeutic: Embolisation - temporary vs permanent\* For active bleed only                                                     | Diagnostic only Suitable for both active and intermittent bleed                |
| Pros          | Widely available, minimally invasive, accurate anatomical localization | Specificity up to 100% with accurate anatomical localization                                                                                | More sensitive than angiogram Repeated scans within 24h for intermittent bleed |
| Cons          | NOT therapeutic Risk of contrast nephropathy                           | False negative: vasoconstriction after bleeding Risk of contrast nephropathy, femoral hematoma/dissection, bowel infarct after embolization | False localisation: overlapping of bowel, forward/backward peristalsis         |

\*Temporary (e.g. absorbable Gelatin sponge): useful in altered anatomy, but higher rebleeding rate
Permanent: coils (most effective, but need patient to form thrombi), particles (bleeding tumor, risk of bowel ischemia), liquid agents e.g. NBCA (good for coagulopathy, but risk of bowel ischemia)

Transfusion and blood products in acute LGIB

- Transfusion threshold: Hb < 7 if clinically stable, Hb <8-9 if massive bleeding or Hx of cardiovascular diseases
- Platelet: top up to 50
- INR: 1.5-2.5 (concomitant reversal agents during endoscopy), >2.5 (reversal agents before endoscopy)
  Management of anti-platelets and anti-coagulants
- Aspirin: stop if primary prophylaxis, continue if secondary prophylaxis (unless severe bleeding)
- DAPT: consult cardiology if recent ACS and coronary stent in-situ
- Warfarin / DOAC: stop +/- reversal

# 4.3 Intestinal obstruction

Description of IO

- Level: small bowel vs large bowel
- Mechanical vs functional
- Simple vs closed-loop
- Underlying cause
  Risk factors: History of hernia, abdominal malignancy, previous IO, previous surgery / RT, medications
  Pathophysiology
- Distal collapse: decompressed as luminal contents are emptied
- Proximal dilation:
  - Initially increased peristalsis overcomes obstruction
  - Soon exacerbated by gas accumulation (swallowed air + bacterial fermentation) + fluid accumulation (risk
    of dehydration and electrolyte imbalance)
- Ischaemia: compromised venous return due to dilated bowel → local mural distension and edema →
  compromised arterial supply → ischaemia, necrosis, perforation
- Dehydration & electrolyte imbalance in IO - Reduced oral intake - Vomiting - Defective intestinal absorption (oedematous wall) - Transudation of fluid into peritoneal cavity
  Aetiology
- Mechanical obstruction
  - Luminal: faecal impaction, gallstone (gallstone ileus), bezoar (trichobezoar, phytobezoar)
  - Intramural: tumour (20%) (lymphoma/GIST/adenoCA), strictures (e.g. diverticular diseases, ischemia,
    Crohn/s disease, post-RT), intussusception
  - Extramural: adhesion (60%) (prior surgery, TB, IBD, post-RT), incarcerated hernia (10%), volvulus,
- Functional obstruction - absence or inadequate peristalsis without mechanical obstruction
  - Paralytic ileus/ post-op ileus (hypoactive bowel sound): mainly SB involvement
  - Pseudo-obstruction: normal bowel sound
- Most common causes according to level:
  - SB (ABC): adhesion, bulge (hernia), cancer
  - LB: cancer, diverticular disease (structuring diverticulitis), volvulus

Cardinal features x4

- **Colicky abdominal pain**: more in SBO, suspect ischaemia if pain becomes constant
- **Vomiting**: profuse in SBO, feculent in late LBO (DDx: gastrocolic fistula)
- **Abdominal distension**: less obvious if high-intestinal obstruction
- **Constipation**: obstipation (+ absence of flatus) OR spurious diarrhoea (increased frequency, small volume)
- SBO vs LBO vs functional
  - Proximal obstruction: more pain & vomiting (bile-stained if high SB, brown if low SB)
  - Distal obstruction: more abdominal distension & constipation; vomiting late (faeculent)
  - Functional obstruction: less colicky pain

Complications

- Local: ischaemia, perforation, closed-loop obstruction
- Systemic: dehydration, electrolyte disturbance, aspiration pneumonia

Physical signs

- Focal tenderness, visible peristalsis, hyperactive bowel sound
- Hydration status: skin turgor, mucous membranes, UO
- Signs of impending strangulation: tachycardia, fever, WCC↑, acidosis, peritoneal signs
- Underlying causes: presence of scars / mass / cough impulse

Initial management

- Resuscitation: ABC
- NPO, O2, IV access, analgesics, anti-emetics
- **Drip and suck:**
  - NG tube / Salem sump tube (suck): free drainage + Q4h aspiration to decompress proximal bowel and reduce n/v
  - IVF rehydration + chart I/O (drip)
- Antibiotics: if suspect bowel perforation; IV ceftriaxone + metronidazole
- Monitor: vitals (temp, BP/P), abdominal tenderness, WBC, ABG

Investigations

- Bloods: CBC (infection), ABG/VBG (acidosis: ischaemia, alkalosis: vomiting), LRFT (↓K due to hypovolaemia and impaired absorption secondary to oedematous bowel wall), amylase, lactate +/- septic work-up
- **Erect CXR:** free gas, aspiration pneumonia, gastric distension, NG tube position
- **Erect and supine AXR**
  - Supine better identify transition point (erect AXR: number of air-fluid levels does not affect Mx)

| Size (3-6-9 rule) | Small bowel                                                                    | Large bowel                                                                             |
| ----------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Site              | >3cm                                                                           | >6cm (colon), >9cm (caecum)                                                             |
| Appearance        | Central                                                                        | Peripheral                                                                              |
|                   | Valvulae conniventes ("stack of coins") pass across width of bowel, more loops | Haustrae not pass across whole width of bowel, fewer loops, may have feces / rectal gas |

- CT abdomen/pelvis with contrast after adequate fluid resuscitation + RFT:
  - Indications: virgin abdomen with IO, peritoneal signs, unstable vitals, non-resolving despite Tx
  - Compared to AXR: more sensitive
    - Identify transition point and severity of IO (partial / complete)
    - Underlying etiology e.g. apple-core lesion (CRC), target sign (intussusception)
    - Complications e.g. ischemic bowel (intramural gas / PV gas / bowel wall thickening and enhancement)
- SBO that does not improve after 3 days: water-soluble contrast (gastrografin) follow-through
  - Diagnostic: Adhesive IO unlikely to resolve if contrast does not reach colon by 4h → Book EOT!
  - Therapeutic: hyper-osmotic → reduce edema and promote peristalsis → need for surgery
  - Water-soluble enema for LBO: to differentiate mechanical vs functional
- Do NOT order colonoscopy /barium enema in acute settings: risk of perforation and chemical peritonitis

Management principles

- Conservative management: Monitor 72h
  - Signs of resolution: Passage of flatus / stool, decreased abdominal distension, reduced NG tube output, resolved AXR signs
- Urgent laparotomy indicated if:
  - Risk of ischaemia (e.g. closed-loop IO)
  - Risk of perforation (e.g. dilated caecum > 12cm)
  - Failed conservative treatment after 72h
- Surgical principle: Treat underlying cause + resection of non-viable bowels
- Anastomosis: Primary anastomosis (usually SB) or double-barrel ileostomy for observation

Specific management
| Small bowel | Adhesions | Conservative management 80% effective Ix: water-soluble contrast follow-through Adhesiolysis (if failed conservative > 72h): risk of subsequent adhesion |
| --------------- | -------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Strangulated hernia | | Inguinal exploration: look for viability (~6P: cold, pulsation, pallor, peristalsis) → hernia repair (if viable) or resection + stoma (if non-viable) Manual reduction should not be performed: - Recurrence likely |

[Image of a small number 80 in the top right corner of the page.]

- Risk of peritonitis due to ischaemic bowel
- Reduction "en masse" (mass reduced to just below fascia)

Intraluminal
obstruction
(bezoar, gallstone)

MC site: distal ileum / ileocecal valve
Laparotomy for:

- Milking down the object through IC valve into LB
- Enterotomy proximal to obstruction and remove object
- Mx gallstone ileus by cholecystectomy + fistula repair (refer to [HBP])

Large bowel CRC
(emergency if
competent IC
valve!)

Emergency surgery: if signs of ischemia / perforation
Choice depends on risk of anastomotic leak vs morbidity of externalising a
stoma

- 1-stage (only for very good risk patients): resection + primary
  anastomosis with on-table lavage
- 2-stage: most common
  - Resectable tumors: Hartmann's procedure (resection + end
    colostomy + close distal end as rectal stump → reversal of stoma)
  - Unresectable tumours: proximal diversion loop colostomy /
    ileostomy or double barrel stoma (Paul-Mikulicz)
- 3-stage (for rectal tumour, no longer performed): defunctioning loop
  colostomy → resection + anastomosis → reversal of stoma

Endoscopic stenting (SEMS): for left-sided tumour except very large or distal
rectal tumour (risk of tenesmus & pain)

- Must first do CT to r/o closed-loop obstruction (perforation → T4 tumor)
- Bridge to elective surgery: wait 2-4 weeks before surgical resection
  - Avoid EOT (better fluid/nutrition, bowel prep) - higher chance of
    successful anastomosis
  - Allow 1-staged procedure (no stoma)
  - Allow complete oncological staging
- Palliation

Diverticular
disease
Elective: 1-stage
Emergency: 2-stage (Hartmann)

Volvulus
Sigmoid volvulus: conservative decompression preferred

- Flexible sigmoidoscopy de-rotation with cautious insufflation
- Leave rectal tube in-situ x 24h for decompression → serial AXR
- Emergency laparotomy (e.g. Hartmann's operation) if complications
  (ischaemia, perforation) or repeated failed compression
- Elective sigmoidectomy: for young or elderly with recurrent volvulus
  Caecal volvulus: surgery preferred
- Right hemicolectomy
- Colonoscopic de-rotation +/- caecopexy (fixation of caecum to RIF) -
  high recurrence

Closed-loop IO

- Bowel obstructed at both proximal and distal points
- Obstruction inside closed loop → impaired blood flow → risk of necrosis and perforation
- S/S: absolute constipation + no vomiting
- Examples
  - Malignant stricture of colon + competent ileocecal valve (1/3 population)
  - Volvulus
  - Hernia
  - Afferent loop syndrome (post-Billroth II gastrectomy)

[Image of the number 81, likely indicating a page number.]

Paralytic ileus

- Lack of propulsive contractions of small bowel
- Most common cause: **post-operative ileus**
  - Bowel sounds should return to normal within 1-2 days (stomach), hours (SB), 3-5 days (colon)
  - Clinically significant if >72h post-op, no return of bowel sounds, no flatus, abd distension
  - Mx: drip and suck, oral gastrografin (hyperosmotic), other prokinetics (e.g. erythromycin, metoclopramide), pethidine (no effect on gut motility c.f. morphine)
- Other causes:
  - After peritonitis / sepsis
  - Reflex ileus: retroperitoneal irritation after hemorrhage / #spine / #rib
  - Metabolic / drug-induced

Pseudo-obstruction
Definition: S/S of mechanical obstruction (usually colon) in the absence of a mechanical cause
Classification

- Acute colonic pseudo-obstruction (Ogilvie's syndrome): diagnosis of exclusion
- Chronic colonic pseudo-obstruction (e.g. Hirschsprung disease, toxic megacolon)
  Aetiology: autonomic imbalance (↓parasympathetic /↑sympathetic) → aperistalsis
- Metabolic disturbance (DM, hypoK, hypothyroidism, uremia)
- Drugs, e.g. opioids, CCB
- Trauma, e.g. post-op
- Neurological diseases, e.g. Parkinson, MS
  Clinical features
- Features of IO: abdominal distension (but not much pain), n/v, constipation
- Differentiating signs from mechanical obstruction
  - Normal bowel sound
  - Dilated rectum in PR exam (c.f. distal collapse in mechanical IO)
    Investigations
- AXR (repeat daily): presence of gas in rectum
- Bloods: CBC, LRFT, TFT
- CT abdomen (r/o mechanical IO), water-soluble contrast enema, colonoscopy (both Dx and Tx)
  Management
- Supportive: first line up to 72h if no peritonism or extreme colonic dilatation (>12cm)
  - Decompression: drip & suck, rectal tube
  - Ambulation
  - Remove underlying cause: electrolyte disturbance, discontinue causative drugs
- Colonoscopic decompression: bowel prep not required (little propulsion, limit air insufflation to reduce risk of perforation)
- IV Neostigmine: S/E bradycardia (cardiac monitor + atropine), excessive salivation, vomiting
- Surgical decompression: cecostomy

  4.4 Stoma
  Definition: artificial opening in GI tract to divert faeces and flatus outside the abdomen to an external appliance

- Good stoma: good blood supply, no tension, correct site, adequate fascial and skin aperture

Choice of stoma site

- Done with standing, bending, sitting
- Avoid surgical scars, skin creases, bony prominences
- Within rectus abdominis but away from umbilicus: muscle
  support → lower risk of parastomal hernia
- Emergency setting: reverse McBurney's point (2/3 from ASIS to
  umbilicus)

Classification of stoma

- Ileostomy vs colostomy

|          | Ileostomy              | Colostomy         |
| :------- | :--------------------- | :---------------- |
| Site     | Right iliac fossa (MC) | Left iliac fossa  |
| Surface  | Spout                  | Flushed with skin |
| Contents | Watery and fluid       | Faeces            |

- End vs Loop vs Double-barrel
- Permanent vs temporary

General indications of stoma

1. Decompression: ileostomy / colostomy to bypass a distal obstructing
   lesion
2. Diversion / Defunctioning
   a. Ileostomy / colostomy: protect distal bowel anastomosis -
   e.g. low anastomoses (higher tension, poorer blood supply),
   pre-op chemo RT (poor wound healing), intra-op bowel leak
   b. Ileal conduit: urinary diversion after cystectomy
3. Exteriorisation: ileostomy / colostomy when anastomosis cannot be
   performed or permanent stoma (e.g. APR)
4. Feeding: gastrostomy / jejunostomy
5. Lavage: appendicostomy for patients with fecal incontinence

Indications based on type of stoma

|      | Ileostomy                                       | Colostomy                                                                  |
| :--- | :---------------------------------------------- | :------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Loop | Temporary:                                      | Temporary                                                                  |
|      | - Fecal diversion after LAR + TME               | - Decompression: IO (e.g. inoperable CA sigmoid / rectum)                  |
|      | - UC with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA)   | - Fecal diversion: e.g. LAR + TME, diverticulitis with primary anastomosis |
|      | - Fistulas                                      | - Facilitate surgical treatment of high anal fistula                       |
|      |                                                 | - Rest distal bowel: acute Crohn's disease                                 |
| End  | Permanent:                                      | Permanent:                                                                 |
|      | - Pan-proctocolectomy (e.g. UC pancolitis, FAP) | - Abdominal-perineal resection\*                                           |
|      | - Subtotal colectomy with mucus fistula (e.g.   | Temporary:                                                                 |
|      | toxic megacolon)                                | - Hartmann's operation                                                     |

[Detailed diagram showing different types of stoma locations. The diagram is an irregular hexagon shape with rounded corners. The top left corner shows a circle labeled "Percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy". To the right of this and slightly lower is a horizontal line with a circle at each end, labeled "Transverse loop colostomy" and "End colostomy". Further down and to the left is a circle labeled "Ileal conduit". To the right of this is a circle labeled "Ileostomy". At the bottom of the shape is a line labeled "Mucous fistula".]

Examination of stoma: Ask to remove stoma bag

- Site
- Content: formed feces / semi-formed liquid / urine / mucus
- No. of lumens: end / loop/ double barrel
- Size and shape
- Relation to skin: spout/ flushed with skin
- Mucosal lining: color, moisture
- Complications
- Cough impulse

Complete: abdominal exam, external genitalia for anus, DRE, digital exam for stoma patency, fluid status

\*End colostomy → Check perineum and scars - APR (absent anus, 4 lap ports) vs Hartmann (present anus, midline laparotomy)

Other types of stoma

- Double barrel colostomy: divide bowel separately - one opening outputs stool, the other is "mucus fistula"
- Ileal conduit: urinary diversion following cystectomy for CA bladder
  [Man with a medical bag on his stomach. The medical bag is transparent, so you can see the fluids inside the bag.]
  Ileostomy
- Usually in right iliac fossa (DDx: ileal conduit)
- Fashioning:
  - Bring out at least 5cm to form a spout - alkaline SB contents are erosive and can damage local skin
  - Opening on distal limb allows bowel prep before LB investigations and rectal washout for clearance
- Ileostomy output: takes up to 6-8 weeks to stabilize (around 200-700mL/day)
  - Post-op Day 1-3: usually 1.5-1.8L of bilious output before adaptation
  - Post-op Day 3-8: critical period of high-output stoma
    - Do NOT discharge patient if ileostomy output >1500mL/day
    - Classification: Early (<3 weeks post-op) vs Late (≥ 3 weeks post-op)
- Management of high-output stoma (Defined as stoma output >1L/day
  - Strict chart I/O and daily BW
  - NPO
  - Aggressive fluid and electrolyte replacement (e.g. IV NS 2-4L/day) +/- oral Mg
  - Identify and treat underlying cause
    - Medications: prokinetics (e.g. metoclopramide, erythromycin), metformin
    - Bacterial infection esp. _C. difficile_ enteritis / colitis
    - Inadequate absorptive surface e.g. short gut, post-RT, fistula
  - Monitor RFT: aim UO 0.5-1mL/kg/h and urine Na >20
  - Dietary modification: adequate oral fluids and electrolytes (despite high output), small meals at 2-3h intervals, avoid foods that quicken transit time (e.g. hyperosmolar food, lactose, high-fibre diet)
  - Anti-motility agents: e.g. loperamide (preferred - non-sedative & non-addictive), codeine phosphate
  - Anti-secretory drugs: PPI (e.g. omeprazole 40mg BD), somatostatin analogues (e.g. octreotide)
  - Mineralocorticoids: might reduce stoma output by enhancing Na reabsorption in ileum

[This image shows a flow chart for NPO for 48 hours to assess baseline output. Starting at the top with NPO, it then branches to greater than 1200 mL per day where Plan long term IVF or TPN is used, or less than 1200 mL per day where ORS for 48 hours is used. This then branches to greater than 1500 mL per day, where commence liquid feed is used, or less than 1500 mL per day where starts food and monitor output is used. Then there is a separate flowchart for sequential trial. The sequential trial is greater than 1500 mL per day. Sequential trial is PPI 80 mg/day, Loperamide 8 mg, 4-5 x per day, codeine 60 mg 4 x per day, octreotide, stop if its impact is less than 300 ml a day after 72 hours.]

[Image shows the anatomy of the large intestine and rectum. The sigmoid colon has diverticula or pouches. A straight object is shown below the intestines.]

Colostomy

- Creation of loop colostomy:
  - Held in place by stoma rod (fig.) → remove at Day 5-7
  - Usually transverse colostomy (RUQ) or sigmoid colostomy (LLQ) - but loop ileostomy is now preferred
- Closure of temporary colostomy: easier when stoma is mature (≥ 2 months)
  - Contrast study (proctogram) to rule out distal obstruction / anastomotic leakage
  - Closed by circumstomal incision

Complications of stoma
Early

1. Necrosis:

- Causes: blood supply, tension, inadequate fascial aperture
- Management:
  - full-thickness necrosis: revision
  - partial-thickness necrosis: conservative, watch out for stenosis

[Image of a stoma with dark black tissue surrounding the opening, indicating necrosis.]

2. Retraction: Stoma recedes 25mm below skin surface

- Causes: tension, obesity
- Management: revision if significant

[Image of retracted stoma. The stoma is a circular opening with pink tissue visible inside, but it is sunken below the surrounding skin level.]

3. Peristomal abscess
   Intermediate 1. Dermatitis

- Causes: effluent dermatitis (excoriation, usually in ileostomy), contact dermatitis (allergy to stoma appliance)
- Management:
  - Educate stoma care techniques
  - Change appliance
  - Protect skin with barriers (e.g. creams, powders)

[Image of a stoma surrounded by red, irritated skin, showing dermatitis. The stoma itself is pink and slightly raised, but the skin around it is inflamed.]

2. Granuloma

- Causes: repeated trauma at suture site (mucocutaneous junction)
- Management:
  - Rule out tumor recurrence by biopsy
  - Resize stoma bag aperture
  - Apply silver nitrate / surgical excision of granuloma

[Image of a stoma with small, raised bumps or nodules (granulomas) around the opening. The stoma appears red and inflamed, and the nodules are scattered around its perimeter.]

3. Stenosis

- Causes: scarring, inflammation (e.g. Crohn's disease)
- Management:
  - Mild: stool softener, stoma dilator
  - Severe: revision

[Image of a stoma with significant narrowing of the opening, indicating stenosis. The opening is small and constricted, with some surrounding redness or inflammation.]

4. Fistula: usually ileostomy, esp. Crohn's disease
5. High output (ileostomy) - refer above
   Late
6. Parastomal hernia

- Risk factors: end stoma, emergency surgery (esp. IO), multiple surgery, post-op complications
- Problems: faecal leak, difficulty in fitting stoma bag, risk of strangulation / obstruction
- Management:
  - Conservative: weight reduction, abdominal truss
  - Surgical repair: mesh repair (laparoscopic)

[Image of a parastomal hernia showing a bulge or protrusion of tissue around the stoma site. The stoma is visible, but there is a noticeable swelling or lump adjacent to it.]

2. Prolapse

- MC in loop transverse colostomy, swollen stoma is at risk of necrosis
- Management:
  - Conservative: larger stoma bag, baby oil to reduce friction
  - Surgical revision if symptomatic / impending gangrene

[Image of a prolapsed stoma, showing a significant portion of the intestine protruding out through the stoma opening. The prolapsed tissue is swollen and appears moist.]

3. Parastomal varix

- Associated with portal hypertension
- Management: hemostasis (e.g. direct ligation, sclerotherapy)

[Image of parastomal varices, showing prominent, dilated veins around the stoma. The veins appear as bluish or purplish lines close to the stoma opening.]

Carcinoid tumors

- Origin: APUD cells of neural crest origin (enterochromaffin cells / Kulchitsky cells)
- Presentations: abdominal pain, ileus, acute appendicitis, ischaemic bowel, carcinoid syndrome
- Site: GIT (3/4), lung (1/4)

| Site    | Carcinoid syndrome                | Metastasis      | Secretion     |
| ------- | --------------------------------- | --------------- | ------------- | ------------------------------------- |
| Foregut | Pancreas, stomach Bronchus / lung | Occur, atypical | Rare          | 5-hydroxytryptophan (5-HTP) Histamine |
| Midgut  | Jejunum, ileum (MC), appendix     | Frequent (70%)  | Almost always | Serotonin                             |
| Hindgut | Colon, rectum                     | Rare            | Rare          | Neither serotonin nor 5-HTP           |

Pathology

- Staging: TNM staging
- Grading: according to mitotic rate and Ki-67 index
- Functionality: most are non-functional (functional, e.g. gastrinoma)
  Investigations:
- Markers: chromogranin A, 5-HIAA
- Localisation: endoscopy, CT enteroclysis, whole body somatostatin receptor scintigraphy (SSRS)
  Management
- Gastric NET: endoscopic resection if type 1-2, gastrectomy with LN clearance if type 3
- SB NET: resect all extra-hepatic lesions + LN clearance, Tx hepatic lesions by chemo-embolization
- Appendiceal NET: appendectomy if < 2cm, appendectomy + right colectomy if >2cm
- Colonic NET (worst prognosis): partial colectomy + LN clearance

Carcinoid syndrome

- Most common in SB (jejunum & ileum)
- Pathophysiology:
  - Altered metabolism of tryptophan (--> serotonin --> 5-HIAA)
  - Other secretory products include histamine, kallikrein, etc
  - Mostly metabolised into inactive forms by liver, unless **liver metastasis** or tumour invasion into IVC bypassing portal circulation --> carcinoid syndrome
- Clinical features:
  - Episodic flushing, hypotension (histamine, substance P)
  - Diarrhoea (serotonin)
  - Bronchospasm (histamine)
  - Secondary restrictive cardiomyopathy (serotonin-induced fibrosis of right heart only due to lung as a filter; cause TIPS: Tricuspid Insufficiency, Pulmonary Stenosis)
- Investigations:
  - 24h urine 5-HIAA: only in those symptomatic; reflect tumour load
- Management: - **IV octreotide** (both symptomatic + improve survival) - Ondansetron (5-HT3 antagonist for diarrhoea)

  4.6 Benign diseases of large bowel
  Constipation
  DDx: IBS, drugs (e.g. CCB), hypothyroidism, hyperCa, hypoK, cord compression, IO

Acute appendicitis
Anatomy

- Base of appendix: McBurney's point (1/3 distance from ASIS to umbilicus)
- Constant position of base of appendix: confluence of 3 taeniae coli of caecum
  → appendix traced by gentle traction on taeniae coli during OT
- Position of appendix: MC is retrocecal but intraperitoneal (74%)
  - Affected by malrotation /non-rotation of cecum (e.g. in RUQ)
- In colonoscopy: posteromedial wall of cecum, around 2cm below IC valve
- Mesoappendix contains appendicular artery (← ileocolic a. SMA) and vein - "End-artery" - thrombosis causes necrosis of appendix (gangrenous appendicitis)
  [A drawing that shows the position of the appendix. It is a small, finger-like projection that extends from the cecum, which is the beginning of the large intestine. The appendix is located in the lower right abdomen. Labeled parts are: Prelleal 1%, Retrocecal 74%, Paracaecal 2%, Postleal 0.5%, Pelvic 21%, Subcaecal 1.5%]
  Overview
- Definition: inflammation of appendix, 2/3 due to occlusion of lumen, 1/3 non-occlusive
  - Obstruction of lumen → venous congestion → ischemia → gangrene / perforation → phlegmon / abscess / peritonitis
- Aetiology:
  - Faecolith: a hard-stony mass of faeces
  - Lymphoid hyperplasia in mesoappendix
  - Rare: tumour (CA caecum), intestinal parasite, foreign bodies
- Complications: transmural inflammation → localized area of sepsis
- Gangrenous appendicitis - Perforation - Walled off: form appendiceal abscess → obstruction - Not walled off: generalized peritonitis
  Clinical features
- Age group: MC 5-12y
- Classical course:
  - Periumbilical pain: crampy, intermittent, poorly localized, aggravated by moving/coughing
  - Low grade fever, vomiting, anorexia (c.f. n/v followed by pain in GE)
  - Pain migrating to RLQ after 12-24h: constant sharp well-localized pain
- Signs (need to know!)
  - Pointing sign: max tenderness at McBurney's point
  - Rovsing's sign (RLQ pain upon rebound pressure of LLQ)
  - Psoas sign (increased pain upon extending hip against resistance) - usually in retrocecal appendix
  - Obturator sign (increased pain upon internal rotation of hip with hip & knee flexed) - usually in pelvic appendix
- Signs of complications: high fever, RLQ mass, imaging shows abscess/ phlegmon (inflammatory mass)
  [An image of the abdomen. It depicts the psoas sign test. The patient is lying on their side, and the examiner is extending the patient's hip. This maneuver will cause pain in the right lower quadrant if the patient has appendicitis.]
  [An image of the abdomen. It depicts the obturator sign test. The patient is lying on their back, and the examiner is flexing the patient's hip and knee. The examiner is then internally rotating the hip, which will cause pain in the right lower quadrant if the patient has appendicitis.]
  [An image of the abdomen that illustrates the Rovsing's sign test. The examiner palpates in the left lower quadrant (LLQ) which elicits pain in the right lower quadrant (RLQ). The text "Pain elicited in RLQ suggestive of acute appendicitis" is below the picture.]

Differential diagnosis

- Caecum: diverticulitis, mesenteric adenitis, cecal /appendiceal tumors (e.g. lymphoma)
- Terminal ileum: Crohn's disease, Meckel's diverticulitis, TB, Yersinia ileitis
- PPU: epigastric pain → RLQ (Valentino's sign)
- Acute pancreatitis
- Urologic: testicular torsion, UTI, ureteric colic
- Gynaecological: "Mittelschmerz" pain (ovulation), ovarian cyst complications, PID, ruptured ectopic pregnancy

Investigations

- Bloods: CBC (leucocytosis) - ↑↑↑ may indicate gangrenous / perforated appendix, normal cannot r/o
- CRP, urine PT for women
- AXR: faecoliths (only 5% radio-opaque)
- Risk stratification: Alvarado score (fig.)
  | 7-10 | Strongly suggestive: consider surgery / further imaging |
  | --- | --- |
  | 5-6 | Equivocal: consider USG / contrast CT abdomen |
  | 0-4 | Not likely: consider other DDx |
- Imaging: - USG: low sensitivity, for pregnant women / children - CT abdomen + contrast: highest diagnostic accuracy - Findings: appendiceal diameter > 6mm, appendiceal wall thickening and hyperenhancement, periappendiceal fat stranding, appendicolith
  Management
- Resuscitation, NPO, IV fluids, analgesics
- **Prophylactic IV antibiotics**
  - Anaerobic coverage, e.g. IV ceftriaxone + metronidazole
  - Non-complicated: continue until 24h post-op
  - Complicated (e.g. abscess, phlegmon): continue 3-7d post-op
- **Laparoscopic appendicectomy (first line!)**
  | | Immediate surgery | Interval surgery (Oschner-Sherren regimen) |
  | :------------------------------- | :--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | :------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
  | Indications | - Present **within 72h** and fit for surgery | Present **>72h and stable** (walled-off appendix → resolve or become abscess → immediate OT is difficult due to adhesions) |
  | | - Complicated and **unstable** (consider open surgery) | |
  | Approach | - **Laparoscopic** is preferred: ↓infection risk, ↓post-op pain, ↓hospital stay | **IV antibiotics** (~90% success rate) +/- image-guided drainage of abscess Lap appendicetomy 6-8 weeks later **Colonoscopy if >40yo:** exclude CA |
  | | - **Open**: indicated if gross sepsis | |
- Positioning: supine +/- Trendelenburg and right side up (allow SB fall away from operative field)
- Incisions in open surgery:
  - Lanz (more popular): transverse incision 2cm below umbilicus, centred on mid-clavicular line
    - ☺ continues with Langer's line - more cosmetically pleasing with reduced scarring
  - Gridiron: perpendicular to line joining ASIS to umbilicus, at McBurney's point
  - Rutherford-Morrison: extend Gridiron obliquely upwards and laterally (for paracecal appendix)
- Risks (**need to know for consent!**)
  - Immediate: convert to open, normal appendix (still removed to avoid diagnostic confusion), malignancy requiring R hemicolectomy ± stoma, injury to surrounding organs, bleeding
  - Early: Wound infection (5-10%), intra-abdominal / pelvic abscess (spiking fever), post-op ileus
  - Late: Incisional hernia, adhesions, recurrent/ stump appendicitis

- **Conservative management** can be considered if uncomplicated (no perforation / abscess) and not fit for surgery
  - Bowel rest, IV ceftriaxone + metronidazole
  - Compared to surgery: shorter duration of disability, but risk of complications and recurrence
  - Recurrence rate: 30% in 3 months, 40% in 1 year, 50% in 3 years

Studies supportive conservative Mx of appendicitis:

- CODA (2020): 10-day antibiotics non-inferior to appendectomy, 30% chance of appendectomy in 90 days, increased risk if appendicoliths +ve
- APPAC I / II / III
- APPIC

The total score at the bottom of the table is 10.]

90
Appendix specimen sent to pathology for assessment of neoplasms (1% chance)

- Carcinoids: appendicectomy if ≤2cm, R hemicolectomy if >2cm or involve cecum / LN
- Epithelial: classified into mucinous or non-mucinous
  Ο
  - Mucinous tumors have risk of perforation and seeding → **pseudomyxoma peritonei (PMP)**
    - Low risk: colonoscopy to exclude associated lesions + surveillance (e.g. CT A+P, tumor markers)
    - High risk: treat as PMP → cytoreductive surgery + heated intraperitoneal chemotherapy (HIPEC)
  - Adenocarcinoma: highly malignant, treated by R hemicolectomy +/- adjuvant chemo

**Volvulus**
Definition: twisting of bowel around its mesentery
Location

- Sigmoid volvulus (70%): elongated mesentery → more mobile
- Caecal volvulus (25%): caecum mostly retroperitoneal, but some intraperitoneal with mesentery
- Transverse colon (3%)
- Splenic flexure (2%)
  Risk factors
- Non-modifiable: aging (stretching of bowel), congenital (hypermobile caecum)
- Modifiable: - Bedbound - High-fibre diet (bulky stool), chronic constipation, laxative abuse - Pregnancy
  Contributed by
- Closed-loop IO: colicky abdominal pain, abdominal distension, vomiting
- Intestinal ischaemia: colicky pain becomes constant
  Investigations
- AXR: sigmoid vs caecal volvulus
  | Sigmoid | Caecal |
  | ----------- | ----------- |
  | Arise in pelvis/ LLQ | Arise in RLQ |
  | Ahaustral | Haustral |
  | 3 lines of sigmoid wall converging to site of obstruction | |
  | Dilated LB with **coffee bean sign** | Dilated SB |
  | Absent rectal gas | Absent rectal gas |

- Barium/ gastrografin enema: bird's beak sign (sigmoid)
- Endoscopy: sigmoidoscopy (sigmoid), colonoscopy (caecal)
- CT (only if AXR/ enema inconclusive): whirl sign (sigmoid, fig.)
  Management
- Initial: NPO, drip & suck, IV antibiotics
- Sigmoid volvulus
  - Endoscopic decompression +/- stenting
    - Flexible sigmoidoscopy de-rotation with cautious insufflation (_first line!_)
      - Successful reduction: sudden expulsion of gas and stool
      - Leave rectal tube in-situ for 24h for decompression → serial AXR to monitor
    - Urgent laparotomy for untwisting +/- sigmoidectomy if non-viable
      - Indication: failed endoscopic treatment, signs of _ischemic bowel_ (e.g. acidosis, T+G+R+), necrotic bowel noted at endoscopy
      - Sigmoidectomy → primary anastomosis + on-table lavage
      - **Emergency Hartmann's operation**: rectal stump + colostomy
      - Paul Mikulicz procedure: removal of volvulus + double barrel colostomy for future anastomosis
  - Elective sigmoidectomy: for young patients or elderly with **recurrent** volvulus (not in every elderly: high mortality) due to high risk of recurrence after endoscopic Tx
- Caecal volvulus: surgery is indicated - usually ischemic
  - Surgery: _right hemicolectomy_
  - Colonoscopic derotation +/- caecopexy (fixation of caecum to RIF) - high recurrence

[Image Description: A coronal view CT scan of an abdomen is displayed. The abdomen is largely distended with air. The descending colon and rectum appear decompressed.]

Ischemic bowel disease
Definition

- Ischaemic bowel/ **mesenteric ischemia:** vascular compromise of the bowel due to occlusion of mesenteric circulation (usually SMA) - further divided into **acute & chronic**
- Ischaemic colitis: vascular compromise of **large bowel** (usually IMA)

Aetiology of mesenteric ischemia

|         |                                           |                                                                                                                                                               |
| :------ | :---------------------------------------- | :------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
| Acute   | Occlusive mesenteric ischaemia            | **Embolism (50%):** cardiac causes (e.g. _AF_, post-MI mural thrombus), abdominal/ thoracic aneurysm/dissection Lodged at more distal segment, less extensive |
|         |                                           | **Arterial thrombosis (15-25%)** e.g. abdominal trauma, mesenteric aneurysm/dissection Obstruct more proximal segment, more extensive                         |
|         |                                           | **Venous thrombosis (5%):** hypercoagulability, malignancy                                                                                                    |
|         | Non-occlusive mesenteric ischaemia (NOMI) | Generalized hypoperfusion / shock: mesenteric vasoconstriction to preserve supply to vital organs Causes: severe CVS disease, drugs (e.g. digoxin, diuretics) |
| Chronic |                                           | Atherosclerosis                                                                                                                                               |

Extrinsic causes of ischemic bowel: strangulating hernia, volvulus

Pathogenesis:

- Hypoxic injury phase: little damage
- Reperfusion injury phase: ↑ROS (↑O2 supply) + ↑inflammation (↑influx of leukocytes and complements)
- Watershed zones prone to damage: end of arterial supplies
  - Splenic flexure (**Griffith's point**): SMA & IMA
  - Rectosigmoid junction (**Sudeck's point**): sigmoid a. and superior rectal a.

Clinical features: Acute abdomen + metabolic acidosis = ischaemic bowel until proven otherwise

- Hyperactive phase: **generalised abdominal pain out of proportion to physical findings** (can be non-tender), **PR bleed / bloody diarrhea**, vomiting
  - Acute embolus: **severe sudden periumbilical pain** in old patient with _AF_
  - Acute thrombosis: patient with strong cardiovascular risk factors (e.g. HT/HL/DM) and PVD
  - Chronic ischemia: **postprandial pain (mesenteric angina) → fear of eating** (sitophobia), weight loss
- Paralytic phase: absent bowel sound
- Shock phase (fluid leaks through damaged bowel): hypotension, shock

Investigations

- Bloods: CBC (leucocytosis: non-specific), **lactate**, **ABG** (HAGMA), clotting (if suspect hypercoagulability), amylase, RFT
- AXR: can be normal
  - Dilated bowel loops (paralytic ileus)
  - **Thumbprinting sign** (submucosal oedema)
  - **Pneumatosis intestinalis / portal venous gas** (necrosis)
  - Bowel wall thickening
  - Pneumoperitoneum, Rigler's double wall sign (perforation)
- CT abdomen with contrast: sensitive for ischemic bowel and SMA occlusion, exclude other DDx
- CT angiogram (gold standard): sensitive for mesenteric ischemia and allow endovascular interventions
  - Arterial occlusion: lack of enhancement of arterial vasculature with timed IV contrast
  - Venous thrombosis: filling defects / absent flow during venous phase

[Radiographic images showing findings related to ischemic bowel disease. The left image demonstrates thumbprinting sign, which is a radiological sign characterized by the appearance of thickened bowel folds resembling thumbprints due to submucosal edema. The right image shows pneumatosis intestinalis, a condition where gas is present within the bowel wall, indicating necrosis.]

91

Management
Acute ischaemia

- Initial: resuscitation + analgesia + IV broad-spectrum antibiotics
- Systemic **anticoagulation**
- Unstable (with peritoneal signs): **urgent midline laparotomy (within 6h)** / diagnostic laparoscopy
  - Mesenteric revascularization: Palpate SMA to differentiate embolism vs thrombosis
    - Present proximal SMA pulse (embolism): open **surgical embolectomy** → surgical revascularization if unsuccessful
    - Absent SMA pulse (thrombosis): surgical revascularization (e.g. thromboendarterectomy, mesenteric bypass, retrograde stenting)
  - Resect non-viable bowels + stoma (do not attempt anastomosis)
  - High risk of short gut syndrome: diarrhoea, steatorrhea → dehydration, malabsorption, weight loss
- Stable (no peritoneal signs): **CT scan / angiography → thrombolysis** (if no C/I)
  - SMA occlusion: surgical / percutaneous revascularization
  - SMV thrombosis: anticoagulation + catheter-directed thrombolysis
  - NOMI: consider transarterial vasodilator infusion
- Post-op management:
  - ICU support
  - Nutrition: TPN
  - Second look laparotomy 24-48h after (if extent of bowel viability uncertain)
  - Stoma care: reverse if stable
  - Investigate and treat underlying cause, e.g. echocardiogram, anticoagulation

Assess viability of bowels:

- **pink serosa**
- **visible peristalsis**
- **mesenteric pulsation**
- **bleeding from marginal arteries**
- intra-op doppler USG
- fluorescein injection → Wood's lamp

[A black and white X-ray image. The image shows a section of the abdomen with several markings. A yellow arrow points to an area within the abdomen, and red arrows indicate other areas. Purple arrows point to the upper section of the abdomen. In the lower right corner, there's a smaller image labeled "Double wall sign". The image appears to be a medical scan, possibly for diagnostic purposes, highlighting key areas of interest.]

Chronic ischaemia

- Risk factor modification: smoking cessation, antihypertensive, statin, etc
- Endovascular: mesenteric angioplasty with stenting
- Surgical: endarterectomy, bypass

# Inflammatory bowel disease

See [MED] for clinical features, investigations and medical management
Indications of surgical management

- Emergency:
  - Fulminant colitis
  - Toxic megacolon: non-obstructive colonic dilatation with systemic toxicity
  - Impending perforation: thumb-printing sign (fig.)
  - Life-threatening haemorrhage
- Elective: - Luminal complications: SBO, abscess, enterocutaneous fistula - Perianal diseases: abscess, fistula, anorectal stricture - Malignancy: treatment (e.g. biopsy-proven adenoCA) or prophylaxis (e.g. dysplasia on surveillance Bx) - Refractory to medical treatment / complications (e.g. osteoporosis) - Debilitating EIM, except EIM independent of colitis activity - sacroiliitis, hepatobiliary complications
  Surgical principle: preservation of bowel length (should document residual SB length)

# Surgical procedures for UC

Emergency surgery: usually indicated in fulminant colitis / toxic megacolon to prevent perforation

- Total colectomy + temporary end ileostomy
- Rectum left in situ temporarily as Hartmann's pouch / brought out as mucous fistula
- Followed by completion proctectomy + ileo-pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA) 6mo later
  Elective surgery:
- Normal sphincter function: **restorative proctocolectomy + ileo-pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA)** - IPAA: in form of J pouch (fig., most common), S pouch or W pouch - Temporary loop ileostomy for diversion - Specific complications - Pelvic nerve damage: impotence - Pouch dysfunction: increased faecal frequency (mean = 6), urgency,
  incontinence; Mx observe - Pouchitis: pouch dysfunction + systemic illness; Mx metronidazole
- Poor sphincter function: **total proctocolectomy + permanent end ileostomy / Koch's continent ileostomy (K-pouch)**
  - Cons: permanent stoma
- Female who wants to maintain fertility: total colectomy + ileorectal anastomosis (IRA)
  - Pros: to avoid pelvic adhesions and thus infertility
  - Cons: risk of rectal disease

# Surgical procedures for CD

- Not curative
- Management strategy according to behaviour of disease: - Inflammatory disease (30%): medical, surgical resection - Fibrostenotic disease (50%): endoscopic dilatation, surgical
  (stricturoplasty or resection for SB, resection for LB) - Fistulising disease (20%): drainage, medical (combined anti-TNF + azathioprine), surgical resection
- Enterocutaneous fistula: abnormal communications between 2 epithelialised surfaces
  - Causes: FRIEND (Foreign body, radiation, inflammation/ infection, epithelialization, neoplasm, distal obstruction)
  - Management
    - Delineate anatomy of fistula: CT abdomen
    - Replace fluid & electrolytes, chart fistula output
    - Wound care, e.g. negative pressure wound therapy (NPWT) (fig.)
    - Bowel rest → drugs (loperamide, octreotide) → endoscopic/ surgical closure
- Perianal CD: Drain pus, lay open for simple fistula, Seton drain for complex fistula
  - Give biologics after drainage of pus to close fistula tract
  - If failed, consider surgery (defunctioning stoma ± proctectomy)
