# Diverticular disease

Definitions

- Diverticulum: sac-like outpouchings of **all layers** from a hollow viscera (c.f. polyps)
- Diverticulosis (coli): presence of multiple **false** diverticula (mucosa and submucosa protrude through muscularis propria)
- Diverticular disease: **symptomatic** diverticulosis (e.g. bleeding, pain)
- Diverticulitis: inflammation of a diverticulum (e.g. infection)

Pathophysiology
[Image of a Diverticula diagram showing the Diverticula with labels such as: Antimesenteric taeniae, Blood vessel penetrating wall, Fecalith, Circular muscle, Mesenteric taenia and Mesocolon.]

- **Bowel weakening with aging + increased intraluminal pressure** (e.g. constipation): sigmoid has narrowest lumen → highest pressure due to Laplace's law
- Outpouching at the weakest point (colon only contains one layer of full thickness muscle → weakest where **vasa recta penetrate circular muscle**)
- Most common sites: **right-sided** in Asia, sigmoid in Western countries
- Rectum is **never** affected: outer smooth muscle encompasses full circumference of rectum
  Risk factors
- Age (rare before 30y)
- Low-fibre diet
- **Intraluminal pressure**, e.g. constipation, obesity
- Drugs: **NSAID**, steroid
- Connective tissue disease, e.g. Marfan's

Clinical features

- Asymptomatic diverticulosis (80%)
- Diverticular bleeding: **Painless** massive PR bleeding (rupture of vasa recta)
- Symptomatic uncomplicated diverticular disease (SUDD): **Colicky pain** relieved by defecation, CIBH
- Complications:
  - Diverticulitis: clinical triad of **lower abdominal pain (RLQ in Asia) + fever + leucocytosis**
    - Obstruction of diverticulum by faecalith → stasis and bacterial overgrowth → inflammation
  - Perforation: acute abdomen, generalised peritonitis
  - Abscess (e.g. peri-colic, psoas, liver): persistent fever / abdo pain despite ABx +/- tender mass on PR
  - Fistula formation: MC colovesical (recurrent dysuria, pneumaturia, faecaluria)
  - Intestinal obstruction: LBO due to fibrosis and stricture, SBO due to adhesion to inflamed bowel

Investigations

- CBC D/C, LRFT, amylase, urinalysis and culture
- AXR: dilated bowel
- CXR: free gas under diaphragm
- **CT abdomen + pelvis with contrast** - Diagnostic: bowel wall thickening - Assess complications: fistula, abscess (5cm as cut-off: likely resolve by antibiotics vs require intervention) - Aid treatment: guide percutaneous drainage of abscess - Prognostic: **Hinchey classification** (note NOT applicable in right-sided disease)
  | Stage | Presentations | Mortality (%) | Treatment |
  | --- | --- | --- | --- |
  | I | Localized pericolic abscess | 0 | IV antibiotics +/- drainage |
  | II | Distant abscess (retroperitoneal/pelvic) | 5 | IV antibiotics + drainage |
  | III | Generalised suppurative peritonitis (abscess ruptured, but bowel intact) | 25 | Hartmann's operation / One-stage resection |
  | IV | Faecal peritonitis (bowel wall perforation) | 50 | Hartmann's operation |

95

- Colonoscopy: only **after** resolution of acute episode (risk of perforation)
  - Definitive diagnosis (localisation) & rule out other DDx (e.g. CRC, IBD)
  - Assess complications: stenosis
  - Therapeutic: endoscopic haemostasis
- CT colonography with water-soluble rectal contrast: especially for colovesical fistula

Management
Diverticular disease

- 50% bleeding stop spontaneously
- Lifestyle modification: high-fibre diet, bulk laxative (e.g. methylcellulose), weight reduction
- Antispasmodics if colicky pain
- Avoid stimulant laxatives and NSAIDs
- Localisation of bleeding: colonoscopy → angiography → on-table lavage and colonoscopy → subtotal colectomy and ileostomy if the bleeding source still cannot be identified

Diverticulitis and complications

- Resuscitation if necessary
- Bowel rest: NPO + IV fluid
- IV broad spectrum antibiotics (cover GN & anaerobes)
- Percutaneous drainage of abscess (CT-guided)
- Surgical treatment:
  - Emergency surgery: indicated in perforation, obstruction, Hinchey stage III-IV diverticulitis, or failed conservative treatment
    - Hartmann's operation with on-table peritoneal lavage
      - One-stage resection (resection + primary anastomosis +/- defunctioning stoma): higher mortality due to excessive contamination/inflammation and high chance of anastomotic leak
      - Note: ensure adequate resection margin
        - Inadequate distal margin is the MC cause of recurrent diverticulitis after resection
  - Elective surgery: indicated in chronic complications (e.g. fistula, Hinchey stage I-II)
    - Colovesical fistula: resection of affected colon + omental pedicle between bowel and bladder to prevent recurrent fistulation + synchronous repair of bladder

Meckel diverticulum

- Definition: **true** congenital diverticulum bulging at the **anti-mesenteric aspect** of small intestine, due to incomplete obliteration of vitelline duct (connect midgut to yolk sac in early weeks of gestation)
- Most common congenital anomaly of GI tract
  Rule of 2s
- 2% of the population, in which 2% becomes symptomatic often by age of 2
- 2:1 male-to-female ratio
- 2 inches in length, found within 2 feet of the ileocaecal valve
- 2 types of ectopic tissue: gastric (60%), pancreatic (6%) or both
  Clinical features
- Haematochezia: **massive painless** maroon-coloured stool (due to acid secretion by the ectopic gastric mucosa)
- Abdominal pain (midgut): due to IO or inflammation (mimic appendicitis)
- Intestinal obstruction: due to
  - Recurrent intussusception: Meckel's diverticulum as the lead point
  - Volvulus
  - Littre's hernia: hernia containing Meckel's diverticulum
    Investigations
- Meckel's scan: Technetium-99m pertechnatate scan
  - Gastric mucosa actively secretes chloride into the intestinal lumen
  - Pertechnatate behaves like chloride ion → actively accumulated in the mucosa → secreted
  - Require pre-med with H2 blockers: inhibit excretion of isotope into bowel lumen
    [A series of six nuclear medicine scans are displayed horizontally, depicting the abdomen with increasing intensity over time. The initial scans show faint, diffuse activity, while the later scans reveal a more concentrated area of uptake in the lower right quadrant, highlighted by a pink arrow. The contrast and brightness are consistent across all images, suggesting a sequential progression of radiotracer accumulation.]
    Acute management if bleeding: Resuscitation, IV fluids, PPI, H2 blocker infusion

Management by laparoscopic-assisted resection

- Asymptomatic:
  - Detected on imaging: **not resect**
  - Detected during OT: depends on age (complications decrease with age)
    - Child: resect
    - Adult < 50y: resect if palpable, length > 2cm & broad base >2cm
    - Adult >50y: not resect
- Symptomatic: resect
  - Narrow base: **simple diverticulectomy** (diverticulum excision and suture at the base)
  - Broad base / ulceration at margin / mesenteric border: **segmental bowel resection** + primary anastomosis

Angiodysplasia
Definitions: abnormal dilated submucosal arterio-venous malformation (AVM)

- Increased with aging, mostly right-sided
  Pathophysiology
- Congenital: Heyde's syndrome (LGIB a/w aortic stenosis due to acquired Type 2A vWD), Rendu-Osler-Weber syndrome (hereditary haemorrhagic telangiectasia)
- Acquired: peristaltic contraction → intermittent obstruction of submucosal veins → loss of pre-capillary sphincter competence → formation of small AVM - Most common sites: right-sided (caecum, ascending colon) - Association: ESRD, vWD
  Clinical features
- Painless haematochezia
- Features of anaemia: fatigue, dizziness, SOB
  Investigations
- Colonoscopy: **cherry red spots**
- Mesenteric angiogram (if CLN inconclusive): **mother-in-law phenomenon** (early filling, delayed emptying)
- Occult GIB: wireless capsule endoscopy or double balloon endoscopy
  Management
- Conservative: bed rest, tranexamic acid
- Endoscopic: **argon plasma coagulation** (APC) or monopolar electrocautery
- IR: mesenteric angiogram for super-selective catheterisation and embolisation
- Surgical: only in selected patients because of high mortality
  - Indications:
    - Failed endoscopic & angiographic treatment
    - Severe acute life-threatening GIB
    - Multiple angiodysplastic lesions that cannot be managed otherwise
  - Approach: resection (right hemicolectomy) with anastomosis

Hartmann's operation
Indications: Often emergency operation

- **Severe complicated diverticulitis** (Hinchey class III or above): fecal contamination → primary anastomosis undesirable
- Left-sided CRC with complications requiring **urgent resection** (e.g. obstruction, perforation, bleeding)
- Sigmoid volvulus with complications (perforation, necrotic bowel) or recurrent failed decompression
- Complicated IBD: life-threatening haemorrhage, toxic megacolon, perforation
  Procedure
- Sigmoid resection
- Formation of **temporary end colostomy** at LIF
- Closure of **rectal stump** (or mucous fistula if high risk of breakdown causing sepsis)
- Re-anastomosis 2-3 months post-op
  Specific complications
- Rectal stump leak, abscess, fistula
- Ureter injury
- Stoma complications

  4.7 Colorectal carcinoma (CRC)
  Familial colon cancer syndrome (**important!**)

- Account for ~10% of CRC (remaining 90% are sporadic)

|                             | Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           | Lynch syndrome                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  |
| --------------------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| % of CRC burden             | <1%                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            | 5-7%                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            |
| Genetics                    | AD mutation in **APC gene** on chromosome 5q21 (~100% penetrance, 25% sporadic cases) → chromosomal instability (CIN) pathway                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  | AD mutation in **DNA mismatch repair (MMR) genes** (e.g. MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2) / deletion in EPCAM gene → microsatellite instability (MSI) pathway                                                                                                                                                            |
| Clinical features           | Adenomas > 100 (usually 500-2500) by age 20 100% risk of CRC Predominantly left-sided                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          | Few polyps (HNPCC as a misnomer) Predominantly right-sided, large flat polyps 80% lifetime risk of CRC                                                                                                                                                                                                          |
| Pathology                   | Moderately differentiated adenoCA                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              | Poorly differentiated, lymphocytic infiltration                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 |
| Extracolonic manifestations | Increased risk of: - CA duodenum (D2 - periampullary) - CA thyroid (papillary CA) - CA pancreas / gallbladder / bile duct <br> Benign fundic gland polyps Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE), epidermoid cysts in childhood                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          | Increased risk of: - CA endometrium - CA small bowel - CA urinary tract: ureter & renal pelvis                                                                                                                                                                                                                  |
| Diagnosis                   | Colonoscopy > 100 adenomatous polyps Genetic testing: APC +/- MUTYH^                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           | Genetic testing: PCR for MSI, IHC for MMR proteins **Amsterdam II criteria\*** - ≥3 relatives with Lynch-associated cancers (at least 1 pair of first-degree relatives) - ≥2 successive generations - ≥1 tumour diagnosed by 50y - FAP excluded - Tumours verified by pathology <br> Revised Bethesda guideline |
| Treatment                   | Prophylactic colectomy: indicated if documented CA, adenoma with high-grade dysplasia, marked increase in polyp number or severely symptomatic, unable to survey colon completely - **Total colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis (IRA)**: avoid temporary stoma, no risk of sexual dysfunction due to proctectomy, lower morbidity & mortality - **Restorative proctocolectomy with IPAA (RPC)**: eliminate risk of rectal cancer (small risk of cancer in rectal mucosa between pouch and anal canal), pouch failure - Total proctocolectomy + end ileostomy | Prophylactic total colectomy + IRA Prophylactic TAHBSO Aspirin to reduce risk of CRC                                                                                                                                                                                                                            |

Flexible sigmoidoscopy Qly from 10y
(proceed to colonoscopy if polyps found) - still
require endoscopy Q1-2y after colectomy to

(colorectal, endometrium, ovary, etc) +

# Colorectal polyps

## Definitions

- Colonic polyps: protuberance into the lumen of normally flat colonic mucosa
- Malignant polyps: polyps that penetrate muscularis mucosae into submucosa

Morphology: **sessile (flat)** / **pedunculated** (with a stalk)

Histological classification

- Non-neoplastic
  - Hyperplastic/metaplastic: MC polyps in adults, usually in rectosigmoid and <5mm
  - Inflammatory pseudopolyps: IBD, solitary rectal ulcer
  - Hamartomatous polyps: juvenile polyps (LB), Peutz-Jegher polyps (SB > LB > stomach)
    - Hamartoma = disorganized overgrowth of tissue indigenous to that particular site
    - Low malignant potential per se, but malignant risk due to associated adenoma in LB
    - PJP: "Christmas tree" appearance, a/w mucosal pigmentation of buccal mucosa & lips
- Neoplastic
  - Adenoma: pre-malignant, <5% progress to CA in 7-10 years
    - Malignant potential - **villous** (secrete K-rich mucus) > tubulovillous > tubular (MC)
    - Advanced adenoma defined as any one of: **high-grade dysplasia, size > 1cm, villous**

[Image Description: This is a flow chart describing the categorization of polyps. On the top layer there are two options: Non-Neoplastic and Neoplastic. Under the Non-Neoplastic category are 4 options: Hamartomatous polyps, Juvenile polyps, Peutz-Jeghers polyps, Hyperplastic polyps, and Inflammatory (pseudo)polyps. Under the Neoplastic category there are 3 options: Adenoma (with the subcategories: Tubular, Tubulovillous, Villous), Serrated Polyps (with the subcategories: Sessile serrated adenoma, Traditional serrated adenoma), and Carcinoma. There is also a rectangle around text saying "Increased risk of CA colon: all neoplastic + hamartomatous polyps"]

- Endoscopic features of malignancy: friability, induration, ulceration, firm consistency
- Sessile serrated polyps (SSP) / Traditional serrated polyps
- Associated with serrated polyposis syndrome

Other classifications: Haggitt, Sano, JNET

- Paris classification of early GI cancer:
  - 0-1 (polypoid): 0-Ip (pedunculated) vs 0-Is (sessile)
  - 0-II (nonpolypoid): 0-IIa (flat and elevated), 0-IIb (flat), 0-IIc (superficially depressed)
  - 0-III (excavated)

Management of colonic polyps

- Investigations: colonoscopy
- En-bloc polypectomy with adequate resection margin by electrocautery snare
- Send polyps for pathology: Require evaluation for radical resection if invasive CA with
  - Poorly differentiated histology
  - Lymphovascular invasion
  - Margin <2mm
  - T2+ lesions

CRC screening in Hong Kong:

- Eligibility: HK residents aged 50-75 who are asymptomatic with no increased risk for CRC
  - Advise direct colonoscopy if increased risk: symptomatic, Hx of CRC / CR polyps, hereditary CRC syndrome (FAP, Lynch), strong FHx (2 or moe FDR with CRC), Hx of IBD
  - Not necessary to enrol: previous normal colonoscopy within past 10 years, previous normal FS within past 5 years, previous normal FOBT within past 2 years
- Protocol: 2-tier system

1. FIT Q2y starting from 50y
2. If FIT positive, colonoscopy Q10y or flexible sigmoidoscopy Q5y

# Colorectal cancer

## Definition

- Rectum
  - Endoscopic definition: up to 15cm from anal verge
  - Oncological definition: bowel below peritoneal reflection
- Right-sided tumour: tumour before splenic flexure
- Left-sided tumour: tumour after splenic flexure

## Risk factors

- Non-modifiable: age > 50, gender (male)
- Central obesity, sedentary lifestyle, diet (increased fat & red meat, reduced fibre), smoking
- GI: IBD (UC > CD), polyps
- Endocrine: DM, acromegaly (IGF-1 as growth factors for colonic mucosal cells)
- Family history: 25% have FHx; 10% have familial syndrome (FAP, Lynch syndrome)
- Protected factors: prolonged aspirin/ NSAID use

## Pathology

- Chromosomal instability (CIN) pathway (85%): higher risk in large (>2.5cm), villous, sessile adenomatous polyps
- Microsatellite instability (MSI) pathway (15%):
- Location of tumours: rectum > sigmoid

## Clinical features

- Most commonly asymptomatic → detected by screening
- Different presentations between right-sided and left-sided lesions
  | Right-sided (Proximal): present later | Left-sided (Distal): present earlier |
  | ------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------- |
  | Tend to bleed (larger calibre, polypoid lesion) | Tend to obstruct (smaller calibre, annular lesion) |
  | **Iron deficiency anemia**, dull vague abdominal pain, right-sided abdominal mass | **Change in bowel habits** (tenesmus, reduced stool calibre, mucoid stool) |
  | Not common to have change in bowel habits (stool is more liquid and colon more space on right side) | Hematochezia, intestinal obstruction |
- Metastasis:
  - Direct spread: radial (implicated in resectability in rectal cancer)
  - Lymphatic spread: Virchow's node (Troisier's sign)
  - Haematogenous spread: liver (MC), lung (distal rectal tumour → IVC → lung)
  - Transcoelomic spread: ovary (Krukenberg tumour), pouch of Douglas

## Investigations

- Bloods: CBC D/C (anemia), Fe profile, LFT (liver met), RFT
- Serum carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA): epithelial marker
  - Cut-off: <4.7
  - Low diagnostic ability: low sensitivity + low specificity for CRC
    - Elevated in ~50% of CRC only: may be first-pass metabolized by liver
    - False positive: pregnancy, smoking, TB, IBD, other carcinomas (e.g. GI tract, pancreas, breast)
    - Post-op: take 4-6 weeks to return to normal
    - Roles: prognostication, treatment monitoring and detection of recurrence (even if pre-op normal: can pick up non-portovenous distant metastases e.g. lung)
- Diagnostic: **colonoscopy with biopsy (gold standard)**
  - Confirm diagnosis with histological evidence
  - Exclude synchronous cancers (3-5%) and synchronous polyps (30-50%)
  - Pre-op localization (esp. if tumor is very small): tattooing (inject ink to stain tumor)
- CT colonoscopy: when caecum cannot be reached by CLN
  - Pros: similar diagnostic accuracy for tumors >1cm, extraluminal info, lower risk of perforation
  - Cons: high radiation dose, not therapeutic (still need CLN to take biopsy)
- Double-contrast barium enema (DCBE): barium + air
  - Superseded by CT colonography: risk of barium peritonitis
  - Classical findings: "apple core" lesion - near-circumferential involvement of bowel walls
- Biomarker: for metastatic disease only
  - KRAS & NRAS (signalling downstream of EGFR): mutated in 45% → no response to anti-EGFR
  - MMR: MMR-deficient/ MSI (microsatellite instability) → PD-1 pathway inhibitors

Staging:

- Objectives
  - Determine resectability
  - Select patients for neoadjuvant therapy / local excision
  - Most important prognostic factor
- Colon cancer:
  - **CT thorax + abdomen + pelvis with contrast:** Most sensitive for T-staging, can also give N and M staging
  - Alternative: PET-CT with contrast: better for detecting distant metastasis, also used for follow-up (localizing site of recurrence if ↑CEA)
  - Other adjuncts: Bone scan, CXR and liver USG, liver MRI with contrast
- Rectal cancer:
  - **MRI pelvis:** important for accurate T-staging for planning of neoadjuvant chemoRT
    - Assess extra-mucosal tumor invasion (EMTI): MRI is superior to CT in delineating mesorectal fat
    - Determine circumferential resection margin (CRM)
  - Alternative: Endorectal ultrasound (EUS): only good for T staging, but operator-dependent and might not admit endoscope for obstructive tumors
- TNM staging:
  - I: T1/2 N0
  - II: T3/4 N0
  - III: N1/N2
  - IV: M1
- Modified Duke's criteria (obsolete):
  - A: touch muscularis propria
  - B: breach muscularis propria
  - C: invade LN
  - D: distant metastasis

[Image of a table with the title Primary tumour (T), showing TX, T0, Tis, T1, T2, T3, T4 and their respective descriptions. The table also contains Regional lymph node (N) section with NX, N0, N1, N2 and their descriptions, and Distant metastasis (M) section with M0, M1 and their descriptions]

Management overview

- Stage I: surgery + analysis of ≥12 LN
- Stage II: surgery +/- adjuvant chemo (consider in high-risk stage II)
- Stage III: surgery + adjuvant chemo (FOLFOX) +/- adjuvant RT (rectal only) +/- neoadjuvant chemoRT (in high risk rectal only\*)
- Stage IV: chemo +/- surgery for isolated liver metastasis

[Image of a table with the title Staging System, showing Stage, T, N, M and Stage 0, Stage I, Stage II, Stage III, Stage IV with their respective descriptions]

Management of colon cancer
Surgery

- Surgical principles (**important!**): En-bloc resection of primary tumor and locoregional nodes (75% cure rate)
  - Adequate resection margins: at least 5cm proximally + distally, actual margin depends on blood supply
  - Resect major vascular pedicles and lymphatic drainage basin
    - Excise colonic mesentery, ligate arterial supply at its origin, and excise all accompanying LN
    - At least 12 nodes for proper N staging: inadequate LN might require adjuvant chemo
  - Restore bowel continuity whenever possible
- Elective surgery: laparoscopic / robotic^ approach is preferred
  - Stoma: Temporary diverting colostomy is preferred for left-sided anastomosis

| Tumour site                                        | Surgical procedures                     | Vessels involved & remarks                                             |
| -------------------------------------------------- | --------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Caecum Ascending colon                             | Right hemicolectomy                     | Ileocolic, right colic, R branch of middle colic (SMA)                 |
| Hepatic flexure Transverse colon Splenic flexure\* | Extended right hemicolectomy            | Ileocolic, right colic, middle colic (SMA) Marginal artery of Drummond |
| Splenic flexure\* Descending colon                 | Left hemicolectomy                      | Left colic a. (IMA)                                                    |
| Sigmoid colon                                      | Sigmoidectomy (high anterior resection) | IMA & left colic a.                                                    |

[Image of Colorectal Major Resections, showing a diagram of the colon with labels A through H indicating different resection locations.
A-B: Right Hemicolectomy
A-C: Extended Right Hemicolectomy
B-C: Transverse Colectomy
C-E: Left Hemicolectomy
D-E: Sigmoid Colectomy
D-H: Anterior Resection
G-H: (Ultra) Low Anterior Resection
D-G: Abdominoperineal Resection
A-H: Subtotal Colectomy]

\*For splenic flexure tumors, peritumoral subserosal ICG injection can be done to demonstrate the lymphatic drainage
of tumor.
^Benefits of robotic surgery: high-quality 3D vision, restoration of eye-hand-target axis

- Emergency surgery: indicated if complicated (obstruction, perforation, haemorrhage)
  - Right-sided lesion: right hemicolectomy with primary anastomosis +/- bowel decompression if stable, temporary ostomy if unstable
  - Left-sided lesion: Hartmann's operation

Other therapies

- Adjuvant chemotherapy: aim to eradicate micro-metastasis and reduce risk of recurrence
  - Options
    - FOLFOX for 6 months: folinic acid + 5-fluorouracil + oxaliplatin
    - Xelox for 3 months if lower risk (T1-3, N1):
  - Indications: Stage 3 (N1+), high risk stage 2 (T4 tumor, lymphovascular invasion, poor histology)
- No role for neoadjuvant therapy
- Refer to MED notes for non-surgical treatment (e.g. upfront chemotherapy)

Management of rectal cancer

- Differences from CA colon:
  - Narrow bony pelvis + presence of sphincter: wide excision is difficult → require neoadjuvant therapy
  - Transanal approach available
  - Proximity to urogenital structures: potential urogenital dysfunction (e.g. urinary/fecal incontinence, sexual dysfunction)

# Curative surgery

- Surgical principles (**important!**): Similar to CA colon, but additionally
  - Organ-preserving (e.g. TEMS)
  - Sphincter-sparing (e.g. AR and LAR): made more possible by stapled anastomosis and chemoradiotherapy downstaging of tumour
  - Adequate resection margins:
    - **5cm proximally + 2cm distally** (1cm for distal rectum if really wish to preserve sphincter)
    - **Circumferential resection margin (CRM)** at least **1mm →** concept of TME\*
  - Vascular ligation and LN dissection: at least 12 nodes
- Option 1: Local excision
  - Indication: T1N0 disease with low-risk features (e.g. <3cm, favourable histology), T2N0/T3N0 if unfit
  - Approaches:
    - Transanal endoscopic microsurgery (TEM): rigid platform, more costly and time-consuming
    - Transanal minimally-invasive surgery (TAMIS): lap., easier to learn, less stable pneumorectum
  - Follow-up:
    - Favourable prognostic factors (e.g. well differentiated, no lymphovascular or perineural invasion, negative margin): regular endoscopic surveillance
    - Adverse prognostic factors or ≥pT2 disease: proceed to radical resection / chemoRT (if unfit)
- Option 2: sphincter-preserving surgeries
  - Indicated if: T2-4 + adequate pre-op sphincter function + adequate distal margins

| Anastomosis         | Anterior resection (AR) + TME          | Low anterior resection (LAR) + TME                                   |
| ------------------- | -------------------------------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------- |
|                     | Above peritoneal reflection            | Below peritoneal reflection ("Ultra-low": Just above anal sphincter) |
| Tumor site          | Rectosigmoid junction Upper 1/3 rectum | Mid 1/3 rectum Low 1/3 rectum with adequate distal margin            |
| TME                 | Only partial: 5cm below cancer         | Total: until anorectal junction                                      |
| Distal margin       | 5cm                                    | 2cm (or 1cm if below distal mesorectal margin)\*                     |
| Defunctioning stoma | Not required                           | **Required:** loop ileostomy / colostomy                             |

# For lesions <1cm from anorectal ring, intersphincteric resection (ISR) may extend the distal margin by removing part/all of IAS (provided that intersphincter groove is not invaded by tumor).

- Ligation of IMA: high tie vs low tie
  - High tie (ligate at origin): allow extra length to facilitate **tension-free anastomosis**, better LN clearance at IMA origin
  - Low tie (ligate below left colic a): prevent left colon ischemia (sole supply from marginal a.)
- Anastomosis by double stapling: Create larger neorectal reservoir
  - Colonic J-pouch / side-to-end / transverse coloplasty (highest leakage rate)
- Defunctioning stoma: protect the anastomosis (↓complication rate) but does not ↓leakage rate - Indications: - Low anastomosis (<5cm) - Intra-op leak tests +ve - Pre-op chemoRT
  [Image of a diagram showing the anatomy of the rectum with labeled sections including the rectosigmoid, upper third, middle third, lower third, anal canal, pelvic floor, and annotations of anastomosis locations above and below the peritoneal reflection. The distances from the rectosigmoid are marked at 15cm, 11cm, and 7cm.]

|     | Intra-operative leak tests                                                                                               |
| --- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
|     | Air leak test (laparoscopically infuse water into peritoneum while insufflating air in the bowel → positive if bubbling) |
|     | Blood supply: see if the resected bowel is pink in colour, especially check for marginal artery of Drummond              |
|     | Injection of ICG into vein and view under ICG camera (for blood supply)                                                  |
|     | On table colonoscopy (check if intact, any bleeding, and check perfusion)                                                |

[Image of a diagram showing Colonic J-pouch reservoir procedure with annotations.]

[Image of a diagram showing Side-to-end anastomosis procedure with annotations.]

[Image of a diagram showing Transverse coloplasty reservoir procedure with annotations.]

Total mesorectal resection (TME): precise dissection of
mesorectal envelope (containing tumor, surrounding
mesorectal fat, LN and vessels), preserving pelvic
autonomic nerves

- Plane: "holy plane" - avascular alveolar plane
  between presacral and mesorectal fascia
- Benefits:↓ local recurrence rate and ↓ post-
  operative genitourinary dysfunction
- Approaches: transabdominal (open / lap /
  robotic), transanal (rarely)

Option 3: **Abdominal perineal resection (APR)**

- Indicated if ANY one of: poor pre-op sphincter function / **failure to achieve negative distal margin** /
  locally advanced or recurrent low-lying CA rectum
- Steps:
  - Insert catheter to protect membranous urethra in males
  - Abdominal part (open/lap) similar to AR
  - Perineal dissection via circumanal incision for en-bloc resection of sigmoid, rectum and anus
  - Construction of **permanent end colostomy**

Other therapies

- **Neoadjuvant therapy for CA rectum** [German Rectal Cancer Study Group] - 3 main indications (**need to know!**) - Resectable but locally advanced disease: sterilize tumour bed, ↓ intra-op tumor spillage & ↓ local
  recurrence rate - T3/T4 disease → _only definite indication proven by RCT_ - Nodal disease - Threatened CRM (<2mm) - Borderline resectable disease: downstage the tumor and ↑ resectability rate - Low-lying tumor: downsize the tumor and ↑ sphincter preservation rate - Options

| Regimen       | Long course chemoRT (HK)                                                                                                                                    | Short course high-dose RT                                                                                      |
| ------------- | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
|               | 5-FU based chemotherapy x 2 cycles + concurrent RT (50.4 Gy = 1.8 Gy daily x 28 fractions) → Wait 8-10 weeks before surgery → 4 cycles of chemo as adjuvant | RT 25 Gy = 5 Gy x 5 days → Wait 7-10 days before surgery                                                       |
| Disadvantages | Max dose of RT for lifetime Delay surgery                                                                                                                   | More S/E of high dose RT Can only sterilize local tumor bed, but not enough time to downstage / downsize tumor |

- Remission after neoadjuvant chemoRT - Clinical complete remission (CCR) ~20%: consider “watch and wait” for 3 years with MRI Q3m,
  flexible sigmoidoscopy Q3m, PET-CT / CT Q6m - Pathological complete remission (PCR) ~15%: surgical specimen found to be tumor-free, may not
  require adjuvant chemo (case-by-case)
- Adjuvant chemotherapy: First-line is 5-FU based, other options include oxaliplatin, irinotecan, cetuximab
- Adjuvant radiotherapy: not common

**Palliative management for colorectal cancer**

- Palliative surgery
  - **Endoluminal stenting:** for palliating obstruction / bridging therapy before elective surgery (avoid EOT)
    - **Not** for distal rectal tumour (can cause tenesmus and pain)
  - Palliative colostomy +/- tumor resection (palliative intent)
- Palliative radiotherapy: control local symptoms (e.g. pain, discharge, bleeding, incontinence) and bone pain
- Palliative chemotherapy for disseminated disease: oral capecitabine
  [Image of Male Pelvis in a Side View and Front View. The side view depicts the male reproductive organs including the urinary bladder, rectum, prostate gland, and the path of the urethra. A schematic line indicating the "holy plane" of dissection for total mesorectal excision is shown cutting through the mesorectal fat. The front view provides an abdominal cross section with a tumor location highlighted within the rectum and indicates the circumferential resection margin.]

Post-operative complications

Immediate
Massive bleeding requiring conversion to laparotomy (<10%)
Injury to neighbouring structures:

- **Left ureter and gonadal vessels**
- Iliac artery
- GB, D2 (right hemi)
- Seminal vesicles (LAR)
- Spleen (splenic flexure mobilization in TME)
- **Autonomic nerve injury** (esp. in rectal surgery)*: sympathetic (incontinence, impaired
  ejaculation) vs parasympathetic (urinary retention, erectile dysfunction)
  *High tie vs low tie
- High tie if reducing tension is desired
- Low tie (distal to left colic) avoids damage of **hypogastric nerve**, and thus lower risk of
  autonomic dysfunction

Early Post-op ileus, infection, **anastomotic leak**

Late
Anastomotic stricture: might require finger / endoscopic balloon dilation
**Fistula**: enterocutaneous (conservative Mx), rectovaginal / rectourinary (proximal fecal diversion)
Perineal hernia (APR)
**LAR syndrome**:

- S/S: change in bowel movement (ranging from constipation to faecal urgency, faecal
  incontinence) that persists ≥ 1 month after surgery
- Patho: colonic dysmotility, neorectal reservoir dysfunction and anal sphincter dysfunction
- Prevention: post-op **pelvic floor muscle exercise**, anterograde colonic irrigation via stoma /
  enema, fecal diversion
- Management: antidiarrheal, transanal irrigation, pelvic floor rehab, sacral nerve stimulation

Stoma See separate sections
complications

Follow-up for colorectal cancer

- Aim: detect **recurrence** (40%) and **metachronous tumors** (_new primary CA diagnosed 6mo afterwards_)
- Follow-up interval:
  - First 2 years: Q3m
  - 3rd year: Q6m
  - 4-5th year: yearly
  - > 5 years: considered to be in remission
- Investigations in each follow-up:
  - CEA, rigid sigmoidoscopy, LFT
  - СТ ТАР/ PET-CT Q1y
  - Colonoscopy:
    - Pre-op not full scope: within 6m of surgery (risk of synchronous tumour in CA rectum = 3-5%)
    - Pre-op full scope: 1 year post-op, then at 3 years, 5 years, then Q5y

Management principles of metastases

- Liver / Lung metastases: **resect** if possible (solitary metastasis, no other mets, controlled primary tumor) - Refer to **HBP** for management of colorectal liver mets

  4.8 Diseases of anal canal & anus
  History taking

- Chief complaints:
  - Bleeding
  - Pain (fissure in ano: pain on defecation)
    - Proctalgia fugax: severe spasm of anal pain that last only a few min, often at night; Mx amitriptyline
  - Itchy
    - Pruritus ani: avoid scratching, clean with clear water, dry area
  - Swelling: where, frequency, size change, hard/soft
  - Tenesmus
  - Discharge
- Colour of PRB - rough guide
  - Fresh PRB: distal to splenic flexure
  - Dark PRB: proximal to splenic flexure

PR exam

- Inspection; scar, sinus, lesions (fissures, thrombosed haemorrhoids, condyloma)
- Palpation: pain, induration, lesion, tone (ask to squeeze the finger), prostate/ rectovaginal septum

Haemorrhoids (piles)
Definitions

- Haemorrhoids: abnormal **engorgement and prolapse of the anal vascular cushions**
- Anal vascular cushions - clusters of vascular tissue, smooth muscle and connective tissue
  - Components: branches of superior rectal artery, superior rectal veins, covered by a mucosal layer
  - Function: assist the anal sphincter in maintaining continence
  - Found in 3, 7, 11 o'clock positions (when looked at with the patient in the lithotomy position)
    Pathophysiology
- Degeneration of supporting fibroelastic tissues and smooth muscles → anal cushions displaced caudally → dilation & engorgement of AV plexuses → prolapse
- May acutely **thrombose**: painful large, swollen, irreducible mass with marked anal sphincter contraction
  Risk factors
- Aging
- Sitting on toilet for long period of time
- Intra-abdominal pressure: constipation, chronic cough, ascites, pregnancy
- Genetic predisposition

Types

|                   | External                                                     | Internal                                                                           |
| :---------------- | :----------------------------------------------------------- | :--------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Origin            | Ectoderm (squamous epithelium i.e. skin)                     | Endoderm (columnar epithelium of anal mucosa)                                      |
| Location          | Below dentate line                                           | Above dentate line                                                                 |
| Innervation       | Somatic innervation (inf. rectal n. ← pudendal n.)           | Autonomic nervous system (inf. hypogastric plexus)                                 |
| Clinical features | Pain after defecation → severe perianal pain (if thrombosed) | Painless bright red PRB (outlet-type)Prolapse, anal itching                        |
| Venous drainage   | Perianal swelling / skin tagsInferior rectal vein → IVC      | Acute pain if incarcerated/strangulatedSuperior rectal vein → portal venous system |

Mixed type: both internal & external, usually found in pregnancy; treated as external

Examination

- **Digital rectal examination:** inspect for prolapsed piles, associated skin tags, perianal excoriation; assess anal tone (IAS) and squeeze pressure (EAS)
- **Proctoscopy** +/- rigid sigmoidoscopy: 1st/2nd degree piles may not be palpable
- **Flexible sigmoidoscopy** +/- colonoscopy if risk of malignancy:
  - PRB in age > 45y
  - Change in bowel habit/ tenesmus
  - FHx of CRC

[Image of Rigid sigmoidoscopy]

[Image of Proctoscopy]

Goligher grading for **internal haemorrhoids** (need to know!)
| Description | Management |
| ----------- | ----------- |
| I Palpable, non-prolapsing and bleeding | Lifestyle, medical |
| II Prolapse with straining and defaecation, **spontaneous reduction** | Lifestyle, medical, RBL |
| III Prolapse requiring manual reduction | Lifestyle, medical, RBL + surgery |
| IV Chronic prolapse that is _irreducible_ +/- strangulated | Surgery |

109
Management

- Lifestyle modification:
  - Diet: avoid spicy food, high-fibre diet, increase fluid intake (to reduce straining)
  - Toileting habit: avoid prolonged sitting, avoid prolonged straining
  - Exercise, weight loss
- Medical: stool softeners, bulking agents (e.g. metamucil), topical antiseptic (KMnO4 sitz bath), topical haemostatic (e.g. Faktu), topical astringent (e.g. Anusol), topical analgesics

- Invasive therapy:
  | | | |
  | ----------- | ----------- | ----------- |
  | Office-based procedures | **Rubber band ligation (RBL)**[Illustration of rubber band ligation procedure] | Apply rubber bands to strangulate the pile by Baroon's bander → **Ischaemic necrosis** of piles → slough off within 10 days Efficacy: 70% resolve, 30% recur Administration: up to 3 bandings at ≥**1cm above dentate line** Indication: symptomatic Grade II/III internal hemorrhoid Complications: **pain, bleeding** (7-10d post-banding due to sloughing of ligated haemorrhoids; C/I anticoagulant use, immunocompromised), post-banding sepsis |
  | Sclerotherapy ("Mitchell") | | Administration: 5% phenol in almond oil submucosally Aim to create fibrosis → obliterate vascular channels and fix position **Largely abandoned now:** risk of allergy to nuts & intraprostatic injection |
  | Excision | Haemorrhoidectomy [Illustration of circular stapler for hemorrhoidectomy]Internal hemorrhoids Circular stapler Hemorrhoids inside Stapler [Illustration of PPH-03 Kit with surgical tools] | Indications: - Grade III/ IV internal haemorrhoids - Symptomatic internal/external haemorrhoids **refractory** to other treatments Approach: - Conventional haemorrhoidectomy: for **internal ≥ grade III or external** - 3-leaf clover excision (fig.): avoid circumferential excision - prone to stenosis - Closed (**Ferguson**): close wound by continuous suture; more commonly used - Open (**Milligan-Morgan**): open wound and heal by 2° intention; preferred for acute gangrenous haemorrhoids (prevent further tissue oedema & necrosis) - Stapled haemorrhoidectomy / haemorrhoidopexy: for **internal only**, less favoured now due to poorer long-term outcomes, less painful but higher recurrence rate Efficacy: 95% resolve Pre-op preparation: stool softener, enema Position: prone jackknife / lithotomy Anaesthesia: _perianal_ / SA / GA Complications: - **Pain** (~100% due to IAS spasm) - **Urinary retention** |

110

- Causes: Pain and anal spasm, fluid overload, rectal packing, drugs (narcotics, anticholinergics), pre-existing outflow tract obstruction
- Mx: Leave urinary catheter in situ for 24h
- Injury: **faecal incontinence**, anal fissure, anal stenosis

Haemorrhoidal artery ligation operation (HALO)
May be Doppler-guided (DG-HALO) to identify feeding vessels
Mainly for bleeding symptoms, indicated for **Grade II/III haemorrhoids**
Lowest post-op complications, but highest recurrence rate

Acute painful anal mass
Differential diagnosis

- Thrombosed prolapsed internal haemorrhoids
- Thrombosed external haemorrhoids (a.k.a. perianal haematoma; present as painful bluish mass, form skin tag after 48h)
- Incarcerated rectal prolapse (with circular folds, fig.)

[External thrombosed haemorrhoids. A view of a thrombosed external hemorrhoid]

[Spontaneous resolution of external thrombosed haemorrhoid changing into skin tag. A view of a spontaneous resolution of external thrombosed haemorrhoid changing into skin tag]

Management

- Symptomatic Grade IV internal haemorrhoids: **hyperosmolar solution** (gauze with lignocaine + cold water + dextrose) / **warm water sitz bath** to reduce size of haemorrhoids before surgery
- Thrombosed (external) haemorrhoids:
  - Early (<72h) + painful: **urgent haemorrhoidectomy**
  - Late (>72h) or small thrombosis: conservative (analgesia, ice pack, stool softeners, topical nifedipine to induce IIAS relaxation)
- Incarcerated rectal prolapse: sugar application + manual reduction + surgery
  - Altemier's operation (perineal rectosigmoidectomy)
  - DeLorme procedure: plication (folding) of sutures

[Rectal prolapse (A & B) vs prolapsed haemorrhoid (C). A view of Rectal prolapse and prolapsed haemorrhoid]

Anal fissure
Definitions: tear in mucosal lining **below** dentate line
Pathogenesis

- Local trauma (constipation, vaginal delivery) → pain → **IAS spasm** → impaired healing → vicious cycle
- Most at 6H (**posterior midline**): least perfused
- 10% at 12H: after vaginal delivery
- Always suspect **perianal Crohn's disease** if: non-midline, recurring, multiple, unusually deep or wide, perianal hypertrophic skin tags
- Others: HIV, TB, STD

[An image of an anal fissure.]

Clinical features

- Pain on defaecation (vicious cycle: avoid defaecation → constipation → further trauma)
- Fresh PRB +/- mucus
- Chronic fissure: triad of fissure + **sentinel piles** (failed healing → skin tags) + **hypertrophied anal papillae**
  Investigations
- EUA (DRE too painful to perform - AVOID Lord's four fingers stretch)
- Proctoscopy

Management
Conservative

- Risk factor modification: increase fibre/ fluid intake, stool softener
  / laxatives, Sitz bath
- Topical analgesics (e.g. 5% lignocaine)
- Topical vasodilators: reduce IAS spasm and increase local blood
  flow, but risk of incontinence
  - Topical GTN (S/E: headache)
  - Topical nifedipine
- Second-line medical therapy:
  - Botulinum toxin 50IU
  - Topical 0.5% diltiazem

Surgical management

- Indications: if fail conservative management for 8 weeks
- Endoscopy to rule out Crohn's disease first
- Low risk of incontinence: lateral internal sphincterotomy
  (to divide IAS), Cx: faecal incontinence
- High risk of incontinence (e.g. multiparous women, older patients): fissurectomy + V-Y advancement flap -
  sphincter-sparing

The surrounding anatomical structures are also clearly labeled. Below this detailed view, there are three images labeled A, B and C, each showing a different stage of the sphincterotomy procedure on the anal region. Image A shows a chronic fissure with an incision line marked. Image B shows the incision being made to cut the fissure. Image C shows the result after the incision with dashed lines.]

# Anal fistula (fistula-in-ano)

Definitions

- Sinus: blind-ending tract joining an epithelial surface to a cavity lined by granulation tissue, e.g. an abscess
- Fistula: abnormal connection between 2 epithelial surfaces
- Anal fistula: abnormal communications (hollow tracts lined with granulation tissue) with internal opening in anal canal & external opening in perianal skin

Risk factors

- **Cryptoglandular hypothesis (90%)**: obstruction of anal gland ducts (connected to crypts of Morgani) → infection and formation of abscess → discharge along path of lowest resistance
- Other causes: malignancy, Crohn's disease, TB, actinomycosis, LGV

Clinical features

- Intermittent perianal discharge + pain (until pus discharges)
- Palpable cord-like tract
- Passage of flatus/feces through external opening (suggest internal opening is at rectum)
- Suspect anal fistula if anorectal abscess persists after 6-12 weeks

Classifications

- Parks classification (fig.): relations to external sphincter
  - Not included: superficial fistula (does not involve sphincter)

|     | Types                   | Description                                                        |
| --- | ----------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------ |
| 1   | Inter-sphincteric (45%) | Begin in dentate line, and travel in the plane between IAS and EAS |
| 2   | Trans-sphincteric (30%) | Track through EAS into ischiorectal fossa                          |
| 3   | Supra-sphincteric (20%) | Encompass entire sphincter apparatus                               |
| 4   | Extra-sphincteric (5%)  | Primary opening in rectum                                          |

[A diagram of an axial view of the rectum with the surrounding anatomy. The diagram shows the levator ani muscle and the puborectalis muscle superiorly. Inferiorly are shown the internal anal sphincter, the external anal sphincter and the superficial fascia. Three types of fistulas are drawn with arrows showing their path: Intersphincteric fistula, trans-sphincteric fistula, and extrasphincteric fistula.]

- Simple vs complex: determine choice of OT
  - Simple: superficial, inter-sphincteric (Type 1), low trans-sphincteric (Type 2) involving <30% EAS
  - Complex: high trans-sphincteric (Type 2) involving ≥30% EAS, supra-sphincteric (Type 3), extra-sphincteric (Type 4), horseshoe fistulas, multiple tracts, women with anterior fistulas / rectovaginal fistulas, fistula a/w Crohn's disease / radiation / malignancy
- High vs low: above vs below anal sphincter complex

Identify internal opening by **Goodsall's rule** (higher reliability if external opening **within 3cm** of anal verge)

- Transversal anal line: draw through ischial spines
- Fistula anterior to transverse anal line: open to anus in a straight line
- Fistula posterior to transverse anal line: curved track, opening in the midline posteriorly

[A line drawing of a dog demonstrating Goodsall's rule for anterior and posterior fistulas. The dog's front is labeled "Anterior" and its tail is labeled "Posterior".]

[A diagram of a patient in the prone position with their buttocks spread apart. A transverse line is drawn across the anus. There are two fistulas illustrated anterior to the transverse line, and two fistulas illustrated posterior to the transverse line. The anterior side of the anus is labeled as "Anterior", and the posterior side is labeled as "Posterior".]

Assessment: determine sites of internal and external openings, course of primary track, any secondary extensions

- Anorectal examination: pustule-like lesion, perianal skin excoriation, external opening (do **NOT** probe!)
- +/- proctoscopy / sigmoidoscopy for internal opening
- Imaging: endoanal USG / MRI pelvis +/- instil H2O2 via external opening
- **Examination under anesthesia (EUA)**: required before surgery to trace the fistula tract
- Colonoscopy if suspect Crohn's disease

# 113

Definitive treatment

- Primary fistulotomy:
  - Indications: simple fistula with low risk of incontinence
  - Approach: fistula probe to define tract → divide all overlying structures → laid open to heal by secondary intention +/- marsupialization to speed up healing
  - Complications: sphincter injury
- Loose (draining/non-cutting) Seton for 6 weeks + secondary sphincter-sparing procedure
  - Indications: high risk of incontinence / complex fistula
  - Loose Seton is usually inserted at EUA (material: silastic vessel loop)
  - Establish drainage and eradicate septic focus
  - Preserve sphincter mechanism
  - Various approaches of secondary sphincter-sparing procedure:
    - Fistulotomy by cutting Seton: elastic and tightened regularly → slowly cut through the tract to cause scarring
    - Advancement flap: close internal opening by mucosal flap → allow fistula tract to heal and close
    - Ligation of intersphincteric fistula tract (LIFT)
    - Fibrin sealant / fistula plug
    - Modified Hanley procedure: horseshoe fistulas
- Crohn's disease: medical → surgical only if failed
  - Lay open if simple fistula, Seton drain if complex

[Image Description: A flowchart titled "Choose a sphincter-sparing procedure based on fistula anatomy and surgeon preference" It begins with "High transsphincteric fistula (Parks type 2)" flowing down to a question: "Is internal opening distal to the dentate line or does the patient have preexisting incontinence?" If "Yes," it flows down to "LIFT" on one path and "Advancement flap or LIFT" on the other. If "No," it flows down to "Advancement flap." Separately, "Suprasphincteric fistula (Parks type 3)" flows down to "Advancement flap," while "Extrasphincteric fistula (Parks type 4)" flows down to "Diversion or proctectomy." Finally, "Horseshoe fistula" flows down to "Modified Hanley procedure or advancement flap."]

114

# Anorectal abscess

Definitions: collection of pus in anal/ rectal region
Classified by anatomical location (fig.)
Pathophysiology

- Cryptoglandular theory: anal gland infection
- Parks theory: pus travels along the path of least resistance
- Other causes unrelated to anal glands: post-haemorrhoidal sclerotherapy, trauma, Crohn's disease, malignancy
  Clinical diagnosis
- Intermittent / Constant perianal pain, exacerbated when sitting down
- Erythematous fluctuant tender mass felt on palpation / DRE
  Management
- Antibiotics: if surrounding cellulitis or immunocompromised (e.g. DM)
- Incision & drainage under GA: heal by secondary intention
  - Perianal abscess: skin incision
  - Ischiorectal abscess (or its supralevator extension): buttock skin incision → drain as close to sphincter complex as possible to minimize length of potential fistula tract
  - Intersphincter abscess (or its supralevator extension): rectal incision (internal sphincterotomy) → drain **transanally** to avoid creating extrasphincteric fistula
- Pus for C/ST
  - Culture shows skin flora: no fistula → reassurance
  - Culture shows gut flora: likely with fistula → treat as fistula after acute state

[Image of diagram illustrating the spread of infection from the anal gland to the anorectal spaces, leading to abscess formation. The diagram is labeled with terms like "Pelvirectal abscess," "High intermuscular abscess," "Ischiorectal abscess," "Intersphincteric abscess," and "Perianal abscess" to indicate different locations of abscesses.]

[Image of two side-by-side diagrams, one labeled "Normal" and the other "Inflammed". Both diagrams show the anatomical structures around the anal canal, but the "Inflammed" diagram highlights the changes that occur in the presence of an anorectal abscess. The diagram is labeled with "Supralevator space", "Supralevator abscess", "Levator muscle", "Column of Morgagni", "Internal sphincter", "Deep external sphincter", "Intersphincteric abscess (origin)", "Ischiorectal abscess", "External sphincter", and "Perianal abscess".]

[Image of a close-up view of a perianal abscess. The abscess is a visible, raised, and inflamed area near the anus, and it appears red and swollen. The word "Abscess" is overlaid on the image with a red arrow pointing towards it.]

# Pilonidal sinus

Definition: formation of sinus in the natal cleft
Pathophysiology

- Infection & obstruction of hair follicle in intergluteal cleft
- Foreign body-type reaction leads to formation of a cavity
  Risk factors
- Caucasian male with coarse dark body hair (rare in HK)
- Prolonged sitting (e.g. lorry drivers)
- Increased sweating
  Clinical features
- Intermittent red, painful mass with discharge in sacrococcygeal region
- Does not continue into anal canal (c.f. anal fistula)
  Management
- Conservative: shave affected region, plucking the sinus free of embedded hair, washout of accessible sinuses, antibiotics
- Surgical:
  - Acute: I&D
  - Chronic: removal of sinus tract + heal by secondary intention

[Image of a diagram illustrating a pilonidal sinus tract and a pilonidal cavity with hair.]

Proctalgia fugax

- Benign, occur in young anxious men
- Brief attacks of rectal pain at night, unrelated to defaecation
- Mx: reassurance, analgesics, topical GTN

Anal carcinoma
Pathology

- Squamous cell carcinoma - below dentate line (80%)
  - Anal intraepithelial neoplasia (AIN): pre-malignant lesions
- Adenocarcinoma - above dentate line (10%)
- Others: melanoma
  Risk factors
- HPV infection (90%): esp. HPV-16 & 18
- HIV infection
- Smoking
- Immunocompromised
- Crohn's disease
  Clinical features
- Painful PR bleeding
- Pruritus
- Signs: palpable mass and its distance from anal verge, LN (superficial inguinal LN if tumour below dentate line)
  Investigations
- Proctoscopy
- EUA for biopsy
- Pap smear for CIN (HPV)
- Staging: - USG-guided FNA of palpable inguinal LN - MRI pelvis for T staging - CT TAP for distant metastasis
  Management
- Chemoradiation
  - First line for most stages (except for early T1N0 disease)
  - EBRT + dual chemotherapy
- Surgical excision
  - T1N0 disease: wide local excision
  - Failed ChemoRT: APR

5.  1 Anatomy and physiology
    Liver
    2 surfaces:

- Diaphragmatic surface: bare area, subphrenic recesses
- Visceral surface: covered with peritoneum except bed of GB and porta hepatis
  Division
- Anatomical division:
  - Right and left lobe divided by **falciform ligament**
  - Caudate lobe: most difficult to resect (related to IVC), anatomically in R liver, but functionally independent (segment I)
  - Quadrate lobe: anatomically in R liver, but functionally related to L liver (segment IVb)
- Functional / Surgical division (Couinaud): 8 segments, each with own branch of portal vein, hepatic artery, bile duct and hepatic vein
  - Divided by 3 portal fissures (sagittal) and transverse fissure (level of porta hepatis)
  - Major portal fissure / Cantlie's line: along middle hepatic vein and gallbladder fossa

| Right liver: Segment 1, 5-8 | Left liver: Segment 2-4 |
| --------------------------- | ----------------------- |
| Right anterior (5, 8)       | Left medial (4a, 4b)    |
| Right posterior (6, 7)      | Left lateral (2, 3)     |

Peritoneal ligaments

- Falciform ligament and ligamentum teres: remnant of umbilical vein
- Coronary ligament → Right and left triangular ligaments
- Lesser omentum (hepatoduodenal lig. + hepatogastric lig.)

Epiploic foramen (of Winslow): Pringle's maneuver

- Anterior: **hepatoduodenal ligament** (free edge of lesser omentum, containing **portal triad** - portal vein, PHA, CBD)
- Posterior: IVC, right crus of diaphragm
- Superior: caudate lobe of liver
- Inferior: D1 duodenum

Vascular supply

- Dual blood supply: receives 1500mL/min blood
  - 75% portal vein
  - 25% hepatic artery (← common hepatic artery ← celiac trunk)
- Anatomical variants:
  - Common hepatic artery: might be absent (direct trifurcation of celiac trunk into RHA, LHA, GDA)
  - Right hepatic artery (major supply to liver): can arise directly from SMA
  - Left hepatic artery: can arise from left gastric artery
- Venous drainage: hepatic veins (left/ mid/ right) → IVC
  - Caudate lobe (segment I) drains directly into IVC via minor hepatic veins

Lymphatics: converge towards portal hepatis → hepatic nodes → celiac nodes → cisterna chyli

# Gallbladder

Anatomical landmark: Intersection of right costal margin & MCL
Parts: **fundus, body, neck**

- Hartmann's pouch: out-pouching of GB wall at junction of GB neck and cystic duct
- Muscle fibers in the wall arranged in criss-cross manner

## Vascular supply

- **Cystic artery** (← right hepatic artery): most arise **posterior** to CHD and **superior** to cystic duct (15% in front of CHD)

## Important triangles

- Calot's triangle:
  - Boundary: **inferior surface of liver**, cystic duct, CHD
  - Content: right hepatic a. → cystic a., Lund's node (sentinel lymph node of GB → liver)
  - Significance:
    - Locate **cystic artery** during cholecystectomy → Avoid injury to extrahepatic biliary tree and R hepatic artery
    - Identify variants (e.g. caterpillar turn / Moynihan's hump)

[Image: A labeled illustration of the gallbladder, cystic duct, and surrounding structures. The gallbladder is pear-shaped and connected to the cystic duct, which joins the common hepatic duct to form the common bile duct. Labels point to the cystic duct, neck, body, fundus, Hartmann's pouch, right and left hepatic ducts, common hepatic duct, and common bile duct.]

Another definition:
Calot's triangle: cystic artery, cystic duct, CHD
Hepatocystic triangle: inf. surface of liver, cystic duct, CHD

[Image: A diagram of Calot's triangle in the biliary system. The triangle is formed by the cystic duct, the common hepatic duct, and the inferior surface of the liver. The cystic artery runs within this triangle. The Hepatocystic triangle is formed by the inf. surface of the liver, cystic duct, CHD, and includes labels such as superior, lateral, and medial.]

[Image: Three variations of Calot's triangle anatomy. (a) shows the usual anatomy, (b) shows a tortuous common hepatic artery, and (c) shows a tortuous right hepatic artery with a short cystic artery. The captions state that (b) and (c) are examples of so-called "caterpillar turn" or "Moynihan's hump", which if not recognised can lead to inadvertent arterial injury or bleeding during cholecystectomy.]

[Image: A labeled diagram of the biliary tree. The diagram shows the confluence of the left and right hepatic ducts forming the common hepatic duct, which joins the cystic duct from the gallbladder to form the common bile duct. It also shows the pancreatic duct joining the common bile duct at the ampulla of Vater. Labels point to the cystic duct, supraduodenal, retroduodenal, infraduodenal, common hepatic duct, left hepatic duct, common bile duct and others.]

## Biliary tree

- Intrahepatic ducts drain individual liver segments → Left and right hepatic ducts → Common hepatic duct (2.5cm)
  - Duct of Luschka: accessory branch from Segment V of liver joining the R hepatic duct → risk of injury during cholecystectomy causing bile leakage
- Cystic duct: 3cm long, mucosa with spiral folds (valves of Heister)
  - Must be identified passing into neck of GB ("critical view of safety") and ligated just next to GB
- Common bile duct: 7.5cm long, <7mm wide
  - 3 portions: supraduodenal, retroduodenal, infraduodenal
- Hepatopancreatic ampulla (of Vater)
  - Sphincterotomy may be required to access CBD in ERCP

# Pancreas

[Image Description: A highly detailed and colorful anatomical illustration of the pancreas and surrounding organs. The pancreas is depicted in the center, with labels pointing to its various parts such as head, neck, body, tail, and uncinate process. Nearby organs including the stomach, duodenum, spleen, gallbladder, and liver. Arteries and veins such as the hepatic portal vein, splenic artery, superior mesenteric artery, and pancreaticoduodenal arteries are also highlighted. The illustration includes directional arrows to indicate blood flow and labels to identify different anatomical structures.]

## Anatomy

- Retroperitoneal organ behind lesser sac and stomach (posterior surface of pancreas is devoid of peritoneum)
- Parts: head, neck, body, tail, uncinate process
- Pancreatic ducts:
  - Main pancreatic duct (of Wirsung): tail 1mm → body 2mm → head 3mm
  - Accessory pancreatic duct (of Santorini)
- Embryology: uncinate process from ventral bud, rest of pancreas from dorsal bud

## Vascular supply

- Head: ant. & post. superior pancreaticoduodenal artery (←GDA), inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery (SMA)
- Neck, body, tail: branches of splenic a. (e.g. dorsal pancreatic a., transverse pancreatic a.)

## Relationship

- Neck of pancreas is **anterior** to formation of **portal vein** (from SMV and splenic v.) on **transpyloric plane** (L1)
  - CA pancreas might involve these vessels (unresectable!)
- Uncinate process is **posterior** to SMA and SMV
- Splenic a. has tortuous course just **above** body of pancreas

## Physiology

- 98% exocrine pancreas: acinar cells release trypsinogen, lipase, amylase (stimulated by CCK)
- 2% endocrine pancreas: islet of Langerhans

| a cell  | glucagon               |
| ------- | ---------------------- |
| ẞ cell  | insulin                |
| 8 cell  | somatostatin           |
| PP cell | pancreatic polypeptide |

5.2 HBP investigations
USG

- Transabdominal USG: may be compromised by excessive body fat and intraluminal bowel gas
  - Can be contrast-enhanced (CEUS)
  - Assessment of USG abdomen
- Pancreas
- Biliary system: dilatation, stone
  - Distal CBD often obscured by bowel gas
- GB: distended or contracted
- Liver: IHD, abscess
- CBD limit: 0.1cm for every 10 years old
- Cause of dilated CBD
  - Obstruction
  - Aging
  - Post-cholecystectomy

Endoscopic USG (EUS):

- Useful in choledocholithiasis
- Useful in diagnosing & staging pancreatic and periampullary cancers

CT abdomen

- Useful in staging HBP tumours
- Not useful in detecting gallstones (only 75% gallstones identified)

MRI liver

- Liver-specific contrast (Primovist): superior to CT in detecting small HCC vs regenerative nodules

Cholescintigraphy (HIDA scan)

- HIDA is selectively taken up by retroendothelial cells of liver and excreted into bile
- Acute cholecystitis: non-visualised GB
- Chronic cholecystitis: reduced GB

Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)

- **Non-contrast, T2-weighted**
- Non-invasive imaging of biliary system & GB
- Avoid complications associated by ERCP, but NOT therapeutic

Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC)

- Diagnostic: visualisation of biliary tree
- Therapeutic: bile drainage by catheter (PTBD) or insertion of indwelling stents
- Preferred to ERCP in:
  - Stricture/ obstruction at or above the level of confluence of hepatic ducts (fig.)
  - Examples: cholangiocarcinoma, PSC, RPC
- Complications: bacteraemia (thus antibiotic prophylaxis required), haemobilia

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)

- See [Basic principles]

5.3 Obstructive jaundice

Definitions

- Jaundice: yellow pigmentation of skin and eyes as a result of excess bilirubin in the circulation, clinically detectable when bilirubin > 50 mmol/L
- Obstructive jaundice: jaundice resulting from biliary obstruction
- **Painless progressive obstructive jaundice** in elderly is malignant biliary obstruction until proven otherwise

Differential diagnosis of obstructive jaundice

- Intraluminal: gallstone (choledocholithiasis, acute cholangitis), RPC
- Mural: cholangiocarcinoma, PSC
- Extramural: CA head of pancreas, lymphadenopathy, gallstone (Mirizzi's syndrome)

Important questions in history taking

- Differential medical (pre-hepatic/ hepatic) vs surgical (obstructive) causes
  - Medical: normal coloured urine & stool
    - Pre-hepatic (hemolysis, Gilbert's syndrome): Palpitation, dizziness
    - Hepatic (hepatitis, decompensated CLD, drugs): Fever, RUQ pain, n/v
  - Surgical: tea-coloured urine, pale-coloured stool, steatorrhoea (floating, foul-smelling, difficult to rush)
    - Tea-coloured urine: no recent intake of rifampicin/ Pyridium/beetroot
- Differentiate stone vs tumour

|                   | Stone                                                                                             | Tumour                                                                                                 |
| :---------------- | :------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ | :----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Jaundice          | Intermittent (stone may pass out)                                                                 | Progressive For HCC, jaundice only when functional liver reserve drops to 25%                          |
| Pain              | Painful: as stones go through Ampulla of Vater                                                    | Painless (until advanced) Except CA pancreatic head: well innervated, spread to coeliac ganglion early |
| Infection (fever) | More likely: accumulation of bile refluxed from GI tract (normally prevented by ampulla of Vater) | Until late stage, malnourished                                                                         |
| Others            |                                                                                                   | Constitutional Sx: LOW, LOA, night sweats                                                              |

- PMH: gallstone, hepatitis B carrier, IBD (risk factor for PSC)
- SH: smoking, alcohol, IVDA, tattoos

Investigations

Note: DDx of post-operative jaundice

- Pre-hepatic: hemolysis (e.g. transfusion)
- Hepatic: use of halogenated anesthetics, sepsis, intra-op / post-op hypotension
- Post-hepatic: biliary injury

Liver abscess
Pathogens

- Pyogenic liver abscess: _Streptococcus milleri, E. coli,_ Klebsiella pneumoniae (common in >60yo + _DM_),
- Amoebic liver abscess: Entamoeba histolytica
  Etiology
- Ascending biliary infection (20-30%): e.g. RPC, cholecystitis, cholangitis, infected tumors
- Spread from portal vein (20%): intra-abdominal infections e.g. acute appendicitis, diverticulitis, Crohn's
- Others: e.g. penetrating injury, systemic bacteremia
  Clinical features
- **Swinging fever,** chills and rigors, septic-looking
- **Tender hepatomegaly** (jaundice not significant: mainly liver abscess affected)
- **Bloody dysentery** for amoebic liver abscess
  Investigations
- CBC D/C (note no eosinophilia in amoebic liver abscess), LFT, CRP (for monitoring Tx)
- **Blood culture**
- +/- Amoebic serology, stool microscopy
- Blood glucose level (DM is risk factor)
- Imaging:
- CXR: right basal collapse / effusion
- USG: multiloculated cystic mass, no vascularity
- **CT abdomen with contrast:** double-target sign (rim-enhancing with central hypodensity), cluster sign
- Image-guided aspiration for C/ST: anchovy paste-like for amoebic liver abscess
- For Klebsiella liver abscess
- Urgent consult **eye** if symptoms of endophthalmitis
- Monitor for meningitis
- Colonoscopy for underlying neoplasm
  Management
- IV antibiotics: Augmentin / ceftriaxone + metronidazole (for amoebic coverage) for at least **4-6 weeks**
- Klebsiella liver abscess: meningitic dose ceftriaxone (2g Q12h)
- Percutaneous drainage: USG/CT-guided, both diagnostic and therapeutic
- Needle aspiration if <5cm, catheter placement if >5cm
- Usually not needed for amoebic abscess (only antimicrobials are enough)
  Complications
- Rupture (esp if large): e.g. subphrenic abscess
- Pleuropulmonary complications: pleurisy, pleural effusion, empyema
- Local compression: Budd-Chiari syndrome

# Hepatocellular carcinoma

Overview

- MC primary liver cancer (80%) (intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma 15%), 5th MC cancer in HK, 3rd in mortality
- Patterns: solitary / multifocal/diffuse
- Histological subtype: - Non-fibrolamellar: a/w HBV and cirrhosis - Fibrolamellar (FLC): a/w younger patients, not a/w HBV or cirrhosis; good prognosis
  Risk factors
- Any cause of cirrhosis: infection (HBV, HCV), metabolic (ALD, NAFLD, Wilson's disease), immune (PBC, PSC)
  - HBV infection carcinogenic in terms of cirrhosis + DNA damage induced by HBV DNA integration
- Smoking, alcohol (free radical production)
- Obesity, DM (liver involved in glucose metabolism)
- Chemical carcinogens, e.g. aflatoxin
  Clinical features: late presentation + absence of pathognomonic symptoms → difficult diagnosis
- Local:
  - RUQ pain +/- right shoulder pain (2° to Glisson's capsule distension)
  - Hepatomegaly
  - Obstructive jaundice (invasion to biliary tree or compression of intrahepatic duct) - NOT common
  - Constitutional symptoms: LOA, LOW
  - Deranged LFT in cirrhotic patients: e.g. encephalopathy, coagulopathy, portal HT (ascites, edema, UGIB), hepatorenal syndrome
- Paraneoplastic syndromes:
  - Erythrocytosis (EPO secretion from tumour)
  - Hypoglycaemia (high metabolic demands of tumour + IGF-2 secretion)
  - Hypercholesterolemia (autonomous cholesterol synthesis)
  - Hypercalcaemia (PTHrP secretion)
  - Watery diarrhoea (VIP secretion)
  - Cutaneous features: dermatomyositis, Leser-Trelat sign (explosive onset of multiple seborrheic keratoses)
- Ruptured HCC
- Metastasis: intrahepatic (via portal vein / hepatic vein), lung (MC), bone, brain, peritoneum, adrenals

Investigations
Investigations for diagnosis

- Bloods: CBC, clotting, LRFT, albumin
- Viral serology for underlying chronic hepatitis
  - HBV: HBV DNA, HBsAg, HBeAg (↑risk of HCC)
  - HCV: anti-HCV IgG, HCV RNA
- AFP: normal <6 (raised in 80%), level correlates with prognosis (risk of recurrence)
  - False positive AFP: pregnancy, germ cell tumor / teratoma, liver cirrhosis, hepatitis,
- USG HBP: screening for HCC (any nodule that is not clearly hemangioma = HCC until proven otherwise)
  - Mass < 1cm: repeat USG Q6m (rationale: tumor doubling time ~4 months)
  - Mass ≥ 1cm: triphasic CT
- **Triphasic CT scan** (gold standard)

|                   | HCC                                                                    | Liver metastasis |
| :---------------- | :--------------------------------------------------------------------- | :--------------- |
| Key features      | Rich supply by hepatic artery (normal liver parenchyma mainly from PV) | Hypovascular     |
| Arterial phase    | Hyperdense                                                             | Hypodense        |
| Portovenous phase | Washout (hypodense)                                                    | Hypodense        |
| Delayed phase     | Hypodense                                                              | Hypodense        |

- MRI liver with Primovist contrast (hepatospecific contrast) - if CT C/I or equivocal findings
  - Typical features: high intensity on T2-weighted and low intensity on T1-weighted images
- Contrast-enhanced USG

The table compares HCC to liver metastasis across different phases and features, including key characteristics, arterial phase, portovenous phase, and delayed phase, highlighting the differences in vascularity and intensity between the two conditions.
