124

- CT hepatic angiography: inject intraarterial contrast (e.g. SMA, hepatic a.)
- Post-lipiodol CT scan: HCC shows up on Day 10 due to lack of Kupffer cells to ingest lipiodol
- Percutaneous liver biopsy: Only done in inconclusive diagnosis and unresectable cases (e.g. differentiate primary from secondary tumors) - Contraindications: bleeding tendency (e.g. INR > 1.2 despite vit K), thrombocytopenia (Plt < 50), high-grade biliary obstruction (risk of bile peritonitis) - Risk of bleeding (hypervascular tumour), organ puncture, needle tract seeding of tumour - IHC can be performed to determine liver metastasis of unknown origin - CK-7 (CA lung), CK-19 (CA breast), CK-20 (CRC), TTF-1 (lung adenoCA / thyroid CA)
  Investigations for staging
- Imaging: triphasic CT, bone scan
- PET-CT: limited sensitivity as HCC does not take up FDG well and liver has high background metabolic activity → require dual-tracer ([11C]-acetate + [18F]-FDG) - taken up by tumour cells at varying degrees
- TNM staging vs BCLC staging (less preferred by HK liver surgeon - KC Ng)
  | TNM staging | BCLC staging |
  |----------------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------|
  | Validated in patients treated with liver resection or transplantation | T staging of tumor: **number, size, vascular invasion** (inc. ruptured HCC) |
  | | Underlying liver function (Child-Pugh score) |
  | | Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group Performance status (ECOG PS): **0-4** |

Investigations for complications

- CBC: low Hb, Plt (hypersplenism)
- Child-Pugh score (alternative: Albi score - only takes into account objective factors i.e. albumin & bilirubin)
  | Points | Class | One year survival | Two year survival |
  |--------|-------|-------------------|-------------------|
  | 5-6 | A | 100% | 85% |
  | 7-9 | B | 81% | 57% |
  | 10-15 | C | 45% | 35% |

| Clinical & Laboratory Parameters | Points scored for increasing abnormality |
| -------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------- | --------- | --------- |
|                                  | 1                                        | 2         | 3         |
| Albumin (g/L)                    | >35                                      | 28-35     | <28       |
| Bilirubin (mmol/l)               | <35                                      | 35-50     | 50        |
| Clotting profile (INR)           | <1.7                                     | 1.7-2.3   | >2.3      |
| Distended abdomen (ascites)      | Absent                                   | Slight    | Moderate  |
| Encephalopathy                   | Absent                                   | Grade 1&2 | Grade 3&4 |

Management overview
Curative options: **liver resection, local ablation, liver transplant (diseased donor / living donor)**
Palliative options: TACE, sorafenib
BCLC algorithm - for reference, different from local management approach

[Image Description: A flow chart illustrates the hepatocellular carcinoma treatment algorithm based on the Barcelona Clinic Liver Cancer (BCLC) staging system. The chart begins with five categories: Very early stage (0), Early stage (A), Intermediate stage (B), Advanced stage (C), and Terminal stage (D). Each stage has specific treatments. Very Early Stage (0) with single nodule ≤2 cm, Child-Pugh A, ECOG 0, flows to ablation, resection, and transplantation (DDLT/LDLT). Early Stage (A) with single or ≤3 nodule ≤3 cm, Child-Pugh A-B, ECOG 0, branches to a decision point: Solitary (leads to "Optimal Surgical candidate 1") or 2 to 3 nodules ≤3 cm (leads to "Transplant candidate"). From there, ablation is the next step. Intermediate Stage (B) with multinodular, Child-Pugh A-B, ECOG 0, progresses to chemoembolization. Advanced Stage (C) with portal invasion, N1, M1, Child-Pugh A-B, ECOG 1-2, flows to first-line systemic therapy (Atezolizumab + Bevacizumab), then second-line systemic therapy (Sorafenib, Lenvatinib), and finally third-line systemic therapy (Regorafenib, Cabozantinib, Ramucirumab) or nivolumab and pembrolizumab. Terminal Stage (D) with Child-Pugh C, ECOG >3, progresses to best supportive care. Median overall survival (OS) data is also given, with 10 years for transplantation and >6 years for resection/ablation, >26 to 30 months for chemoembolization, >17 months for first-line systemic therapy, 13 to 15 months for second-line, 8 to 12 months for third-line, and 3 months for best supportive care. ]

Liver resection^

- First-line treatment unless not eligible (80% not eligible)
- High recurrence rate (80% within 5 years): "field change" effect
  - Intrahepatic metastasis (< 2 years) vs De-novo HCC (> 2 years)
- Types of resection: Wedge resection, segmental resection, hepatectomy^
- Pre-requisite: size < 5cm is usual threshold (lower risk of vascular invasion) but tumor number and size itself is NOT a contraindication
- Resectability (_must know!_)

| Liver factor                             | Adequate future liver remnant (FLR)^ ≥30% (non-cirrhotic liver), ≥40% (cirrhotic liver), 50% (chemoRT) Hepatic reserve assessment: CT hepatic volumetry: volume of remnant / ideal liver volume (est. by weight & height) Indocyanine green (ICG) clearance: ICG retention at 15 mins (ICG-15) <15% for major resection, <21% for minor resection Pre-operative liver function: C/I if Child's C or portal hypertension |
| :--------------------------------------- | :---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Tumor factor (Similar to Milan criteria) | Contraindications include: Extrahepatic metastasis (except GB) Tumor involving main vessels e.g. main portal vein*, hepatic artery, IVC Bi-lobar tumors* (_not absolute C/I: can do ALPPS_)                                                                                                                                                                                                                             |
| Patient factor                           | General fitness for GA e.g. DM, RFT                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     |

\*Multiple tumors / intrahepatic vascular invasion (e.g. main hepatic vein, left / right PV) are not considered contraindications for liver resection.

^Liver augmentation: ↑FLR

- Portal vein embolization (PVE): obliterate portal blood flow to selected portion of liver (on tumor side) → elicit physiological hypertrophy of liver remnant
- Portal vein ligation: similar to PVE
- Associating liver partition and portal vein ligation for staged hepatectomy (ALPPS): 2-staged procedure for initially unresectable liver

| Stage 1 | Tumor resection from L lateral segment Ligate R portal vein but preserve R hepatic artery, hepatic vein and bile duct: prevent liver failure during interval Parenchymal transection: remove collateral PV → accelerated hypertrophy, but frisk of bile leakage |
| :------ | :-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Stage 2 | R trisectionectomy after 1-2 weeks                                                                                                                                                                                                                              |

Surgical techniques during hepatectomy

- Head up position and keep CVP low to reduce bleeding
- No-touch technique: separation of hemi-liver and tumor from IVC before mobilization - risk of vessel rupture
- Pringle's maneouver at Foramen of Winslow: intermittent clamping (15 minutes →5 minute rest)
- Intraoperative USG: localize tumor
- Anatomical resection: follow Couinaud segments to remove potential satellite nodules
- Instruments: Ligasure, Cavitron ultrasonic surgical aspirator (CUSA) for parenchyma
  Post-operative care
- Specific complications: mortality < 5%
  - Bile leakage: drain bilirubin concentration ≥ 3x serum bilirubin on or after Post-op Day 3
  - Post-hepatectomy liver failure: Day 5 bilirubin >50 and INR > 1.7 (50-50 rule) = high risk
  - Ischemic damage to liver remnant: prolonged rotation → twisting of inflow and outflow pedicles
- Surveillance: Imaging (USG alternating with CT), AFP - FU Q3m for 2 years, then Q6m until 5 years

^Hepatectomy

- Minor (<3 segments), major (≥4 segments)
- Right = segments 5-8
- Central = segments 4, 5, 8
- Left lateral = segments 2, 3
- Left = segments 2-4
- Extended left = segments 2-5, 8

[Image Description: The image has two columns. The first column shows a flow chart, a list of conditions, and a table. The second column shows a diagram of the liver divided into sections, and below the liver, a long, narrow color photo of a torso showing a scar on the stomach.]

A. Open left lateral sectionectomy
B. Laparoscopic left lateral sectionectomy

Associating liver partition and portal vein ligation for staged hepatectomy (ALPPS)

[Image Description: This is a diagram of two stages of liver resection with labels indicating the changes at each stage.]

126

Liver transplantation

- Scar: Mercedes-Benz scar
- Indications: ≤65 years with Child C cirrhosis / **unresectable** HCC who meet transplant criteria
- Contraindications: active uncontrolled infection, active alcohol/ substance abuse
  - HBV carriers: antivirals x 2mo before transplant + long-term HBIG after transplant
- **Bridging therapy** (e.g. RFA, TACE) is possible to shrink the disease to fulfil transplant criteria, and to prevent tumor progression whilst waiting for transplant

| Criteria                                 | Details                                                                                                                                       | Role                                                             |
| ---------------------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------- |
| UCSF criteria                            | Single lesion ≤ 6.5 cm in diameterOR ≤3 lesions, each ≤ 4.5cm, sum ≤ 8.0cm                                                                    | Drop-off criteria: only those fulfilled are included in the list |
| Model for End-stage Liver Disease (MELD) | Cr (hepatorenal Sx), bilirubin, INR+/- Na (vasodilation and fluid retention in cirr.)                                                         | Prioritize the list for liver transplant(benefit if score > 18)  |
| Milan criteria                           | Single lesion ≤ 5cm in diameterOR ≤ 3 lesions, each ≤ 3cm in diameterNo gross vascular invasion (PV thrombosis)No nodal or distant metastasis | Bonus score if fulfilled(>75% 5-year survival)                   |

- Complications:
  - Graft failure
  - Acute & chronic rejection
  - Vascular: hepatic artery or portal vein thrombosis, IVC obstruction
  - Complications due to immunosuppression: HT, DM, hyperlipidaemia, osteoporosis, infection

Local ablation

- Roles: Potentially curative, bridge therapy to transplant, or palliative
- Radiofrequency ablation (RFA)
  - Indications: small single tumour < 2cm (as alternative to resection – _resection is preferred if 2-5cm_), **inoperable** solitary HCC < 5cm, **inoperable** ≤3 nodules ≤3cm where transplant not feasible
  - Contraindications: too close to major vessels / major bile ducts / diaphragm (if percutaneous)
  - Route: percutaneous, open
  - Complications: bile duct injury, thermal injury to surrounding tissues
- Other less commonly used: ethanol, microwave, high-intensity focused ultrasound (HIFU), cryotherapy

Trans-arterial chemoembolization (TACE)-大牌針

- Based on the premise that tumour is mainly supplied by hepatic artery
- Procedure:
  - Selective intra-arterial administration of chemotherapy e.g. cisplatin, doxorubicin (drug-eluting beads)
  - Emulsified with lipiodol: retain longer in HCC (no Kupffer cells to ingest)
  - Partial embolization of major tumor artery with Gelfoam: ↓ clearance of chemo, promote tumor necrosis
- Indication: large (>5cm) + unresectable + Child A/B
- Contraindications: portal vein thrombosis (→ liver ischaemia), Child's C, distant metastasis, AV shunt to hepatic vein (→ risk of PE)
- Complications:
  - Post-embolisation syndrome (within 14 days): liver injury due to tumour lysis or ischaemic damage to normal liver tissue; S/S fever, RUQ pain, anorexia; resolve spontaneously after 1 week
  - Liver failure: due to infarction of normal liver tissues
  - Bile duct injury
  - GI bleeding: cytotoxic reflux into other arterial supply to stomach
  - Alterative: transarterial radioembolization (TARE) with 90Yttrium

Others

- Selective internal radiation therapy (SIRT): high-dose RT (3-6 fractions) to small inoperable HCC
- Sorafenib: multitargeted kinase inhibitor (e.g. Raf, VEGF, PDGF)
  - Prolonged survival by 3 months [SHARP trial]
  - Side effects: hand-foot syndrome (acral erythema)
  - Alternatives: other TKI (e.g. regorafenib / lenvatinib), single-agents (e.g. doxorubicin, cisplatin), bevacizumab

Ruptured HCC
Pathogenesis: tend to occur in large and peripherally located tumors (occur in 5-10% of HCC)

- Increased intra-tumoural pressure with occlusion of hepatic veins by tumour thrombi or invasion
- Rapid tumor growth and necrosis
- Vascular dysfunction --> friable vessel
  Clinical features
- Sudden onset of epigastric pain with abdominal distension
- Hypovolemic shock
- Increased likelihood of peritoneal seeding
- Prognosis poor: mortality 25-100%
  Acute management - Resuscitation and initial investigations
- Admit ICU
- NPO, IV access, fluid resuscitation +/- blood products transfusion, monitor vitals, I/O, CVP
- CBC, LRFT, clotting, X-match, HBsAg (may need entecavir cover)
- CXR, USG
- CT scan when stabilized to rule out portal vein thrombosis
  Definitive treatment
- Transarterial embolisation (TAE) if portal vein patent and reasonable LRFT
  - Cx: liver failure, embolism, arterial dissection
- Emergency laparotomy
  - Perihepatic packing + suture plication (small bleeding site only)
  - Absolute alcohol injection
  - Selective hepatic artery ligation (HAL)
  - Staged liver resection
    [Abdominal CT Scan Image: Two axial views of the abdomen are displayed. The image on the left shows a large mass in the liver, indicated by a red arrow, suggesting a tumor. The image on the right shows another axial view, with a red arrow pointing to what appears to be a mass or abnormality in the pelvic region.]
    HCC Screening
- Targets: HBV carriers > 40y, HBV with cirrhosis, HBV/ HCV co-infected with HIV
- Method: USG + AFP Q6m
- CUHK-HCC score: age, albumin, bilirubin, cirrhosis, HBV DNA
  127

Liver metastasis

- MC liver tumour (20x more common than 1º liver tumour)
- Aetiology: _Some GU Cancers Produce Bumpy Lumps_
  - Stomach
  - GU: kidney, ovary, uterus
  - Colon (MC) - 1/3
  - Pancreas
  - Breast
  - Lung
- S/S: hard nodular hepatomegaly, RUQ tenderness, obstructive jaundice (if met to porta hepatis LN)
- Investigations
  - Tumor markers: CEA, CA19-9, AFP, chromogranin A (neuroendocrine marker)
  - **Triphasic CT scan:** hypodense lesion on all phases
  - Full staging workup: e.g. CXR, CT T+A+P, PET-CT, MRI liver with contrast

[Image: CT scan of the abdomen showing multiple liver metastases. The liver is enlarged and contains numerous round lesions, indicating widespread tumor involvement.]

Management of colorectal liver metastasis - similar to primary HCC

- 5-year survival 40-50%
- Resectability
  - Liver factor: **adequate future liver remnant >25%**
  - Tumor factor: R0 (>1cm resection margin), risk scores (e.g. disease course, CEA, # and size of metastasis)
  - Patient factor: fitness for surgery
- C/I: **unresectable** extrahepatic malignancy
- Approach: **laparotomy**
  - Search for regional LN involvement, peritoneal deposits, etc.
  - Intra-op USG to assess number of lesions and determine resectability
  - Total vascular exclusion: may allow resection with involvement of major vessels
- Perioperative chemotherapy: FOLFOX

[Image: A CT scan of a liver with multiple metastatic lesions, similar to the first image but potentially showing a different view or stage.]

Management of other metastases

- Hepatic resection: may be beneficial for some tumors e.g. carcinoids
- TACE: for hypervascular metastases e.g. RCC, breast

Liver injury
AAST scale of liver injury

[Image: A schematic diagram illustrating the American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) scale for liver injury, showing different grades of injury based on depth of laceration, surface area involved, and the presence of active bleeding. The diagram depicts liver injuries ranging from Grade I (minor laceration) to Grade V (severe parenchymal disruption and vascular injury). The different grades are visually represented with corresponding depths of injury, surface area percentages, and textual descriptions. Grade I shows a small laceration less than 1 cm in depth affecting less than 10% of the surface area. Grade II shows a laceration of 1-3cm in depth affecting 10-50% of the surface area. Grade III depicts a laceration of more than 3cm in depth affecting more than 50% of the surface area with active bleeding contained with the parenchyma. Grade IV shows parenchymal disruption extending to the peritoneum with active bleeding. Grade V shows parenchymal disruption with juxtahepatic venous injury.]

5.5 Gallstone diseases
Overview
Stone composition and pathophysiology

- Most are mixed stones

| Constituents                                                                                                                             | Features     | Pathophysiology                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         |
| :--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | :----------- | :---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Cholesterol stone (85%)                                                                                                                  | Radiolucent  | Increased cholesterol secretion in bile / Supersaturation of cholesterol (lithogenic bile) - Oestrogens: **fat, female, forty, fertile** (OCP) Decreased emptying of GB - GB stasis, e.g. DM neuropathy - GB malignancy - Pregnancy: progesterone - Fasting, TPN (JCCK) |
| Pigmented stone Black stone: Ca bilirubinate Cholesterol < 30% Brown stone: Ca bilirubinate with bacterial cell bodies Cholesterol < 30% | Radio-opaque | Chronic haemolysis, e.g. G6PD, thalassemia Chronic liver disease                                                                                                                                                                                                        |
|                                                                                                                                          | Radio-opaque | Bacterial infection (e.g. E. coli / Klebsiella: b- glucuronidase - converts conjugated bilirubin back to unconjugated) RPC e.g. Clonorchis sinensis, Ascaris lumbricoides                                                                                               |

[Image of factors associated with gallstone formation. The image shows the impaired gall-bladder function (Emptying, absorption, excretion) and supersaturated bile and the effect of age, sex, genetics, obesity, and diet on it. There is also a description of cholesterol nucleating factors such as mucus, glycoprotein, and infection and absorption/enterohepatic circulation of bile acids such as deoxycholate, bowel transit time, faecal enteric flora, Ileal resection, and cholestyramine. The image also contains illustration of different parts of the liver, gallbladder, cystic duct, biliary colic, and asymptomatic stone. The common bile duct, choledocholithiasis, acute cholangitis, pancreatic duct, and acute biliary pancreatitis are also illustrated.]

Summary: Possible clinical presentations of gallstones

- Asymptomatic (MC – 80%)
- Symptomatic: fig.
  - Biliary colic
  - Complications:
    - Gallbladder: acute cholecystitis, chronic cholecystitis, CA gallbladder, Mirizzi's syndrome, gallbladder empyema/hydrops, gallbladder perforation, mucocele
    - Biliary tree: choledocholithiasis, acute cholangitis, acute biliary pancreatitis
    - Bowel: cholecystoenteric fistulation (Bouveret's syndrome, gallstone ileus)

Note: Courvoisier's Law

- Definition: in painless jaundice with enlarged gallbladder, the cause is unlikely to be gallstone
- Pathophysiological basis: a gallbladder containing stones is likely subject to repeated episodes of cholecystitis, causing extensive fibrosis of the wall → unable to distend when obstructed → periampullary tumours until proven otherwise
- Exceptions (acute cholecystitis with jaundice) - Double impaction (7%): stone simultaneously occluding the cystic duct and the distal CBD - Mirizzi syndrome - RPC
  Note: Saint's triad = gallstones + hiatal hernia + colonic diverticulosis

130
Asymptomatic gallstones

- Risk of future complications: 1-4%/ year
- Management:
  - Watchful waiting: risk factor modifications
  - Ursodeoxycholic acid (oral bile acid: only useful for cholesterol stone)
  - Prophylactic cholecystectomy in high risk patients [Refer to "Cholecystectomy"]

Symptomatic gallstones - summary of main conditions
| | Biliary colic | Acute cholecystitis | Choledocholithiasis | Acute cholangitis |
| :---------------- | :---------------------------------------------- | :-------------------------------------------------------------- | :--------------------------------------------- | :------------------------------------------------------ |
| Mechanism | Gallstone stuck at Hartmann's pouch or cystic duct | Inflammation of GB due to gallstone or biliary sludge | Migration of gallstones into CBD | Bacterial infection secondary to CBD obstruction |
| Clinical features | RUQ pain < 6h | RUQ pain > 6h Fever Murphy sign | RUQ pain > 6h | Charcot triad Reynold pentad |
| Lab | Normal | ↑WBC, CRP | LFT: cholestatic pattern | ↑WBC, CRP LFT: cholestatic pattern |
| Diagnostic imaging| USG: gallstone with posterior acoustic shadow + gravity dependent | USG: distended GB, GB wall thickening, pericholecystic fluid Inconclusive: HIDA scan or MRCP | USG: dilated CBD with gallstone | USG: dilated CBD with gallstone Inconclusive: MRCP |
| Management approach| Elective LC | Resuscitation IV antibiotics Prevent recurrence by LC | Supportive Biliary decompression Prevent recurrence by LC | Resuscitation IV antibiotics Biliary decompression Prevent recurrence by LC |

Biliary colic

- Definitions: GB contracting against **transient obstruction** in Hartmann's pouch/ cystic duct due to gallstones
- Clinical features:
  - **Steady** (usually not colicky: no peristalsis in GB / cystic duct)
  - RUQ/epigastric pain
  - Radiates to right shoulder / scapula
  - More severe after fatty meal (↑CCK), n/v
  - Suspect acute cholecystitis if pain > 6h
- Investigations
  - USG gallbladder (fig.): **hyperechoic stone with posterior acoustic shadowing**, gravity-dependent (turn lateral → rolling stone sign)
    - readily available, quick
    - operator-dependent, limited by body fat and bowel gas
  - AXR: +/- Mercedes Benz sign, radio-opacity (only 15%), differentiated from renal stone by lateral view
  - CBC D/C, LFT (cholestatic picture), amylase and lipase (r/o pancreatitis)
- Management: NPOEM, analgesics (NSAIDs preferred), **elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy** (↓risk of future complications)

[An ultrasound image shows the liver, the GB wall, and a hyperechoic gallstone with posterior shadowing. The image is labeled "Liver", "GB Wall", "Hyperechoic gallstone with posterior shadowing" and "SAG GB 0.26cm"]

Acute cholecystitis
Definition: inflammation of GB
Aetiology

- Calculous (95%)
- Acalculous (5%): dehydration, shock, TPN

[An x-ray image shows an upper quadrant of the body with a vague mass in the upper right side, and an arrow pointing to it.]

# Acute calculous cholecystitis

Pathogenesis

- Prolonged gallstone impaction at Hartmann's pouch/ cystic duct → Stagnant bile leads to bile **concentration** (mucocele/ hydrops) → **Chemical** inflammation in first 48h → **Secondary bacterial** infection (G- rods e.g. E coli, Klebsiella, Strep faecalis)

Clinical features

- Pain starts as biliary colic, but:
  - More constant (local parietal peritoneal inflammation)
  - Longer > 6h
  - With signs of inflammation (fever, tachycardia)
- Murphy's sign: inspiratory arrest during deep palpation of RUQ
- Complications:
  - Gallbladder empyema: tender RUQ mass + septic-looking
  - Gangrenous cholecystitis (20%)
  - Perforation: necrotic GB wall (less likely as usually wrapped by omentum) → biliary peritonitis
  - Emphysematous cholecystitis: secondary bacterial infection of GB wall with gas-forming organisms (e.g. Clostridium welchii); S/S insidious onset, abdominal crepitus
  - Cholecystoenteric fistula & gallstone ileus

Investigations

- USG: **5 cardinal signs of acute cholecystitis** (fig.) - _important!_
  1. Presence of gallstones
  2. Distended GB (> 4 x 10cm)
  3. GB wall thickening > 3mm
  4. Peri-cholecystic fluid (due to wall oedema) /stranding
  5. Sonographic Murphy sign
- Inconclusive USG:
  - Radio-isotope scan (HIDA scan): non-visualisation of GB
  - MRCP + Morphine augmentation: ↑SoD pressure
- Bloods: CBC D/C, LRFT, amylase, clotting, blood C/ST, X-match, lipid profile (risk factors)
- CT A+P: to rule out complications (e.g. empyema, emphysematous cholecystitis, perforation)

Initial management

- NPO & IVF until inflammation subsides (bowel rest)
- IV antibiotics: Augmentin
- Monitor vitals, I/O, analgesics

[An ultrasound image displaying a gallbladder with a thickened wall, pericholecystic fluid, and gallstones. The gallbladder (GB) is labeled within the image. Arrows point to the thickened wall and the pericholecystic fluid surrounding the gallbladder. Gallstones are visible at the bottom of the gallbladder.]

[A table titled "Table 1. Diagnostic Criteria for Acute Cholecystitis, According to Tokyo Guidelines.". The table has two columns: "Clinical manifestations" and a description of the manifestations. The table lists Local symptoms and signs, including Murphy's sign, Pain or tendemess in the right upper quadrant, Mass in the right upper quadrant. It also lists Systemic signs: Fever, Leukocytosis, Elevated C-reactive protein level. There are also Imaging findings: A confirmatory finding on ultrasonography or hepatobiliary scintigraphy. Finally, it lists Diagnosis: The presence of one local sign or symptom, one systemic sign, and a confirmatory finding on an imaging test.]

Definitive treatment: **early or interval laparoscopic cholecystectomy (LC) +/- PTC** (_need to know!_)

- Emergency laparoscopic cholecystectomy (LC): if **complicated** (gangrene, perforation, emphysematous cholecystitis) or disease progression despite best supportive care
- Elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy: 1st line for most patient

| Early LC: within 3-5 days of symptom onset                                          | Interval LC: delayed presentation → LC after 6-8 weeks                                                     |
| :---------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | :--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Initial inflammation: pericholecystic fluid in dissection plane → easier dissection | After 72h: dense adhesions form at Calot's triangle                                                        |
| Shorter hospital stay, single admission                                             | Lower risk, better laparoscopic success                                                                    |
| Higher risk of bleeding and post-op infections, higher risk of converting to open   | Separate admission, fibrosis causes difficulty in mobilizing GB, chance of recurrence while waiting for OT |

- GB drainage: if not fit for surgery / waiting for interval LC + **not responding to antibiotics**
  - Percutaneous transhepatic cholecystostomy (PTC) [Tubes & Drains]
    - Specific complications: catheter migration, bile leakage, bowel injury
  - Endoscopic drainage: if PC not feasible; transpapillary (ERCP) or transmural (EUS-guided needle drainage / LAMS)

Acute acalculous cholecystitis

- Definitions: microvascular occlusion within GB causing ischaemia and infection
- Risk factors: **hospitalized / critically ill** patients with medical comorbidities
  - Dehydration
  - Shock: systemic hypoperfusion
  - TPN: JCCK
- Clinical features: similar to calculous cholecystitis, but higher mortality
- Investigations: CT/USG to differentiate from calculous cholecystitis
- Management: laparoscopic cholecystectomy / gallbladder drainage (if unfit)

Chronic cholecystitis

- Definitions: chronic inflammation of gallbladder (as seen in histology), almost always due to **gallstone (95%)**
  - Recurrent acute cholecystitis / persistent mechanical irritation → fibrosis and thickening of GB
  - Infected by Salmonella typhi→ typhoid carrier
- Clinical features:
  - Repeated attacks of biliary colic
  - Complications:
    - **CA gallbladder**
    - **Porcelain gallbladder**: calcification of GB
      wall due to extensive scarring, - 2-3% risk of malignancy - Subtypes: complete intramural, selective mucosal
- Investigations: USG +/- HIDA scan (**contracted gallbladder** with wall thickening and gallstones)
- Management: laparoscopic cholecystectomy

[Detailed anatomical illustration of a gallbladder affected by Mirizzi Syndrome. The gallbladder is green and swollen, with a large gallstone impacted in Hartmann's pouch, causing obstruction of the common hepatic duct. There is an eroded duct wall, with a small portion of the bile duct exposed. An inset image shows a close-up of the gallstone impaction in Hartmann's pouch.]

Mirizzi syndrome
Definition

- **CHD obstruction** caused by extrinsic compression from an **impacted stone in Hartmann's pouch/ cystic duct**
- Chronic inflammation can lead to erosion of bile duct wall, causing **cholecystobiliary fistula** (cholecystohepatic or cholecystocholedochal)
  Clinical features
- Variable presentation: acute cholangitis (fever, RUQ pain, jaundice), acute cholecystitis (RUQ pain), etc.
- **Jaundice with palpable GB** - exceptions to Courvoisier's Law
- Complications: **CA gallbladder** - recurrent inflammation and biliary stasis
  Classification: Csendes classification
  | Type | Cholecystobiliary fistula | Remarks |
  |------|---------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
  | 1 | X | |
  | 2 | ✅ | Fistula diameter <1/3 of CBD wall circumference |
  | 3 | ✅ | Fistula diameter 1/3 – 2/3 of CBD wall circumference |
  | 4 | ✅ | Fistula diameter >2/3 of CBD wall circumference (i.e. complete destruction) |
  | 5 | Any type + **cholecystoenteric fistula** | (5A: no gallstone ileus, 5B: gallstone ileus) |

Investigations

- USG: dilated biliary tree above stone impaction, presence of gallstone at GB neck, contracted GB
- MRCP
- ERCP: diagnostic (presence of **cholecystobiliary fistula**) + therapeutic (stenting for obstructive jaundice / removal of stones)
- CT abdomen + contrast: rule out malignant causes (e.g. porta hepatis LN)

132

Management:

- Without fistula (type I): laparoscopic / open cholecystectomy
- With fistula (II - V): **open surgery**
  - GB: Subtotal cholecystectomy (severe inflammation impedes safe dissection of Calot's triangle)
  - CBD: Closure of fistula / choledochoplasty / bilioenteric anastomosis (choledochojejunostomy) depending on size of defect

Gallstone ileus

- Definitions: gallstone erodes through GB into adjacent bowel through a **cholecystoenteric fistula**
  - **Bouveret's syndrome**: stone stuck at duodenum/ stomach, causing GOO
  - Cholecystoduodenal fistula (MC): symptomatic gallstone ileus (mechanical obstruction)
  - Cholecystocolic fistula: asymptomatic
- Associated with Mirizzi's syndrome
- Clinical features
  - Features of distal SBO (terminal ileum **2 feet proximal** to ileocaecal valve as the narrowest portion of SB)
- Investigations
  - AXR: **pneumobilia\*** (40%), radio-opaque stone in bowel (10%), features of SBO
    - **Rigler's triad**: **pneumobilia**, **SBO**, **ectopic gallstone** (usually in RIF: stuck at IC valve)
  - CT abdomen: gallbladder wall thickening, Rigler's triad
- Management
  - **Enterolithotomy** to relieve SBO
    - Exploratory laparotomy → **Proximal** enterotomy (NOT over the stone because of ulceration) → **Milk the stone proximally** for extraction
    - Same-session / Elective cholecystectomy
    - Fistula repair

[Image of diagram A and B showing the removal of the gallbladder and impacted stone during Mirizzi syndrome. Diagram A shows the liver, gallbladder, inflamed gallbladder, impacted stone, common hepatic duct, and jejunum. Diagram B illustrates the liver, gallbladder with stone, common bile duct, and jejunum]

[Image of an X-ray showing areas of pneumobilia, SBO and a radio-opaque stone in the bowel]

\*Other DDx of pneumobilia:

- Emphysematous cholecystitis
- Post-ERCP
- Post-cholecystectomy
- Blunt abdominal trauma
- Sphincter of Oddi incompetence

# Cholecystectomy

Indications

- **Symptomatic gallstones** (with or without complications) – study: OT can ↓ risk of recurrent Cx from 25% to 8%
- **Asymptomatic gallstones:** in high risk patients
  - Increased risk of gallstone complications, e.g. gastric bypass (altered anatomy), haemolytic disorders
  - Increased risk of gallbladder cancer: **GB polyps >1cm, porcelain gallbladder, large gallstones >3cm**
  - Concomitant liver surgery

Approach

- Laparoscopic vs open (Kocher incision):
  - ↓pain & early mobilization, ↓hospital stay, ↓most Cx (e.g. wound, chest, ileus), cosmetic
  - ↑biliary tree injury, ↑Cardiopulmonary compromise by pneumoperitoneum (Cx of laparoscopy)
- Indications for open:
  - Cannot tolerate pneumoperitoneum, e.g. cardiopulmonary comorbidities
  - Refractory coagulopathy
  - Multiple abdominal surgeries
- CA gallbladder (extensive adhesions, risk of rupture and thus tumour seeding)

Operative procedure of lap. cholecystectomy

- Positioning: reversed Trendelenburg position (head up), slightly rotated to left
- Surgeon stands on left of patient
- Establish pneumoperitoneum by Hasson open technique: insert 10mm blunt trocar at central umbilical site and insufflate CO2 till ~15mmHg
- Retract gallbladder fundus and lift Hartmann's pouch to identify Rouveiere's sulcus (R posterior portal pedicle)
- Ensure "critical view of safety" to minimize bile duct injury
- Identify and divide cystic duct & cystic artery near GB
- Remove gallbladder via umbilicus

[Diagram of "Standard techniques" for laparoscopic cholecystectomy, showing the positioning of ports. There are 3 ports on the abdomen, one 10 mm primary operating port, one 10 mm camera port, one 5 mm static retraction port and one 5 mm dynamic retraction port]

Critical View of Safety (CVS):

1. Hepatocystic triangle clearance
2. Cystic plate clearance
3. **Only two structures seen** entering gallbladder: cystic duct & cystic artery

[Two images showing the Critical View of Safety (CVS) during cholecystectomy, specifically the identification and isolation of the cystic duct and cystic artery before division]

Specific complications

Immediate:

- **Conversion to open** surgery (5% in elective, 25% in emergency) - NOT indicate failure
- GA risks, bleeding
- **Damage to neighbouring structures:** bile leakage (biliary tree), bleeding (cystic artery), pneumoperitoneum (duodenum, transverse colon, hepatic flexure)

Early:

- **Biliary leakage** (from cystic duct stump / duct of Luschka): 0.5% (elective ~ emergency)
  - Noted intra-op: repair + T-tube placement
  - Delayed presentation (usually post-op D2-10)
  - S/S: fever, RUQ pain, dLFT
  - Ix: USG/CT abdomen → HIDA scan / MRCP
  - Mx: to re-establish flow by ERCP stent (minor) or laparotomy + lavage + Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy (major)
- **Bleeding:** due to liver (middle hepatic vein close to GB fossa), cystic artery, trocar site
- Post-op jaundice (dropped / missed CBD stones), cholangitis (infected stone)
- Post-op diarrhoea (initial uncoordinated excessive bile salt excretion + fat malabsorption)

[Illustration of the biliary system after Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy, highlighting the connection between the liver, gallbladder remnant, and jejunum. The remnant bile duct is attached to the roux limb]

Late:

- Bile duct stricture: Mx by reconstruction +/- hepatojejunostomy
- Subphrenic abscess: Mx by drainage + antibiotics
- **Post-cholecystectomy syndrome:** persistent symptoms (e.g. biliary colic, diarrhea) after operation
- Post-cholecystectomy choledocholithiasis: bile stasis due to increased CBD calibre (loss of GB storing function)

# 5.6 Diseases of biliary tract

## Choledocholithiasis

Definitions: obstruction of CBD/CHD by gallstone
Clinical features

- RUQ pain
- Obstructive jaundice
- Complications: acute cholangitis (see separate section)
  Investigations
- CBC (infection), LFT (cholestatic pattern), amylase (r/o pancreatitis)
- USG:
  - Gallstone in CBD (visible in 1/3 cases only: obscuring gas in duodenum)
  - Dilated CBD (>8mm)
  - Limited value for distal CBD stone due to bowel gas
- Subsequent investigations depend on risk of complications:
  - Low risk: MRCP or EUS (if C/I to MRCP)
  - High risk: ERCP (diagnostic + therapeutic) - high risk of complications (e.g. perforation, pancreatitis)
    Management
- Stone removal:
  - ERCP: sphincterotomy + CBD stone removal
    - Methods of stone removal:
      - Wire baskets
      - Stone extraction balloon
      - Mechanical lithotripsy
  - Surgical: exploration of CBD
    - Indicated if ERCP is C/I (e.g. altered anatomy)
    - Approaches:
      - Transcystic (1st line): insert catheter via cystic duct → perform
        cholangiogram → extract stones (e.g. balloon)
      - Choledochotomy (2nd line): incise CBD → remove CBD stone
        through defect → choledochoscopy to confirm clearance
      - Percutaneous choledochoscopy
    - Technique of stone removal: wire basket, saline flushing, biliary
      Fogarty balloon
    - Advantage: can be performed as one-stage surgery together with LC
    - After exploration
      - T-tube may be inserted for subsequent cholangiogram and bile
        drainage (fig.), but shown to increase complications e.g.
        infection, bile leak, tube dislodgement
      - Primary closure if existing biliary stent
- Elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy (still ~5% risk of recurrent biliary events e.g.
  residual / dropped stones, primary RPC stones)

[Image Description: A diagram illustrating the process of sphincterotomy and stone removal. Two figures, side by side, depict the sphincter of Oddi being widened with a wire, allowing for the passage of a stone.

A diagram shows the liver, gallbladder, stomach, duodenum, and pancreas connected by a network of ducts. A catheter is inserted through the cystic duct.

A vertical diagram shows the common bile duct and a Y-shaped section of ducts. One branch goes to the liver and the other to the duodenum.]

## Acute cholangitis

Definition: bacterial infection of biliary tract due to CBD obstruction
Classification of cholangitis

- Anatomical: Ascending vs descending
- Pathological: Pyogenic, obstructive, etc.
- Others:
  - Primary sclerosing cholangitis: obliterative fibrosis of biliary tree, associated with IBD, rare in Asia
  - Immune (IgG4-associated cholangitis): infiltration of biliary system with IgG4, mostly elderly male

135

Etiology of acute cholangitis

- Biliary obstruction: bile stasis → infection
  - Choledocholithaisis (CBD stones)
  - Strictures (bile duct injury, PBC/PSC)
  - Malignancy: CA pancreas, cholangioCA, periampullary CA, porta hepatis LN
- Post-ERCP: sphincterotomy disrupts barrier to infection
- Biliary stent in-situ: FB serves as nidus for infection
- Pathogens: GNR (E coli, Klebsiella) > enterococcus, Pseudomonas (if stent present)

Clinical features

- **Charcot's triad** (50-70%): Fever, RUQ pain, jaundice
- **Reynold's pentad** (<10%): above + shock + altered mental state

Urgent investigations

- Bloods: CBC, clotting, LFT(+GGT), RFT, amylase, **blood culture!!**
- Erect CXR, AXR (aerobilia)
- USG abdomen: dilated duct, gallstone; rule out liver abscess (similar presentations)
- **ERCP (1st line):** diagnostic and therapeutic, but invasive
- Alternatives: MRCP, EUS, CT scan (r/o liver abscess or malignant obstruction)

Acute management (RAD) - **must know!!**

- **Resuscitation:** NPO, IV fluids, monitor vitals & I/O Q1h
- **Antibiotics** (broad-spectrum): IV Augmentin (mild) or IV Tazocin (severe) x 7 days
- **Drainage:** Urgent if **Reynold's pentad**, not responding to antibiotics for 24h (obstruction: impair secretion of antibiotics in bile)
- Endoscopic:
  - ERCP (plastic stent with/without sphincterotomy) - mortality < 5%
  - Role: **biliary drainage and decompression** in unstable patients (NOT stone removal)
  - Aspirate bile duct to remove bile & pus to decompress biliary tree and reduce risk of inducing bacteraemia during contrast injection
  - Then inject contrast and place plastic stent (temporary, require scheduled change)
  - Remove stone now or interval ERCP after sepsis resolves [refer to "choledocholithiasis"]
  - Therapeutic EUS (EUS-guided cholangiopancreatography)
- Percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage (PTBD):
  - Similar efficacy & rate of complications as ERCP
  - Indicated when ERCP unsuccessful / contraindicated (e.g. poor respiratory function)
  - Transhepatic insertion of **intrahepatic** BD (Not CBD)
  - Easy output monitoring (external drainage, but can be internalized later)
  - Risk of fluid and electrolyte loss
- Surgery:
  - Intra-op ERCP (supine position)
  - Exploration of CBD - high mortality 30% [refer to "choledocholithiasis"]

Long-term management

- Gallstone: ERCP for lithotripsy + laparoscopic cholecystectomy (early instead of interval)
  - Ascending cholangitis is still possible after LC: biliary stasis due to
    - ERCP-induced CBD dilatation
    - Aging-related CBD dilatation
- Stricture (benign/ malignant): endoscopic stent placement
- RPC: regular stone clearance, surgical resection (see separate section)

136

Recurrent pyogenic cholangitis (RPC)
Definition: recurrent syndrome of bacterial cholangitis that occurs in association with **intrahepatic pigment stones** and **intrahepatic biliary obstruction (strictures)**
Also known as "Hong Kong disease" / oriental cholangiohepatitis
Pathophysiology: usually start in _left intrahepatic ducts_

- Parasitic infestation (e.g. Clonorchis sinensis in raw freshwater fish 淡水魚): epithelial damage → bacterial translocation → stricture formation → biliary stasis
- Malnutrition: low protein diet in Orientals → relative enzyme deficiency → breakdown of conjugated bilirubin to unconjugated form by bacterial glucuronidase → brown pigment stone formation

Different from other gallstone diseases: stones not formed in GB, mainly pigment stones but not cholesterol stones

Clinical features

- Middle-age onset
- Recurrent episodes of acute cholangitis (1-2 episodes per year)
- Complications: - Cx of acute cholangitis: e.g. biliary sepsis, pancreatitis, abscess, fistula - Cirrhosis (due to chronic biliary obstruction) - Cholangiocarcinoma
  Investigations
- Bloods: CBC, LFT, clotting, ova & parasites
- Imaging:
  - USG abdomen: dilated duct, stone, liver abscess
  - CT: central dilated bile ducts with peripheral tapering, left lobe predilection, liver atrophy
  - Cholangiogram (ERCP/MRCP/ PTBD): anatomy of biliary tree

Management

- Acute complications:
  - Resuscitation
  - Antibiotics
  - Biliary drainage: ERCP difficult to access intrahepatic drainage → PTBD, T-tube drainage, HCJ (hepaticocutaneojejunostomy, fig.)
- Prevention of long-term complications
  - Regular ductal clearance: USG surveillance, ERCP to remove stones / dilate strictures
  - Resection of affected hepatobiliary segment + biliary-enteric anastomosis (e.g. HJ)
    - Indication: atrophic liver segment, failed non-operative Tx, suspected cholangioCA

[An anatomical illustration depicting the liver, gallbladder, stomach, duodenum, pancreas, and biliary tree. The liver is a large, reddish-brown organ located in the upper right abdomen. Connected to the liver is the gallbladder, a small, green sac that stores bile. The biliary tree consists of a network of ducts that transport bile from the liver and gallbladder to the duodenum, the first part of the small intestine. The illustration shows the common bile duct, which is formed by the union of the cystic duct from the gallbladder and the common hepatic duct from the liver. The common bile duct joins the pancreatic duct before entering the duodenum. The stomach is a large, muscular organ located on the left side of the abdomen. The duodenum is a C-shaped tube that curves around the head of the pancreas. The pancreas is a long, slender organ located behind the stomach. The illustration provides a clear and detailed view of the anatomy of these important digestive organs, highlighting the complex network of ducts that make up the biliary tree. The colors are vibrant and the lines are sharp, making it easy to distinguish between the different structures.]

Clonorchis sinensis infection

- Humans as definitive host: adult form in biliary tract, embryonated eggs passed in faeces
- Transmission: poorly cooked freshwater fish
- Clinical presentation: asymptomatic, acute cholangitis, RPC,↑ risk of cholangioCA
- Diagnosis: stool microscopy for eggs, duodenal aspirate for eggs, USG for adult flukes, intra-op choledochoscopy for adult flukes
- Treatment: praziquantel 25mg/kg PO tds x 1 day

138
Choledochal cyst

- Definitions: congenital dilations of intra/ extrahepatic biliary system
- Most diagnosed before 10y (60%)
- Todani classification: most commonly type I

[Image: A black and white diagram illustrates five types of choledochal cysts. Type I shows a solitary extrahepatic cyst. Type II shows an extrahepatic diverticulum. Type III shows a choledochocoel. Type IVA shows extra and intrahepatic cysts. Type IVB shows multiple extrahepatic cysts. Type V shows multiple intrahepatic cysts (Caroli's Disease).]

Clinical features

- RUQ mass + pain, jaundice, fever
- Pancreatitis
- Complications: cholangiocarcinoma
  Investigations
- Diagnostic: USG
- Anatomy: MRCP
- Extent: CT
  Management
- Radical excision of cyst + biliary tract reconstruction using a
  Roux-en-Y loop of jejunum (HJ or choledochojejunostomy) - Prevent development of cholangiocarcinoma - Reduced risk of stricture - Reduced risk of recurrent cholangitis
  5.7 Cancers of gallbladder and biliary tree
  Gallbladder polyps
  Types of benign polyps
- Non-neoplastic: no malignant potential
  - Adenomyomatosis: intramural diverticula (Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses)
  - Cholesterol polyps (MC)
  - Inflammatory polyps
- Neoplastic - Adenomatous polyps: benign epithelial tumors, risk of malignant transformation (↑ if larger size)
  Management of GB polyps
- Polyps <1cm: regular USG (Q6mo if 6-9mm, Q12mo if ≤5mm)
- Indications of laparoscopic cholecystectomy - Symptomatic (e.g. RUQ pain) - Adenomatous polyps ≥1cm (or 8mm if underlying PSC): >2cm might need extended cholecystectomy
  with LN dissection and partial hepatic resection - Rapidly growing polyps
  Gallbladder carcinoma
  Overview
- Very rare in Hong Kong, more common in women
- Very poor prognosis: most discovered late and are unresectable at diagnosis - 5-year OS < 5%
  Risk factors (4P)
- Polyps: higher risk if polyps ≥1cm
  - To differentiate from gallstone: no gravity dependence, no acoustic shadow
  - Higher risk if sessile polyp
- Porcelain gallbladder / other gallstone diseases (chronic inflammation → dysplasia)
- Primary sclerosing cholangitis
- Pancreatobiliary duct anomalous junction: a/w choledochal cyst
  Pathology
- Mostly adenocarcinoma (90%), others are SCC
  Clinical features: difficult to differentiate from other gallbladder diseases
- Early stage: biliary colic, RUQ pain - due to gallstone instead of CA (gallstone found in 95% patients)
- Late stage: obstructive jaundice, palpable mass, constitutional symptoms
- Metastasis: direct extension into liver (adjacent segments IV & V), seedings into peritoneum

Investigation

- Bloods: LFT (cholestatic picture), CA19-9
- Diagnostic: USG, CT, MRI/MRCP, percutaneous biopsy
- Staging: PET/CT, laparoscopy

Treatment
Curative: **Open cholecystectomy with intra-op frozen section**

- Stage I disease (confined to mucosa, T1N0): no further treatment required
- Higher stage disease (extend to _serosa/ transmural_): **extended cholecystectomy**
  - _En-bloc resection_ of gallbladder with rim of liver ≥2cm adjacent to gallbladder bed
  - Segmental hepatectomy (segments IVb, V)
  - Extrahepatic bile duct resection (if cystic duct involved)
  - Regional lymphadenectomy (porta hepatis LN)

Palliative care

- Stenting: for malignant obstructive jaundice
- Surgical bypass: for duodenal obstruction

Cholangiocarcinoma

[Anatomical illustration of the liver, gallbladder, and bile ducts. The liver is depicted in brown with the gallbladder in green attached to its underside. The common bile duct, also in green, extends from the gallbladder and connects to the duodenum. Labels point to Intrahepatic, Perihilar, and Distal extrahepatic areas of the bile ducts.]

[Diagram illustrating Bismuth-Corlette classification of cholangiocarcinoma. The diagram includes 6 types of classifications: Type I, Type II, Type IIIa, Type IIIb, Type IV, Type IV multicentric. Each type shows a different configuration of tumor location relative to the confluence of the hepatic ducts.]

Definitions: carcinoma of bile duct (>90% adenoCA)
Classification by site

- Intrahepatic (10%): proximal to CHD bifurcation, bulky tumour ~HCC; increasing incidence
- Perihilar (MC, 60%): between CHD bifurcation and cystic duct origin, prone to cholangitis, resection difficult; further classified by Bismuth-Corlette classification (table)
- Distal extrahepatic (20-30%): distal to cystic duct origin, decreasing incidence
- Klatskin's tumor: cholangioCA that involves the common hepatic duct bifurcation (usually perihilar type)

Risk factors

- Systemic conditions: DM, obesity, chronic hepatitis (Hep C)
- Cholestatic disease: PSC (less common in Asia), RPC, cholelithiasis
- Congenital: choledochal cysts, Caroli's disease, Lynch syndrome
- Chemicals: thorium dioxide (Thorotrast)

|           |                                         |
| --------- | --------------------------------------- |
| Type I    | Below CHD bifurcation                   |
| Type II   | Reaching CHD bifurcation                |
| Type IIIa | Involve CHD and RHD                     |
| Type IIIb | Involve CHD and LHD                     |
| Type IV   | Involve CHD, RHD and LHD / Multicentric |

139

Clinical features
140

- Local: painless obstructive jaundice (hilar / distal tumors tend to present earlier), RUQ discomfort, cholangitis, haemobilia (UGIB from biliary tree)
- Constitutional symptoms
- Signs: - Hepatomegaly (intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma) - Painless jaundice, tea-coloured urine, pale-coloured stool - Palpable GB (Courvoisier's Law - if distal tumor)
  Investigations
- Bloods: LFT (cholestatic pattern), CA19-9 (only raised in 80%), CEA, AFP
- Imaging: USG (dilated duct, mass lesion), CT, MRI/MRCP
- Cholangiography: ERCP for distal tumors, PTC for proximal tumors - define level of obstruction +/- stenting
- Tissue diagnosis (not must): brush cytology/CT-guided biopsy if uncertain
- Staging: MRCP (intrahepatic metastasis), EUS (nodal involvement), staging laparoscopy
  Management
  Surgical resection (1st line, but only 10% operable at presentation)
- Unresectable if:
  - Invasion of major vessels (e.g. main PV, main hepatic a., celiac trunk, SMA, SMV)
  - Extensive involvement of biliary tree (bilaterally > 2° radicles)
  - LN metastasis (retropancreatic, paracoeliac, paraaortic)
  - Distal organ metastasis (lung, peritoneum)
- Approach: - Intrahepatic: partial hepatectomy + portal LN dissection - Perihilar (further depend on Bismuth-Corlette type): extrahepatic bile duct resection + cholecystectomy + portal LN dissection (+/- partial hepatectomy) + reconstruction (Roux-en-y hepaticojejunostomy) (fig.)
  [Diagram illustrating the Roux-en-Y Hepaticojejunostomy procedure. The diagram shows the liver and gallbladder with a portion of the bile duct removed. The remaining bile ducts are connected to the jejunum via a surgical connection known as hepaticojejunostomy. The jejunum is also connected to itself in a procedure called jejunojejunostomy, creating a "Y" shape. The text labels different parts of the anatomy, including "Removed bile duct and gallbladder," "Hepaticojejunostomy (Bile ducts drain into small intestine)," and "Jejuno-jejunostomy." Text below the image states: Roux-en-Y Hepaticojejunostomy Procedure performed for cholangiocarcinoma and biliary injuries.] - If FLR inadequate: portal vein embolisation (PVE) to induce atrophy of affected segment + hypertrophy of unaffected segments - Distal CBD tumour: Whipple's procedure (pancreaticoduodenectomy)
- Pre-operative drainage (ERCP / PTBD) considered if biliary sepsis / poor LFT
  Palliative care: Relieve malignant biliary obstruction by stenting / surgical bypass
- Self-expandable metallic stents (SEMS): for established malignancy (longer patency, but cannot be removed)
- Uncovered stents preferred: lower risk of occluding branches of biliary system
- Approaches
  - Internal drainage: ERCP + stenting
  - External drainage: PTBD
  - Internal-external biliary drainage: PTBD (push pass obstruction → internalized)
- Complications:
  - Stent occlusion (e.g. tumor ingrowth, bile sludge): Mx by sweeping or placing new stent
  - Stent migration

# 5.8 Diseases of pancreas

## Acute pancreatitis

Definition: acute inflammation of pancreas parenchyma
Pathogenesis:

- Duodeno-pancreatic reflux → Release and premature activation of pancreatic enzymes (most importantly trypsinogen) → Autodigestion of pancreas → Release of inflammatory mediators & cytokines (SIRS)

Revised Atlanta classification system:

- 2 broad categories:
  - No necrosis = Interstitial edematous acute pancreatitis
  - Necrosis = Necrotizing acute pancreatitis
- By severity: any organ failure (respiratory/cardiovascular/renal) or local/systemic complications
  - Mild = **NO** organ failure / complications
  - Moderately-severe: transient organ failure <48h or local/systemic complications
  - Severe = **persistent** organ failure >48h

Aetiology (GAME ID)

- Gallstone (MC): suspect if Hx of biliary colic or ↑ALP
- Alcohol: suspect if ↑AST
- Metabolic: hyperTG/hyperCa
- ERCP: reduced by PR NSAID or temporary pancreatic stenting
- Idiopathic (10%)
- Drugs (NSAID, steroid, azathioprine, ACEI, valproate)
- Others: trauma, infections (e.g. mumps), autoimmune (e.g. SLE), pregnancy, scorpion venom, pancreatic divisum (MC congenital anomaly)

Clinical features

- Epigastric pain: severe constant, **radiating to the back**, improve with leaning forward, exacerbated by movement, refractory to analgesics
- N/v, fever (chemical but not infection)
- Tetany: _transient hypocalcaemia_ due to fat saponification (lysis of fat cells → release of fatty acids → precipitate with calcium)
- Signs of retroperitoneal haemorrhage: **Cullen's sign** (periumbilical, fig. A), **Grey Turner's sign** (flank, fig. B), Fox's sign (inguinal ligament, fig. B near groin)
- Pleural effusion (ARDS)

[Image of Cullen's sign, represented in two parts. Part A shows a close-up of a patient's abdomen with a prominent, circular, dark bruise around the umbilicus, indicating periumbilical haemorrhage. Part B presents a broader view of a patient's flank area, exhibiting multiple linear bruises along the side, which indicates Grey Turner's sign.]

Investigation

- CBC, LRFT, CRP, glucose, Ca
- Cardiac markers +/- ECG
- Pancreatic enzymes - cut off is 3x ULN, NOT indicative of severity
  - Serum amylase: rise within 6-12h of onset, normalize in 3-5 days, normal: 30-100 U/L
    - Prolonged elevation indicates complications e.g. pancreatic pseudocyst
    - False positive: PPU, ruptured AAA, DKA, macroamylasemia
    - If equivocal / delayed presentation: urine amylase (rise within 24-48h, persist 1 week)
  - Serum lipase: rise within 4-8h of onset, normalize in 8-14 days (longer t1/2), normal: 10-140 U/L - Preferred for **delayed presentation > 24h** - More specific
    Diagnostic criteria (Revised Atlanta criteria):
    Fulfilment of 2 out of 3
- Clinical: typical epigastric pain
- Lab: serum amylase or lipase > 3x ULN
- Imaging findings (USG/CT/MRI)

- Imaging:
  - CXR: rule out perforation (PPU) or other DDx
  - AXR: **sentinel loop sign** (dilated bowel loop due to ileus), **colonic cut-off sign** (descending colon spasm), **obliteration of psoas outline** (retroperitoneal fluid accumulation)

[Image of abdominal X-rays demonstrating "Sentinel loops" on the left and "Colonic cut-off" on the right. The "Sentinel loops" image shows dilated loops of the small intestine. The "Colonic cut-off" image shows a sharp cut-off in the colon, indicating a possible obstruction.]

[Image of a computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen showing "Fat stranding" and "Heterogenous swelling" marked with yellow arrows. The "Fat stranding" refers to increased density in the fat surrounding the pancreas, indicating inflammation. "Heterogenous swelling" suggests uneven swelling of the pancreas due to inflammation and fluid accumulation.]

[Image of a computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen demonstrating "Peripancreatic fluid collections" marked with a yellow arrow. "Peripancreatic fluid collections" indicates areas of fluid accumulation around the pancreas, which is a common complication of pancreatitis.] - USG abdomen: signs of pancreatitis (pancreas seen in ~50% of cases: **swollen pancreas**, **peripancreatic fluid collection**), associated gallstone, cholangitis & cholecystitis - CT abdomen with contrast: gold standard, performed if - Characteristics of acute pancreatitis - Focal / Diffuse enlargement of pancreas with **heterogenous** contrast enhancement - Peripancreatic fat stranding - Necrosis - **hypoenhancement** / **gas** on contrast CT - Indications: - Diagnose severity of AP and identify complications (especially **necrosis**) - best done on 72-96h after admission, but can be earlier if organ failure - Uncertain diagnosis (DDx PPU, gangrenous cholecystitis, ischaemic bowel) - ERCP/MRCP: not routinely done as the culprit stone is usually passed, but indicated if: - Suspected biliary pancreatitis (stone found in USG, septic) - Severe (last resort)

- Scoring system to estimate severity
  - **Ranson's score (need to remember!)**: require parameters at **0h** ("GALAW") and **48h** ("CHOBBS")
    - Predicts mortality of acute pancreatitis (severe if score ≥3) - validated for alcoholic / gallstone pancreatitis only

- Ranson's Criteria

|               | 0 hours (admission) | 48 hours               |
| :------------ | :------------------ | :--------------------- | ------------------------------------------ |
| Glucose level | > 11.1 mmol/L       |                        |
| Age           | > 55                |                        |
| LDH           | > 350 U/L           |                        |
| AST           | > 250 U/L           |                        |
| WBC count     | > 16 x 10^9/L       |                        |
|               |                     | Ca^2+ level            | < 2 mmol/L (8 mg/dL)                       |
|               |                     | Hematocrit             | Fall by ≥ 10%                              |
|               |                     | Oxygen (PaO2)          | <8 kPa (60 mmHg)                           |
|               |                     | Base deficits          | > 4 MEq/L                                  |
|               |                     | BUN                    | ↑ by ≥ 1.8 mmol/L (5 mg/dL) despite fluids |
|               |                     | Sequestration of fluid | > 6000 mL                                  |

- Glasgow score: ≥ 3 out of 8 in first 48h indicate severe attack
- APACHE II: originally for critically ill, calculated on admission then daily, ≥8/71 indicate severe attack
- Balthazar CT severity index: grade of pancreatitis (0-4) + percentage of necrosis (0-6)
- CRP > 150 at 48h also predicts severe attack

Management
Mild pancreatitis: conservative

- Monitor vitals, I/O, RFT, Ca, glucose +/- ABG
- DAT / NPO + IV fluids to maintain UO > 0.5mL/kg/h (+/- NG suction if ileus / protracted vomiting)
- Correct electrolyte and glucose disturbances
- Analgesics: _tramadol/pethidine_, avoid NSAID (worsen pancreatitis) or morphine (↑sphincter of Oddi pressure)
- PPI for prophylaxis of acute stress ulcer
- Antibiotics: prophylactic Abx is **NOT** recommended – give only when
  - Concurrent **cholangitis** (e.g. LFT shows cholestatic pattern): IV Augmentin
  - Complications e.g. **necrosis** - use antibiotics that penetrate necrosis, e.g. **imipenem**
  - SIRS
- Nutritional support: **Enteral** route is preferred as long as tolerated
  - Encourage early oral feeding if mild
  - Consider NG / NJ tube: similar efficacy and safety
- Biliary pancreatitis:
  - ERCP **within 24-72h** after admission for sphincterotomy and stone extraction (alternative: PTBD to decompress biliary tract if unfit)
  - Lap **cholecystectomy** within the same hospitalisation

Severe pancreatitis:

- **Surgery** indicated if:
  - Infected pancreatic necrosis
  - Progressive clinical deterioration
- **Consult ICU** for organ support
  - GI: enteral feeding (NJ) → TPN
  - CVS: CVP, inotropes
  - Resp: intubation
  - Renal: HD
  - Measure IAP for abdominal compartment syndrome

Complications of acute pancreatitis
Local complications:

- **Pancreatic fluid collections** [refer below]
  - Acute peripancreatic fluid collection
  - Pancreatic pseudocyst
  - Acute necrotic collection
  - Walled off necrosis
- **Pancreatic pseudo-aneurysm:** erosion into artery (esp. GDA)
- **Splenic vein thrombosis:** erosion into vein
- Pancreatic exocrine insufficiency (steatorrhea & malnutrition)
- Pancreatic ascites
- Diabetes mellitus (endocrine insufficiency)

Systemic complications

- Hemodynamic instability
- Electrolyte imbalance
- Sepsis
- Multiple organ failure: ARDS, AKI, DIC

Revised Atlanta classification for pancreatic fluid collections

|           | Interstitial edematous pancreatitis (Necrosis absent)                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        | Necrotizing pancreatitis (Necrosis present)                                                                                             |
| :-------- | :------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | :-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| <4 weeks  | Acute peripancreatic fluid collection                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        | Acute necrotic collection Definition: area of non-viable pancreatic parenchyma (mix of semisolid & solid)                               |
|           | Mx: observe (resolve within 7-10 days)                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       | S/S:                                                                                                                                    |
|           |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              | - Mass effect                                                                                                                           |
|           |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              | - Infected (usually after 2 weeks): ongoing fever, worsening abdominal pain, organ failure                                              |
|           |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              | Ix: difficult to tell if its infected                                                                                                   |
|           |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              | - CT abdomen with contrast (hypodense segment +/- gas if infected, e.g. GNR)                                                            |
|           |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              | - Imaging-guided FNA x C/ST: rarely done due to risk of infection                                                                       |
|           |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              | - Procalcitonin                                                                                                                         |
|           |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              | Mx:                                                                                                                                     |
|           |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              | - Sterile: supportive                                                                                                                   |
|           |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              | - Infected: step up approach                                                                                                            |
|           |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              | - Antibiotics: imipenem / meropenem                                                                                                     |
|           |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              | - +/- Delayed drainage (4 weeks to allow walling off)                                                                                   |
|           |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              | - +/- Necrosectomy: debridement (minimally invasive method preferred, i.e. endoscopic/ percutaneous > open)                             |
| ≥ 4 weeks | Pancreatic pseudocyst Definition: collection of pancreatic fluid walled by inflammatory fibrosis (but not epithelium) with NO necrosis Risk factors: chronic pancreatitis > acute pancreatitis S/S: persistent epigastric pain, mass effect (GOO, obstructive jaundice) Ix: amylase (persistently elevated), CT abdomen with contrast (fig.) | Walled off necrosis Definition: encapsulated collection of pancreatic / peri-pancreatic necrotic material within inflammatory wall S/S: |
|           | Mx:                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          | - Mass effect: palpable mass, GOO, obstructive jaundice                                                                                 |
|           | - Watchful waiting for 6 weeks: allow wall to "mature" (thicken), 50% resolve spontaneously                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  | Ix:                                                                                                                                     |
|           | - Drainage (internal preferred) for symptomatic "mature" pseudocyst with size > 6cm, e.g. EUS-guided cystogastrostomy (CG)/CD/Roux-en-Y CJ                                                                                                                                                                                                   | - CT abdomen with contrast (well-defined wall, can be intra-pancreatic / extra-pancreatic)                                              |
|           |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              | Mx: based on symptoms, location and size                                                                                                |
|           |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              | - EUS/ERCP-guided transmural drainage +/- necrosectomy (first-line)                                                                     |
|           |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              | - Percutaneous drainage: high recurrence rate, risk of pancreatocutaneous fistula                                                       |
|           |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              | - Surgical debridement (open / lap) with external / internal drainage                                                                   |

Chronic pancreatitis
Difficult to distinguish from CA pancreas!
Aetiology

- Alcoholism (60%)
- Idiopathic (30%)
- Autoimmune: autoimmune pancreatitis (IgG4-related disease), SLE
- Obstruction: neoplasm, stricture
  Pathophysiology
- Chronic inflammation / Recurrent acute inflammation → Diffuse scarring of pancreatic duct →
- Pancreatic fluid changes composition and facilitates deposition of CaCO3 stones → diffuse pancreatic
  calcification
- Exocrine insufficiency, then endocrine insufficiency (islet of Langerhans more resistant to injury)
  Clinical features
- Local inflammation: recurrent epigastric pain radiating to back;
  painless in 10% (burnt-out pancreas)
- Exocrine insufficiency (<10% exocrine function when it is clinically
  significant): steatorrhea, malnutrition, clotting dysfunction,
  osteoporosis (fat-soluble vitamin deficiency)
- Endocrine insufficiency: T1DM
- Complications: pancreatic pseudocyst, CBD obstruction, pancreatic
  ascites, splenic v. thrombosis, CA pancreas (2%)
  Investigations
- Bloods: ↑glucose; normal amylase & lipase (burnt-out pancreas)
- Stool: Jelastase, chymotrypsin
- Imaging:
  - AXR: pancreatic calcifications at pyloric plane
  - CT: calcification, dilated pancreatic ducts, pseudocyst
  - ERCP: "chain of lakes" appearance (ductal narrowing &
    dilation); can be combined with IV secretin for better view of
    stricture (stimulate production of bicarbonate-rich fluid)
  - MRCP: emerging modality

Classical triad (only seen in
late stage):

1. Pancreatic calcification
2. Steatorrhoea
3. Diabetes mellitus

Test for pancreatic function (if imaging normal): OGTT & HbA1c, 72h fecal fat, secretin stimulation test (rare)

- CA 19-9 and CEA: rule out CA pancreas

Management: mainly medical

- General: - Total abstinence from alcohol and smoking - Narcotics: pain difficult to control → refer to pain specialist - Pancreatic enzyme replacement + fat restriction: Creon + insulin (note risk of hypoglycaemia due to
  glucagon deficiency)
- ERCP for pancreatic sphincterotomy, stenting, stone retrieval, drainage of pseudocyst
- Surgical: to relieve obstruction and remove mass lesions, preserving pancreatic tissues whenever possible - Longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy (Puestow
  procedure) - Frey procedure (part of head resected) - Beger procedure (duodenum-preserving
  pancreatic head resection) - Resection of tail/ head/ entire pancreas if dysplasia
