# Pancreatic cyst

Definitions

- Collections of fluid that form within the pancreas
- True cysts (non-inflammatory) or pseudocyst (inflammatory)

Subtypes of true cysts

- High risk of malignancy: mucinous cysts, e.g. intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm, cystic pancreatic neuroendocrine tumour (associated with MEN1 syndrome)
- Low risk of malignancy: serous cysts, e.g. simple cyst, serous cystic adenoma

| Cystic neoplasms                               | Malignant potential | Management                                                                                                                                                                     |
| ---------------------------------------------- | ------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
| Intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN) | Yes                 | Pancreatic head in old men. Two types: - **Main duct**: resection - **Branch duct**: observe (e.g. Qly MRCP) unless high risk stigmata (e.g. >4cm, nodules within cystic wall) |
| Mucinous cystic neoplasm (MCN)                 | Yes                 | Pancreatic body/tail in _perimenopausal_ women. Similar to IPMN, but have ovarian-type stroma.                                                                                 |
| Serous cystic neoplasm (SCN)                   | No                  | Found in older women. Resection not required.                                                                                                                                  |
| Solid pseudopapillary tumor                    | Yes                 |                                                                                                                                                                                |

Clinical features

- Mostly asymptomatic
- Epigastric pain radiating to back, obstructive jaundice, fever
- Infected cysts: fever
- Malignant transformation: constitutional symptoms

Investigations

- CA 19-9: for monitoring disease progression
- Imaging: CT abdomen → EUS if equivocal findings/ low risk
  - Low risk features: cyst diameter < 3cm, cystic morphology with central calcification
  - High risk features: cyst diameter >3cm, enhancing solid component, main pancreatic duct dilatation > 10mm, pancreatic tail atrophy, lymphadenopathy
- Diagnostic: resection for pathology or EUS-FNA
  - Fluid for CEA (mucin-secreting cyst) & amylase (pseudocyst)

Management

- Low risk: surveillance Q5y
- High risk: surgical resection, then MRI Q2y for surveillance

# Pancreatic carcinoma

Types

- Ductal adenocarcinoma (90%)
- Cystic tumours, ampullary cell tumours, islet cell tumours: much better prognosis
- Metastasis: from RCC (MC), lung, breast

Sites: head (60%), body (15%), tail (5%), diffuse (20%)

Risk factors

- Smoking (3x risk)
- DM, chronic pancreatitis
- FHx
- Pre-malignant conditions e.g. pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN)
- Hereditary cancer syndromes e.g. Lynch

[Image of the number 146, likely representing a page number]

Clinical features

- **Painless progressive obstructive jaundice** (tumor at head)
- **Severe epigastric pain radiating to the back** (tumor at body/tail: retroperitoneal infiltration)
- Constitutional symptoms
- Symptoms of pancreatic insufficiency: e.g. steatorrhoea, maldigestion, malabsorption, new onset DM
- Acute pancreatitis / GOO
- Signs of metastasis: liver, peritoneum, lung, bone
- Paraneoplastic manifestations
  - Trousseau syndrome: hypercoagulable state → migratory superficial thrombophlebitis
  - Paraneoplastic pemphigoid

Investigations

- Bloods: CBC, clotting, LFT (cholestatic pattern), RFT, glucose, amylase, lipase
- Tumor markers:
  - CA19.9 (raised in 80%): prognostic marker + monitoring after Tx
    - Low diagnostic value: not sensitive, not specific
    - Other causes: HCC, cholangioCA, CA gallbladder, chronic pancreatitis, cholangitis
  - CEA (raised in 30-60%)
- Imaging:
  - USG (dilated bile ducts)
  - CT abdomen with contrast (pancreatic protocol) – thin-sliced triphasic (arterial + pancreatic + portovenous phases)
    - Double duct sign: dilated pancreatic duct + CBD
    - Hypoattentuating mass within pancreas
    - Determine resectability: encasement of **SMA**, hepatic artery, celiac trunk, SMV, PV
  - +/- MRCP: delineate anatomy of biliary tree
- Tissue diagnosis: **NOT** mandatory if potentially resectable - only required if CT failed to demonstrate typical features, before chemotherapy, or suspected 2º mets to pancreas
  - EUS-guided FNAC/biopsy preferred over percutaneous USG/CT-guided biopsy (↑risk of tumor seeding)
  - ERCP brush cytology / biopsy: can also relieve jaundice by placing temporary stent
- Staging:
  - CT T+A+P or PET/CT
  - Intra-op laparoscopy (peritoneal metastasis often missed in imaging)

TNM staging

- Resectable: stage 0 - IIB
- Unresectable: stage III (T4) & IV
  - Stage III: longer survival, more beneficial from systemic therapy
  - Stage IV: shorter survival, less beneficial from systemic therapy

Curative treatment
Principle: Upfront pancreatectomy (+ local lymphadenectomy) + adjuvant chemotherapy (all cases) +/- RT

Resectability: require CT abdomen with pancreas protocol +/- EUS +/- staging laparoscopy

- Absolute contraindications
  - SMA/ celiac trunk encasement >180°
    - Tumor contact <180° relative C/I: may be still borderline resectable
  - Unreconstructible SMV / portal vein due to tumour involvement or thrombus
    - Still borderline resectable if suitable vessel proximal and distal to involved site for interposition graft reconstruction
  - Distant metastasis

[Image Description: This is a transverse section of a computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen. The liver is seen as a large, homogenous structure. The gallbladder is a dark, teardrop-shaped structure in the upper right quadrant. The pancreas appears as a lobulated structure. The spleen is seen as a crescent-shaped structure.]

Options of pancreatic resection reviewed below:
Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple's operation)

- Indications: CA head of pancreas (and other periampullary tumours)
- Types:
  - Pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy (PPPD): standard - preserve gastric antrum, pylorus and proximal 3-6cm of duodenum
  - Conventional Whipple operation: only when entire duodenum has to be removed (e.g. FAP), or when PPPD would not achieve a clear resection margin (tumour encroaches on D1 or distal stomach)
  - PPPD vs conventional Whipple
    - No difference in survival or recurrence rates
    - Less blood loss and shorter operation time
    - Lower rate of post-op dumping syndrome (UTD: similar rate of delayed gastric emptying)
    - Lower rate of marginal ulcer (mucosal erosion at GJ)
    - Lower rate of bile reflux gastritis (difficult to manage)
- Pre-op preparation
  - Top up nutrition, correct electrolyte abnormalities, T&S
  - Pre-op ERCP x biliary drainage: NOT routine, only if septic / OT cannot be arranged in 1-2 weeks
    - Plastic stent is preferred: c.f. metal stent would induce inflammation → difficult removal in OT
- Surgical procedure: exploration → resection → reconstruction
  - Staging laparoscopy: rule out peritoneal metastasis and liver metastasis (intra-op USG)
  - Kocher maneuver: mobilize duodenum to expose retroperitoneal structures
  - Cholecystectomy + dissection of liver hilum (e.g. hepatic a. proper, GDA, CBD)
  - Mobilize relevant structures (e.g. distal stomach, right colon, SMV)
  - Resection of head of pancreas + duodenum + jejunum for ≥15cm distal to ligament of Treitz
  - Upper margin:
    - Pylorus-preserving (PPPD): up to 2-3cm distal to pylorus
    - Conventional Whipple: truncal vagotomy + antrectomy
  - Local lymphadenectomy: LN around SMA, para-aortic LN - take at least **12 LN** for accurate staging
  - Roux-en-Y reconstruction + **triple anastomoses** (in the following order):
    - Pancreaticojejunostomy (PJ)
    - choledochojejunostomy (CJ)
    - gastrojejunostomy (GJ) / duodenuojejunostomy (DJ)

[Illustration showing two surgical procedures. The first image, labeled "A", depicts a classic pancreaticoduodenectomy (Kausch-Whipple), where a tumor is located in the head of the pancreas near the portal vein. The second image, labeled "B", showcases the surgical outcome after the procedure. Below the illustration are detailed diagrams. One diagram illustrates the resection of the head of the pancreas in a pylorus-preserving pancreatoduodenectomy, highlighting the pancreatic duct, jejunum, body and tail of the pancreas, and the superior mesenteric artery and vein. The other diagram shows reconstruction after a pylorus-preserving pancreatoduodenectomy, detailing the liver, bile duct, choledochojejunostomy, pancreaticojejunostomy, jejunum, pylorus, and duodenum.]

- Specific complications
  - Early: anastomotic leak
    - Risk: PJ (30%, due to digestive enzyme + small and soft duct) > CJ > GJ
    - Severe PJ leak: may require distal pancreatectomy
    - Pancreatic fistula and Cx (e.g. GDA pseudoaneurysm, splenic v. thrombosis) (see below)
    - Somatostatin analogue (e.g. octreotide) does NOT reduce risk
  - Late:
    - Delayed gastric emptying (PPPD) or dumping syndrome (Whipple)
      - Mechanisms of DGE in PPPD: Injury to nerve of Laterjet, disrupted pacemaker cells, reduced
        CCK (high concentration found in duodenum)
    - Pancreatic insufficiency: new-onset DM (16%)
- Distal pancreatectomy + splenectomy
  - Indications: body/ tail disease
  - Procedure: resection of pancreas lateral to SMV + splenectomy + local lymphadenectomy
  - Post-splenectomy: vaccination for encapsulated organisms
  - Complications: higher anastomotic leak c.f. Whipple's
- Total pancreatectomy
  - Indications: multifocal tumor (e.g. main duct IPMN), or when body/ tail of pancreas is too inflamed to achieve a
    safe anastomosis with bowel
- Adjuvant chemotherapy
  - Indications: ALL resected CA pancreas
  - Start within 12 weeks post-op
    - FOLFIRINOX (folinic acid, 5-FU, irinotecan, oxaliplatin)
    - Gemcitabine + capecitabine x 6 months
- Palliative treatment
  - Tumor found unresectable during laparotomy: double bypass surgery
    - Gastric bypass: gastroenterostomy (relieve duodenal obstruction)
    - Biliary bypass: choledochoenterostomy (relieve jaundice)
    - Obtain transduodenal trucut biopsy +/- celiac plexus block
  - Tumor found unresectable on imaging: ERCP stenting (PTBD if unfit) + systemic chemotherapy
    - Stenting (SEMS preferred): biliary stent and/or duodenal stent
    - Chemotherapy: first obtain EUS-guided biopsy for tissue diagnosis (DDx: lymphoma)
      - FOLFIRINOX (folinic acid, 5-FU, irinotecan, oxaliplatin)
  - Symptomatic relief
    - Pain control: analgesics (e.g. opioids), celiac plexus block, short course RT
    - Exocrine insufficiency: enzyme replacement
    - Endocrine insufficiency: OHA / insulin
- Pancreatic fistula
  Definition: Abnormal connection between the pancreas and adjacent structures
- Post-op fistula: drain output of any volume after post-op D3 with a drain amylase level > 3xULN
  Risk factors: high BMI, soft pancreas, narrow duct
  Aetiology
- Iatrogenic: pancreatic resection, percutaneous drainage of pancreatic pseudocyst
- Non-iatrogenic: acute/ chronic pancreatitis
  Classification by International Study Group of Pancreatic Fistula (ISGPF)
- Biochemical leak: drain amylase > 3xULN but asymptomatic
- Grade B: persistent drainage >3 weeks, requiring change in Mx, signs of infection but no organ failure
- Grade C: unstable, require re-operation, risk of organ failure

Pathogenesis & clinical features
Partial disruption of pancreatic duct → leak of pancreatic juice →

- Pseudocyst
- High output fistula: dehydration, malnutrition, metabolic acidosis (as loss of HCO3 in pancreatic juice)
- Artery: GDA pseudoaneurysm → intraabdominal haemorrhage / UGIB
- Vein: portal vein thrombosis, splenic vein thrombosis
- Peritoneal cavity: pancreatic ascites

Investigations: CT abdomen
Management

- Conservative management
  - Biochemical leak:
    - Maintain oral feeding
    - Drain in situ for 3 weeks
  - Symptomatic pancreatic fistula:
    - NPO, NJ feeding
    - Correct fluid & electrolyte disturbance
    - Drain in situ
    - Antibiotic prophylaxis
    - Somatostatin analogue
- Management if persistent leak or symptomatic despite conservative
  - Endoscopic: transpapillary stent placement
  - Surgical repair (if Grade C)
  - Embolization for bleeding

Methods to reduce PJ leakage:
Only proven method: **high volume center** with
high case load
Possible options explored:

- Octreotide
- Prophylactic stenting
- Blumgard technique: duct-to-mucosa
  anastomosis
- Small bowel invagination

Periampullary malignancy
Definitions: tumours that arise within 2cm of ampulla of Vater

- All require Whipple's procedure as curative treatment

| Tumours                          | Important features                                                       |
| -------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
| CA head of pancreas              | Dull aching pain radiating to the back                                   |
|                                  | New-onset DM                                                             |
| Cholangiocarcinoma of distal CBD | Elderly                                                                  |
| Periampullary duodenum carcinoma | Rare, except in FAP                                                      |
|                                  | **Thomas' sign:** silver stool due to obstructive jaundice (white stool) |
|                                  | + melena (ulceration of tumour)                                          |
| Ampulla of Vater carcinoma       | Jaundice, fat malabsorption                                              |

5.9 Diseases of spleen
Vascular supply

- Splenic artery (from CT)
- Short gastric artery (from splenic artery)
  Splenic infarct
- Definitions: occlusion of splenic artery or one of its branches
- Aetiology
  - Haematological disorders (e.g. leukaemia): by congestion of splenic circulation by abnormal cells, anaemia & splenomegaly
  - Embolic disorders (e.g. AF)
- Clinical features
  - LUQ pain radiating to shoulder (Kehr's sign)
  - Fever, n/v, pleuritic chest pain
- Investigations - CT abdomen with contrast: segmented wedge of hypoattenuated tissue (fig.)
  [Abdominal CT Scan showing a axial slice on the left and a coronal slice on the right, with an asterisk denoting the spleen on both images.]
- Management - Treat underlying cause - Splenectomy if: - Persisting symptoms - Complications develop: - Splenic rupture - Splenic abscess: if embolus non-sterile (e.g. IE); Dx CT abdomen with contrast - Auto-splenectomy: repeated infarction causes progressive atrophy of spleen
  Splenic rupture
- Aetiology:
  - Abdominal trauma: seat-belt injury, fall onto left side
  - Stretched splenomegaly: haematological disorders, EBV infection
- Clinical features
  - Can present late -delayed rupture
  - Kehr's sign
  - Hypovolemic shock (spleen as extremely vascular organ)
  - Triad of LLL atelectasis, elevated left hemidiaphragm, left pleural effusion
- Management - Haemodynamically unstable: urgent laparotomy - Haemodynamically stable: CT thorax-abdomen-pelvis with contrast for AAST splenic injury scale (grade I - V) - Grade V: urgent laparotomy - Grade I-III: conservative management (strict bed rest, repeat CT scan in 1 week, prophylactic vaccinations)
  [Diagram illustrating different grades of splenic injury based on depth and surface area involvement, with descriptions of lacerations, haematomas, and vascular injuries for each grade, ranging from Grade I (minor) to Grade V (shattered spleen).]

---

Splenectomy
Indications

- Trauma (accident, operative)
- **Oncological**: part of en bloc resection (radical gastrectomy, distal/ total pancreatectomy)
- **Haematological (hypersplenism)**: ITP (+/- Evan's syndrome), PMF, spherocytosis
- Portal hypertension: variceal surgery
  Pre-op preparations
- Antibiotic prophylaxis (clean if elective, dirty if traumatic)
- Optimised clotting profile and platelet
- Vaccination: >2 weeks pre-op if elective, ASAP if urgent
  Specific complications
- Immediate:
  - Bleeding: slipped ligature, haematemesis from gastric mucosal damage
  - Injury to surrounding structures: pleural effusion, left basal atelectasis, stomach, pancreas (abscess, fistula)
- Early:
  - Post-op thrombocytosis: prophylactic aspirin if platelet > 1000
  - Post-splenectomy septicaemia:
    - Risk factors: young, immunocompromised
    - Pathogens: Strep pneumoniae, N meningitidis, H influenzae
- Late: overwhelming post-splenectomy infection (OPSI)
  - Patho: asplenic patients unable to mount immunological response against encapsulated organisms
    - Some Nasty Killers Have Some Capsule Protection
      - _Streptococcus pneumoniae_
      - _Neisseria meningitidis_
      - _Klebsiella pneumoniae_
      - _Haemophilus influenzae_
      - _Salmonella typhi_
      - _Cryptococcus neoformans_
      - _Pseudomonas aeruginosa_
  - Prevention:
    - Vaccination: PCV13 + PPSV23 (repeat Q5y), Hib vaccine, meningococcal ACWY vaccine, Flu
    - Penicillin V prophylaxis: not required in adults

6 Hernia

6.1 Anatomy
Anterior abdominal wall
Layers: skin, Camper's fascia, Scarpa fascia, EO, IO, TA, extra-
peritoneal fat, parietal peritoneum

Rectus sheath

- Interlaced aponeuroses of ext. oblique, int. oblique &
  transversus abdominis
- Contents:
  - Rectus abdominis & pyramidalis
  - SMA, SMV, IMA, IMV, lymphatics
  - Thoraco-abdominal n. and subcostal n.
- Arcuate line: 1/3 distance from umbilicus to pubic crest
- Above arcuate line (5cm below umbilicus): rectus sheath encloses
  rectus abdominis
- Below arcuate line: rectus sheath covers rectus abdominis anteriorly →
  transversalis fascia is the only layer between rectus abdominis and
  peritoneum

Inguinal canal

- Contents of inguinal canal
  - Spermatic cord (or round ligament in F)
  - Ilioinguinal nerve
- Deep inguinal ring: 1cm above midpoint of
  inguinal ligament (halfway between PT and ASIS),
  lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels
- Superficial inguinal ring: just superolateral to PT
- Mid-pt of inguinal ligament vs mid-inguinal point
  - Midpoint of inguinal ligament (PT-ASIS):
    deep inguinal ring is 1cm above
  - Mid-inguinal point (PS-ASIS): femoral pulse
- Myopectineal orifice of Fruchard: weak point

[Diagram of the abdominal wall showing layers, Above Arcuate Line, Below Arcuate Line, Roof, Anterior wall, Posterior wall, Pubis bone, Floor]

[Table with 4 rows and 2 columns describing each side of the abdominal wall: Anterior, Posterior, Roof, Floor. Each row contains the following:]

[Row 1: Anterior - External oblique aponeurosis]
[Row 2: Posterior - Lateral 1/3: lower fibres of internal oblique, Transversalis fascia, Medially: conjoint tendon (merging pubic attachment of internal oblique and transversus abdominis aponeurosis)]
[Row 3: Roof - Central: conjoint tendon, Lateral: transversallis fascia, Medial: medial crus and inter-crural fibres, Central: superior surface of inguinal ligament]
[Row 4: Floor - Lateral: iliopubic tract, Medial: lacunar ligament]

Spermatic cord
3 layers: TA does not contribute

- External spermatic fascia (from EO)
- Cremasteric fascia and muscle (from IO)
- Internal spermatic fascia (from TF)

3 arteries

- Testicular artery (from aorta)
- Cremasteric artery (from inferior epigastric)
- Artery to vas deferens (from inferior vesicular)

3 nerves

- Ilioinguinal nerve (L1) (enter laterally into inguinal
  canal) - NOT inside spermatic cord
- Genital branch of genitofemoral (L1): for cremasteric
  reflex
- Autonomic nerves (T10)

3 other structures

- Vas deferens
- Lymphatics (drain testis to para-aortic LN)
- Pampiniform plexus of veins (drain right testis into IVC, left
  testis into renal vein)

# Hesselbach triangle

- Landmark for **direct** inguinal hernia
- Boundaries
  - Medial: Lateral border of rectus abdominis
  - Lateral: Inferior epigastric vessels
  - Inferior: Inguinal ligament

# Triangles of doom and pain

Triangle of pain (lateral)

- Boundaries
  - Superolateral: iliopubic tract
  - Inferomedial: **gonadal vessels**
- Contents
  - Lateral femoral cutaneous n. of thigh
  - Femoral n.
  - Femoral branch of genitofemoral n.
- Significance: **damage / entrapment** during lap repair → motor and sensory impairment

Triangle of doom (medial)

- Boundaries
  - Apex: deep ring
  - Medial: **vas deferens**
  - Lateral: **gonadal vessels**
- Contents
  - **External iliac vessels**
  - Deep circumflex iliac vein
  - Genital branch of genitofemoral n.
  - Femoral nerve (hidden by fascia)
- Significance: damage to external iliac vessels during lap repair → **massive bleeding**

# Femoral triangle and femoral canal

Femoral triangle

- Boundaries
  - Medial: adductor longus
  - Lateral: sartorius
  - Superior: inguinal lig.
- Contents: NAVEL
  - Femoral Nerve
  - Femoral Artery
  - Femoral Vein
  - Empty space (femoral canal)
  - Lymph nodes

[Image of the femoral triangle anatomy showing the femoral nerve, femoral canal, femoral sheath, and great saphenous vein.]

Femoral canal

- Boundaries
  - Anterior: inguinal ligament
  - Posterior: pectineal (Cooper's) ligament
  - Medial: lacunar ligament
  - Lateral: femoral vein
- Significance of femoral canal
  - Contain deep inguinal node of Cloquet
  - drain penis/ clitoris
  - Narrow dead space where femoral hernia can occur

[Image of a cross-sectional view of the femoral canal with color-coded labels for the femoral canal, inguinal ligament, pectineus, femoral vein, and lacunar ligament.]

6.2 Overview
Definitions

- **Hernia:** protrusion of an organ (or part of organ) through the wall of its containing cavity
- **Reducible:** ability to return the displaced hernia contents to their usual anatomic site
- **Incarcerated:** no IO - 'imprisoned' - swollen or fixed within the hernia sac so that it cannot be replaced into abdomen
- **Obstructed:** IO - loop of bowel trapped in hernia sac such that its lumen (but not blood supply) is obstructed (closed-loop IO)
- **Strangulated:** IO with ischemia (blood supply also affected), impending gangrene - Incidence: femoral > indirect inguinal > direct inguinal - **Richter's hernia:** incarcerated hernia involving only one sidewall of bowel, causing ischaemia but not obstruction - **Reduction-en-masse:** apparently "reducing" the sac but did not push the contents out of the sac → still strangulated
  Risk factors
- **Male**
- Weakened abdominal muscles: **aging**, **trauma**
- **Increased intra-abdominal pressure:** chronic cough, heavy lifting, chronic constipation, straining urine (BPH), pregnancy, ascites
- Congenital: patent processus vaginalis

Types of hernia: inguinal > incisional > femoral > others

|          |                                         |                                                                                                                                  |
| :------- | :-------------------------------------- | :------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Internal | Hiatus hernia                           | Hernia through oesophageal hiatus                                                                                                |
| External | Inguinal (78%)                          | Indirect (80%): lateral to inferior epigastric vessels                                                                           |
|          |                                         | Direct (20%): medial to inferior epigastric vessels at Hasselbach triangle                                                       |
|          |                                         | Pantaloon (concurrent direct + indirect hernia) → straddle inf. epigastric vessels                                               |
|          | Femoral (7%)                            | Femoral canal                                                                                                                    |
|          | Umbilical                               | Umbilical ring                                                                                                                   |
|          | Epigastric                              | Linea alba above umbilicus via aponeurotic intersections (only contain preperitoneal fat) Occur in middle-aged men after lifting |
|          | Divarication of recti (Diastasis recti) | Linea alba stretches laterally due to overweight or pregnancy Exacerbated by looking at toe                                      |
|          | Paraumbilical                           | Linea alba around umbilicus                                                                                                      |
|          | Spigelian                               | Linea semilunaris                                                                                                                |
|          | Superior lumbar (Grynfeltt's)           | Superior lumbar triangle: rib 12, inferior oblique, quadratus lumborum                                                           |
|          | Inferior lumbar (Petit's)               | Inferior lumbar triangle: LD, external oblique, iliac crest                                                                      |

DDx of groin lump (L SHAPE)

- Lymph nodes
- Saphenous varix
- Hernia (inguinal / femoral)
- Aneurysm (femoral a.)
- Psoas abscess
- Ectopic testis
- Lipoma / sebaceous cyst
- Transplanted kidney

6.3 Inguinal hernia

|                          | Direct                                                          | Indirect                                                                                                                                 |
| ------------------------ | --------------------------------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Proportion               | 20%, older male                                                 | 80%, younger male                                                                                                                        |
| Site of protrusion       | Medial to inferior epigastric vessels (**Hesselbach triangle**) | Lateral to inferior epigastric vessels                                                                                                   |
| Deep ring occlusion test | Not controlled                                                  | **Controlled**                                                                                                                           |
| Course                   | Traverse medial 1/3 of canal                                    | Traverse entire inguinal canal                                                                                                           |
| Descend into scrotum     | NO (rarely)                                                     | **YES**                                                                                                                                  |
| Aetiology                | Acquired (weakened abdominal wall, e.g. in elderly)             | Congenital (incomplete closure of processus vaginalis, i.e. young) Acquired (peritoneum pushed via deep ring, forming a sac, in elderly) |
| Strangulation            | Less common: broad base                                         | More common (esp. deep ring)                                                                                                             |

Clinical features

- Lump in groin (2/3 on right side): cough impulse + reducibility
  - Differentiate from scrotal mass (palpate lower border)
- Incarcerated hernia: painful, tender, erythematous
- Obstructed hernia: features of IO
- Associated features: examine abdomen, chest (COPD), PR (BPH)
- Content: small bowel (MC), omentum, ascending colon
  Investigations
- Clinical diagnosis
- USG: if diagnosis uncertain (esp. irreducible) / post-op for hematoma

Management
Conservative: _watchful waiting_, indicated if asymptomatic inguinal hernia / not fit
for surgery

- Lifestyle modification: weight reduction, change job nature, quit smoking
- Manage underlying medical conditions
- Abdominal truss (fig.): not effective

[Image of Maydl's hernia is shown. Two adjacent loops of bowel are in the sac. The intervening portion in the abdomen is the first to suffer if the neck of the sac is tight, because it is the centre of the whole loop involved. The strangulated piece is intra-abdominal. This is a rare variety of strangulation.]

[Image of Sliding hernia is shown. If bowel which is normally extra-peritoneal forms one side of the sac, it is thought to have slid down the canal pulling peritoneum with it, hence the name hemi-englasade. The sac can contain other loops of bowel, and the gut forming the wall of the sac can be strangled by the external ring.]

[Image of Abdominal truss is shown. The person is wearing it around their waist with straps going down their groin to hold two padded supports. ]

Surgery: mesh repair

- Indications of hernia repair:
  - Irreducible / Complicated inguinal hernia (IO/incarceration/strangulation)
  - Symptomatic inguinal hernia (e.g. groin pain, ADL impairment, difficulty in reduction)
  - All cases of femoral hernia
- Principles:
  - Reduction of hernia content +/- removal of non-viable tissues and repair bowels
  - Excision and closure of peritoneal sac
  - Re-approximate walls of neck of hernia
  - Reinforce abdominal wall defect with sutures or mesh
- Mesh: Prosthetic material to strengthen hernia repair
  - Lower recurrence rate, reduce post-op groin pain, faster recovery
  - Types:
    - Synthetic: polypropylene, PTFE (polytetrafluoroethylene)
    - Biological: sterilized decellularized connective tissue, eventually broken down
  - Positioning: open allows all, lap only allows sublay
    - On-lay: subcutaneous
    - In-lay: plugged within the defect - risk of migrate and "meshoma"
    - Sub-lay: extraperitoneally
  - May be difficult if complicated hernia (infected / edematous) → use non-mesh repair

| Approach    | Open                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   | Laparoscopic                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               |
| ----------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
|             | Tension-free mesh repair (Lichtenstein) [Image of Surgical illustration of a Lichtenstein tension-free mesh repair. The illustration depicts an open surgical field with instruments holding tissue. A patch of mesh is positioned over the inguinal area. The illustration includes anatomical details such as the inguinal nerve and blood vessels.] | Total extra-peritoneal approach (TEP): pre-peritoneal space less adhesions, large mesh possible C/I if prior lower abdominal surgery; technically more challenging (limited working space) Trans-abdominal pre-peritoneal repair (TAPP): enter peritoneal space : larger working space, lower risk to convert open : intraabdominal adhesions, injury to organs [Image of A comparative diagram illustrating laparoscopic operations TEP (Total Extraperitoneal Repair) and TAPP (Transabdominal Preperitoneal Repair). On the left is the TEP operation, where the pre-peritoneal space is accessed without entering the peritoneal cavity. On the right is the TAPP operation, where entry into the peritoneal cavity is necessary before accessing the pre-peritoneal space. Arrows and annotations indicate the surgical steps and anatomical differences between the two procedures. "Pre-peritoneal space" and "Abdomen" are written as annotations in the diagram.] |
|             | Non-mesh techniques: more recurrence, indicated if active infection / bowel perforation Shouldice repair: division and reconstruction of inguinal canal with 4-layer overlap Bassini repair: suture conjoint tendon to inguinal ligament                                                                                                               |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            |
| Anaesthesia | LA: ilioinguinal & iliohypogastric n. (or SA/GA)                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       | GA                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         |
| Indications | 1st occurrence Complicated hernia (emergency) Previous lap repair Previous pelvic / lower abdominal midline surgery (adhesions - not fit for TEP) Ascites Not fit for GA                                                                                                                                                                               | Recurrent or bilateral hernia Recurrent: increased adhesions after 1st open repair Bilateral: single port placement for both hernias, allow exploration of contralateral groin if suspected hernia                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         |

158
Advantages
No need GA
Shorter operating time
Quicker recovery, shorter hospital stay
Fewer complications, better cosmetics
Less chronic pain (performed at a deeper level
away from the 3 nerves: ilioinguinal,
iliohypogastric, genital branch of genitofemoral)
Disadvantage Only 1 side (limited by LA max dose)
Higher risk of recurrence
Terminology

- **Herniotomy:** excision of hernia sac without repair, only used in children
- **Herniorrhaphy:** excision + repair of hernia sac + reinforcement of posterior wall of inguinal canal _without mesh_
- **Hernioplasty:** excision + repair + reinforcement of posterior wall of inguinal canal _with mesh_
  - "Tension free": mesh is used to cover the defect, avoiding muscle fibre distortion that increases tension
  - Mesh used: macroporous polypropylene - large pores allow permeation of new blood vessels and
    inflammatory cells such as fibroblasts - essential for creating strong repair

Specific complications
Immediate

- Damage to _vas deferens_ / _ilioinguinal nerve_
- AROU
- Injury to surrounding organs during pneumoperitoneum: bladder, bowels, vascular
- LA: femoral nerve blockade → unilateral LL weakness (usually resolve ~12h)
  Early
- Wound infection: require empirical antibiotics +/- drainage +/- EOT to debride and remove mesh
- **Mesh complications:** infection, migration, erosion, shrinkage
- Seroma (excessive inflammatory response to mesh/ sutures → fluid collection): resolve later, no
  need to aspirate unless infected
- Hematoma
- Testicular infarction (damage to testicular artery)
  Late
- **Chronic pain >3mo** after surgery: injury to nerves (iliohypogastric / ilioinguinal / genitofemoral /
  lat. cutaneous n. of thigh)
- **Hernia recurrence**
- Sexual dysfunction
- Ischemic orchitis / Testicular atrophy due to pampiniform plexus thrombosis
- Adhesions / Internal herniation through peritoneal defect (lap TAPP)

Post-op recovery

- **Early mobilisation**
- Hygiene: allow bathing immediately post-op, keep area clean
- Resume light activities 1-2 weeks post-op, but avoid heavy lifting or vigorous exercise until **6 weeks** post-op
- Avoid predisposing factors: treat chronic cough, give laxatives for constipation

  6.4 Incisional hernia
  Definition:

- Extrusion of abdominal content through a weak scar or accidental wound on abdominal wall
- Partial wound dehiscence (skin remains intact)
  Physical examination:
- Define **fascial defect** by tilting head up to look at toes
- Percuss for content (dull omentum vs resonant bowel)
  Risk factors
- Patient factors: age, obesity, immunocompromised
- Local factors: infection, haematoma, chemo/ RT
- Surgeon factors: poor surgical technique **(tension)**, placing drains through wounds, emergency/prolonged OT
  Complications:
- Intermittent obstruction, incarceration/strangulation
- Enterocutaneous fistula (skin excoriation)

159

Management
Conservative: lifestyle modification, treat medical conditions, **truss**

- Indicated if: high anaesthetic risk, concurrent medical problems, risk of infection/dehiscence/hematoma
  Surgical repair (open / lap): Indicated if **symptomatic** / **risk of strangulation**
- Dissect hernia sac and surrounding tissues ≥3cm on all sides
- Reduce hernia contents and repair fascial defect
  - Defects <1cm: **Mayo repair** (fascial edge repaired with 2cm overlap, use interrupted + continuous sutures)
  - Defects >1cm: **tension-free mesh repair**
    - Allow 5-8cm adequate overlapping over normal tissues for mesh shrinkage / contraction in ALL directions
  - Approach (fig.): _sublay_ has lowest recurrence rate

|       | Laparoscopic                                                                                          | Open                                                                                                           |
| :---- | :---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | :------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Layer | Underlay (intraperitoneal), i.e. dual layer mesh (outer layer induces fibrosis, inner layer does not) | Sublay (preperitoneal): between rectus muscle and posterior rectus sheath                                      |
| Role  | ↓Pain, recovery Smaller wound, infection rate                                                         | Emergency Large hernia > 10cm (possibility of "sister hernia": occurrence of hernia elsewhere in the incision) |

6.5 Umbilical hernia
Definition:

- True umbilical hernia: Defect through _linea alba_ (union of rectus sheath) through umbilical scar
- Para-umbilical hernia: Defect through side of umbilical scar (higher risk of strangulation)
  Management:
- Congenital: repair if **symptomatic**
- Acquired: always consider surgery (small defect: Mayo repair; large defect: _sublay_ extra-peritoneal mesh)

  6.6 Femoral hernia
  Risk factors

- **Obese women**: wider pelvis and thus wider femoral canal
  Content of hernia sac
- Omentum
- Knuckle of small bowel (Richter's hernia)
  Clinical features
- **High risk of strangulation** - _all_ femoral hernia should be treated surgically
- Cough impulse can be absent - tight neck of hernia sac → rapidly irreducible
  Investigations
- Groin USG: to differentiate from inguinal hernia (conservative management may be a treatment option)
  Management
- Open repair:
  - Low approach (Lockwood's): infrainguinal approach
    - Preferred in _elective_ settings under LA if no risk of bowel strangulation
    - Direct incision over hernia → reduce content → close femoral ring by non-absorbable sutures
    - Need to protect femoral vein
  - Inguinal approach (Lotheissen's):
    - Incision into inguinal canal → mobilize spermatic cord (round lig.) → open transversalis fascia (femoral hernia is below this) → reduce hernia and repair the defect
  - High approach (McEvedy's): suprainguinal approach
    - Preferred in _emergency_ under SA/GA - easier access to strangulated small bowel
    - Incision at lower abdomen → expose pre-peritoneal space → close femoral defect
- Laparoscopic repair (usually elective cases): TEP, TAPP

Each diagram shows a cross-sectional view of the abdominal wall with different layers labeled, including "anterior rectus sheath," "rectus abdominis muscle," "posterior rectus sheath," "transversalis fascia/peritoneum," "Onlay," "Sublay," "Underlay," and "Inlay." These diagrams illustrate different mesh placement techniques in hernia repair. Below the diagrams, there is an illustration of the inguinal region, showing various anatomical structures. Labels include "Incision through linea semilunaris," "Inguinal ligament," "(C) High approach of McEvedy," "(B) Transinguinal approach of Lotheissen," "Femoral canal," "Superficial ring," "Spermatic cord," and "Low approach of Lockwood."]

7.1 Aneurysm
Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)
Definitions

- Aneurysm: pathological, localized and permanent dilatation of blood vessels by ≥50% of normal diameter
  - True aneurysm: wall is formed by all 3 layers of vessels (TI, TM, TA)
  - Pseudo-aneurysm: wall is formed by extravascular connective tissue
- AAA: permanent dilatation of (infrarenal) abdominal aorta ≥ 3cm (MC type of true arterial aneurysm)

Risk factors: 95% associated with atherosclerosis

- Age
- Male (9:1)
- Most CV risk factors (e.g. smoking, HT, lipid) except DM (unknown mechanism)
- Connective tissue disease (e.g. Marfan's, EDS)
- Others: mycotic (e.g. non-typhoid Salmonella, Staphylococcus, Syphilis)

Locations: Infrarenal (95%), juxtarenal, pararenal, suprarenal

[Image Description: This image presents a series of diagrams illustrating different types and classifications of aortic aneurysms. The top right shows a simplified cross-section of a normal artery and three types of true aneurysms (Saccular, Fusiform, Dissecting) and one type of false aneurysm. The diagrams emphasize the layers of the arterial wall (Adventitia, Media, Intima) and how they are affected in each type of aneurysm. The middle of the image depicts Crawford aneurysm classifications (I-V) showing the extent of aneurysms in the thoracic and abdominal aorta, followed by a series of abdominal aortic aneurysms classifications, infrarenal, juxtarenal, pararenal, and suprarenal. These diagrams highlight the location of the aneurysm in relation to major arterial branches and anatomical landmarks. The aneurysms are represented as dilated sections of the aorta, with arrows indicating the position of key anatomical structures such as the celiac trunk, renal arteries, and bifurcation. The diagrams are color-coded to distinguish different aneurysm types and classifications, and anatomical structures are labeled for clarity.]

Clinical presentation

- Most asymptomatic (60%): +/- concomitant femoral (80% has AAA) or popliteal aneurysm (50% has AAA)
- Symptomatic (10%): must rule out rupture
  - Abdominal / back / loin / groin pain: due to compression on nerves and organs
  - Limb ischemia (e.g. blue toe syndrome, trash foot): due to distal embolization of mural thrombus
- Rupture (30%): refer to separate section
- Others: aortoenteric fistula (massive GIB), aorto-ureteric fistula (hematuria), aortocaval fistula (high-output HF)

Physical examination: pulsatile and expansile mass (usually in epigastrium)

- Features: Non-tender, immobile, firm in consistency, smooth surface, fusiform/saccular
- Border: can get above = infrarenal, can get below = no iliac involvement
- Measure transverse diameter
- Palpate for other aneurysms, femoral pulse and features of limb ischemia

Investigations

- USG abdomen: confirm diagnosis and surveillance of AAA size (surgery if ≥5.5cm)
  - Hemodynamically unstable patients: FAST scan indicated
- CT abdomen + pelvis with contrast: preoperative assessment of anatomy for suitability for EVAR
- Others: CTA/MRA/DSA (not for size due to intramural thrombus), AXR (calcification of aortic wall)

7 Vascular surgery
Thoracoabdominal Aortic Aneurysm: Crawford classification
Class I: below left subclavian artery (SCA) to above renal a.
Class II: below left SCA to include infrarenal aorta
Class III: from 6th intercostal space (ICS) to bifurcation
Class IV: from 12th ICS to aortic bifurcation
Class V: from 6th ICS to above renal arteries

| Aneurysm size | Annual rupture risk (%/year) |
| ------------- | ---------------------------- |
| <5.5cm        | <1%                          |
| 5.5-5.9cm     | 5-10%                        |
| 6.0-6.9cm     | 10-20%                       |
| 7.0-7.9cm     | 20-30%                       |
| ≥8.0cm        | 30-50%                       |

161
Management
Conservative management

- Indication: AAA <5.5cm (no survival benefit)
- CV risk factor modification: smoking cessation, BP control, statin, aspirin, weight loss, exercise
- USG monitoring: yearly for 3.0-3.9cm, Q6m for 4.0-5.4cm
  Surgical management
- Indications (need to know!)
  - AAA ≥5.5cm (_UK Small Aneurysm Trial_) / 5cm (local consensus)
  - Rapidly expanding AAA (>1cm/year or >0.5cm/6months)
  - Symptomatic AAA e.g. pain, distal embolisation
- Open repair vs endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR): [trials: EVAR1, DREAM, OVER]
  - EVAR: less 30-day morbidity and mortality, shorter duration of hospitalization, rapid return of QoL
  - Open: lower risk of rupture / re-intervention in the long run
  - No significant difference in long-term morbidity and mortality

| Approach     | Open repair: Aneurysmorrhaphy                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       | Endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR)                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      |
| :----------- | :------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ | :----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
|              | - Midline / supraumbilical transverse incision\* - Small bowel and peritoneum manipulated - Clamp aorta above and below lesion (~30min) give systemic heparin + induce hypotension - Open sac and clear mural thrombus - Plicate backflow from lumbar a. / IMA - Replace the sac with prosthetic graft (Dacron / PTFE) - suture with Prolene - Release clamps to check for hemostasis: give inotropes to prevent hypotension - Close the aneurysm sac around the prosthesis (to lower risk of aortoenteric fistula) | Bilateral femoral arteriotomy / Percutaneous Placement of covered stent graft (2 parts: main body with ipsilateral limb, contralateral limb) under epidural / LA Post-op: lifelong surveillance (CT at 1m, 6m, 1y then Q1y), aspirin (2º prevention of PVD)              |
| Specific Cx  | - Mortality rate ~5% - Early: mainly related to ischemia - Myocardial infarction - Acute renal failure (esp. suprarenal repair) - Ischemic bowel / Prolonged paralytic ileus (IMA occlusion) - LL ischaemia: trash foot (anastomotic kinking, clamp injury, embolism) - Spinal cord ischemia (artery of Adamkiewicz): sexual dysfunction, weakness, incontinence                                                                                                                                                    | Access site complications - Bleeding, haematoma - Pseudoaneurysm - AV fistula - Thromboembolism Endograft-related complications - Endoleak (30%)^: incomplete seal around the aneurysm causing blood leaking around the graft - Graft infection / thrombosis / migration |
| Late         | - Graft infection / thrombosis - Aortoenteric fistula (mostly D3/4 - can occur years after repair) - Pseudoaneurysm                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 | Systemic complications (similar to open) - Ischaemic: LL, renal, bowel, pelvic (sexual dysfunction due to pelvic artery injury) - Contrast complications: nephropathy, allergy                                                                                           |
| Preferred if | - Failed anatomic requirement for EVAR# - Do not want lifelong surveillance - High risk for AAA rupture                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             | First line: lower early morbidity & mortality, but higher rupture rate in long term Poor cardiorespiratory reserve                                                                                                                                                       |

\*Retroperitoneal approach if previous abdominal surgery / obese / COPD
Juxta/suprarenal / thoracoabdominal AA

- Open: retroperitoneal approach (left flank incision) - increased risk of renal impairment
  - Suprarenal aorta clamping (e.g. supraceliac) or balloon occlusion
- EVAR: fenestrated graft (fig.), "Chimney" technique
  [Illustration depicting a "Chimney/snorkel graft" technique used in endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). The illustration shows a stylized aortic aneurysm, where a main stent graft is placed within the aneurysm sac to exclude it from blood flow. Additionally, one or more smaller stents (chimneys or snorkels) are deployed from the main graft into the renal arteries, maintaining their patency. The "chimneys" run parallel to the main graft within the aorta. The label "a. Chimney/snorkel graft" is present below the illustration.]

#Prerequisites of EVAR:
162
Anatomic requirement

- Aortic neck length (from lowest renal a. to origin of aneurysm): 215mm - adequate proximal landing zone
- Aortic neck diameter: 18-32mm (endograft diameter is 15-20% larger - undersizing → endoleak; oversizing → infolding and inadequate seal)
- Aortic neck angulation (angle formed by lowest renal a., origin of aneurysm and aortic bifurcation) <60°
- Aortic neck morphology: C/I if reverse-tapered
- Common iliac length 220mm: adequate distal landing zone
- Common iliac diameter 8-22mm
- External iliac diameter 27mm for graft to pass through
- Minimal calcifications and tortuosity

[A diagram shows an abdominal aortic aneurysm with measurements. The aortic neck is labeled as ">10-15 mm" and "18-32 mm". The neck angulation is shown as "<45-60°". The common iliac artery (CIA) is marked as "8-22 mm" and ">20 mm", and the external iliac artery (EIA) is labeled as ">7 mm". The text "Minimal CA++ and tortuosity" is placed near the lower part of the illustration.]

Anatomical limitations might be overcome by

- Extend into proximal landing: fenestrated/branched device, chimneys, snorkels
- Proximal sealing with EndoAnchor
- Preservation of internal iliac a. with iliac bifurcation devices

^Types of endoleak after EVAR: Types I and III has continuous direct flow into AAA → require re-operation!
| Type | Description | Management |
|---|---|---|
| I | Seal failure at proximal / distal end - usually stent migration Subtypes: 1a (proximal end), 1b (distal end), 1c (iliac occluder plug in aorto-uni-iliac device) | Repeat EVAR |
| II | Backflow of blood from side branches (lumbar arteries / IMA) Subtypes: 2a (1 vessel), 2b (2 or more vessels) - Most common type of endoleak, a.k.a. "retroleak" | Close observation for AAA expansion → Lap / Open clipping / IR embolization |
| III | Stent break (fabric tear), modular dehiscence Subtypes: 3a (segment disconnection), 3b (holes in endograft fabric) | Repair defect / Bridge across defect |
| IV | Porosity: Blood goes through small pores of endograft material | Observe |
| V | Flow visualized but source not identified ("endotension") | Observe |

Approach to UGIB with background of AAA repair

- Aortoenteric fistula until proven otherwise
- Classic triad: UGIB, fever, abdominal pain
- Ix: OGD (up to D4), contrast-enhanced CT abdomen
- Mx: graft excision with extra-anatomical bypass

[A colorful diagram illustrates different types of endoleaks in an aortic stent graft. Type Ia is at the proximal end, Type Ib at the distal end, Type II from side branches, Type III through fabric tear, and Type IV through the graft material.]

Ruptured AAA

- Risk of AAA rupture increases exponentially with the diameter of aneurysm
  Clinical features
- 50% Clinical triad: severe abdominal/ back pain, pulsatile mass, hypotension
- 20% rupture anteriorly (massive intraperitoneal free bleeding), 80% rupture posteriorly (retroperitoneal haematoma with tamponade effect)
- Rule: 50% reach hospital alive → 50% can do OT → 50% survive OT
  Differential diagnosis
- Ruptured HCC
- Ruptured ectopic pregnancy
  Investigations
- CT abdomen with contrast (skip if haemodynamically unstable)
- USG cannot diagnose ruptured AAA
  Management

[An axial CT scan image shows an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The aneurysm is a large, dilated blood vessel in the abdomen, easily visible on the CT scan.]

- Resuscitation: high flow O2, IV access, urgent bloods (CBC, LRFT, clotting, X-match), pain control
- Permissive hypotension (SBP 80-100) to prevent further tear
- Unstable patient: immediate open repair
- Stable patient: CT angiogram to decide suitability of open repair vs EVAR
- Massive transfusion protocol: packed cells : platelet : FFP = 1 : 1 : 1 (e.g. 8 units each)

  7.2 Peripheral vascular disease
  Anatomy of arterial system
  [Diagram of the arterial system: Aorta branches into common iliac arteries, which further divide into external and internal iliac arteries. The external iliac artery transitions into the common femoral artery, then into profunda femoris and superficial femoral arteries. The superficial femoral artery becomes the popliteal artery, which branches into anterior tibial, posterior tibial and peroneal arteries, finally leading to dorsalis pedis.]

- External iliac a. passes through inguinal lig. and becomes femoral a.
- Femoral artery
  - Deep femoral → perforating branches, lateral femoral circumflex, medial femoral circumflex (supply femur neck → risk of AVN if #NOF)
  - Superficial femoral → enter Hunter's canal to become popliteal artery
- Popliteal artery gives off LAMP
  - Lateral - Anterior tibial, peroneal, Posterior tibial - Medial

[Diagram of vessel layers: A cross-sectional diagram shows the layers of a blood vessel, including the tunica intima, tunica media, and tunica adventitia. The tunica intima is the innermost layer, consisting of endothelium and subendothelial connective tissue. The tunica media is the middle layer, composed of smooth muscle and elastic fibers. The tunica adventitia is the outermost layer, containing connective tissue, vasa vasorum, and nerves.]
Layers of vessel wall

- Tunica intima
- Tunica media
- Tunica adventitia

History taking
Symptoms

- Onset, duration, progression
- Site of pain
  - Bilateral thigh / buttock: aortoiliac (30%)
  - Unilateral buttock: iliac
  - Calf: superficial femoral a. (70%), femoropopliteal
- Nature of pain: must be muscular pain
- Associated symptoms: numbness, pallor, cold, motor disturbances
- Rule out differential diagnosis
  - Spinal claudication: variable claudication distance, relieved by bending forward
  - Sciatica: back pain with radiation, not relieved by resting
    Severity
- **Claudication distance** (flat surface/ slope)
- How long they have to take rest (usually ~5min)
- Whether they can then walk the same distance again
- **Rest pain** (wake up due to pain, swing legs out of bed to help relieve) / Nocturnal pain
- **Any tissue loss**: ulcer, gangrene +/- infection
  Risk factors
- CV risk factors: DM, HT, HL, smoking
- Previous AF, IHD/MI, TIA/stroke, FHx
- DHx: aspirin, anticoagulants, statin
  Complications
- Impotence (Leriche's syndrome)
- Hx of stroke, MI
  Management-related
- Contrast allergy
- Saphenous vein condition
  Physical examination
- **Buerger's test**: lift both legs slowly for pallor (Buerger's angle) → swing legs down for reactive hyperemia
- To complete: **bedside Doppler** for pulses, measure ABI on both sides, examine abdomen for AAA / RAS, **cardiovascular examination** for other CV risk factors (e.g. BP/P, AF), urine multistix for glucose
  [Diagram of lower limb arterial anatomy: The diagram shows the arterial blood supply of the lower limb, including the aorta, iliac arteries, femoral artery, profunda femoris artery, superficial femoral artery, popliteal artery, tibioperoneal trunk, anterior tibial artery, posterior tibial artery, peroneal artery, and dorsalis pedis artery. The diagram highlights the inflow and outflow segments.]

- Investigations for PVD
  - **Ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI):** to confirm diagnosis & quantify severity (but normal values may present with IC)
    Left ABI = ratio of

  Higher of the left ankle systolic pressure (posterior tibial or dorsalis pedis)
  Higher arm systolic pressure (left or right arm)
  Right ABI = ratio of

  Higher of the right ankle systolic pressure (posterior tibial or dorsalis pedis)
  Higher arm systolic pressure (left or right arm)
  - Interpretation:
  - Normal 0.9-1.3
  - Claudication 0.4-0.9
  - Severe < 0.4
  - Calcified vessels > 1.3: additional vascular studies required, e.g. toe-brachial index (small vessels spared from calcification), arterial Doppler USG, transcutaneous oxygen measurements (TcO2)

- **Duplex USG = B-mode USG + Doppler**
  - Locate level of obstruction and quantify severity (normal arterial flow should be **triphasic**)
  - Non-invasive, no radiation. Operator-dependent, poor image for aortoiliac segment
- CT angiography
  - Less invasive alternative of DSA Contrast allergy / nephropathy, radiation dose
- MR angiography (MRA) - rarely done
- **Digital subtraction angiography (DSA): gold standard**
  - Indicated only for patients with planned intervention (angioplasty / stenting)
  - Inject radio-opaque dye into arterial tree (usually via femoral a.) → Imaging and digitalized by computer
  - Can be done **intra-op:** guide endovascular intervention
  - Allergy, contrast nephropathy, arterial injury (e.g. dissection, embolism, pseudoaneurysm)

# Chronic limb ischaemia

Definition

- Gradual onset (> 2 weeks) symptomatic limb ischaemia:
  - Progressive narrowing of vessels → time to develop collaterals → multi-level disease (critical limb)
- Subdivided into: - Critical limb ischaemia - Non-critical limb ischaemia
  Risk factors
- Atherosclerosis: **CV risk factors** (especially smoking) → a/w IHD, stroke, AAA
- Vasculitis e.g. Buerger's disease, Behcet's disease
- Others: trauma, popliteal entrapment syndrome

Clinical features

|                                                                                                         | Fontaine classification                                               | Rutherford classification                                            | Description                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               |
| :------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ | :-------------------------------------------------------------------- | :------------------------------------------------------------------- | :-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| **Non-critical limb ischaemia**                                                                         | Stage I: Asymptomatic                                                 | 0: Asymptomatic                                                      | Reproducible pain of a defined group of muscles that is induced by exercise & relieved by rest                                                                                                                                                            |
|                                                                                                         | Stage II: Intermittent claudication IIA: walk > 200m IIB: walk < 200m | 1: Mild claudication 2: Moderate claudication 3: Severe claudication |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |
| **Critical limb ischaemia:** rest pain/ ulcer/ gangrene + ankle SBP <50mmHg (DM: toe pressure < 30mmHg) | Stage III: Rest pain / Nocturnal pain                                 | 4: Rest pain                                                         | Severe distal LL pain at rest, exacerbated by lying down / limb elevation, relieved by placing the leg in a dependent position May wake patient from sleep - Limb elevation - Reduced cardiac output Relative skin vasodilation due to warmth of blankets |
|                                                                                                         | Stage IV: Ulcer/ gangrene                                             | 5: Minor tissue loss                                                 | Initial: non-healing minor trauma Dry gangrene: uncomplicated, hard shrunken with clear line of demarcation, may fall off (auto-amputation) Wet gangrene: complicated by infection, require debridement                                                   |
|                                                                                                         |                                                                       | 6: Major tissue loss                                                 |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |

[Image of Dry gangrene, showing a foot with blackened and shriveled toes. The skin appears dry and cracked.]
[Image of Wet gangrene, showing a foot with discolored, swollen skin and blisters. There are signs of infection and pus.]

- Leriche syndrome: gradual occlusion of terminal aorta, causing
  - Absent femoral pulses
  - Intermittent claudication
  - Gluteal pain
  - Impotence

Differential diagnosis

- Acute limb ischaemia: presentation < 2 weeks
- Spinal stenosis (neurogenic claudication)

|                     | Vascular claudication                         | Neurogenic claudication                          |
| :------------------ | :-------------------------------------------- | :----------------------------------------------- |
| Cause               | Chronic limb ischaemia                        | Spinal stenosis                                  |
| Radiation of pain   | From distal to proximal                       | From proximal to distal                          |
| Exacerbating factor | Walking uphill                                | Walking downhill                                 |
| Relieving factor    | Rest "Shop window to shop window"             | Bending over, sitting "Park bench to park bench" |
| Pulse               | Absent                                        | Present                                          |
| Associations        | Atherosclerotic risk factors Atrophic changes | Only 10% SLR +ve Back pain                       |

Management
Conservative: **CV risk factor modification**

- Lifestyle: smoking cessation, weight reduction, _supervised exercise programme_ (to increase O2 extraction, collateral circulation and improve muscle metabolism)
- DM / HT / HL control (**statin** - regardless of lipid level for overall CVS protection)
- Low dose **aspirin** (72-325mg): 2° prevention of coronary heart disease and stroke
- **Cilostazol** (PDE3 inhibitor with antiplatelet & vasodilatory effect, C/I CHF)
  - Alternatives: naftidrofuryl (5-HT2 antagonist: reduce platelet aggregation), pentoxifylline / Trental (PDE inhibitor), prostaglandins

Definitive treatment

- Indications: failed conservative management (6 months), disabling claudication, critical limb ischaemia
- Endovascular treatment: **percutaneous transluminal balloon angioplasty (PTA) +/- stenting**
  - Preferred if TASC Types A and B, aortoiliac diseases, short segment occlusion <10cm long, life expectancy < 2y (better short-term outcome)
  - Angioplasty: balloon inflated for ~30 seconds, dilation confirmed by angiogram
  - Stenting (+/- drug-elution): improve patency and reduce distal embolism, NOT used below knee
  - Post-op: antiplatelet + anticoagulation to prevent stent thrombosis
  - Specific complications:
    - Arterial dissection / rupture
    - Distal embolization
    - Re-stenosis
- Surgical treatment
  - Endarterectomy: open up artery to evacuate atheromatous plaque (uncommon now except at **carotid** and femoral bifurcation - profundoplasty)
  - Bypass surgery
    - Preferred if TASC Types C and D, failed angioplasty, long-segment occlusion, **complete occlusion** (no lumen for angioplasty guidewire to pass through)
    - Method of reconstruction

| Anatomical bypass: preferred                                                                 | Extra-anatomical bypass: when anatomical bypass not possible                                                                                                                                                                                                              |
| -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| - Aorto-bifemoral bypass - Femoro-popliteal bypass (above/below knee) - Femoro-distal bypass | - Femoro-femoral bypass: for unilateral iliac occlusion + unfit for abdominal surgery, can be performed under LA - Axillo-bifemoral bypass: no need enter thoracic / abdominal cavity, can be performed under LA - Axillo-popliteal bypass: last resort before amputation |

- Type of graft
  - Autogenous: preferred for smaller arteries
    - Vein grafts (GSV, SSV, arm veins)
    - Lined by endothelium: natural antithrombotic
    - More resistant to infection
    - Valvulotome is used to disrupt venous valves
  - Prosthetic: preferred for larger arteries
    [Image of a prosthetic graft with a thin tube and a balloon-like structure at the end, likely a vascular graft]
    - PTFE (polytetrafluoroethylene)
    - Dacron
    - +/- Miller cuff (vein cuff) to improve patency
  - Complications of bypass surgery
    - Graft failure: graft kink (early), neointimal hyperplasia (intermed.), atherosclerosis (late)
    - Palpate for patency, auscultate for bruits, serial USG surveillance
    - Ureter injury
    - Graft infection (esp. prosthetic)
    - Autonomic nerve damage (sexual dysfunction)
    - Aortoenteric fistula
    - Embolic complications: e.g. renal impairment, ischemic bowel, spinal cord ischemia
    - Surveillance: Doppler USG
- Amputation if failed above or gangrene
  \*TASC classification: anatomical distribution, number, length and nature of lesions (stenosis / occlusion)

(C) The guidewire is used to direct a balloon angioplasty catheter across the lesion. (D) The balloon is inflated. (E) A metal stent may be mounted on a catheter. The stent may be self-expanding or require expansion with a balloon. (F) The first segment of stent is always deployed to ensure a solid and in this circumstance steps C and D may be omitted. (F) Metal stent holding open the stenosis.]
