Acute limb ischaemia
Definitions: sudden decrease in limb perfusion that threatens the viability of limb

- Sudden = <2 weeks duration
  Etiology:
- Acute thrombotic occlusion of a pre-existing stenotic arterial segment (acute-on-chronic PVD): 60% (MC)
- Embolism (30%): usually lodge at branching points - femoral bifurcation (MC), popliteal trifurcation (2nd MC)
- Arterial trauma: e.g. iatrogenic, penetrating, blunt

Acute limb + chest pain:

- MI: mural thrombus /new-onset AF
- Aortic dissection

Distinguish embolism vs thrombosis-in-situ is important because different Ix and Mx
| | Embolus | Thrombosis-in-situ |
| ----------- | ----------- | ----------- |
| Common causes | Cardiac origin (80%) - Atrial fibrillation - MI: LV mural thrombus - Valvular heart diseases / prosthesis AAA (blue toe syndrome / trash foot) | Atherosclerosis: acute plaque rupture in PVD Aortic dissection Hypercoagulability: malignancy, APLS, sepsis Buerger's disease (thromboangiitis obliterans) |
| Severity | Complete ischemia (no collaterals) | Incomplete ischemia (collaterals) |
| Onset | Hyperacute (seconds to minutes) | Acute (hours or days) |
| History and PE | Embolic source identifiable (e.g. AF) Contralateral limb pulses present Absent bruits | Previous claudication PVD in contralateral limb (e.g. absent pulse) Present bruits |
| Management | Embolectomy, anticoagulation | Medical, bypass, thrombolysis |

Clinical features (6P)

- Pain (early: nerves are most sensitive to ischemia)
- Pallor^
- Perishingly cold
- Pulseless: can assess with handheld Doppler
- Paraesthesia
- Paralysis (late: poor prognosis, indicating muscle infarction)

^Limb colour progresses:

- 0-6h: "Marble white" pallor
- 6-12h: Blanchable mottling
- > 12h: Fixed mottling (irreversible: revascularization might cause significant reperfusion injury)

DDx of acute limb ischemia:

- Acute extremity compartment syndrome
- DVT with superficial vein thrombosis (phlegmasia cerulea dolens)

[Image: A photograph shows a human foot, possibly of a deceased person. The foot is pale with areas of blanching mottling, indicating compromised circulation. Additionally, there are patches of fixed mottling, suggesting irreversible tissue damage. The foot is resting on a surface, and there are annotations pointing to areas of skin infection, blanching mottling, and fixed mottling.]

Rutherford classification & corresponding management
| Category | Prognosis | Sensory loss | Motor deficit | Arterial Doppler | Venous Doppler | Ix | Management |
| ----------- | ----------- | ----------- | ----------- | ----------- | ----------- | ----------- | ----------- |
| I (Viable) | No immediate threat | None | None | Audible | Audible | СТА | Revascularisation |
| IIA (marginally threatened) | Salvageable if promptly treated | Minimal (toes) or none | None | Inaudible | Audible | СТА | Revascularisation |
| IIB (immediately threatened) | Salvageable only if immediately revascularised | More than toes Rest pain | Mild/moderate | Inaudible | Audible | СТА | Revascularisation (emergency) |
| III (irreversible) | Inevitable limb loss | Profound | Paralysis | Inaudible | Inaudible | Not required | Amputation |

# Management

Initial management

- NPO, IV fluids, monitor BP/P, SpO2, Foley for I/O
- Anticoagulation (therapeutic dose of heparin, i.e. heparin 5000 IU)
- Improving perfusion: **high-flow O2, keep foot dependent**
- Urgent revascularisation (see below): tissue damage becomes irreversible after 6h

Urgent investigations:

- CBC D/C, clotting, LRFT, T&S, CK (muscle injury)
- ECG and CXR: rule out aortic dissection (especially if chest pain)
- **Urgent CT angiogram** to confirm level of occlusion and determine any run-off (2-3 patent lower leg arteries to the foot / 1 patent artery with intact anterior or posterior foot arch)

Conservative management

- Indications: Rutherford I and IIA
- **Heparin:** IV bolus 3000-5000U + continuous infusion (limit propagation of thrombus and protect collaterals)
  - Monitor APTT (60-80s)
  - Must rule out aortic dissection before giving heparin

Surgical management

- Indications: Rutherford IIB or IIA failing conservative management
- Management according to aetiology and anatomy:

| Embolic cause                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       | Thrombotic cause                                                                                                                                |
| :-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | :---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Above knee: **open embolectomy with Forgaty catheter +/- prophylactic fasciotomy** (if ischemia >6h)                                                                                                                                                                                                | Run-off present: **bypass surgery**                                                                                                             |
| - Usually for femoral emboli and aortic saddle emboli                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               | Run-off absent: **Local thrombolysis (tPA) → angioplasty +/- stenting** after lysis of clot                                                     |
| - Done under LA or GA                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               | Thrombolysis: Pre-op angiogram to locate occlusion site → Pass catheter into the clot → Inject tPA → Regular angiogram to check extent of lysis |
| - Post-op: angiogram, continue heparin infusion → bridge with warfarin / NOAC for at least 3 months!                                                                                                                                                                                                | - rtPA (alteplase/reteplase), urokinase, streptokinase                                                                                          |
| [Figure 58.29 - A Fogarty catheter is inserted through an arterial entry in the common femoral artery and fed distally down the superficial femoral artery. The balloon is inflated, and the catheter withdrawn, removing the embolus; the deep femoral artery is protected by an occlusion clamp.] | - Need >6h to lyse clot: non-emergency situation                                                                                                |
|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     | - C/I: previous stroke/TIA, recent GI bleed, bleeding tendency, pregnancy                                                                       |
|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     | Blue toe syndrome: manage medically e.g. statins                                                                                                |

Below knee: **local thrombolysis / bypass**

- Consider extent of ischemia:
  - Complete ischemia: proceed to LA open embolectomy
  - Incomplete ischemia: obtain pre-op imaging if possible → endovascular treatments
  - Non-viable limb: amputation

Complications:

- Stroke and haemorrhage: after thrombolysis
- Reperfusion injury due to sudden increase in capillary permeability
  - Compartment syndrome: Prolonged ischemia → cell lysis → fluid leak into interstitium
    - Intracompartmental pressure > 30mmHg
    - S/S:
      - Pain out of proportion with clinical signs worsening with time despite analgesia
      - Numbness in distribution of nerves running within the compartment
      - Tense compartment on passive toe dorsiflexion and plantarflexion
      - Pulses can be present (SBP >> intracompartmental pressure)
    - Mx: urgent fasciotomy (medial + lateral incisions
  - Rhabdomyolysis: Release of K+, H+ and myoglobin from damaged muscle cells
    - Post-op: monitor BP/P, UO, APTT, RFT, cardiac monitor
    - S/S arrhythmia, AKI
    - Mx: aggressive hydration, diuresis with mannitol, IV bicarbonate

Amputation
Indications (3D)

- Dead limb: PVD causing gangrene (delay in amputation results in infection & rhabdomyolysis)
- Dangerous: infection (e.g. wet gangrene, necrotising fasciitis), malignancy
- Damn nuisance: un-reconstructable critical limb ischemia, paralysis, contracture, major trauma
  Principles of amputation
- Remove all infected tissue
- Preserve as much length as safely possible
- Adequate blood supply to heal the amputation - revascularisation may be required
  before amputation to ensure good healing
  Level of amputation (fig.)

1. Above-the-Knee Amputation (AKA): if femoral pulse -ve
2. Below-the-Knee Amputation (BKA) (MC): aim to preserve knee joint because much
   easier to walk on below-knee prosthesis, C/I if fixed flexion deformity of knee
3. Syme's amputation: ankle joint
4. Transmetatarsal amputation
5. Toe amputation & ray amputation (not shown; removal of a toe & its metatarsal)
   [Image: A diagram of a leg with dotted lines indicating different levels of amputation. Number labels 1 through 5 point to the thigh, above-knee, below-knee, ankle, mid-foot, and toe amputation levels respectively.]

Specific complications
Early complications

- Wound: hematoma, infection, abscess, dehiscence, gangrene (Mx: higher amputation)
- Surrounding skin: skin necrosis (poor perfusion to stump)
- Nerve: phantom limb pain (Mx: reassurance, amitriptyline, gabapentin)
- Vein: DVT/PE (Mx: prophylactic heparin)
  Late complications
- Joint: fixed flexion deformity
- Bone: osteomyelitis, osteophyte formation
- Surrounding skin: stump ulceration (pressure from prosthesis)
- Nerve: stump neuroma
  Rehab: Usually can bear weight on contralateral limb by 1 week, and fit temporary prosthesis by 3 weeks

Carotid artery disease
Anatomy

- Carotid sheath: Carotid artery, internal jugular vein, vagus nerve, deep cervical LN
  Clinical features
- Asymptomatic: even in unilateral complete occlusion → development of collateral supply
- ΤΙΑ
- Stroke
  Investigations
- Urgent non-contrast CT brain
- CT angiogram: if endovascular therapy is considered
- Carotid Doppler USG
  Management
- Medical therapy: diet, exercise, antiplatelet, antihypertensive (ACEI), statin
- Endovascular therapy: if stenosis > 70% (asymptomatic or symptomatic)
  - Carotid endarterectomy (CEA) → more effective, preferred if tortuous vessels, no need DAPT
  - Carotid angioplasty and stenting (CAS) → preferred if re-stenosis after CEA, unfit for GA, need DAPT 3/12

Subclavian steal syndrome

- Occlusion of proximal subclavian artery, causing retrograde blood flow from vertebral artery
- S/S: UL claudication, syncope, ataxia, diplopia, sensory loss

Anatomy

Divided into deep venous system & superficial venous system, separated by the deep fascia

- Deep venous system: veins corresponding to the arterial supply, i.e. popliteal vein, femoral vein
- Superficial venous system: great saphenous vein (GSV) & short saphenous vein (SSV)
- Joined by perforators^
  Course

| GSV 大隱靜脈                                                                   | SSV                                                                  |
| ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ | -------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Arise from medial aspect of dorsal venous arch                                 | Arise from lateral side of dorsal venous arch                        |
| Anterior to medial malleolus\*, accompanied by saphenous nerve                 | Posterior to lateral malleolus, accompanied by sural nerve           |
| Posterior to medial border of patella                                          | Pierce deep fascia over popliteal fossa to drain into popliteal vein |
| Drain into femoral vein at SFJ (2.5cm inferolateral to pubic tubercle)         |                                                                      |
| \*Constant relationship of GSV with medial malleolus → life-saving cannulation |                                                                      |

# Varicose veins

Physiology of venous return from lower limb

- Decreased intrathoracic pressure during inspiration
- Calf muscle pump (major mechanism)
- One-way valve

Pathophysiology: **venous hypertension** → loss of compliance, thickening, dilation and valvular dysfunction

- Reflux due to pressure gradient dysfunction (90%)
  - Increased abdominal or thoracic pressure: COPD, pregnancy, constipation
  - Decreased calf muscle pump function: prolonged immobility, paralysis
- Venous obstruction
  - Intramural: DVT / trauma
  - Mural: valvular incompetence
  - Extramural: ovarian cysts / fibroids, _May-Thurner syndrome_ (left common iliac vein compressed by right common iliac artery)

Congenital causes of CVI

- Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome: congenital venous malformation causing triad of VV, port wine stains and bony and soft-tissue hypertrophy of limbs; VV may be present over the lateral aspect of thigh
- Parkes-Weber syndrome: multiple AV fistulae with limb hypertrophy, possibly causing high-output HF

Clinical features

- Risk factors: old age, occupation (prolonged standing), posture (cross legs), obesity, chronic cough, constipation, pregnancy, previous Hx of DVT, FHx
- Presentation:
  - Asymptomatic: cosmetic concerns
  - Symptomatic: usually worsen throughout course of day / standing, relieved by lying down / leg elevation
    - Pain, muscle cramps, swelling, dragging sensation, itchiness
    - Complications: hyperpigmentation, eczema, lipodermatosclerosis, ulcers
- Physical examination
  - Inspection: surgical scars, location of varicosities (_GSV / SSV territories_), other signs of chronic venous insufficiency according to CEAP grading
  - Palpate along course of GSV and SSV
  - Check **peripheral pulses** (rule out PVD for planning of OT)
  - +/- Check for saphena varix: painless compressible groin lump with cough impulse
  - +/- Feel inguinal LN if venous ulcers are present
  - +/- Test neuro function (e.g. sural n.) if scars are present
  - Tourniquet test:
    - Ensure all VV are emptied first
    - Apply tourniquet → Stand up and observe filling → Release tourniquet
    - Sites: just below SFJ, mid-thigh, above knee, below knee
  - To complete
    - Examine inguinal region for mass / LN
    - Abdominal + PR examination for masses obstructing IVC
    - ABI to rule out PVD
    - +/- modified Perthes' test to assess deep venous patency (apply tourniquet around SFJ → ask patients to walk → swelling and painful = deep system not patent

[A diagram of incompetent perforator(s) with finding and interpretation. The first image depicts SFJ only. The second image depicts SFJ AND other perforator(s) below SFJ. The third image depicts Perforator(s) below SFJ, but not SFJ. The finding for the first image is VV reappear only above tourniquet. The finding for the second image is Some VV reappear but others do not. The finding for the third image is All VV reappear. The Interpretation for the first image is All VV completely controlled below SFJ. The Interpretation for the second image is VV partially controlled below SFJ. C-Clinical

| Class | Characteristics                           | Comments                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       |
| ----- | ----------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
| C0    | Asymptomatic                              |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                |
| C1    | Telangiectasia or reticular veins         | Telangiectasia (spider veins) < 1mm Reticular vein: 1-2.9 mm                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   |
| C2    | Varicose veins                            | Dilated tortuous vein ≥3mm                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     |
| C3    | Pitting oedema                            |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                |
| C4    | 4A Pigmentation and/or eczema             | Interstitial accumulation of hemosiderin                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       |
|       | 4B Lipodermatosclerosis, atrophie blanché | Lipodermatosclerosis: progressive fibrosis of the skin and subcutaneous tissues due to fibrin deposits; hyperpigmentation + erythema + induration + tender (palpate!) Atrophic blanche: avascular fibrotic scars, prone to secondary venous ulceration due to poor blood supply; ivory white areas with hyperpigmented borders |
| C5    | Healed ulcers                             | At medial gaiter area: site of medial calf perforators Painless unless infected (usually _S. aureus_) Long-standing ulcer → Marjolin's ulcer (2%)                                                                                                                                                                              |
| C6    | Active ulceration                         | Ulcer: full-thickness skin loss                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                |

E: aetiology (Ec = congenital, Es = secondary, Ep = primary, En = no venous cause identified)
A: anatomy (As = superficial, Ap = perforator, Ad = deep, An = no venous location identified)
P: pathophysiology (Pr = reflux, Po = obstruction, Pro = both, Pn = no venous pathophysiology identified)

173
Investigations

- **Duplex USG (B-mode USG + Doppler)**
  - Confirm diagnosis & establish exact distribution and extent:
    - Squeeze calf to elicit reflux
  - Assess function of deep venous system (C/I surgical treatment if concomitant superficial & deep insufficiency)
  - Assess suitability for endovenous treatment: diameter, extent, **tortuosity**, saphena varix
- USG abdomen: if secondary causes suspected

Management
Conservative

- Risk factor modification: avoid prolonged standing, weight loss, increase exercise (promote calf muscle pump)
- **Graduated compression stockings**: improve VV symptoms
  - At least 20mmHg at ankle with decreasing pressure proximally
  - Pre-requisite: ABPI (absolute C/I if ABPI < 0.4)
  - Complications: pressure necrosis, contact dermatitis, fungal infection
- Venotonic drugs (e.g. **Daflon**, micronized disomin): increase venous tone and lymphatic drainage
  - Good for edema (CEAP ≥ C3)

Surgical therapy

- Indications: documented superficial venous reflux (i.e. retrograde flow >0.5sec in duration)
  - Symptomatic: bleeding, recurrent phlebitis
  - Complications: severe disease (C4 or above), thrombosis
- Contraindications:
  - Pregnancy: risk of DVT
  - Combined deep & superficial venous insufficiency (blood has no route back) → conservative treatment
- Treatment option - Endovenous treatment - Approach: under LA, USG-guided - Thermal: use of tumescent^, risk of thermal injury - **Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA)**: preferred due to higher success rate - **Radiofrequency ablation (RFA)**: quicker recovery and less post-operative pain - Non-thermal: tumescent NOT required, but risk of vein hyperpigmentation & ulcer (due to extravasation) - Mechanical occlusion chemically-assisted (MOCA) ablation: both mechanical (rotating wire) + chemical (sclerosant injection) damage - **Cyanoacrylate glue / Venaseal**: adhesive agent to seal off VV, require compression from proximal to distal after injection, post-op stockings NOT required - Foam sclerotherapy (e.g. 1% STS - sodium tetradecyl sulfate): destroy endothelium by detergent or osmotic action, post-op stockings for 2 weeks to appose inflamed vessel walls - Surgical treatment: ligation +/- stripping (above-knee) or stab avulsion (below-knee) - GSV: Trendelenburg's operation\* + stripping +/- below-knee stab avulsion (risk of saphenous nerve damage) - SSV: SPJ ligation + stripping +/- below-knee stab avulsion (risk of sural nerve damage) - Choice between endovenous treatment vs surgical treatment - Endovenous treatment usually as first line - Surgical treatment preferred if: - Superficial varicose veins (<1cm deep): risk of skin burns - Tortuous veins - Chronic/ recurrent phlebitis: formation of adhesions that prevent passage of device
  [Image of "Micky Mouse" transverse B-mode image of the right common femoral vein (CFV) and artery (CFA), great saphenous vein (GSV) and saphenofemoral junction. The image shows a cross-sectional ultrasound view with three circular dark regions. The labels “R CFV” (Right Common Femoral Vein) and “R CFA” (Right Common Femoral Artery) point to the two larger circular regions positioned relatively close to each other on the lower part of the image. A third, smaller circular region labeled “GSV” (Great Saphenous Vein) is positioned above the other two, slightly to the right.]

Treatment for perforators & deep system

## 8.1 Anatomy

Breast

- Normal boundaries of breast
  - Superior (2nd rib) - inferior (upper rectus sheath /7th-8th rib)
  - Medial (sternum) - lateral (mid-axillary line / edge of LD)
  - Depth: **pre-pectoral fascia**
- Components: - Terminal ductal lobular unit (TDLU): structural unit - lobules (10-100) → lactiferous ducts (15-20) lined by
  myoepithelial cells - **Ligaments of Cooper**: separate the lobules; fibrous tissue attached firmly to superficial fascia → skin
  tethering in CA breast - Areola: contain Montgomery's tubercle (sebaceous glands that lubricate nipple during lactation) and
  involuntary muscles arranged in concentric rings & radially - Nipple: thickened skin, contain orifices of lactiferous ducts - **Axillary tail** (of Spence): between pectoralis muscle and latissimus dorsi, blend with axillary fat

[Image showing a superficial dissection of the pectoral region of the female. The image shows the deltoid muscle, cephalic vein, axillary tail of the breast, latissimus dorsi, areola, serratus anterior, and pectoralis major. Additionally, an image showing a breast lobule with the lactiferous duct and ampulla, areola, and ductule is present, along with the clavicle, rib, pectoralis minor, pectoralis major, and cooper's ligament.]

- Vascular supply:
  - **Internal thoracic artery (ITA)** / internal mammary artery ← Subclavian a.
  - **Lateral thoracic artery (LTA)** / external mammary artery Axillary a.
  - Posterior intercostal a.
- Lymphatics: **axillary LN** (75%), parasternal LN / **internal mammary LN** (run with ITA; not routinely dissected)
  Axilla
- Borders of axilla (fig.)
- Superior border for surgical dissection: **axillary vein**
- 3 levels
  - Level I: **lateral** to pectoralis minor
  - Level II: **deep** to pectoralis minor
  - Level III: **medial** to pectoralis minor
- 5 groups
  - **Anterior**: posterior to pectoralis major
  - **Posterior**: anterior to fold of latissimus dorsi
  - **Medial**: along chest wall
  - **Lateral**: along head of humerus
  - **Apical**: medial to pectoralis minor
  - **Interpectoral (Rotter's)**: between pectoralis minor and pectoralis major
- Drain to supraclavicular LN → subclavian lymph trunk

8.3 Assessment of breast mass
Triple assessment: clinical + radiological + pathological assessment
Clinical assessment
Important questions in history taking (_must know!_)

- Mass: Onset & progression, any cyclical changes / mastalgia
- Nipple: discharge / retraction
- Skin: itchiness, erythema, dimpling / Peau d'orange
- Constitutional symptoms: weight loss, bone pain, SOB
- Risk factors of malignancy
  - FHx: BRCA - any CA breast / ovary / prostate / pancreas
  - PMHx: breast disease (e.g. DCIS), breast RT
  - Estrogen exposure: age of menarche, age of menopause, parity, breastfeeding, use of COC/HRT

Physical examination

- Position: 45°
- Inspection:
  - Size, symmetry, surgical scars (e.g. LN biopsy), skin changes (e.g. ulceration, dimpling, Peau d'orange)
  - Nipple changes (5D): deviation, discolouration, dermatitis , depression (retraction), discharge
- Palpation of breast: start from normal side
  - Comment on: site, size, shape, border, surface, consistency, tenderness, mobility (skin & muscle)
  - Include axillary tail of breast
- Palpation of axilla:
  - Groups: anterior, posterior, medial, lateral, apical
  - Comment: number, site, size, consistency, tenderness, fixation

Radiological assessment

- **Mammogram: only for female > 35y** (poor resolution in dense breasts in young female)
  - Low-dose X ray that can be performed even in pregnant female (with shield)
  - 🌝 **Gold standard**, more sensitive for calcifications, less operator- dependent, used for annual screening
  - 😩 Limited localization, difficult to see chest wall & axilla, radiation
  - Presentation of mammogram (_important!_)
    - Breast tissue _appropriate_ for age
    - Views: **craniocaudal (CC) vs mediolateral oblique (MLO)**
    - Location of mass
      - MLO view: upper vs lower half of breast (line perpendicular to pec major)
      - CC view: outer vs inner quadrant of breast
    - Features of malignancy
      - Spiculated opacity with irregular borders
      - Clusters of pleomorphic microcalcifications
      - Architectural distortion e.g. tent sign (fig.)
      - Pectoralis major involvement (only in MLO view )
      - Skin thickening / tethering
      - Nipple involvement

[Radiographic views of the breast Standard views *45° Medio lateral Oblique (MLO view)/Lundgren's view * Craniocaudal view (CC view) A series of black and white mammogram images showing the internal structures of a female breast from different angles, alongside a diagram depicting the Mammogram imaging process. The images highlight the variations in tissue density and are presumably used for diagnostic purposes.]

- **USG breast: for all patients**
  - Roles of USG
    - Improved Sn & Sp combined with mammogram, esp. in young women with dense breast tissue
    - Distinguish cysts from solid lesions
    - Guide FNAC, biopsy and clipping before neoadjuvant chemotherapy
    - Assess axillary LN

Ο Suspicious features on USG: "SHIT CME" - same as thyroid

Breast MRI: not routinely done; unnecessary biopsies may be performed

Reporting system: Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BIRADS)

Final Assessment Categories

| Category                                        | Management                                                    | Likelihood of cancer                                                                                                                                   |
| ----------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
| 0 Need additional imaging or prior examinations | Recall for additional imaging and/or await prior examinations | n/a                                                                                                                                                    |
| 1 Negative                                      | Routine screening                                             | Essentially o%                                                                                                                                         |
| 2 Benign                                        | Routine screening                                             | Essentially o%                                                                                                                                         |
| 3 Probably Benign                               | Short interval-follow-up (6 month) or continued               | >0 % but ≤ 2%                                                                                                                                          |
| 4 Suspicious                                    | Tissue diagnosis                                              | 4a. low suspicion for malignancy (>2% to ≤ 10%) 4b. moderate suspicion for malignancy (>10% to ≤ 50%) 4c. high suspicion for malignancy (>50% to <95%) |
| 5 Highly suggestive of malignancy               | Tissue diagnosis                                              | ≥95%                                                                                                                                                   |
| 6 Known biopsy- proven                          | Surgical excision when clinical appropriate                   | n/a                                                                                                                                                    |

Pathological assessment

- FNAC: cytological diagnosis
  - Advantage: no need LA, smaller needle (21-23G)
  - Disadvantages: Cannot assess architecture (i.e. carcinoma in situ vs invasive carcinoma)
  - Preferred if low risk (e.g. non-palpable mass, equivocal MMG) or simple cysts
- Core needle biopsy (CNB) - first line: histological diagnosis
  - Performed if BIRADS 4+
  - Advantages: architectural assessment, tumour grading, receptor status (ER/PR/HER2)
  - Disadvantages: require LA, larger needle (9-14G)
  - Non-palpable mass: USG, stereotactic (XR), tomosynthesis (3D mammogram by multiple XR), MRI
  - Increase yield: vacuum-assisted core biopsy

Approach to FNAC:

- Cystic lesion:
  - Lump disappears/ clear fluid: no further Ix
  - Residual thickening/blood-stained fluid: core biopsy
- Solid lesion:
  - Benign: observe or excision
  - Atypical: core needle biopsy
  - Malignant: treat as cancer

- Excisional biopsy:
  - Indicated when core biopsy reveals suspicious lesion by not diagnostic
  - Localizing non-palpable lesions
    - Hook-wire localization (HWL)
      - Problems: extensive normal tissue removal, wire outside skin, risk of broken wire
    - Radioactive seed localization (RSL): 125I-labelled titanium seed inserted 0-5 days prior to surgery
    - Radio-opaque lesion localization (ROLL): 99mTc-labelled albumin-based colloid, injected within 24h of surgery
    - Magseed localization: non-radioactive
    - On-table USG

A wire with a hook on the end is inserted into the breast, close to the mass. A scalpel is shown cutting around the mass and wire.]

8.  4 Breast malignancy
    Pre-malignant lesions
    Atypical ductal / lobular hyperplasia: 4-5x ↑risk of invasive CA on same side

- If found on core biopsy: excisional biopsy MUST be performed to rule out malignancy
  Carcinoma in-situ: malignancies contained within basement membrane (i.e. no invasion)
- DCIS (20% of all breast CA) >> LCIS (rare)

|                   | Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS)                                                                                                                                           | Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS)                                                                        |
| :---------------- | :------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ | :------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
| Pathology         | Malignant cells within TDLU (ductal predominant) without invasion LG: non-comedo (e.g. cribriform) HG: comedo necrosis (with central necrosis → dystrophic calcification) | Malignant cells within TDLU (lobular predominant) without invasion                                      |
|                   |                                                                                                                                                                           | Loss of E-cadherin                                                                                      |
| Clinical features | Asymptomatic, non-palpable Usually unifocal                                                                                                                               | Asymptomatic, non-palpable Usually multifocal + multicentric                                            |
| Investigations    | Mammography: microcalcifications Diagnostic: core biopsy Prognostic: van Nuys prognostic index                                                                            | Mammography: NAD (i.e. incidental findings because of other breast diseases) Diagnostic: core biopsy    |
| CA risk           | Precursor to invasive ductal carcinoma of the same breast 1%/ year                                                                                                        | Precursor and marker of bilateral invasive carcinoma (ductal/ lobular) 1%/ year                         |
| Management        | BCS (2mm margin) + RT (if high risk): first line, if disease limited to one quadrant and cosmetically acceptable tumor-to-breast ratio                                    | Classical LCIS: close observation Non-classical LCIS (pleomorphic): more aggressive → surgical excision |
|                   | Mastectomy + SLNB (altered lymphatic drainage afterwards → impossible to accurately perform SLNB later if IDC is found in mastectomy specimen - 10-20% chance)            |                                                                                                         |
|                   | Adjuvant: tamoxifen/AI if ER/PR+                                                                                                                                          |                                                                                                         |

Breast carcinoma
Epidemiology

- Incidence in female: 1st; mortality: 3rd
- Median age 55 (younger than global data)
- Lifetime risk 1: 16

Classification
Pathology

- Invasive ductal carcinoma (76%): further subclassified into tubular, mucinous (good prognosis), metaplastic, inflammatory (poor prognosis)
- Invasive lobular carcinoma (8%): E-cadherin mutation → loose diffuse pattern → more difficult to detect clinically
- Others: ductal/lobular (7%), colloid (mucinous) (2.4%), tubular (1.5%), medullary (1.2%), papillary (1%)

Male breast carcinoma

- Incidence: M:F = 1:100
- Average age at diagnosis: 65
- Risk factors
  - BRCA2 carriers
  - Increased oestrogen: oestrogen therapy, etc
  - Radiation
  - Klinefelter's syndrome (XXY)
- Management: mastectomy + SLNB/ ALND (if clinically +ve LN)

St Gallen's IHC subtyping

| IHC Subtype     | Definition         | Type of adjuvant therapy                  |
| :-------------- | :----------------- | :---------------------------------------- |
| Luminal A       | HR+/HER2-/Ki67low  | Endocrine therapy alone\*                 |
| Luminal B       | HR+/HER2-/Ki67high | Endocrine therapy ± cytotoxic therapy     |
| Luminal B       | HR+/HER2+          | Cytotoxics + anti-HER2 + hormonal therapy |
| HER2-positive   | HR-/HER2+          | Cytotoxics + anti-HER2 therapy            |
| Triple-negative | HR-/HER2-          | Cytotoxic therapy                         |

\*A few patients require cytotoxics (such as high nodal status or other indicator of risk). Abbreviation: HR, hormone receptor.

Risk factors

- **Unexposed oestrogen**: obesity, early menarche, late menopause, nulliparous, no breastfeeding, COC/HRT
- Lifestyle: smoking, alcohol
- FHx in 1st deg relative (if young)
- Benign breast diseases (refer to table)
  - Epithelial hyperplasia: atypical ductal / lobular hyperplasia (5x risk), sclerosing adenosis
  - Benign tumour: intraductal papilloma, Phyllodes tumour
- Genetics (10%, AD)
  - BRCA1/2: 85% lifetime risk, ↑risk of CA breast (triple negative), ovary (BRCA1), male breast, prostate, pancreas, melanoma (BRCA2); Mx: prophylactic bilateral mastectomy, BSO, PARP1 inhibitor
  - TP53 germline mutation: Li Fraumeni syndrome
  - PTEN mutation: Cowden syndrome/ multiple hamartoma syndrome
  - Peutz-Jeghers syndrome

Clinical features

- Breast mass: hard, irregular, fixed, non-tender, mostly at upper outer quadrant
- Nipple discharge: increased risk if unilateral, single duct, bloody
- Special types:
  - Paget's disease of nipple: invasion of nipple-areolar complex; unilateral nipple eczema + nipple discharge
    - Ix: triple assessment, nipple biopsy x Paget cells
  - Inflammatory breast cancer (T4d): invasion of local lymphatic ducts; painful swollen breast with cutaneous edema involving at least 1/3 of breast (peau d'orange)

[Image Description: The images show two examples of breast abnormalities. On the left is a breast with a dark red, ulcerated lesion on the nipple, representing Paget's disease of the nipple. On the right is a breast exhibiting peau d'orange, characterized by thickened skin with prominent pores, resembling an orange peel.]

- Metastasis: bone, liver, lung, brain

Multifocal vs multicentric disease

- Multifocal: ≥2 foci contained within a limited area, i.e. usually the same quadrant of breast - not C/I to BCT
- Multicentric: ≥2 foci separated by significant disease, i.e. usually involve ≥ 1 quadrant - C/I to BCT

Investigations

- Triple assessment, including bilateral mammogram (for synchronous contralateral breast cancer)
- Bloods: LFT (liver met), CaPO4 (bone met)
- Tumour markers: CA15.3, CEA
- Staging: CXR, PET-CT, bone scan

Breast cancer screening
HK local practice

- All ages: recommend monthly self-examination
- ≥40 year old (earlier if high risk e.g. FHx +ve): annual mammogram + USG

# TNM staging

- Clinical staging: tumour size, chest wall invasion, axillary LN metastasis
- Pathological staging: core biopsy + sentinel LN assessment (see separate section)

Tumour (T)

|                |                                                                                                       |
| :------------- | :---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
|                | T0: no evidence of primary tumour                                                                     |
|                | **T1: tumour ≤ 2cm**                                                                                  |
|                | - Tla: tumor ≤ 0.5cm                                                                                  |
|                | - T1b: 0.5cm < tumor ≤ 1cm                                                                            |
|                | - T1c: 1cm < tumor ≤ 2cm                                                                              |
|                | **T2: 2cm < tumor ≤ 5cm**                                                                             |
|                | **T3: tumour > 5cm**                                                                                  |
|                | T4: tumour of any size, with direct extension to                                                      |
|                | - T4a: chest wall (except pectoralis major alone)                                                     |
|                | - T4b: skin (ulceration, edema i.e. Peau d'orange) but not meeting criteria of inflammatory CA breast |
|                | - T4c: both chest wall & skin                                                                         |
|                | - T4d: inflammatory cancer (at least 1/3 of breast)                                                   |
| Node (N)       | N0: no regional LN involvement                                                                        |
| - Clinical     | N1: movable ipsilateral axillary nodes                                                                |
| - Pathological | N2: fixed ipsilateral axillary nodes / internal mammary nodes only                                    |
|                | - N2a: Level I/II axillary LN                                                                         |
|                | - N2b: internal mammary LN without axillary LN                                                        |
|                | N3:                                                                                                   |
|                | - N3a: Level III axillary LN only                                                                     |
|                | - N3b: internal mammary LN + axillary LN                                                              |
|                | - N3c: supraclavicular LN                                                                             |
| Metastasis (M) | M0: no distant metastasis                                                                             |
|                | M1: with distant metastasis                                                                           |

Summary for staging

- T1N0 → Stage Ia
- TxN1 → at least Stage II
- T4Nx → Stage IIIb
- TxN3 → Stage IIIc

Terms

- Early: T1/T2, N0/N1
- Locally advanced: T4 or above

Number of axillary LN metastasis is the strongest prognostic factor

- N0: 5-year survival ~70%
- The more lymph nodes, the worse 5-year survival

Treatment for breast cancer

Breast management
Breast-conserving surgery (BCS)/ wide local excision (WLE)

- Approach:
  - Surgical excision: negative margins defined by "**no ink on tumour**"
    - Wider margin does not reduce recurrence / survival since there will be breast RT
    - Positive margin (ink on tumour): >2x increase in ipsilateral breast tumor recurrence (IBTR)
  - RT to breast
- Contraindications:
  - C/I to BCS (**must know!**): multicentric disease, high tumour-breast ratio >20% (can be downstaged by neoadjuvant chemo), tumor too close to NAC, persistent +ve resection margin, presence of diffuse malignant-appearing calcifications on imaging, inflammatory breast cancer
  - C/I to RT: Hx of RT to affected chest wall / breast, pregnancy, connective tissue disease (e.g. scleroderma, Sjogren's disease - poor skin healing, causing fistula formation)
  - Patient choice, e.g. refuse adjuvant RT (5d/ weeks for 5 weeks)
  - Prophylactic mastectomy (e.g. BRCA carrier)

184
Mastectomy

- Indications: C/I to BCS
- Similar efficacy to BCS
- Approach:
  - Simple mastectomy (indicated if clinically -ve LN): axillary LN not dissected → SLNB
    - Nipple-sparing mastectomy: C/I include IBC, involvement of NAC, nipple retraction
    - Skin-sparing mastectomy: C/I if IBC
  - Modified radical mastectomy (MRM): whole breast + overlying skin + axillary LN (level I + II)
  - Radical mastectomy: not done due to ↑↑morbidity, include pec major
- Drains: Jackson-Pratt drain (closed suction - placed through separate stab wounds inferolateral to main incision) ± 2nd drain at axilla if MRM → remove drains if output <30mL/day x 2 days
- Locally advanced cases:
  - Require removal of part of pectoralis muscle for margin
  - Place clips in anticipation of subsequent RT therapy
  - Positive margin = require adjuvant RT
- Complications:
  - Seroma, hematoma, wound infection
  - Skin flap / NAC necrosis (if reconstruction)
  - Arm morbidities: arm or shoulder pain, numbness, frozen shoulder
  - Phantom breast syndrome: altered chest wall sensation, might persist years after surgery

Axillary management

- Sentinel LN biopsy (SLNB)
  - Indications: clinically -ve LN (for early stage), DCIS with planned mastectomy
  - Sentinel LN: first draining LN group, "gatekeeper" of rest of axillary LN
  - Identified by dual tracer injection to intradermal / subareolar / intratumoral region
    - Technectium99m-labelled albumin: injected on the day before OT, C/I in pregnancy
    - Methylene blue: injected intra-op for direct visualization
  - Techniques:
    - Remove max 3-4 sentinel LN
    - Injection should not be close to axilla (avoid interference), and lateral to previous scars (may block lymphatic drainage)
  - Results

|                                                   |                             |
| ------------------------------------------------- | --------------------------- |
| No metastasis                                     | NO NEED axillary dissection |
| Micrometastasis (cluster of tumors ≤ 2mm)         |                             |
| Macrometastasis (cluster of tumors >2mm) x 1-2 LN | Controversial               |
| Macrometastasis (cluster of tumors >2mm) x ≥ 3 LN | Axillary dissection         |
| Extra-nodal extension                             |                             |
| Sentinel LN not found                             |                             |

- Limitations: false -ve rate 9.8% [NSABP B-32 trial], only 75% lymphatics drain to axilla, skip metastases
- New advancements: ICG, SPIO (supra-paramagnetic iron oxide)
- Axillary LN dissection (ALND):
  - Indications: clinically +ve LN (by palpation/ USG axilla), +ve sentinel LN, inflammatory CA breast (T4d)
  - Routine: Level I (lateral to pec minor) + Level II (deep to pec minor)
    - Level III is NOT indicated unless grossly positive: ↑morbidity without ↑survival
  - Complications: 4 nerves
    - Seroma (lymphatics)
    - Long thoracic nerve injury (winged scapula)
    - Thoracodorsal nerve injury (latissimus dorsi: weak adduction & IR of shoulder)
    - Medial pectoral nerve injury (pec major)
    - Intercostobrachial nerve injury (paraesthesia of axilla, medial arm & lateral chest wall)
    - UL lymphedema: Mx - pneumatic compression device
    - UL lymphangiosarcoma (Stewart-Treves syndrome)

# Assessment for adjuvant therapy

All patients have to be assessed for adjuvant therapies:

- Patient factors: age, menopausal status, medical co-morbidities (esp. cardiac & renal), family / social
- Tumour factors: size, axillary LN status, ER/PR/HER2 status, tumor histology & grading (Ki67), resection margin, operation done (BCS vs MRM), genomic studies

| Adjuvant therapy | Modality                     | Indications                                                                                                    | Comments                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               |
| ---------------- | ---------------------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
|                  | RT                           | After BCS (whole breast RT) **Role: locoregional recurrence** **Positive margins**                             | Common S/E: **skin fibrosis**, telangiectasia, cardiac damage, pneumonitis / pulmonary fibrosis, lymphoedema, RT-induced malignancy                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    |
|                  |                              | Positive LN (regional nodal RT) High risk cancers: e.g. T4, high grade, PNI/LVI                                |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        |
|                  | Chemo                        | Positive LN High risk cancers: e.g. T2+, high risk scores\*, high grade, PNI/LVI                               | General S/E: n/v, alopecia, mucositis (oral, diarrhoea), BM suppression, infertility, leukemia Specific S/E: Anthracyclines: **cardiotoxicity** (Mx: dexrazoxane) Cyclophosphamide: haemorrhagic cystitis, premature ovarian failure Taxanes: neuropathy, myalgia/ arthralgia                                                                                                                                                                                                                          |
|                  |                              | HER2+ if >1cm TNBC if ≥0.5cm (only option)                                                                     | Example regimen: AC x 4 cycles → T x 4 cycles Each cycle is 3 weeks Add cabecitabine if received neoadjuvant                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |
|                  | Hormonal therapy             | All ER/PR +ve cases unless C/I                                                                                 | Total treatment for **5-10 years**, choices: SERM (e.g. tamoxifen): S/E weight gain, flushing, ↑risk of CA corpus, VTE Aromatase inhibitor (e.g. letrozole, anastrozole, exemestane): post-menopausal only, S/E fracture More effective than tamoxifen GnRH analogue: pre-menopausal Combine with tamoxifen / exemestane: more effective but more S/E (SOFT, TEXT) Radiation / Oophorectomy (rarely done) NOT given concurrently with chemo: stop breast tissue proliferation → affect uptake of chemo |
|                  | Targeted therapy             | HER2 +ve (strong) 20-25% of CA breast                                                                          | **Trastuzumab (Herceptin):** IV infusion Q1mo x 12 S/E cardiotoxicity (not used concurrently with anthracycline), HSR                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  |
|                  |                              | High risk BRCA carriers High risk ER +ve                                                                       | PARP inhibitors e.g. olaparib CDK4/6 inhibitors e.g. abemaciclib                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       |
| Neoadjuvant      | Chemo ± Herceptin (if HER2+) | Locally advanced disease that is inoperable Large operable tumour that may be converted from mastectomy to BCS | Mark the location of tumor with **metal clip / radioactive seed** in case it becomes undetectable after Tx Advantages of neoadjuvant Tx: Tumor shrinkage → **Reduce extent of surgery** Provide **prognostic** information Allow addition of different adjuvant regimens Disadvantages of neoadjuvant Tx: No proven benefit c.f. standard therapy May **upstage** if no response to treatment                                                                                                          |
| Palliative       | Hormonal Bone Tx             | ER/PR +ve Bone metastasis                                                                                      | May be used with targeted therapy (HER2) Bisphosphonates, e.g. pamidronic acid RANKL inhibitor, e.g. denosumab                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         |
|                  | Chemo RT                     | Organ metastasis: liver, lung Brain metastasis, cord compression, SVCO                                         | Can also give steroids for brain met                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   |

\*Risk scores: Oncotype DX21-gene Recurrence Score (RS), Amsterdam 70-gene profile (MammaPrint), PAM50

Breast reconstruction
Principle of oncoplastic surgery: achieve oncological clearance together with reasonable cosmetic outcome
Timing: immediate vs delayed (if RT required)
Modalities:

|               | Autologous tissue (flaps)                                                                          | Prosthesis / implants                                                                                                                          |
| :------------ | :------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | :--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Options       | Pedicled flap: LD, TRAM Free flap: TRAM, DIEP                                                      | Silicone / Saline bag                                                                                                                          |
|               |                                                                                                    | Tissue expander                                                                                                                                |
| Advantages    | Correct skin defects with better cosmesis No foreign body Suitable for salvage if local recurrence | No donor site morbidity                                                                                                                        |
| Disadvantages | Technically demanding (↑OT time) Infection Flap necrosis                                           | C/I if post-RT or anticipated RT Require 2 stages (tissue expander → implant) Foreign body in-situ Implant-related complications (refer below) |

Comparison for common flaps

|                         |                                                        | Pedicle                                                             | Strengths                                         | Weaknesses                                                                                 |
| :---------------------- | :----------------------------------------------------- | :------------------------------------------------------------------ | :------------------------------------------------ | :----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Pedicled flap           | LD (latissimus dorsi)                                  | Thoracodorsal a.                                                    | Low risk of flap loss (reliable blood supply)     | Limited ROM                                                                                |
| Pedicled flap Free flap | TRAM (transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous) flap   | Superior epigastric a.                                              | Sufficient volume                                 | Hernia Not preferred if Hx of abdominal surgery                                            |
| Free flap               | DIEP (deep inferior epigastric artery perforator) flap | Inferior epigastric vessels anastomosed to internal mammary vessels | Abdominal muscle strength maintained Better shape | Longer OT time: require microsurgery Risk of complete flap loss (failed micro-anastomosis) |

Other possible flaps (seldom): sup. / inf. gluteal artery perforator (SGAP/IGAP), lumbar a. perforator

8.5 Benign breast disease
"Aberrations of normal development and involution (ANDI)": new term to classify most benign diseases as aberration in one of three stages:

- Development (15-25yo) → Cyclical changes (25-55yo) → Involution (>35-55yo)

# 8.7 Gynaecomastia

Definition: benign enlargement of the male breast resulting from breast glandular proliferation

- Pseudo-gynacomastia (lipomastia 肥仔波): fat deposition without glandular proliferation

Aetiology

- Physiological: newborn, adolescence
- Pathological: change in oestrogen: androgen activity ratio
  - ↑Oestrogen: liver disease, drugs (e.g. spironolactone)
  - Androgen: hypogonadism, **testicular tumour**
  - Defect in AR: androgen insensitivity syndrome

Clinical features

- Rubbery or firm mass extending from nipple
- Suspect CA breast if:
  - Old patients without risk factors
  - Unilateral gynaecomastia
  - Non-tender hard mass within breast tissue
  - Lymphadenopathy

Investigations

- Bloods: LFT, sex hormone profile
- Testis: testicular USG, AFP, βHCG

Management

- Treat underlying cause
- Physiological: reassurance
- Idiopathic: tamoxifen, surgical excision

9.1 Thyroid
Anatomy
Basic anatomy

- Level: C5-C7
- True capsule vs false capsule (pre-tracheal layer of deep cervical fascia)

Components: 2 lobes → lobule as functional unit → each lobule contains 20-40 follicles → each contains

- Follicular cells (secrete thyroid hormone)
- Colloid (store thyroglobulin)
- C cells (secrete calcitonin)

[Illustration of the Thyroid Gland: The thyroid gland is depicted in an anterior view, situated in the neck region. The trachea is shown as the main airway, leading up to the thyroid cartilage, which is positioned above the lobe of the thyroid gland. The isthmus of the thyroid gland connects the two lobes. The pyramidal lobe, when present, extends upwards. Key anatomical features are labeled including the trachea, thyroid cartilage, lobe of the thyroid gland, isthmus of the thyroid gland, and the pyramidal lobe.]

Arterial supply: anastomosis extensively within gland and on gland surface to provide collateral circulation

- Superior thyroid artery (1st branch of ECA):
  - Divide close to gland to avoid damaging EBSLN
- Inferior thyroid artery (thyrocervical trunk ← subclavian a):
  - Divide away to gland to avoid damaging RLN
  - Arise in vertebral artery triangle (between scalenus anterior and longus colli)
  - Thyroidea ima artery (3-4%, from brachiocephalic trunk/ arch of aorta)

[Illustration of the Arterial Supply of the Thyroid Gland: This diagram showcases the arterial supply to the thyroid gland. It highlights the relationship between the external carotid artery and the superior thyroid artery. The inferior thyroid artery originates from the thyrocervical trunk, which comes off the brachiocephalic artery. The illustration labels key vessels such as the external carotid artery, superior thyroid artery, inferior thyroid artery, thyrocervical trunk, and the brachiocephalic artery.]

Venous drainage - does NOT mirror arterial supply

- Superior thyroid vein (to IJV)
- Middle thyroid veins (to IJV)
- Inferior thyroid vein (to brachiocephalic vein)

[Illustration of the Venous Drainage of the Thyroid Gland: This diagram details the venous drainage of the thyroid gland. It presents the superior thyroid vein draining into the internal jugular vein, the middle thyroid vein also draining into the internal jugular vein, and the inferior thyroid vein draining into the brachiocephalic vein.]

Lymphatics: first to Level VI (central compartment, bounded by CCA)

[Illustration of the Arterial Supply to the Neck, focusing on the Thyroid: The diagram provides a detailed view of the arterial supply to the neck region, focusing specifically on the vessels related to the thyroid gland. The image is labeled with anatomical structures such as the transverse cervical artery, suprascapular artery, vertebral artery, thyrocervical trunk (right), thyrocervical trunk (left), internal thoracic artery, costocervical trunk (right), costocervical trunk (left), dorsal scapular artery, subclavian artery, common carotid artery.]

Important nerves

- External branch of superior laryngeal nerve (motor to cricothyroid which tenses vocal cord):
  - Run close to superior thyroid artery
  - Injury causes loss of high-pitch voice
  - Space of Reeve: avascular space between upper pole of thyroid and cricothyroid muscle
- Recurrent laryngeal nerve (motor to all thyroid muscles except cricothyroid):
  - Run close to inferior thyroid artery
  - Injury causes voice hoarseness or airway obstruction (if bilateral partial injury)
  - Simon's triangle: CCA (lateral), esophagus (medial), ITA (superior)
  - Berry's ligament: attach thyroid gland to cricoid and first 2 rings

[Surgical Image: A surgical site showcasing the recurrent laryngeal nerve. The nerve is highlighted by a yellow arrow, indicating its position in the surgical field. The tissues and surrounding structures are also visible, providing context to the nerve's location.]

Approach to thyroid nodules
Differential diagnosis
(Hyperthyroid, euthyroid, hypothyroid) Around 10-15% of nodules are malignant
| | |
| :---------------- | :----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Solitary nodule | Dominant nodule in MNG Cyst: true simple cyst, colloid nodule Neoplastic: adenoma, **toxic adenoma**, carcinoma |
| Multiple nodules | MNG (Hyperplastic/ adenomatous nodules with varying degree of cystic degeneration), **toxic MNG** Cyst (multiple) Neoplastic: multiple adenoma |
| Diffuse | Graves' disease Physiological (pregnancy, puberty) Hashimoto's thyroiditis De Quervain's/ subacute thyroiditis |

History taking

- Neck lumps:
  - Number
  - Onset & progression
  - Pain (haemorrhagic cyst, thyroiditis, anaplastic carcinoma)
- Compression symptoms: dysphagia, SOB (stridor), HOV
- Thyroid status
- Risk factors for CA:
  - Prior neck irradiation
  - FHx of CA thyroid: MENII, FAP

Physical examination

Investigations
| | Routine | Selective | |
| :------------------- | :------ | :------------------------------------------------ | :------------------------------------------------------------------ |
| History + Physical exam | √ | | |
| Thyroid function test | √ | | |
| USG thyroid +/- FNAC | √ | | |
| Thyroid scan | X | Only in toxic (elevated TSH) + nodules | |
| CT scan | X | Only when (1) Retrosternal goiter | |

Retrosternal goitre requires CT because:

1. Cannot be visualised by USG
2. Surgical planning
3. Retrosternal goitre may be malignant

Locally advanced disease for CT because:

1. Important structures within cervical fascia (for better delineation)

Routine for all patients: TFT, thyroid USG, FNAC
Thyroid function test (TFT): routinely done to identify potentially toxic nodules
Thyroid USG:

- Role:
  - Thyroid gland: assess size of goitre
  - Nodule: number, any suspicious features
  - Cervical LN (esp. deep nodes, e.g. level VI nodes)
  - Assess retrosternal extension
  - Guide FNAC
- Sonographic features suspicious of malignancy: "SHIT CME" - most important are **solid & hypoechoic**

[Image of a Thyroid ultrasound showing different nodules. From left to right, top to bottom, there are images of a hypoechoic nodule, a solid nodule, and an irregular lobulated margin. Below these, there is an image showing taller than wide, microcalcifications, and extrathyroidal extension.]

SHIT CME

- Solid nodule
- Hypoechoic nodule
- Irregular margin
- Taller than wide (AP > TS)
- Chaotic central vascularity
- Microcalcifications
- Extrathyroidal extension

FNAC (under USG guidance)

- Diagnostic and therapeutic for **thyroid cysts**
- Limited assessment on architecture: cannot distinguish follicular adenoma vs carcinoma
- Note: theoretically only for nodule ≥ 1cm based on risk stratification, but all nodules are aspirated in practice
  _Indications for FNAC (UpToDate)_

| Sonographic pattern    | Ultrasound features                                                      | Risk of malignancy | FNA size cut-off       |
| :--------------------- | :----------------------------------------------------------------------- | :----------------- | :--------------------- |
| High suspicion         | Solid hypoechoic nodule + ≥ 1 suspicious features                        | ≥ 70-90%           | FNA if ≥ 1cm           |
| Intermediate suspicion | Hypoechoic solid nodule with smooth margins without other suspicious S/S | 10-20%             | FNA if ≥ 1cm           |
| Low suspicion          | Isoechoic or hyperechoic nodule with no suspicious features              | 5-10%              | FNA if ≥ 1.5cm         |
| Very low suspicion     | Partially cystic nodule                                                  | ≤ 3%               | FNA if ≥ 2cm / observe |
| Benign                 | Purely cystic nodules                                                    | ≤ 1%               | No biopsy              |

- Complications: pain, bleeding, false negative

Thyroid scan (I-123)

- Indicated for clinical or subclinical hyperthyroidism (only ↓TSH)
- Differentiate between toxic nodule (→ hemithyroidectomy) vs toxic MNG / Graves' (→ total thyroidectomy)
- Cold nodules are more likely malignant (3-15% risk)

PET CT has **NO diagnostic role** in thyroid diseases - even malignant nodules can have low uptake

Approach to multiple nodules

- Malignancy risk much lower
- USG: assess each nodule separately
- FNAC: depend on USG result
  - If no suspicious nodules: FNA the largest nodule
  - Any suspicious nodules: FNA all suspicious nodules

Overview of management

|              | Solitary           | Multinodular        |
| ------------ | ------------------ | ------------------- |
| Euthyroid    | Observe Hemi if 4C | Observe Total if 4C |
| Hyperthyroid | Hemi               | Total               |

Thyroglossal cysts
Definition: failure of thyroglossal tract to obliterate by gestational weeks 7-10 → cystic expansion of remnant

Clinical features:

- Midline upper neck mass, can be slightly lateral
- 60% located at thyrohyoid membrane level
- Tongue tug test +ve
- Association: thyroid ectopia (mostly lingual thyroid) → hypothyroidism
- Complications: abscess (tenderness, fever), fistula formation, malignant transformation to papillary CA (rare)

Investigations:

- CT neck with contrast (USG cannot delineate relations with hyoid)
- USG ± FNAC: confirm presence of normal thyroid gland (otherwise removal of thyroglossal duct might cause
  hypothyroidism)

Management:

- Sistrunk operation: remove cyst + duct + whole tract (including **body of hyoid bone** up to foramen cecum) to prevent recurrence
- Infected cyst: antibiotics → Sistrunk operation

Thyrotoxicosis
Indications
| | Graves' | Toxic MNG (Plummer's) | Toxic nodule |
| :-------------------- | :------- | :------------------------------------------------------------ | :----------- |
| Antithyroid drugs | 1st line | (Ineffective: recur upon discontinuation) Prolonged use if patient does not want RAI or surgery | |
| Radioactive iodine | 2nd line | Preferred if no 4C | |
| Surgery | 2nd line | Preferred if 4C | |

Pre-op preparation in thyrotoxic patients undergoing thyroid surgery

- Maintain **biochemically euthyroid** at operation to prevent thyroid storm
  - High dose carbimazole (30-40mg/day) for 8-12 weeks, then low dose (15mg/day) to maintain euthyroid
  - Propranolol (40mg tds): block beta receptor + reduce T4-T3 conversion
    - More rapid clinical response (days instead of weeks)
    - T4 level still high post-op: continue propranolol until **7 days** post-op
  - Lugol's iodine: ↓iodine uptake + ↓vascularity of thyroid gland (↓intra-op bleeding)
    - Can be given with carbimazole / beta-blocker for 10 days before operation
- Monitor Ca & vit D level and supplement accordingly (post-op hypoPTH/hungry bone syndrome)
- Vocal cord function by laryngoscopy

Extent of resection

- Graves': total thyroidectomy recommended (c.f. subtotal thyroidectomy)
  - Total thyroidectomy vs subtotal thyroidectomy in Graves' disease
    - Immediate return to euthyroid state (vs variable duration)
    - No risk of recurrence
    - Higher risk of
      - Thyroid failure (100%)
      - Parathyroid injury
      - RLN injury
- Toxic MNG: total thyroidectomy
- Toxic adenoma: hemithyroidectomy (if no evidence of nodules in contralateral lobe)
