Metastatic thyroid cancer

- Renal cell carcinoma (MC)
- Others: colorectal, lung, breast, uterine

Risk factors

- Female
- Family history of thyroid cancer
- Previous H&N irradiation e.g. childhood leukemia
- Familial syndrome, e.g. FAP (papillary), MENII (MTC)
- Hashimoto's thyroiditis (thyroid lymphoma), iodine deficiency (follicular CA)
  Note: Follicular adenoma is NOT a risk factor of follicular CA
  Clinical features
- Palpable neck lumps
- Rapidly enlarging lumps: pain, HOV, stridor
- Multiple enlarged cervical LN

Investigations

- Bloods: TFT (normal), CaPO4 (parathyroid function), thyroid Ab and thyroglobulin (tumor marker)
- Thyroid USG: suspicious features (SHIT CME)
- FNAC: Bethesda system
- CT neck and chest: if locally advanced CA thyroid / bulky LN
- Pre-op workup for MTC - Rule out familial disease (25%): FHx, 24h urine metanephrines, Ca & PTH - Tumour markers: calcitonin (metatstatic if >500), CEA - Workup for metastatic disease if calcitonin > 500: СТ
  T+A+P & bone scan

Staging of thyroid cancer

- Differentiated thyroid cancers: age-dependent
  - Age <55: Stage I if MO, Stage II if M1, never Stage III/IV
  - Age 255: Up to Stage IVB
- Anaplastic thyroid cancers: Stage IV automatically

- T staging:
  - Tla: tumor ≤ 1cm
  - T1b: 1cm < tumor ≤ 2cm
  - T2: 2cm < tumor ≤ 4cm
  - T3: >4cm but limited to thyroid
  - T4: extrathyroidal extension
- N staging: - Nla: Level VI / VII nodes - N1b: Level I-V nodes
  [Image: The number 194 is written in the top right corner of the page.]

Management
Choice of thyroidectomy

1. Differentiated CA thyroid (papillary / follicular)

# Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma

[Image of a flowchart showing the management of Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma. It starts with "Surgery for thyroid gland" and then asks "Any one of the following: 1. Size >4cm (T3) 2. Gross extrathyroidal extension (T4) 3. LN positive (N1) 4. Metastasis positive (M1) 5. Familial disease (high risk) 6. Bilateral or multifocal". If the answer is "NO", it asks "Tumor size?". If the tumor size is >1cm-4cm, then "Total thyroidectomy" is chosen, otherwise, if size ≤1cm "Observation" is chosen. If the answer to the first question is "YES" Total thyroidectomy is chosen. From "Tumor size?" is "Surgery for LN" which leads to "Therapeutic CCD When central LN +ve" and "+ Therapeutic lateral MRND When lateral LN +ve"]

| Total thyroidectomy                                                                  | Hemithyroidectomy                                            |
| ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ | ------------------------------------------------------------ |
| Total thyroidectomy                                                                  | Hemithyroidectomy                                            |
| - Papillary CA tends to be multifocal                                                | - Morbidities are lower, especially parathyroid & RLN injury |
| - Prevent local recurrence which may progress to undifferentiated CA (anaplastic CA) | - Progression to undifferentiated CA is rare                 |
| - Allow post-op thyroglobulin monitoring                                             | - No evidence to show inferior prognosis                     |
| - Allow adjuvant RAI                                                                 | - Lifelong thyroxine replacement not required                |
|                                                                                      | - RAI is not required in most patients                       |

2. Medullary CA thyroid: total thyroidectomy (require prophylactic total thyroidectomy in high-risk MEN2 cases)
   Choice of neck dissection
   Terms: central compartment dissection (Level VI) vs lateral neck dissection (Level II-V)
1. Papillary CA thyroid:

- Therapeutic CCD/LCD if respective compartment +ve
- No role for prophylactic neck dissection

2. Follicular CA thyroid:

- Usually not required (haematogenous spread)

3. Medullary CA thyroid: often need to dissect one level up

- Prophylactic CCD for all patients
- Ipsilateral central LN +ve: + ipsilateral LCD
- Ipsilateral lateral LN +ve: + ipsilateral LCD (if calcitonin < 200), + bilateral LCD (if calcitonin > 200)
- Contralateral LN +ve: +bilateral LCD

[Image of a diagram of Lymph node levels in the neck, numbered I to VII with corresponding anatomical locations highlighted in different colors. Lymph node levels (I, II, III, IV, V, VI, VII) and associated Lymph node levels]

Post-operative adjuvant treatments

- Remnant ablation: - Residual thyroid tissue actually non-functional (require T4 supp anyway), but it interferes with post- op thyroglobulin monitoring and also cannot r/o residual malignancy!
  | Radioactive iodine ablation (RAI): | External beam irradiation (EBRT) |
  | ----------- | ----------- |
  | Pre-op give rTSH or withdraw T4 to promote ¹³¹I intake<br>Low iodine diet x1 week | |
  | Similar to indication for total thyroidectomy (above): | Indications include: |
  | - T3 / T4 disease | - Positive surgical margins |
  | - N1 / M1 disease | - Incomplete resection (residual tumor left) |
  | - Aggressive histology: tall cell, columnar cell, diffuse sclerosing, poorly differentiated PTC | |

Thyroxine

- Roles: Replacement (prevent hypothyroidism) ± suppression (high TSH stimulates tumour growth)
- Target TSH depends on risk - note that low risk group does NOT require TSH suppression (for reference)
  | Low risk | None of the following features | No TSH suppression (0.5-2.0 mIU/L) |
  | ------------------ | ------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------ |
  | Intermediate risk | - T3, N1 | Low TSH suppression (0.1-0.5 mIU/L) |
  | | - Aggressive histology | |
  | | - Vascular invasion +ve | |
  | High risk | - T4, M1 | High TSH suppression (<0.1 mIU/L) |
  | | - Incomplete resection | |

- Disease monitoring:
  - Neck USG Q6m
  - Bloods: TSH & thyroglobulin (on thyroxine suppression) Q3m - can be performed for both total/hemithyroidectomy
    - Total hemithyroidectomy: Tg < 0.2
    - Hemithyroidectomy: Tg < 30

Thyroidectomy
Indications (4C)

- CA thyroid
- Uncontrolled thyrotoxicosis
- Compression
- Cosmetic concern

Pre-op evaluation

- Maintain biochemically euthyroid (refer to [Thyrotoxicosis])
- Vocal cord function by laryngoscopy
- Monitor Ca & vit D level and supplement accordingly (post-op hypoPTH/hungry bone syndrome)

Terminologies

- Total thyroidectomy: resection of both lobes + isthmus + pyramidal lobe
- Subtotal thyroidectomy: resection of > 1/2 of both lobes + isthmus
- Hemithyroidectomy: resection of one lobe + isthmus
- Lobectomy: resection of one lobe (isthmus preserved)

Alternative surgical approaches (reference)

- Bilateral axillo-breast approach (BABA)
- Transoral vestibular approach
- Retro-auricular trans-hairline approach (RATH)

[Image of a patient's neck post-surgery, displaying significant bruising and swelling. The bruising is most prominent around the surgical incision site in the lower neck area, extending upwards towards the jawline and down towards the upper chest. The skin appears discolored, with shades of purple, blue, and yellow indicating the presence of blood underneath the skin. The swelling causes the neck to appear enlarged and distorted compared to its normal contours. There are visible surgical sutures or staples along the incision line.]

Early complications x3

- Reactionary haemorrhage (fig.) - Patho: reactionary bleeding within first 24h post-op → haematoma
  compresses on venous return → laryngeal oedema → complete closure
  of vocal cord → asphyxiation
- Management:
  - Remove all stitches from skin down to cervical fascia at bedside (first action!)
  - Resuscitation: protect airway, give supplemental oxygen
  - Arrange EOT for haemostasis

- Hoarseness of voice (HOV)
  - Transient HOV: due to vocal cord oedema caused by endotracheal intubation, resolve spontaneously
  - Persistent HOV: RLN injury

|            | Partial injury (irritation)                    | Complete injury                                         |
| :--------- | :--------------------------------------------- | :------------------------------------------------------ |
| Unilateral | Hoarseness                                     | Hoarseness                                              |
| Bilateral  | Airway obstruction (6 adductors > 2 adductors) | Hoarseness: stay in anatomical position (i.e. mid open) |

- Management: cord medialization procedures – e.g. injection thyroplasty, open thyroplasty (Gortex)
- EBSLN injury: loss of high pitch (cricothyroid muscle), poor volume, easy fatigue
- Parathyroid injury
  - Only in total thyroidectomy
  - Most common complication, but usually transient
  - S/S: **perioral numbness**, carpopedal spasm, Chvostek's sign, Trousseau's sign
    - Severe hypoCa can lead to **laryngospasm** requiring emergency intubation / surgical airway
  - Mx: Ca + vit D supplement (acute: IV Ca gluconate)

Late complications x2

- Hypothyroidism (late)
- Wound complications
  - Hypertrophic / Keloid scar
  - Wound infection is NOT a recognized complication (clean surgical field)

Post-op dyspnoea DDx:

- Haemorrhage: hypovolaemic shock, laryngeal oedema
- Bilateral RLN irritation causing airway obstruction
- Laryngeal spasm due to hypocalcaemia
- Injury to trachea/ pneumothorax
- Tracheomalacia (floppy tracheal wall due to chronic compression)

  9.2 Parathyroid
  Basics
  Anatomy
  | | Embryology | Position |
  | :----------------- | :------------------------ | :----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
  | Superior (x2) | 4th pharyngeal pouch | **More constant** (shorter migration) Most common: intersection of ITA & RLN |
  | Inferior (x2) | 3rd pharyngeal pouch | Less constant (longer migration) Most common: inferior pole of thyroid gland |

- Vascular supply: inferior thyroid artery supplies all four glands

Physiology
| | PTH (active 84-aa peptide) | Calcitonin |
| :-------------------- | :----------------------------------------------------------------------------- | :----------------------- |
| Site | Chief cells of parathyroid glands | C cells of thyroid gland |
| Half life | 4 min | 60min |
| Effect | Kidney: ↑Ca reabsorption Activate vitamin D Bone: act on osteoblast & osteoclast to ↑Ca | Antagonist PTH action |

[Diagram illustrating the physiological effects of PTH and calcitonin on calcium levels. It depicts the parathyroid gland releasing PTH in response to low calcium levels. PTH acts on the kidneys to increase calcium reabsorption and phosphate excretion. It also stimulates the conversion of 25(OH)D to calcitriol, which promotes calcium absorption in the intestine. In bone, PTH stimulates both osteoblasts and osteoclasts, leading to bone resorption and the release of calcium. In contrast, calcitonin, produced by C cells of the thyroid gland, inhibits osteoclastic activity, reducing calcium release from bone.]

Causes of hypercalcemia
| | | |
| :-------------------- | :----------------------------------- | :----------------------- |
| Hyperparathyroidism | Primary hyperparathyroidism | Check PTH |
| Renal failure | Secondary or tertiary hyperparathyroidism | Check history and RFT |
| Malignancy | Paraneoplastic syndromes (PTHrP) | Check history and PE |
| Granulomatous diseases| Sarcoidosis Tuberculosis | Check history and PE |
| Medications | Thiazide diuretics Vitamin A or D intoxication Lithium intoxication | Check history |
| Increased bone turnover | Immobilization Paget's disease Thyrotoxicosis | Check history and PE |

Clinical features of hypercalcaemia

- Renal stone (MC): dehydration
- Painful bone: osteopenia / osteoporosis, "salt-and-pepper" degranulation of skull
- Abdominal groans: due to ileus, PUD (gastrin secretion), pancreatitis
- Psychic moans: fatigue, memory impairment

[X-ray image showing a skull with "salt-and-pepper" degranulation, a characteristic feature of hyperparathyroidism.]

Acute management of hypercalcemia [MED]
| | |
| :------------------------------------- | :---------------------------------------------------- |
| Intravenous saline rehydration | Induce natriuresis and calciuresis |
| Intravenous loop diuretics e.g. furosemide | Induce natriuresis and calciuresis |
| Intravenous bisphosphonate e.g. pamidronate | Inhibit osteoclastic activity and reduce Ca release from bone |
| Calcitonin / Glucocorticoids | Inhibit osteoclastic activity |
| Dialysis | Mechanically remove plasma calcium |

# Primary hyperparathyroidism

Aetiology

- Sporadic: risk factor is previous H&N irradiation
- Familial: MENI/ΙΙΑ

Pathology

- Solitary parathyroid adenoma (80%)
- Multi-gland parathyroid adenoma (5-10%)
- 4-gland hyperplasia (MEN1, MEN2A) (10%)
- Parathyroid carcinoma (<1%)

Investigations

- Biochemical diagnosis: **hyperCa + high/normal PTH**
  - Vit D: rule out vit D deficiency
  - **24h urine Ca (must check!)**: rule out familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia (FHH)
- Screen for complications of hyperCa
  - Bone scan
  - KUB / USG kidney
  - ALP: ↑ level predict risk of hungry bone syndrome post-op
- **Localisation studies of hyperfunctioning parathyroid: USG + Sestamibi scan**
  (Role: to localise the parathyroid glands to determine whether unilateral
  exploration is needed - 5% present with double adenoma) - USG neck: non-invasive, parathyroid adenomas appear hypoechoic - Sestamibi scan: - Mechanism - **Sestamibi** accumulates in **mitochondria**, and washout rate depends on number of mitochondria in tissues - Parathyroid adenomas are rich in **oxyphilic cells** (lots of mitochondria), so there is **slow washout** compared to thyroid gland - Protocols: Take photo 10 min after injection + after **2h washout time** - Single isotope dual-phase scan - Dual isotope subtraction imaging (**⁹⁹Tc-Sestamibi scan**): subtract thyroid signal
  [Image of two nuclear medicine scans of a patient's neck and upper chest. The images are side-by-side. The left image is labeled "10 mins" and shows a small, bright area in the lower left part of the neck. The right image is labeled "2 hours" and shows that the bright area is still visible, but it has not spread or changed significantly.]

              - Single-photon emission CT scan (SPECT): 3D scan with higher resolution
              - False positive: Hurthle cell adenoma
          - 4D CT scan: multiphase CT imaging, but high radiation dose ®
          - Parathyroid angiography with **selective venous sampling**: invasive, reserved for re-operative cases

Management
Indications of surgical management

- **Symptomatic** PHPT: renal stones, abdominal groans, psychic moans, painful bones
- Asymptomatic PHPT (CASR):
  - Adjusted **Ca ≥ 2.8**
  - Young Age < 50 (longer exposure to PTH → _osteoporosis_)
  - Skeletal (DEXA T score < -2.5 / vertebral fracture on imaging)
  - Renal (CrCl < 60 / 24h urine Ca > 10mmol/L / nephrolithiasis on imaging)

Options

- Focused parathyroidectomy
  - Indication: **adenoma identified** on pre-op localization studies
  - Based on the premise that 80% are due to single adenoma
  - Approach: open with <3cm incision (fig.), video-assisted, imaging-guided
  - Intra-op PTH measurement to confirm removal of hyperfunctioning gland
    - Miami criteria: PTH drop to normal range + <50% of max value at 10min post-resection
    - If -ve: multigland disease possible → convert to BCE
  - Benefits: ↓ post-op hypoCa

[A photograph shows a person's neck and upper chest area. The person has fair skin. A thin white bandage covers a small incision in the lower neck, slightly to the right of the midline. The skin around the bandage is slightly red. A blue surgical drape is visible below the neck. To the right of the neck, the skin appears somewhat mottled and discolored with yellowish tint.]

- Bilateral neck exploration (BCE)
  - Indications: conversion from focused parathyroidectomy, MEN1/2A, uncertain imaging (e.g. USG not consistent with MIBI findings)
  - Approach: Kocher's incision (transverse collar scar)
  - Subtotal parathyroidectomy: "3.5 resection"
    - 3 glands resected
    - Fourth gland: 1/2 gland taken out for **frozen section**(to confirm presence of parathyroid tissue), remaining 1/2 gland left in situ, marked with non-absorbable sutures to aid identification in case of recurrent disease
  - Total parathyroidectomy with autotransplantation (rare)

- ± Cervical thymectomy: indicated if MEN1 to resect supernumerary glands in thymus

Specific complications

- RLN injury
- Reactionary haemorrhage (refer to [Thyroidectomy])
- Hypocalcemia: routinely check Ca level on post-op Day 1
  - Hungry bone syndrome: rapid, profound hypocalcaemia due to sudden drop in PTH, causing a rapid deposition of Ca into demineralised bone; Mx Ca + vit D
  - After focused parathyroidectomy: **transient** suppression of normal glands by adenoma
  - **Permanent hypoparathyroidism**: requiring Ca / vit D supplement **1 year** post-op
- Hyperparathyroidism:
  - Persistent (<6 mo post-op): due to missed pathology → Mx BCE
  - Recurrent (>6 mo post-op): due to missed pathology, parathyromatosis (disseminated parathyroid tissue within the soft tissue of neck and mediastinum due to rupture of parathyroid gland during operation) → Mx MIBI scan, BCE

Medical management

- Indications: surgically unfit
- Options: bisphosphonates, calcimimetics (e.g. cinacalcet), SERM

Tertiary hyperparathyroidism
Definition: persistent autonomous hypercalcaemic hyperparathyroidism after renal replacement therapy
Indications: persistent severe hypercalcaemia, impaired graft
function, progressive symptoms (e.g. osteoporotic fracture)
Procedures

- Total parathyroidectomy: only considered when renal
  transplant is highly unlikely
- Total parathyroidectomy with autotransplantation at
  forearm (brachioradialis) or neck (SCM)
- Subtotal parathyroidectomy (three-and-a-half resection):

[An illustration shows the superficial veins of the left elbow and forearm. The basilic vein runs up the inner arm, the cephalic vein runs up the outer arm, and the median cubital vein connects them in the elbow area. Labels point to each vein. Adjacent to this image is another illustration. It depicts a cross-sectional view of skin. A needle is inserted into the epidermis, past the sebaceous gland, into the subcutaneous fat and deep venous plexus. Labels point to the sweat gland, surface vascular plexus, sebaceous gland, subcutaneous fat, deep venous plexus, and parathyroid graft.]

9.3 Adrenals
Anatomy

[Diagram of the kidneys and adrenal glands. The right and left adrenal glands are located above the right and left kidneys, respectively. Blood vessels surround the kidneys and adrenal glands, including the inferior phrenic artery, the superior suprarenal arteries, the left suprarenal gland, the middle suprarenal artery, the left suprarenal vein, the inferior suprarenal artery, the left kidney, the right suprarenal gland, the right suprarenal vein, the right kidney, the inferior vena cava, and the abdominal aorta.]

- Retroperitoneal organ, situated within Gerota's capsule
- Right adrenal gland
  - Pyramid shaped
  - Relations: diaphragm (posterior), **right lobe of liver** (anterior), IVC (anteromedial)
- Left adrenal gland
  - Crescent shaped
  - Relations: pancreatic tail, spleen, stomach (anterior), diaphragm (posterior)
- Arterial supply
  - Superior suprarenal arteries (6-8) from inferior phrenic a.
  - Middle suprarenal arteries (≥1) from abdominal aorta
  - Inferior suprarenal arteries (≥1) from renal artery
- Venous supply
  - Right adrenal vein → IVC
  - Left adrenal vein → left renal vein
- Physiology
  - Adrenal cortex: zona glomerulosa (aldosterone), fasciculata (cortisol), reticularis (androgen)
  - Adrenal medulla: epinephrine (80%), norepinephrine (20%)
    - **Urine metanephrines:** breakdown product of dopamine metabolism

[Diagram illustrating the pathway of dopamine synthesis and the production of normetanephrine and metanephrine in the adrenal medulla. The pathway starts with L-Tyrosine, which is converted to DOPA by Tyrosine hydroxylase. DOPA is then converted to Dopamine by DOPA decarboxylase. Dopamine is converted to Norepinephrine by Dopamine hydroxylase and then to Epinephrine by PNMT. Norepinephrine is converted to Normetanephrine and Epinephrine is converted to Metanephrine by COMT. A small graphic of the adrenal gland is shown next to "Adrenal Medulla"]

[Diagram of a hexagon with a lightening bolt in the middle of it. It says A cortisol-induced enzyme underneath the hexagon.]

202

Adrenal incidentaloma
Definition

- Adrenal mass > **1cm** in diameter _incidentally found_ in radiological investigation
- Incidence: 0.5-4.5%
- Most important to know: **Functional? Malignant potential?**

Aetiology

- Benign:
  - Non-functional 90%, e.g. **adenoma** (MC), cyst, haemangioma, myelolipoma
  - Functional: subclinical Cushing's syndrome (6%), phaeochromocytoma, Conn's syndrome
- Malignant:
  - Primary: malignant phaeochromocytoma, adrenocortical carcinoma
  - Secondary (more common)

History taking

- History of hypertension (all functional tumors), diabetes (Cushing's)
- S/S of Cushing syndrome: weight gain, striae
- Triad of pheochromocytoma: episodic headache, sweating, palpitations
- FHx / Hx of endocrine tumors (MEN)

Physical examination

- BP, H'stix
- Cushingoid features: moon face, buffalo hump, proximal muscle wasting, central obesity, striae, hirsutism, easy bruising
- Abdominal mass
- Thyroid mass

Investigations

- Screening tests for functional tumors: **ONDST + spot ARR + 24h urine metanephrines**

|                    | Screening                      | Confirmation               |
| :----------------- | :----------------------------- | :------------------------- |
| Cushing's syndrome | 1mg ONDST > 50 nmol/L          | Low dose DST               |
|                    | 24h urine free cortisol        |                            |
|                    | Midnight salivary cortisol     |                            |
| Conn's syndrome    | Aldosterone: renin ratio (ARR) | Salt loading test          |
|                    | RFT for hypoK                  | Saline suppression test    |
| Pheochromocytoma   | 24h urine metanephrines        | Clonidine suppression test |

- CT abdomen (preferably **contrast CT with adrenal protocol**) to evaluate malignant potential
  - Size **>4cm** (25% risk of malignancy)
  - Growing **>0.5cm over 6 months**
  - Morphology: irregular shape, heterogenous, ill-defined border, hypervascularity, central necrosis
  - Hounsfield unit: >10HU (c.f. 70% adenoma has high lipid content -> hypo-attenuated)
  - Contrast wash-out (compare non-enhanced PV phase vs 15-minute delayed phase): **<40% relative washout or <60% absolute washout** (c.f. adenoma usually has more washout)
  - Local invasion
  - Para-aortic lesions
  - Contralateral side involvement
- ± Other investigations
  - MRI adrenal: compare signal intensity with spleen
  - PET-CT: ↑Sn & ↑Sp to differentiate benign vs malignant lesion; compare SUV with liver
  - Fine needle aspiration: only useful in **ruling out metastasis**; must **exclude pheochromocytoma before biopsy** (risk of hemodynamic instability)

Management

- Conservative:
  - Imaging: CT abdomen Q6m for 4 years
  - Biochemical: Q1y for 4 years
- Surgical: if
  - Functional
  - Suspected malignancy (refer above): e.g. >4cm, growing >0.5cm in 6 months

Adrenalectomy
Indications

- Adrenal incidentaloma that meets the resection criteria (see above)
- Adrenal malignancy
- Functional adenoma (phaeochromocytoma, Conn's syndrome, adrenal Cushing's syndrome)
- Cushing disease that is persistent after transsphenoidal resection
  Approach
- Laparoscopic trans-peritoneal approach (lateral decubitus, ipsilateral side up): for mass < 6cm
- Open: preferred if mass > 6cm or malignant
  Pre-op preparation
- Primary aldosteronism: correct electrolyte imbalance, e.g. K
- Cushing's syndrome: peri-op steroid cover, antibiotic prophylaxis (chronic suppressed cortisol)
- Phaeochromocytoma: alpha blockade → beta blockade, fluid replacement
  Complications
- Intra-op:
  - Haemodynamic instability (phaeochromocytoma)
  - Adrenal insufficiency (Conn's, Cushing's): IV hydrocortisone upon removal of adrenal gland
  - Injury to surroundings:
    - Right adrenalectomy: IVC, right lobe of liver
    - Left adrenalectomy: pancreatic tail, spleen
- Early: adrenal insufficiency (PO hydrocortisone post-op)
- Late: hypertension (renal artery injury)

Cushing syndrome
Refer to [MED] for details
Diagnosis
2 out of 3 screening tests ± high pre-test probability by clinical presentation

- 1mg ONDST > 50 nmol/L
- 24h UFC x 3
- LDDST / Late night salivary cortisol x2 / Late night plasma cortisol
- OR: 24h UFC > 3-4x ULN

Management
Definitive treatment depends on underlying cause

- Pituitary: trans-sphenoidal surgery ± pituitary radiotherapy / radiosurgery
- Adrenal: adrenalectomy ± chemotherapy (if CA)
- Ectopic: treat underlying malignancy

Peri-operative cautions:

- Steroid cover: normal HPA axis usually suppressed
- Prophylactic antibiotics ± anticoagulation: high risk of infections / VTE
- Post-op glucocorticoid ± mineralocorticoid supplement until HPA axis recovers ~1y later
- Risk of Nelson's syndrome if bilateral adrenalectomy

204
Conn's syndrome
Refer to [MED] for details
Differential diagnosis
Differentiated by salt-loaded balance study (9am supine + 1pm erect)

- Aldosterone-producing adenoma: paradoxical aldosterone (ACTH-dependent production)
- Bilateral idiopathic adrenal hyperplasia (BIAH): Taldosterone (sensitive to postural change)
  Management
- Adenoma: laparoscopic adrenalectomy (4 week pre-op spironolactone to correct hypoK)
- BIAH: medical treatment e.g. MRA, amiloride (bilateral adrenalectomy would lead to adrenal crisis)
  Phaeochromocytoma
  Definitions
  Pheochromocytoma: catecholamine-secreting tumour derived from chromaffin cells of adrenal medulla
  Paraganglioma: tumour arising from chromaffin cells of sympathetic / parasympathetic nervous system
- Sympathetic paraganglioma: usually catecholamine-secreting (i.e. "extra-adrenal pheochromocytoma"), located
  along sympathetic chain
- Parasympathetic paraganglioma: usually non-functional, located in neck / skull base
  Aetiology
- Sporadic (MC)
- Familial (AD inheritance) - NF1 - MEN2 (RET oncogene) - Von Hippel-Lindau disease - Carney triad (GIST + pulmonary chondroma + paragangliomas): succinate dehydrogenase gene mutation
  Clinical features
- 60% incidentally discovered
- Classic triad: paroxysmal headache, sweating, palpitations
- Other S/S: young-onset paroxysmal HT + postural hypotension (due to
  adrenaline action), anxiety, pallor
- Pressor response during procedures or with certain drugs (e.g. TCA, IV
  contrast) or food (cheese)
- 10% rule: 10% familial, 10% bilateral, 10% extra-adrenal, 10% malignant,
  10% secrete adrenaline/ dopamine (c.f. 90% NA), 10% children, 10% not
  associated with HT, 10% recurrence - Extra-adrenal: para-aortic (75%), urinary bladder (10%), thorax
  (10%), skull base / neck / pelvis (5%), others\*
- Pheochromocytoma crisis: APO, ICH
  [Image of a box containing five P's of Pheochromocytoma. Each P is on a separate line. The P's are: Pressure (HT), Pain (headache, chest pain), Palpitation, Perspiration, Pallor (vasoconstriction)]

\*Organ of Zuckerkandl

- Location: origin of IMA / around aortic bifurcation
- Function: secrete catecholamines during early gestational period
  to regulate BP → regress in late 3rd trimester
  Investigations
  Biopsy is NOT required: high risk of hypertensive crisis and hematoma
- Biochemical:
  screening
- 24h urine catecholamines + fractionated metanephrines (more sensitive: continuous release)
  - Abnormal if >2x elevation
  - False positive: stress, OSA, drugs (e.g. TCA, a agonist, levodopa → stop 1 week)
- Plasma catecholamine / metanephrine (most specific, but need indwelling catheter >30min)
  - Preferred in chronic renal failure because 24h urine sample is difficult to interpret
- Imaging:
  localize tumour
- Anatomical scan: CT with low-osmolar contrast / T2-MRI with gadolinium contrast
  - CT: alpha blockade prior to administration of IV contrast ('.'risk of HT crisis)
  - Low-osmolar contrast: safe even without alpha/beta blockade
- Functional scan: I-123 MIBG scan
  - MIBG (metaiodobenzylguanidine): NE analog, taken up by pheochromocytoma
- PET-CT: 68Gallium-DOTATATE - to detect metastatic disease

205
Dynamic test

- Clonidine suppression test: only if strong clinical suspicion but above tests inconclusive - C/I in pregnancy - Procedure: - Fast overnight → Insert cannula 30 minutes before test → Take bloods for Epi & NE x2 (5 mins apart) - Give PO clonidine 0.3mg with 250mL water - Closely monitor BP/P Q30min for postural hypotension and bradycardia - Take bloods for Epi & NE at 2h and 3h after clonidine
  Management
- Laparoscopic resection (1\* line) - consider open if large tumor / suspected malignancy
- Adequate pre-op preparation: aim to prevent intra-op pheochromocytoma crisis
  - BP and HR control: target BP 130/80 HR 70 (seated)
    - **Alpha blocker** (BP): phenoxybenzamine x 4 weeks (S/E: stuffy nose)
    - **THEN Beta blocker** (HR): propranolol x 2-3 days preoperatively
    - Rationale: ẞ-blocker alone can cause unopposed a-mediated vasoconstriction → HT crisis
    - Postural hypotension indicates adequate alpha blockade
  - Volume expansion: high Na diet on 2nd/3rd day of alpha blockade to reverse catecholamine-induced volume contraction
- Intra-op
  - Meticulous monitoring: risk of unstable haemodynamics → ensure A-line, CVP, Foley
  - Communicate with experienced anesthesist: e.g. possible HT crisis during intubation, inform anesthetist before mobilization / ligation of tumor, medications stand-by (e.g. nitroprusside, adrenaline/NA)
  - Gentle manipulation of lesion
  - Dissect and control adrenal vein first
- Post-operative ICU monitoring for specific complications
  - Cardiac arrhythmia
  - Hypotension: drug effect
  - Hypoglycemia: rebound hyperinsulinemia
- Genetic testing & counselling
- Disease monitoring: lifelong yearly screening for recurrent / metastatic / metachronous tumor - Urine catecholamines, chromogranin A (not useful for diagnosis), imaging
  Malignant pheochromocytoma
- Histologically and biochemically indistinguishable from benign disease, defined by metastasis
- Management: - Surgical excision (tumor debulking) to control catecholamine excess - Symptomatic relief: alpha blockers - Mitotane: adjuvant / palliative treatment
  Adrenocortical carcinoma
- Rare malignancy, highly malignant
- May show biochemical evidence of steroid overproduction
  Investigations
- Contrast CT/MRI: look for vascular and adjacent organ invasion
- FNA biopsy is NOT indicated: cannot differentiate between benign and malignant mass, risk of tumor seeding
  Treatment
- Surgery: open adrenalectomy ± en-bloc resection of kidney / spleen (if invaded)
- Adjuvant mitotane for at least 2 years (disrupt cortisol synthesis)
  - High-dose glucocorticoid replacement: mitotane induces CYP3A4 → rapid activation of glucocorticoids
- Chemotherapy for refractory disease

  9.4 Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumours (pNET)
  Insulinoma
  Clinical features

- Most common pancreatic NET
- Arise from beta-cells of pancreas
- 90% benign, usually solitary (if multiple: consider MEN1 syndrome)
- Whipple's triad: hypoglycemic symptoms + low BG during symptomatic episodes + relief after glucose intake
  Investigations
- Biochemical tests: glucose, insulin, C-peptide, chromogranin A
  - Exclude MEN1: CaPO4, PTH, prolactin, gastrin
- Confirmatory test: prolonged fasting test [MED]
  - Fast for max 72h (± vigorous exercise 20mins if still no hypoglycemia)
  - H'stix Q4h / when symptomatic → Terminate test if BG < 3.0 (Ensure IV D50 40ml & glucagon stand-by)
  - Check BG, insulin & C-peptide Q24h / when symptomatic / H'stix <3.0
  - Results: ↑insulin, ↑C-peptide = insulinoma
- Localization studies: gold standard is intra-operative localization - CT/MRI scan with contrast: 60-70% sensitivity - EUS with biopsy - PET-CT scan with 68Gallium-DOTATATE - Arterial stimulation with hepatic venous sampling: inject 10% Ca gluconate at 4 different arteries (GDA, SMA, splenic a., hepatic a.), and sample R hepatic vein for 30s & 60s insulin for 2-fold increase
  Treatment
- Medical treatment: buy time for surgery / unfit for surgery / metastatic disease
- Diazoxide: ↓insulin release (S/E: edema, hirsutism)
- Octreotide (2nd line)
- Chemotherapy if inoperable: e.g. doxorubicin, everolimus
  Surgical treatment: advised for ALL patients
  Open surgery with extended Kocher maneuver and mobilization of entire pancreas
- → Intraoperative exploration / ultrasound (IOUS) to locate tumour and identify relation to duct
- → Determine surgical extent
- Surgical enucleation for superficial tumours
- Distal pancreatectomy for tumours deep in body/tail of pancreas or ductal involvement
- Whipple's operation for tumours deep in head/neck of pancreas
  Alternative: EUS-guided alcohol ablation

Gastrinoma / Zollinger-Ellison syndrome
Clinical features

- Arise from G cells: gastrin stimulate parietal cells to ↑acid production & ↑parietal cell mass (synergistic effect)
- 60-80% risk of malignancy
- Commonly arise in "gastrinoma triangle" / Passaro's triangle (fig.)
- Classical triad of
  - Multiple PUD in unusual locations e.g. post-D1 duodenum, jejunum, esophagus
  - Gastric acid hypersecretion
  - Gastrinoma: in pancreas (MC), proximal duodenum, etc.
- Other features: chronic diarrhoea, MEN1 (pituitary adenoma, parathyroid hyperplasia)

Investigations

- Fasting serum gastrin >1000 pg/mL (10x ULN)
- Secretin test: distinguish G cell hyperplasia vs gastrinoma
  - G cell hyperplasia: no change in gastrin level (secretin normally inhibits gastrin)
  - Gastrinoma: ↑serum gastrin > 200 pg/mL (aberrant secretin receptor on gastrinoma cells)
- Pre-op localization: OGD with EUS, contrast CT/MRI, 68Gallium-DOTATATE PET-CT, somatostatin receptor scintigraphy (SRS) scan (i.e. octreotide scan)

Management
Medical management

- High-dose PPI
- Octreotide
- Systemic chemotherapy if metastatic

Surgical management: indicated if non-metastatic

- Pancreatic gastrinomas (worse prognosis): enucleation + peripancreatic LN dissection
- Duodenal gastrinomas: enucleation (if small), full-thickness excision (if large)

Non-functioning pNET

- Worse prognosis than functioning pNET
- Most commonly metastasize to liver
- Differentiated from pancreatic adenocarcinoma

|                                          | CA pancreas                    | Non-functioning PET           |
| ---------------------------------------- | ------------------------------ | ----------------------------- |
| Tumour size                              | <5cm                           | ≥5cm                          |
| CT scan                                  | Hypodensity, no calcifications | Hyperdensity ± calcifications |
| Chromogranin A                           | -                              | +                             |
| Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy (SRS) | -                              | +                             |

- Mainstay of treatment: surgery

# 1.3 Management overview

Non-trauma management
Non-operative

- Health advice: reassurance, change of daily activities, diet, posture, weight reduction, avoid pain-provoking
- Physiotherapy (early mobilisation): RICE, passive stretching, active muscle strengthening, instrumental (TENS), walking exercises
  - Walking aids: stick → tripod/ quadripod → crutches → walking frame → rollator → wheelchair
- Occupational therapy: UL training, ADL training, vocational training, home visits
- Prosthetics & orthotics: splint, brace, corset, prosthesis
  - Orthosis: to support function
  - Prothesis: to replace function
- Pharmacotherapy: analgesics, steroids, drugs for osteoporosis
- Non-operative intervention: closed reduction, manipulation, etc
  Operative
- Treat underlying cause
- Compression (nerve): decompression, removal
- Deformity: correct and reconstruct
- Joint instability: joint re-alignment, joint replacement, joint fusion

[Image Description: The image shows an illustration of different types of mobility aids for individuals with walking difficulties. From left to right are forearm crutches, a pair of armpit crutches, a walking frame, and a cane.]

Enhanced recovery after surgery (ERAS)

- MSSA screening: de-colonization x 1 week
- Pre-op analgesics
- Dexamethasone on call to OT (16mg IV stat)
- HbA1c control: <8
- Confirm definite discharge plan: 1 month full-time carer after TKA

Fracture healing
Types of healing

- Primary (contact) healing
  - Fragments directly apposed with <0.1mm distance
  - Require anatomical reduction and rigid internal fixation
- Secondary (spontaneous) healing
  - Fracture ends are brought close to each other (instead of "apposed")
  - Stages:
    - Haematoma formation (immediate)
    - Soft callus formation (< 2 weeks): inflammatory cells recruited to haematoma; non-weight bearing
    - Bony callus formation (> 2 weeks): allow controlled weight-bearing
    - Remodelling: formation of lamellar bone
- Favourable factors for remodeling
  - Younger age (periosteum thicker)
  - Fracture in metaphysis (close to growth plate)
  - Minimal angulation/ angulation in the plane of joint movement
- Evaluation of bone healing
  - Clinical
  - XR: visible callus, trabeculae across fracture site
- Disturbed fracture healing
  - Risk factors: - Disease factor: blood supply, severe soft tissue damage, etc - Patient factor: smoking, DM, diet - Treatment factor: previous radiation
    [A table with light green header cells and white content cells. The table displays information about bone healing times in the upper and lower limbs. The columns are "Callus visible", "Union" and "Consolidation", and the rows are "Upper Limb" and "Lower Limb" . Callus Visible Upper Limb values is 2-3 wks. Callus Visible Lower Limb value is 2-3 wks. Union Upper Limb value is 4-6 wks. Union Lower Limb value is 8-12 wks. Consolidation Upper Limb value is 6-8 wks. Consolidation Lower Limb value is 12-16 wks.]
- Delayed union: fracture healing 2x normal time (c.f. Perkin's time frame for
- Non-union: fracture healing does not occur after 6 months
  - Sites: scaphoid, NOF
  - Types: atrophic (no callus: failure of biology), hypertrophic (callus +++: failure of stability)
- Malunion: healing in the wrong position
- Refracturing: cortical atrophy due to prolonged fixation material in situ → removed within 18m after remodelling

Fracture XR
XR interpretation
| Site | Name of injured bone |
| -------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
| | **Intra-articular vs extra-articular** (epiphyseal, metaphyseal, diaphyseal) |
| Integrity of skin | **Closed fracture:** fracture with intact overlying skin |
| | **Open fracture:** fracture with direct communication to external environment |
| | - Degree of contamination, extent of soft tissue injury (muscle, vessel) |
| Morphology | Transverse: fracture line perpendicular (<30°) to long axis of bone |
| | Oblique: angular fracture line (30-60°) |
| | Spiral: multi-planar fracture lines as a result of rotational force |
| | Butterfly: triangular fracture fragment (c.f. comminuted) |
| | Comminuted: > 2 fracture fragments |
| | Avulsion: bone fragment pulled off by tendon or ligament |
| | Impacted/ compression: shortened bone, e.g. vertebra |
| Alignment | **Displacement:** non-displaced, displaced, translated (loss of contact) |
| | **Angulation:** varus, valgus |
| | Length: impacted, distracted |
Associated fracture-dislocation (e.g. Monteggia)

XR interpretation in paediatrics

- Specific morphology: due to more active periosteum
  - Bowing (plastic: due to elasticity)
  - Greenstick: incomplete fracture of one cortex
  - Buckled (impacted cortex)
- Epiphyseal injury: weaker part of bone - susceptible to fracture
  - Salter-Harris classification of epiphyseal injury

| Type                     | Stability | Management                        | Remarks                           |
| ------------------------ | --------- | --------------------------------- | --------------------------------- |
| I (Straight through)     | Stable    | Closed reduction + castSCFE: ORIF |                                   |
| II (Above)               | Stable    | Closed reduction + cast           | **Most common**                   |
| III (Low)                | Unstable  | ORIF                              |                                   |
| IV (Through and through) | Unstable  | ORIF                              |                                   |
| V (Ram)                  | Unstable  | No specific treatment             | **Highest risk of growth arrest** |

Principles of trauma management

Overview (6A)

- ABC (resuscitation)
- Anti-swelling (RICE)
- Analgesics: immobilisation as the best analgesic
- Anaesthesia: prepare for OT
- Anchorage (temporary splint, slab, neck collar, Thomas splint, etc.)
- Anti-sepsis (wound cleansing & dressing, antibiotics in open fracture, tetanus prophylaxis)

Immediate management (SAQ)

- Resuscitation if necessary
- Analgesics
- Trauma series: C-spine (#→ neck collar), CXR (pneumothorax → chest drain), pelvic X-ray (external fixator,
  pelvic binder)
- Extremities stabilisation: splint fracture
- Wound dressing: remove gross debris but not bone fragments; cover wound with sterile dressing
- Anti-sepsis: urgent IV antibiotics (cefuroxime + metronidazole), tetanus prophylaxis
- Urgent consult anaesthesia & O&T
- Prepare for OT: NPO, T&S, consent, ECG, CXR

Management of closed fractures (3R)

- Reduction:
  - Aim: tamponade of bleeding, restore blood supply, reduce traction on traversing nerves (neuropraxia),
    reduce traction on surrounding soft tissue (compartment syndrome)
  - Not indicated if:
    - No/ little displacement
    - Reduction unlikely to succeed, e.g. compression fracture of vertebrae
  - Methods:
    - Closed reduction: apply traction in the long axis of limb (Laplace law) + repositioning of fragments
      by reversing the original direction of trauma
    - Open reduction: indicated in (NO CAST)
      - Failed closed reduction
      - Non-union
      - Open fracture
      - Neurovascular Compromise
      - Intra-Articular fracture (2° OA, misalignment)
      - Salter-Harris 3-5
      - PolyTrauma
  - Post-reduction: check neurovascular supply + XR
- Restraint (immobilization)
  - Cast & splints:
    - Splint: elastic, non-circumferential, used in pre-hospital setting, but ↑ROM at injury site
    - Brace: elastic, circumferential
    - Slab: rigid, non-circumferential, used if significant soft tissue swelling
    - Cast (plaster or fibreglass): rigid, circumferential, higher risk of Cx (e.g. pressure sore)
    - Spica: immobilise limb with trunk, e.g. hip spica
  - External fixation: Bone & soft tissues stabilised at a distance from site of injury with external frame
    - Indications: significant soft tissue injury
    - Risk of infection over site of application
  - Internal fixation
    - Indications: unstable fracture, multiple fractures
    - Ensure anatomical reduction (to avoid early degenerative changes)
    - Affect healing (periosteum stripped)
    - Types: extramedullary (screws, plates, wires), intramedullary (nails)
      - Extramedullary: very stable reconstruction
      - Intramedullary: semi-closed procedure, shorter OT time, direct full weight bearing
        afterwards

Treatment choice based on stability of fracture
| | Stable | Unstable |
|---|---|---|
| Energy of trauma | Low | High |
| Displacement/angulation | Minimal | Yes |
| Fragments | 2 | >2 (comminuted) |
| Risk of displacement upon weight-bearing or normal physical activity | Tend not to displace | Tend to displace |
| Management | Reduction **not required/ closed** Repair: **cast** (slab if significant soft tissue swelling) | Reduction: closed/ **open** Repair: **internal fixation** (external fixation if significant soft tissue injury) |

- **Rehabilitation**: as in non-trauma management (PT, OT, etc)

Management of open fracture

- **Gustilo-Anderson classification**: fracture pattern, degree of contamination, soft tissue injury
  | Grade | Wound length | Description | Antibiotics |
  |---|---|---|---|
  | I | < 1cm | Low energy, minimal contamination & soft tissue injury | 1st generation cephalosporin |
  | II | 1-10cm | Moderate energy, moderate contamination & soft tissue injury | 1st generation cephalosporin + aminoglycoside |
  | III | Usually >10cm | High energy, extensive contamination & soft tissue injury IIIA: adequate soft tissue covers wound IIIB: extensive periosteal stripping requiring soft tissue transfer IIIC: vascular injury requiring vascular repair |

- Urgent wound debridement and lavage
  - To reduce risk of infection if done within 6-8h
  - Wound left open for re-examination in 48h
- **Reduction and external fixation**: primary aim is to facilitate soft tissue healing for wound coverage

Complications of trauma
Classification

- General vs specific
- Early vs late
- Anatomical

Early complications

- Local: **neuro-vascular injury** (be specific!), **compartment syndrome**, wound infection (osteomyelitis)
- Systemic: shock, sepsis, DVT, PE, ARDS (due to fat embolism)

Late complications

- Local: skin (bed sores), muscle (atrophy), tendon/ ligaments (adhesions, joint instability), nerve (paralysis), bone (delayed/mal/non-union, **heterotopic ossification**, AVN, chronic osteomyelitis), CRPS type I (complex regional pain syndrome), Volkmann's contracture
- Systemic: crush syndrome

| | |
| :-------------------- | :------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
| Fracture blisters | Formed by elevation of epidermal layer from dermis - indicate severe soft tissue injury |
| | Puncture not required: may even lead to local infection |
| Heterotopic ossification | Formation of bone in abnormal locations, e.g. muscle (myositis ossifican) |
| Compartment syndrome | Patho: fintra-compartmental pressure due to bleeding, oedema, inflammation → ↓capillary flow → muscle ischaemia More common in legs (4 compartments) than thigh (3 compartments) Diagnosis: Clinical: 6P of ischaemia (paralysis and pulseless late); most sensitive sign = **excessive pain on passive stretching** Intra-compartmental pressure > 30 mmHg (if P/E unreliable) Management: Remove constrictive dressings (e.g. cast), limb elevation at the level of heart Analgesia, O2, IV fluid **Emergency fasciotomy of all compartments** Leave skin incisions open for re-inspection after 48h +/- remove necrotic tissues Post-op: RFT, CK (rhabdomyolysis) |

# 1.5 Orthopaedic appliances

**Casts & splint**
**Casts**
Types

- Slab: incomplete enclosure
  Cast material
- **Plaster of Paris (CaSO4)**: easier to mould, cheaper

  - Allergic reaction

# 1.6 Summary of special tests

Cervical spine

- Radiculopathy: Spurling's test
- Myelopathy: Lhermitte's test, 10-second test, finger escape test, Hoffmann's test, inverted supinator reflex
  Lumbar spine
- Ankylosing spondylitis (forward flexion): Schober test
- Scoliosis: Adam's forward bending test
- Radiculopathy (sciatica): Straight leg raise (Lasegue test), tension sign, bowstring sign, cross straight-leg-raise, femoral nerve stretch test
  Shoulder
  Degenerative
- Impingement: Neer impingement sign, Hawkin's sign, painful arc
- Biceps tendon: speed test, Yergason test
- AC joint: crossed chest adduction
- Rotator cuff: ext. rotation (IT) → Hornblower's sign (teres minor), empty beer can test (supraspinatus), lift-off test / belly press test (subscapularis)
  Others
- Instability: load and shift test, apprehension test (ant.), sulcus sign (inferior), posterior apprehension test (post.)
- Scapula winging: push against wall
  Elbow
- Collateral ligament laxity: valgus stress test (medial), varus stress test (lateral)
- Ulnar nerve: palpate for subluxation, Tinel's sign
- Tennis elbow: Cozen's test, Mill's test
  Hand and wrist
- De Quervain's tenosynovitis: Finkelstein's test
- CMC arthritis: Grind test

UL nerves

- Screening test: palm down → wrist extension (radial n.) → thumb up (PIN) → palm up (proximal ulnar & median ns.) → thumb opposition (distal median n.) → OK sign (AIN) → finger ab/adduction (distal ulnar n.)
- Median nerve:
  - Carpal tunnel syndrome: Durkin's compression test, Phalen's & reverse Phalen's
  - Pronator teres: resisted pronation at full extension (PT), isolated long finger PIPJ flexion (FDS)
- Ulnar nerve
  - Wrist: Froment's sign, cross finger sign
  - Elbow: Pollock's sign, elbow flexion test + ulnar n. subluxability
- Radial nerve:
  - Supinator: provocative test (extend elbow + flex wrist + pronate arm)
  - Tinel's signs: 9cm proximal to radial styloid (supf. Branch), 2cm distal to lateral epicondyle (PIN)

Hip

- Abductor insufficiency: Trendelenburg's test (lurch? sacral dimple tilting?)
- Fixed flexion deformity: Thomas's test
  Knee
- Effusion: fluid displacement test (minimal), fluid thrill test (moderate), patellar tap test (severe)
- ACL: Lachman test (Endpoint? Excessive laxity?), anterior drawer test, pivot shift test (IR foot + valgus stress)
- PCL: Posterior drawer test, posterior sag test
- Collateral lig.: Valgus/varus stress test at 30° flexion, then at full extension (also test capsular structures)
- Meniscus: McMurray test (turn the foot away from the testing meniscus), Apley's grinding test
  Ankle
- Instability: talar tilt test, anterior drawer test
- Achilles tendon: single leg heel raise, Thompson test

Trendelenburg's gait:

- **Abductor weakness**
  - Polio
  - Sup. gluteal n. palsy
- Decreased lever arm at hip joint
  - #NOF
  - Short neck(coxa vara)
- Painful hip arthropathy
  - Septic hip
  - OA hip

219

2 Spine
2.1 Anatomy
Functions of vertebral column

- Protection of spinal cord (risk of compression/ irritation)
- Support body weight above pelvis (risk of mechanical instability)
- Movement
- Axis
  Structure of vertebra
  [Illustration of a vertebra cross-section viewed from above. The illustration is colored to distinguish the different parts of the vertebra: The spinous process is colored purple, the lamina is orange, the superior articular processes are green, the pedicles are teal, and the transverse processes are pink.]

[Illustration of two cervical vertebrae connected to each other, showing the Facet joint, Cervical vertebra, Cervical disc, and Facet capsule. The vertebrae are light brown in color.]

Features of vertebrae at different levels
| | |
|---|---|
| Cervical | Bifid spinous process except C1 (nil) & C7 (not bifid) Transverse foramina (for vertebral arteries) Triangular vertebral foramen |
| Thoracic | Demi-facets & costal facet for ribs Spinous process oriented inferiorly |
| Lumbar | Largest vertebrae, largest spinal canal Congenital abnormalities: 4 lumbar vertebrae (sacralisation), 6 lumbar vertebrae (lumbarisation) |
| Sacrum & coccyx | Fused vertebrae |

Intervertebral disc

- Fibrocartilaginous cylinder that acts as shock absorbers
- Components:
  - Nucleus pulposus: no nerve endings - asymptomatic even with desiccation
  - Annulus fibrosus: with nerve endings, posterior aspect always convex
    Intervertebral foramen
- Exit of spinal nerves
- Border:
  - Upper & lower: pedicles
  - Anterior: vertebral body & disc
  - Posterior: facet joint & ligamentum flavum
- Any anomaly in any border component causes radiculopathy
  - Short pedicles
  - Intervertebral disc herniation
  - Hypertrophic ligamentum flavum
  - Osteophyte formation at facet joint

Ligaments
[Illustration of the ligaments of the vertebral column. The vertebral column is shown from the side, with the vertebrae stacked one on top of the other. The anterior longitudinal ligament is shown in red, running along the front of the vertebral bodies. The posterior longitudinal ligament is shown in purple, running along the back of the vertebral bodies inside the vertebral canal. The ligamentum flavum is shown in light blue, connecting the laminae of adjacent vertebrae. The interspinal ligament is shown in green, connecting the spinous processes of adjacent vertebrae. The supraspinous ligament is shown in yellow, running along the tips of the spinous processes. A color-coded legend is next to the illustration, each color corresponding to a specific ligament.]

- Posterior longitudinal ligament (PLL)
  - Ossification of PLL (OPLL) very common in Japanese and Chinese - common cause of cervical myelopathy
- Ligamentum flavum (LF)
  - Dynamic compression: osteophytes + buckled LF during extension
  - Ossification of LF (OLF)

220

2.2 XR spine interpretation

[Image showing a lateral X-ray of the cervical spine, with labels indicating anatomical structures. On the left, the bony structures are labeled: Occiput, Dens (Odontoid Process), Clivus, C1, Spinous Process, Articulating Facets, Pedicle, Laminae, C4, C5, C6, C7, Spinous Process Line, Spinolaminal Line, Posterior Vertebral Line, Anterior Vertebral Line, and Vertebral Body. On the right, the soft tissues are labeled: naso-pharyngeal space (blue arrow), retro-pharyngeal space (red arrow), retro-tracheal space (green arrow), Hyoid Bone, Epiglottis, Tracheal Shadow, Pre-Vertebral Soft Tissue, Intervertebral Disk Space.]

Adequacy

- C spine (lateral): from pituitary fossa to C7/T1 junction
  - Odontoid view/ open mouth view: C1 & C2
  - Swimmer's view: cervicothoracic junction
- L spine (lateral): whole L spine including sacral spine

Alignment

- Curvature: cervical/ lumbar lordosis is preserved/ increased/ decreased/ lost/ kyphosis
- Vertebral line (fig.)
  - Ignore the bony spurs
  - Posterior vertebral line easiest to detect

Bone: fracture, bony lesion

Cartilage:

- Joint space: **Pavlov ratio > 0.8** (fig.: the ratio is a/b)
- **Atlantodental interval (ADI)** (fig.):
  - Definition: distance between anterior cortex of dens to posterior cortex of C1 anterior arch at midsagittal plane
  - Abnormal (atlanto-axial subluxation) if ADI ≥ 3mm (adult) or ≥5mm (children)
  - Causes: trauma, Down's (absent transverse ligament), RA (inflammation/ rupture of transverse lig.)

[Image showing a lateral view of a spine, with the vertebral column clearly visible]

[Image showing an open mouth view X-ray of the cervical spine, with clear visualization of the C1 and C2 vertebrae. Labels indicate occiput, lateral masses of C1, dens, C2 body, and spinous processes.]

[Image showing a lateral X-ray of the cervical spine, with the lines indicating the measurement of "a" and "b".]

Soft tissue (only for C spine)

- 3x7=21 rule: C1 ≤ **10mm**, C3≤ 7mm, C7 ≤ 21mm
- 123456 rule: C1-2 less than dens, C3-4 <3-4mm, C5-6 narrower than AP diameter of vertebral body
- Vertebral body rule: mid-cervical level ≤ half of vertebral body thickness, lower cervical level < full vertebral body thickness
  221

  2.3 Approach to spine diseases
  Differential diagnoses of back pain

- Degeneration (**spondylosis**): e.g. OA spine, facet joint arthritis
- Prolapsed intervertebral disc
- Spinal stenosis
- Cauda equina syndrome
- Muscle / ligamentous injury: **muscle strain**
- Fractures / injuries: compression fractures, spondylolysis/spondylolisthesis
- Infection: TB spine, epidural abscess
- Tumor: primary, metastases (e.g. lung, breast, prostate)
- Inflammation: AS, PSA, RA
- Extra-spinal causes / Referred pain: e.g. pancreatitis, AAA, uro/gynae causes, zoster

Manifestation of spinal cord disease
Cervical myelopathy (refer to separate section)

- Definition: compression of cervical spinal cord
- Clinical features
  - Weakness, numbness, clumsiness in arms with UMN signs
  - Neck: Lhermitte's sign, reversed Lhermitte's sign
  - Myelopathic hand signs

Radiculopathy

- Definition: conduction block in axons of a spinal nerve or its roots
- Clinical features
  - Sensory (paraesthesia, numbness)
  - Motor (weakness, hyporeflexia)
  - Radicular pain
  - Red flags:
    - Cauda equina syndrome (most important to r/o!): faecal incontinence, painless urinary retention +/- incontinence, saddle anaesthesia
    - Infection: fever, immunosuppression
    - Fracture: chronic steroid use, osteoporosis / metabolic bone disease

Cauda equina syndrome

- Definition: compression of cauda equina (below **L2**)
- Aetiology:
  - Degenerative: PID (L4/5, L5/S1)
  - Fracture: traumatic, pathological
  - Malignancy (metastasis from paired organ: thyroid, breast, lung, kidney, prostate)
  - Infection: discitis, Pott's disease
  - Inflammatory: AS
  - Iatrogenic: haematoma secondary to spinal anaesthesia
- Clinical features:
  - Motor: LMN signs - weakness, hypotonia, hyporeflexia
  - Sensory: low back pain, bilateral radicular pain, saddle anaesthesia
  - Autonomic: urinary retention with overflow incontinence, faecal incontinence, impotence
- Investigations: whole spine MRI
- Management:
  - High-dose steroid: to reduce localised swelling
  - Surgical decompression < 48h (laminectomy / discectomy)

222

2.4 Cervical myelopathy
Definition: compression of cervical spinal cord
Etiology:

- Degenerative cervical spondylosis (MC): e.g. osteophytes, hypertrophy of ligamentum flavum, degenerative spondylolisthesis
- Congenital spinal stenosis
- Ossification of posterior longitudinal ligament (OPLL)
- Trauma
- Others: tumor, epidural abscess

Clinical features

- Neck pain and stiffness
- UL +/- LL weakness and numbness with UMN signs (e.g. hyperreflexia)
- Neck: Lhermitte's sign, reversed Lhermitte's sign, loss of lordosis
- UL signs: inverted supinator reflex, inverted biceps reflex, finger escape sign, 10-second test, Hoffmann sign, grip and release, pseudoathetosis
- LL signs: gait instability with Romberg test, difficulty in toe-to-heel walk

Classification: Japanese Orthopaedic Association (JOA) classification

Management: surgical decompression and stabilization

- Non-operative: NSAID, lifestyle modification, PT
- Operative: surgical decompression and restoration of lordosis - Laminoplasty / Laminectomy +/- fusion
  2.5 Spinal stenosis
  Definition: abnormal narrowing of spinal canal or IV foramen, MC: lumbar spine > cervical spine
  Aetiology
- Degenerative: prolapsed IV disc (PID), OA spine, facet joint OA, spondylolysis/ spondylolisthesis
- Ossification: ossification of posterior longitudinal ligament (OPLL), ossification of ligamentum flavum (OLF)
- Fracture: traumatic, pathological
- Malignancy
- Infection: Pott's disease, epidural abscess
- Inflammatory: RA (C1/2 subluxation), MS
  Clinical features
- Cervical spine
  - Neck pain
  - Cervical radiculopathy
  - Cervical myelopathy
- Lumbar spine
  - Back pain, radiating to buttock and leg
  - Neurogenic claudication: pain worse with extension, relieved with flexion
  - Bladder disturbance

Investigations
XR spine

- Cervical stenosis: loss of cervical lordosis, Pavlov ratio (ratio of AP diameter of canal to diameter of vertebral body of same level) < 0.8 (fig.)
- Lumbar stenosis: loss of lumbar lordosis, reduced disc height, spondylolysis/ spondylolisthesis, calcification of PLL/ LF
  [Image Description: This is a table titled "TABLE I Japanese Orthopaedic Association Criteria for the Evaluation of Operative Results in Patients with Cervical Myelopathy". The table has four main sections numbered I through IV, with each section further divided into categories. Section I is "Upper extremity function", describing possible movements with chopsticks and spoons with points assigned from 0 to 4. Section II is "Lower extremity function", describing how a person can walk with points assigned from 0 to 4. Section III is "Sensory", further divided into upper extremity, lower extremity and trunk, describing sensory loss with points assigned from 0 to 2. Section IV is "Bladder function" describing bladder disturbances with points from 0 to 3. At the end of the table, it says "Total normal score = 17 points"]

| Cause               | Vascular claudication        | Neurogenic claudication    |
| ------------------- | ---------------------------- | -------------------------- |
| Radiation of pain   | Chronic limb ischaemia       | Spinal stenosis            |
|                     | From distal to proximal      | From proximal to distal    |
| Exacerbating factor | **Walking uphill**           | **Walking downhill**       |
|                     | Exercise                     | Increased lordosis         |
| Relieving factor    | Rest                         | Bending over, sitting      |
|                     | "Shop window to shop window" | "Park bench to park bench" |
| Pulse               | Absent                       | Present                    |

MRI spine

- Disc: intensity signal, disc height (normally L4/5 > L5/S1 > L3/4), PID (note for any high-intensity zone, i.e. oedema)
- Neural tissues: mickey mouse sign (i.e. cauda equina + traversing nerve roots), cord oedema
  Management
- Non-operative
  - PT: flexion exercise, stretching exercise
  - Pharm: NSAID, epidural steroid
- Operative
  - Without spondylolisthesis: decompressive laminectomy / laminoplasty (at every relevant level), interspinous process spacer (MIS)
  - With spondylolisthesis: decompressive laminectomy + spinal fusion

  2.6 Degenerative spine disorders
  Cervical spondylosis

- Definition: degeneration of cervical vertebral column, e.g. OA, PID, OPLL/OLF
- Site: most common at C5/6 (most flexion & extension)

Prolapsed intervertebral disc (PID)
Definition: protrusion of nucleus pulposus (NP) secondary to tear in annulus fibrosis (AF)
Pathogenesis

- Decreased aggrecan content in NP, most commonly at L4/5 and L5/S1
- More fibrous NP unable to evenly distribute compressive forces between the vertebral bodies → transferred to surrounding AF
- Pathology:
  - Bulging
  - Prolapse (AF still containing NP)
  - Extrusion (partial rupture of AF)
  - Sequestration (free movement of NP)
- Herniation and nerve roots affected
  - Level of herniation: L5/S1 > L4/5 > L3/4
  - Direction of herniation: posterolateral > central > lateral
  - Nerve roots affected (L4/5 as example): unilateral L5 (posterolateral) > bilateral L5 (central) > unilateral L4 (lateral)

[Image Description: This image shows Interspinous spacer for stenosis. It illustrates how a spacer device is placed between the vertebrae to alleviate spinal stenosis. The illustration highlights the vertebra, disc, and spacer device.]

[Image Description: This image shows a table comparing Mechanically Stable and Mechanically Unstable conditions in relation to neurology and spinal stabilization. The table has three columns: Neurology, Mechanically Stable and Mechanically Unstable. In Mechanically Stable, the Neurology is Stable with Routine management. In Mechanically Unstable, the Neurology is Unstable. Under Routine management, it mentions Stable with Routine management, which includes early stabilization of spine. Under early stabilization of spine, it mentions 1. Other causes - e.g. epidural haematoma, Incomplete Cord Lesion, Stroke 2. Wrong diagnosis on mechanical stability.]

[Image Description: This image shows two separate illustrations comparing the lumbar and cervical spine anatomy. The lumbar spine illustration shows the L4, L4/5, L5/S1, and S1 vertebral segments, highlighting the L4/5 far lateral disc and L4/5 paracentral disc. The cervical spine illustration shows the C6, C6/7, C7, and T1 vertebral segments with the C6/7 foraminal disc and C6/7 central disc highlighted. Arrows indicate relationships and potential mismatches between lumbar and cervical nerve root locations. In the top right corner it says "Both discs affect same nerve root in cervical spine, different than lumbar spine." One arrow indicates "CB and above Pedicle/ Nerve Root MISMATCH." Another Arrow indicates "Extra CB Nerve Root (without CB pedicle) allows transition from MISMATCH to MATCH. T1 and below Pedicle/ Nerve Root MATCH. At the bottom of the image it states "Lumbar Spine Pedicle/nerve Root MATCH".]

Risk factors

- Patient factor: aging, man, smoking
- Mechanical factor: posture, weak paraspinal muscles
- Occupational factor: heavy lifting

Possible clinical features

- Back pain
- Sciatica: shooting pain in hip radiating down posterior thigh and calf + limited straight leg raise + features of radiculopathy (e.g. diminished sensation over heel, absent ankle jerk, weakness of ankle plantarflexion)

| L4 root | Pain and sensory symptoms in anterior thigh                                                                                                       |
| ------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| L5 root | Pain radiates down the posterior thigh, lateral calf, and into the great toe Sensory symptoms affect the lateral calf and great toe               |
| S1 root | Pain radiates down the posterior leg and into the fourth and fifth toes Sensory symptoms affect the lateral calf, foot, and fourth and fifth toes |

- Rule out cauda equina syndrome

Investigations

- XR spine: exclude fracture/ spondylolisthesis
- MRI spine: disc (colour, height, bulging), nerve root compression

Management

- Non-operative: **encourage mobility**, physiotherapy, NSAID, selective nerve root steroid injection
- Operative:
  - Indications: failed non-operative treatment, progressive neurological deficit, cauda equina syndrome
  - Approach: **microdiscectomy** (hemi-laminotomy + partial disc removal)

Spondylolysis & spondylolisthesis
Definition:

- Spondylolysis: defect in pars interarticularis with no movement of vertebral body
- Spondylolisthesis: defect in pars, causing forward slip of one vertebra on another (most commonly **L5/S1**)

Aetiology of spondylolisthesis

- Lytic (50%): spondylolysis
- Degenerative (25%): facet joint/ disc degeneration
- Dysplastic (20%): congenital defect of superior sacral facets (associated with spina bifida occulta)
  XR spine
- Oblique view (or lateral view): broken "Scottie dog", forward shift of vertebral column
- Flexion & extension view: translation of vertebral body
  Management
- Non-operative:
  - Activity restriction, brace
  - PT: stretching & strengthening exercise
- Operative:
  - Indications:
    - Disabling symptoms (ADL)
    - Slip > 50% and **progressing**
    - Significant neurological deficit
  - Approach: decompressive laminectomy + TLIF (transforaminal lumbar interbody fusion)

[Image of human spine, showing L3, L4, L5 and S1 vertebrae. The facet joint, pars interarticularis and sacrum are labeled. The intervertebral disc is also labeled.]

[Image of a single vertebra. The back, body, facet joint, pars interarticularis, transverse process, disc and spinous process are labeled.]

[Image showing Pars Interarticularis, with red arrows showing a stress fracture in the Pars Interarticularis and the text "Spondylolysis (Stress fracture in the Pars Interarticularis)".]

[Image illustrating Spondylolisthesis with a red arrow showing a stress fracture and sliding of vertebra and the text "Spondylolisthesis (Stress fracture and sliding of vertebra)".]

## 2.7 Spine trauma

Spinal cord injury

| Mechanism              | Spinal shock                                                        | Neurogenic shock                                                                                                                                    |
| ---------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
|                        | Peripheral neurons become temporarily unresponsive to brain stimuli | Interrupted SNS below level of injury True hypovolemia: blood loss from wound Relative hypovolemia: venous pooling due to skeletal muscle paralysis |
| BP/P                   | Hypotension Bradycardia                                             | Hypotension Bradycardia                                                                                                                             |
| Bulbocavernosus reflex | **Absent**                                                          | **Present**                                                                                                                                         |
| Motor                  | **Flaccid paralysis**                                               | **Normal**                                                                                                                                          |

Investigations in traumatic spine injury

- Minor injury: full C-spine XR (AP + lateral + open mouth view, fig.)

[X-ray image of the cervical spine showing the lateral mass of C1, the dens, and the C2 vertebral body labeled. Red lines indicate the width of the dens. Blue lines indicate the borders of the lateral masses of C1.]

[Diagram illustrating the three columns of the spine: anterior, middle, and posterior. Arrows pointing to each column.]

- All injuries otherwise: CT +/- MRI (if focal neurological deficit)

Three-column theory

- Used in assessing stability of lower C spine and thoracolumbar spine
- Unstable fracture if 2/3 segments disrupted:
  - Anterior column: anterior 2/3 of vertebral body, disc & anterior longitudinal ligament
  - Middle column: posterior 1/3 of vertebral body, disc & posterior longitudinal ligament
  - Posterior column: remaining arch

**ASIA classification for spinal cord injury (IMPORTANT!)**

[Table describing the ASIA Impairment Scale. Column 1 contains the letters A through E. Column 2 contains the descriptions Complete, Incomplete, Incomplete, Incomplete, and Normal, respectively. Column 3 describes the level of impairment for each letter grade. For A, the description reads: No motor, No sensory, No sacral sparing. For B, the description reads: No motor, sensory only. For C, the description reads: 50% of muscles LESS than grade 3 (cant not raise arms or legs off bed). For D, the description reads: 50% of muscles MORE than grade 3 (can raise arms or legs off bed). For E, the description reads: Motor and sensory function are normal.]

AO classification of cervical spine fracture

- Upper cervical fracture

| Region(s) involved                                  | Injury type                   |
| --------------------------------------------------- | ----------------------------- |
| Type 1: occipital condyle, cranio-cervical junction | Type A: bony injury only      |
| Type 2: C1 ring, C1/2 joint                         | Type B: tension band injuries |
| Type 3: C2 and C2/3 joint                           | Type C: translation injuries  |

- Subaxial fracture

| Injury type                  |     |
| ---------------------------- | --- |
| Type A: compression injuries |     |
| Type B: distraction injuries |     |
| Type C: translation injuries |     |
| Type F: facet joint injuries |     |

Upper cervical spine injury

|                         |                                                                           |                                                                                                                       |
| :---------------------- | :------------------------------------------------------------------------ | :-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Jefferson fracture (C1) | MOI                                                                       | Features                                                                                                              |
|                         | Axial compression/hyperflexion of neck → Occipital condyles drive into C1 | Burst fracture of C1 Unstable fracture although no cord injury (rupture of transverse ligament) Mx: SOMI brace        |
| Hangman's fracture (C2) | Sudden hyperextension and distraction with axial loading                  | Bilateral pedicle fracture of C2 Unstable fracture                                                                    |
| Odontoid peg fracture   | Complete flexion/ extension                                               | Type I: tips of dens, stable Type II (MC): base of dens, unstable Type III: vertebral body, stable Mx: Odontoid screw |

[Image of Jefferson fracture, showing a CT scan with a fracture of the C1 vertebra. The fracture lines are visible on the axial view of the scan. The fractured segment is labeled in red.]

[Image of Hangman's fracture, showing a lateral X-ray of the cervical spine. The fracture is visible in the pedicle of the C2 vertebra. The fractured segment is labeled in red.]

[Image of Odontoid fracture (type II), showing an open-mouth view X-ray of the cervical spine. The fracture line is visible across the base of the dens (odontoid process) of the C2 vertebra. The fracture line is highlighted with arrows.]

[Image of a diagram showing three types of odontoid fractures: Type I, Type II, and Type III. The diagram shows the location of the fracture in each type with respect to the dens and vertebral body.]

Lower cervical spine injury

|                            |                                  |                                                                                                                                                                                                                               |
| :------------------------- | :------------------------------- | :---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Flexion teardrop fracture  | MOI                              | Features                                                                                                                                                                                                                      |
|                            | Sudden hyperflexion              | Teardrop fragment at anteroinferior aspect of vertebral body Unstable fracture: "teardrop" - associated with severe ligamentous injury & risk of displacement of posterior portion of vertebral body causing cord compression |
| Wedge compression fracture | Compression secondary to flexion | Flattening of vertebral body Stable fracture: single column affected                                                                                                                                                          |
| Burst fracture             | Axial compression                | Unstable fracture: cord damage 2º to retropulsed bony fragment                                                                                                                                                                |

[Image of Teardrop fracture, showing a lateral X-ray of the cervical spine. The teardrop fragment is visible at the anteroinferior aspect of the vertebral body. The image shows a teardrop fragment, anterior dislocation, posterior displacement of vertebral body, and the narrowing of the spinal cord.]

[Image of Wedge compression fracture, showing a lateral X-ray of the thoracic spine. The vertebral body appears wedge-shaped due to compression. The image shows anterior vertebral cortex, site of height loss of vertebral body.]

[Image of Burst fracture, showing a lateral X-ray of the lumbar spine. The vertebral body is fractured with fragments extending into the spinal canal.]

Thoracolumbar spine injury

- Wedge compression fracture
- Burst fracture
- Spondylolisthesis (see above)

Acute management of spinal cord injury

- Assume spinal cord injury and stabilise spine (Philadelphia neck collar) if:
  - Unconscious
  - Significant HI
  - Neck pain
  - Focal neurological deficit
- Resuscitation: ABCD - Delicate spine: - Cervical fracture: halo vest, traction devices, internal fixation (if unstable) - Thoracolumbar spine fracture: bed rest, external brace, internal fixation

  3.1 Anatomy
  Scapula

# 3 Shoulder and arm

[Image of the scapula with labels indicating the acromion, coracoid process, glenoid fossa, and subscapular fossa. The scapula is depicted as a three-dimensional anatomical illustration, showcasing its shape and features.]

- Subacromial space
  - Space **below coracoacromial arch** (acromion + coraco-acromial ligament + coracoid process) and **above humeral head** and greater tuberosity
  - Contents: **rotator cuff tendons** (mainly supraspinatus), **long head of biceps tendon**, subacromial bursa
- Rotator cuff interval
  - Space between supraspinatus and subscapularis
  - Free space that allows direct access to shoulder joint for steroid injection in frozen shoulder
- Proximal humerus
  - Shaft: radial groove (radial nerve, profunda brachii artery)

[Image of the shoulder joint, focusing on the ligaments and tendons, with labels such as Acromion, Bursa, Coracoacromial ligament, Subacromial space, Supraspinatus muscle and tendon, Long head of biceps tendon, Clavicle, Coracoid process and Scapula. The image is a detailed anatomical illustration.]

[Image illustrating the posterior and anterior faces of the proximal humerus. The images are detailed anatomical illustrations.]

Shoulder joint (glenohumeral joint)

- Joint capsule
- Bursa, e.g. subacromial bursa
- Stabilising mechanism - Rotator cuff (most important) - Joint capsule - Glenoid labrum: to deepen the socket - Biceps tendon long head at superior labrum
  AC joint
- Plane type synovial joint: only allow gliding motion
- Atypical features: - Articular surfaces lined with fibrocartilage (instead of hyaline cartilage) - Joint cavity partially divided by an articular disc (~ meniscus)

  3.2 Shoulder trauma
  Shoulder X-ray

- AP view: also look for associated pneumothorax / rib fractures
- Axillary view / Lawrence view (upper fig.): good for visualizing articular surfaces of glenohumeral joint, and any Hill Sachs lesion
- Y view (lower fig.):
  - Upper arms are acromion & coracoid process
  - Lower arm is scapula
