Inferior shoulder dislocation

- Least common
- MOI: hand outstretched in cycling accident
- Clinical feature: **hold injured arm above head**
  - Highest incidence of axillary n. injury (c.f. ant/post dislocation)
- Radiological features: **luxatio erecta** (humeral head displaced downward, with arm hyper-abducted) (fig.)

Complications of shoulder dislocation

- Recurrence
- Chronic pain / stiffness
- Adhesive capsulitis
- Rotator coff injury
- Nerve damage (especially axillary & suprascapular n.)
- Degenerative joint diseases e.g. secondary OA

Clavicle fracture
Risk groups: adolescents and young adults (MC), elderly with osteoporosis
ΜΟΙ

- Direct: direct blow to shoulder
- Indirect: fall on shoulder, fall on outstretched hand (FOOSH)
  **Allman classification:** by anatomical location
- Type 1: middle 1/3 (80%) - generally stable
- Type 2: lateral 1/3 (15%) - often unstable if displaced
- Type 3: medial 1/3 (5%) - high incidence of pneumothorax / hemothorax
  Clinical features
- Focal tenderness
- Medial fragment displaced _superiorly_ (pull of SCM) and lateral fragment displaced _inferiorly_ (pull of arm)
- **Threatened skin** (tented, tethered, non-blanching skin due to pull of SCM and arm): impending conversion to open injury
- Complications: malunion / delayed union (MC), brachial plexus injury, pneumothorax
  XR: AP, Zanca view (15° cephalic tilt for AC joint)

[Illustration of a clavicle with dotted vertical lines dividing it into thirds labeled as follows: Lateral ⅓ 15%, Middle ⅓ 80%, and Medial ⅓ 5%]

[A man wearing a brace that wraps around his shoulders and upper back to stabilize the clavicle.]

Management: mainly conservative

- Conservative: _sling immobilization_ (e.g. figure-of-eight brace (fig.)), PT (ROM exercise, muscle strengthening)
- Operative:
  - Indications: threatened skin, open fracture, bilateral (to permit weightbearing)
  - Modalities: closed reduction with IM fixation, ORIF (if unable to unite)
- Usually heal within 4-6 weeks

AC joint dislocation

[Radiograph of a shoulder joint labeled to show the acromioclavicular joint dislocation in AP view.]

[Radiograph of a shoulder joint labeled to show the acromioclavicular joint dislocation in AP view, with yellow lines showing clavicle, coracoid, and acromial process; red lines showing misalignment of the clavicle and acromion; and green circles showing increased coracoclavicular distance.]

GEEKYMEDICS.COM

- X-ray features: misalignment of clavicle and acromion, increased coracoclavicular distance (>13mm)

Proximal humerus fracture

- Site: most commonly surgical neck
- Mechanism: low-energy injuries (e.g. FOOSH) in osteoporotic elderly
- Clinical features:
  - Injury to **axillary nerve** (deltoid), **suprascapular nerve** (supraspinatus & infraspinatus)
  - Injury to **axillary artery** (may be masked by extensive collateral circulation preserving distal pulse) → AVN
- **Neer classification** – relationship between 4 main segments (greater tuberosity, lesser tuberosity, articular segment, humeral shaft)
- Investigations: X-ray (AP, Y-view, axillary view) +/- CT scan for pre-operative planning
- Management
  - Non-operative (if no displacement): **sling immobilisation** then rehabilitation
  - Operative (e.g. displaced, open, neurovascular compromise):
    - Closed reduction with **percutaneous pinning**: preferred if surgical neck #
    - ORIF: preferred if head-splitting #
    - Other options (rare): e.g. hemiarthroplasty, reverse shoulder arthroplasty (RSA)
- Complications: AVN of humeral head

Humeral shaft fracture

- Mode of injury
  - Slip and fall (e.g. outstretched hand, fall laterally onto adducted limb)
  - High-energy trauma e.g. RTA
- Pathology
  - Fracture location: proximal, middle or distal third of humeral shaft
  - Fracture pattern: spiral, transverse, comminuted
  - **Holstein-Lewis fracture** (fig.): spiral fracture of _distal third_ of humeral shaft → **entrapment** and neuropraxia of **radial nerve**
- Clinical features
  - Limb shortening and varus
  - **High radial nerve palsy**: wrist drop, finger drop (triceps extension intact), reduced sensation over dorsal 1st webspace
- XR forearm: AP & lateral (fig.)
- Management
  - Non-operative (1st line): coaptation splint with functional bracing (fig.)
    - Suitability: <20° anterior angulation, <30° varus/valgus angulation, <3cm shortening
  - Operative:
    - Indications: open fracture, vascular injury, brachial plexus injury or pathologic fracture
    - ORIF (e.g. plate and screws, intramedullary nail)
  - Usually heal in 8-12 weeks

SLAP tear (superior labrum from anterior to posterior tear)

- MOI: repetitive overhead activity
- Clinical features: vague deep shoulder pain, popping sensation during overhead activity, **O'Brien's active compression test** (fig.)
- Investigations: MRI arthrogram (hyperintense labrum suggests tear)
- Management
  - Conservative: analgesics, stretching
  - Operative (arthroscopic repair): if fail conservative for 3 months

3.3 Shoulder pain
Differential diagnosis

- Rotator cuff syndrome (MC): pain during activity only, passive ROM > active ROM, external rotation spared (infraspinatus + teres minor)
- Frozen shoulder: DM as risk factor (check Hstix), symptoms change over time (pain → pain + stiffness → stiffness → resolution), night pain/ rest pain (inflamed capsule); limited active + passive ROM
- AC joint arthritis: more localised tenderness
- Biceps tendonitis: more localised tenderness
- Cervical radiculopathy: neck pain, radiating pain, weakness

  3.4 Biceps tendinopathy
  Tendinopathy: variety of pathological changes that result in painful, swollen and weakened tendon (↑risk of rupture)
  Clinical features:

- Pain worsened with contracting biceps (e.g. speed test, Yergason test) and relieved with rest
- Localized tenderness
- Disuse atrophy
  Investigations: mainly clinical diagnosis +/- X-ray, USG, MRI (thickened tendons)
  Management:
- Conservative (first line): analgesia, ice therapy, steroid, physiotherapy
- Operative (rare): arthroscopic tenodesis (divide and reattach), tenotomy (divide the tendon)

Biceps tendon rupture
Clinical features:

- Sudden onset pain, weakness with "pop" sound
- Occur at sudden forced extension of flexed elbow
- Popeye sign (fig.): bulging of biceps muscle belly upon contraction
- Elbow flexion and supination intact (due to brachialis & supinator)
  Investigation:
- USG (first-line): localize distal end of biceps tendon
- MRI
  Management
- Conservative: analgesia, physiotherapy
- Operative: form a bone tunnel in radius to re-insert tendon end (single-incision vs dual-incision technique)

[Image of a male arm, flexed with a large bulge on the front of the upper arm. The bulge is the contracted biceps muscle, which has become detached from its tendon and recoiled up the arm. The skin is pale, and the bulge is very prominent and easily visible.]

3.5 Rotator cuff syndrome
Definition: A continuum of disease including

- Subacromial impingement
- Subcoracoid impingement
- Calcific tendonitis
- Rotator cuff tear

Subacromial impingement syndrome (SAIS)
Definition

- Irritation and inflammation of rotator cuff tendons as they pass through the subacromial space
- Range of pathology: rotator cuff tendinosis, subacromial bursitis, calcific tendonitis
  Pathophysiology
- Intrinsic degeneration: repetitive microtrauma, degenerative tendinopathy, rotator cuff muscle weakness
- Extrinsic compression:
  - Humeral head: glenohumeral instability (→ sup. subluxation)
  - Acromion: anatomical variation (curved, hooked)
  - Coracoacromial ligament: hypertrophy
  - ACJ: osteoarthritis

[Image of a diagram of the shoulder joint, showing the bones, ligaments, tendons, and bursae. Key structures are labeled, including the acromion, bursa, clavicle (collarbone), coracoid process, coracoacromial ligament, subacromial space, supraspinatus muscle and tendon, long head of biceps tendon, and scapula.]

Clinical features

- Progressive pain in anterosuperior aspect of shoulder: **exacerbated by abduction**, relieved by rest
- Signs: - Limited ROM in forward flexion - Painful arc (60-120°) - Impingement signs: Neer's impingement sign, Hawkin's sign
  Investigations
- XR shoulder: acromiohumeral distance, acromion morphology, bony spurs, calcification of supraspinatus tendon (chronic)
- MRI shoulder: degree of rotator cuff pathology, bursitis
  Management
- Conservative (first line): analgesia, steroid, physiotherapy (rotator cuff strengthening)
- Operative: - Indications: failed conservative for **6 months** - Approaches: usually arthroscopic - Surgical repair of supraspinatus / long head of biceps tendon → improve ROM - **Subacromial bursectomy**: increase subacromial space - **Acromioplasty** (removal of a section of acromion): increase subacromial space
  Complications
- Rotator cuff degeneration and tear
- Adhesive capsulitis (frozen shoulder)

Rotator cuff tear
Pathophysiology: chronic impingement, degenerative, trauma, iatrogenic (shoulder surgery)
Clinical features

- Pain over lateral aspect of shoulder
- Inability to perform overhead activities
- Signs - Muscle atrophy: supraspinatus & infraspinatus - Loss of active ROM (usually SIT) but **intact passive ROM** - **Drop arm sign**
  Classification
- Acute (<3 months) vs chronic (>3 months)
- Partial thickness vs full thickness - Full thickness: small (<1cm), medium (1-3cm), large (3-5cm), massive (>5cm or multiple tendons)
  Investigations
- XR shoulder: exclude fractures, acromiohumeral distance (proximal migration of humerus), acromion morphology, bony spurs
- **USG shoulder**: dynamic test for tear
- MRI shoulder: gold standard, degree of tear (irreparable if fatty infiltration or muscle tendon atrophy)
  Management
- Considerations:
  - Age & activity of patient
  - Severity of tear (MRI)
  - Shoulder arthropathy status (shoulder not weightbearing thus primary OA uncommon)
- Non-operative (mainstay): analgesics, steroid, PT
- Operative: not a must, indicated if **failed conservative Tx / large and massive tears** / > 2 weeks since injury - Surgical repair (arthroscopic / open) - Tendon transfer: if massive cuff tears - Reverse total shoulder arthroplasty (fig.): if massive cuff tears + glenohumeral arthritis
  Complication: **adhesive capsulitis**, recurrence

[X-ray image of a right shoulder replacement. The image is in grayscale. The humerus is visible in the bottom half of the image and it is connected to the shoulder joint. There is a visible artificial metallic shoulder joint connecting the humerus and the shoulder, with a cup-shaped component on the glenoid side and a stem inserted into the humerus. The bone appears dense, and the soft tissues are less clear. The image is oriented vertically, with the shoulder at the top. There is a marker labeled R in the top left corner]

## 3.6 Frozen shoulder / Adhesive capsulitis

Definition

- A shoulder condition where **active and passive** ROM is lost without clear underlying cause
- Adhesive capsulitis: glenohumeral joint capsule becomes contracted and adherent to humeral head
  Pathophysiology
- Primary (idiopathic): associated with **DM**
- Secondary: - Rotator cuff syndrome - Biceps tendinopathy - Post-trauma - Post-surgery: shoulder surgery, axillary LN dissection
  Clinical features
- Disease course
  - Freezing phase (pain): 2-9 mo
  - Frozen phase (pain + stiffness): 4-12 mo
  - Thawing phase (stiffness): 5-24 mo - may not completely resolve spontaneously
- Signs: joint tenderness and stiffness, muscle wasting (e.g. deltoid), ↓ROM (esp. **ER/IR** and flexion)
  Investigations
- HbA1c
- XR shoulder: rule out AC pathology
- MRI shoulder: thickened joint capsule, rule out SAIS
  Management
- Conservative (first line):
  - Analgesics, e.g. intra-articular steroid (at rotator interval): only during **pain** phase
  - PT: after inflammation/ pain subsides
- Operative:
  - Indications: _stiffness_ fails to improve after conservative management for 6 months
  - Modalities:
    - Manipulation under anaesthesia (MUA)
      - Complications: fracture (esp. during ER)
    - Arthroscopic capsular release
      - Complications: residual stiffness (early mobilisation), axillary nerve injury

4.1 Anatomy of elbow
Elbow joint & Ligaments

- Carrying angle: 8-12° (male), 10-14° (female)
  Anterior: Posterior:

[Detailed drawing of the anterior and posterior views of the elbow joint.
The anterior view depicts the capitulum, head of radius, and coronoid process.
The posterior view shows the trochlea and olecranon.]

[Detailed drawing of the elbow joint showing ligaments and tendons.
The radial collateral ligament and ulnar collateral ligament are labeled, along with the anular ligament of radius and sacciform recess of synovial membrane.]

Bursa

- Definition: membranous sac filled with synovial fluid, acting as a cushion to reduce friction
- Olecranon bursitis: inflammation (and possible infection) of olecranon bursa
  Cubital fossa
- Content (from lateral to medial): biceps tendon, brachial artery, medial nerve (TAM)
- Median cubital vein (MCV): at the roof of cubital fossa, for venepuncture
  Stability of elbow joint:
- Static: humeroulnar joint, medial and lateral collateral ligaments, radiocapitellar joint, joint capsule
- Dynamic: surrounding muscles e.g. triceps, brachialis

  4.2 Elbow trauma
  Important lines in elbow XR

- Seen in true lateral film (i.e. trochlea overlaps with capitellum)
- Anterior humeral line: should pass through mid-third of capitellum; disruption suggests **supracondylar fracture** (child)
- Proximal radial line (radiocapitellar line): centre of radius should pass through centre of capitellum; disruption suggests capitellar dislocation or radial head dislocation

[Detailed drawing of a sagittal view of the elbow joint, illustrating the anterior humeral line and proximal radial line. The radius, ulna, and humerus are labeled. Key anatomical features and measurement points are also indicated with labels like 'a', 'b', and 'b'.]

[Detailed medical illustration of the cubital fossa with different structures highlighted. The image labels the Superior border (imaginary line between the epicondyles), the Medial border (Lateral border of the pronator teres), and the Lateral border (Medial border of the brachioradialis).]

Elbow fracture
Children:

- Supracondylar (60%)
- Lateral condyle (15%)
- Medial condyle (10%)

Adult:

- Radial head/neck (50%)
- Olecranon (20%)
- Supracondylar (10%)

Supracondylar fracture
MOI: common in children

- 95% extension injury via FOOSH
- 5% flexion injury
  Complications
- Nerve palsy (10%): AIN injury is most common
  - Posterolaterally displaced: **median n.** and brachial artery
  - Posteromedially displaced: radial n
- Malunion: **cubital varus** deformity ("gunstock deformity")
- **Volkmann's contracture** (fig.): brachial artery injury → ischaemic
  necrosis of forearm flexors, causing claw-like deformity
- **Pucker's sign** (fig.): skin tenting, indicate significant soft tissue
  injury (proximal fracture fragment spikes through fascia →
  subcutaneous bruising)
  Radiological features: AP and lateral X-ray elbow
- **Disrupted anterior humeral line**
- **Fat pad sign** (fig.): inflammation around the elbow joint pushes
  the fat pad away
- Displacement: most commonly postero-medial displacement
  (i.e. cubital varus)
  Gartland classification
- Class I: undisplaced
- Class II: displaced, with intact posterior cortex
- Class III: displaced in two or three planes
  Management
- Gartland class I (non-displaced): long-arm cast in < 90° flexion
- Gartland class II-III (displaced) / associated **neurovascular** injury:
  - Closed fracture: CRPP (closed reduction with percutaneous
    K-wire fixation)
  - Open fracture: open reduction with percutaneous pinning +/-
    consult vascular team for vascular exploration
- K-wire insertion:
  - Risk of ulnar n. injury during insertion of medial K-wire
  - Remove in clinic after 3-4 weeks

[Figure 2: Clinical Picture of the Forearm - A photograph illustrates the clinical appearance of a forearm. The image shows a hand with labels pointing to thumb adduction, wrist flexion, MP extension, and IP flexion. The forearm is also labeled with forearm pronation and elbow flexion.]

[Clinical photograph of a child's arm from the side. A bruise is visible on the elbow.]

[An X-ray image of an elbow. Yellow arrows indicate the fracture and displacement.]

[Two x-ray images of an elbow joint after K-wire fixation.]

Radial head fracture
MOI: FOOSH with a carrying angle

- Radial head normally articulates with **capitulum** of humerus
- Indirect trauma → Axial loading pushes radial head against capitulum of humerus

Clinical features

- Elbow effusion
- Limited pronation/ supination
  Complications:
- Essex-Lopresti fracture: radial head # + DRUJ disruption →
  require OT
- **Terrible triad of elbow** (fig.): associated with high risk of
  **instability, stiffness, arthritis** → require OT (see below)
  - Radial head fracture
  - Coronoid fracture
  - Posterior elbow dislocation with LCL injury
- Nerve injury: all 3, but PIN (radial) highest risk

[A medical illustration of a radial head fracture and posterior dislocation of the elbow joint, including labeling of coronoid process fracture.]

Radiological features: AP + lateral X-ray elbow

- **Fat pad sign / Sail sign**: joint effusion (blue arrow)
- Radial head fracture line (red arrow)
- Disrupted radiocapitellar line
- MRI may be required to assess associated ligament injury (LCL)
  **Mason classification & management**
- Type 1 (non-displaced / displaced < 2mm): non-operative (**elbow sling** x 1 week in flexion → early mobilisation)
- Type 2 (displaced >2mm /angulation): **ORIF**
- Type 3 (comminuted fracture):
  - ORIF (+ LCL reconstruction if torn)
  - ORIF not feasible: radial head excision with replacement

[X-ray image of an elbow showing a red arrow pointing to a fracture line and a blue arrow indicating joint effusion.]

**Olecranon fracture**
MOI: FOOSH → sudden pull of triceps muscle

- All olecranon fractures are **intra-articular** (articulate with trochlea of humerus)
  Clinical features
- Elbow effusion
- Inability to **extend** elbow against gravity
  Classifications: Mayo classification, Schatzker classification
  Management:
- Non-operative: if minimally displaced <2mm / not fit
  - Elbow sling x 1 week in flexion → early mobilization
- Operative:
  - Tension band wiring (if # is proximal to coronoid process) (fig.)
  - Olecranon plating (if # is at / distal to coronoid process)

[X-ray image of an elbow with an olecranon fracture.]

[X-ray image of an elbow showing surgical repair with wires.]

**Elbow dislocation**
MOI: FOOSH → usually **posterior** dislocation, 50% associated with bony injury
Clinical features

- Elbow effusion, limited pronation-supination
- Disrupted equilateral triangle of elbow
- Complications: **terrible triad** of elbow, **ulnar nerve injury**, vascular injury
  Radiological features: AP + lateral X-ray elbow
- **Radio-capitellar incongruence** (Disrupted radiocapitellar line)
- **Ulno-trochlear incongruence** (Disrupted anterior humeral line)
  Management
- Simple dislocation (no fracture): **closed reduction** + splinting
  - CR: by in-line traction or manipulation of olecranon
- Complex dislocation (with fracture, e.g. terrible triad): **ORIF** of coronoid process & radial head, LCL/MCL reconstruction

[X-ray image of a dislocated elbow joint.]

Management of forearm fractures:

- Acute: RICE, analgesics, immobilization by slab
- Definitive: **Open reduction internal fixation (ORIF)** is preferred: affect motion (e.g. supination, pronation)

  4.4 Epicondylitis
  Definition: chronic inflammation of forearm tendons at the elbow
  Pathophysiology: repetitive overuse of tendons
  Risk factors: occupations / hobbies that require excessive use of forearm muscles, e.g. tennis, golf
  DDx: cervical radiculopathy, OA elbow, radial carpal tunnel syndrome
  **Lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow)**: more common

- Anatomy: common extensor tendon attaches superficial extensor muscles to the lateral epicondyle
- Clinical features:
  - Elbow pain radiating down the forearm, worsen over weeks to months
  - Local tenderness on palpation of lateral epicondyle
  - **Cozen's test:** pronate + radially deviate forearm → extend wrist against resistance
  - **Mill's test:** pronate forearm, flex wrist and extend elbow

[Illustration depicting the clinical testing for lateral epicondylitis, also known as tennis elbow, showing the elbow joint. The test involves applying pressure to the affected area while the patient attempts to extend their wrist against resistance.]

[Illustration depicting the Mills Test to evaluate for lateral epicondylitis. The elbow is fully extended, the forearm is pronated, and the wrist is flexed, increasing tension on the wrist extensors.]

- Investigations: clinical diagnosis; USG or MRI to detect any structural abnormalities
- Management:
  - Conservative: activity modification, **PT** (stretching, strengthening exercise, orthoses e.g. **elbow brace**)
  - Pharmacological: analgesics, local steroid injection
  - Surgical: open/arthroscopic debridement of tendinosis, repair of damaged tendon insertions, tendon transfer if >50% damage

**Medial epicondylitis (golfer's elbow)**: less common

- Pronator teres and FCR most commonly affected
- Associated ulnar nerve neuropathy
- Similar management as tennis elbow

Muscles

- Forearm (Extrinsic muscles)
  - Anterior compartment: all innervated by **median nerve** except FCU & FDP 4/5 (ulnar n.)

    - Deep: supinator, APL, EPB, EPL, EIP (extensor indicis proprius)
- Hand (Intrinsic muscles): all innervated by **ulnar nerve** except lateral 2 lumbricals & thenar (median n.)
  - Thenar (APB, OP, FPB): only APB & OP are solely innervated by median nerve, thus tested

  - Lumbricals: account for ulnar claw and hand of benediction

Immobilisation of hand
Safe position: A position that is designed to

- Prevent joint contractures upon prolonged immobilisation - volar plates are
  maximally stretched in MCPJ flexion + PIPJ/DIPJ extension
- Stabilise joint during trauma (e.g. carpal bone fracture) - collateral ligaments are stretched that does not allow abduction/ adduction

[Drawing of hands, demonstrating "Position of Safety" and "Position of Function"]

Functional position (holding cup): A position that is designed to ensure certain degree of function of hand even if it develops contracture in the future, e.g. in stroke patients

| Ulnar            | C8, T1     | Forearm: FCU & median 2 FDP Hand: All except thenar & lateral 2 lumbricals         | Medial 1.5/5 hand         |

Other muscles supplied: scapular muscles (C5, 6), pectoralis & lati. dorsi (C6-8)

- Skin over deltoid by C4 instead

Brachial plexus injury
Erb's palsy

- Upper plexus injury (C5-6)
- MOI: stretch during delivery
- Waiter's tip sign: adducted & internally rotated shoulder + extended & pronated forearm
  Klumpke palsy
- Lower plexus injury (C8-T1)
- MOI: UL pulled superiorly, e.g. tree branch
- Automatic 4-finger claw hand: ulnar + median nerve injury

5.2 Compression neuropathy
Differential diagnosis of compression neuropathy

- Cervical radiculopathy
- Brachial plexopathy
- Peripheral neuropathy
  Pathophysiology
- Nerve compression impairs epineural blood flow & axonal conduction
- **Double crush syndrome:** peripheral entrapment syndromes often associated with cervical/ lumbar spondylosis
  - Proposed explanation: proximal compression of a peripheral nerve renders it more susceptible to the effects of a second, more distal injury (e.g. cubital tunnel syndrome & Guyon's canal syndrome)

Overview of UL compression neuropathy
| | Syndrome | Compression site | Remarks |
| ----------- | ----------- | ----------- | ----------- |
| Brachial plexus | Thoracic outlet syndrome | 1st rib & clavicle | Causes: cervical rib, fracture clavicle, Pancoast tumour |
| Median nerve | Pronator teres syndrome | 2 heads of pronator teres | |
| | **Carpal tunnel syndrome (MC)** | Carpal tunnel | |
| Ulnar nerve | Cubital tunnel syndrome | Median epicondyle of humerus Olecranon process | Associated with cubital valgus |
| | Guyon canal syndrome | Guyon canal (pisiform & hook of hamate) | Most common cause: ganglion from the triquetrohamate joint |
| Radial nerve | PIN syndrome | Arcade of Frohse | Motor weakness |
| | Wartenberg's syndrome | ECRL & BR | Sensory loss (superficial radial nerve) |

Thoracic outlet syndrome
Anatomy:

- Brachial plexus and subclavian a. pass through scalene triangle
- Subclavian v. passes ant. to scalenus anterior
  Causes:
- Anatomical abnormalities: e.g. **cervical rib**, scalenus hypertrophy, **previous fracture (e.g. clavicle, 1st/2nd rib)**
- **Pancoast tumor**
- Trauma: hyperextension injury, repetitive microtrauma (e.g. athletes), poor posture

[Image of the anatomy of the thoracic outlet with labels indicating the brachial plexus, scalenus medius, scalenus anterior, and subclavian artery.]

Classification, clinical features and management
| Type | Signs | Treatment |
| ----------- | ----------- | ----------- |
| Neurological (nTOS) | **Lower brachial plexus injury** (e.g. paraesthesia / weakness along ulnar distribution) | Physiotherapy +/- Botox injection to relax scalene muscles |
| Venous (VTOS) | Deep vein thrombosis (Paget-Schroetter syndrome) | Thrombolysis, anticoagulation Surgical decompression |
| Arterial (aTOS) | Claudication, acute limb ischemia | Embolectomy Surgical decompression |

Special tests: Adson's maneuver (fig.), Roo's test, Elvey's test
Investigations: bloods, **CXR, Doppler USG**, nerve conduction studies, MRI, CT angiogram

[Image of a doctor performing the Adson's maneuver on a patient.]

Surgical procedures to decompress thoracic outlet: seldom required

- Supraclavicular / Transaxillary excision of 1st rib / cervical rib
- Scalenectomy

244
Cubital tunnel syndrome

- Ulnar nerve entrapment at elbow (DDx: cervical myelopathy, T1 radiculopathy)
- Examine elbow: **cubital valgus** deformity, limited ROM, Tinel sign, ulnar nerve subluxability, elbow flexion test
- Differentiate from distal compression: less prominent claw hand (FDP 4/5), dorsal sensory also affected

Management

- Conservative: **soft elbow extension splint** (fig.), physiotherapy, lifestyle modification
- Pharmacological: local steroid injection, pyridoxine
- Surgical: Decompression in-situ, medial epicondylectomy, **anterior transposition** of ulnar nerve

Carpal tunnel syndrome
Risk factors

- Primary (MC): **aging, female**
- Secondary:
  - Endocrine: **DM, hypothyroid,** acromegaly
  - Inflammatory: **RA**, gout
  - SOL: ganglion
  - Post-traumatic: wrist fracture
  - Physiological: **obesity, pregnancy**

Clinical features

- **Pain & numbness in distribution of median nerve** (first 3 1/2 digits)
  - Thenar area spared: palmar cutaneous branch of median nerve branches proximal to flexor retinaculum
  - Worse at night, relieved by hanging over the side of bed or shaking
- **Thenar muscle wasting** and weakness of thumb abduction

Differential diagnosis

- Cervical spondylosis (esp. C6/7): neck pain + neck movement exacerbates
- Pronator teres syndrome: forearm motor involvement + palmar sensation affected
- Thoracic outlet syndrome
- Peripheral neuropathy

Investigations

- Clinical diagnosis
- Nerve conduction studies (normal conduction does not r/o CTS)

Management

- Conservative: **night-time wrist splint** (fig.), physiotherapy, lifestyle modification
- Pharmacological: local steroid injection to reduce swelling, pyridoxine, diuretics
- Surgical:
  - Indications: CTS **unresponsive to conservative treatment** for 6 weeks, associated **sensory / motor deficit**, axonal loss on NCS
  - **Carpal tunnel release** (division of flexor retinaculum): open vs endoscopic (fig.)
  - Specific complications:
    - Persistent CTS symptoms (inadequate release)
    - Nerve injury: palmar cutaneous branch
    - Vascular injury: superficial palmar arch

[Image of a person wearing a blue elbow brace that immobilizes the elbow joint, keeping the arm straight. The brace is secured with straps around the arm and forearm.]

[Image of a person's hand with an arrow pointing to the thenar eminence, the fleshy area at the base of the thumb. The hand shows signs of aging, with wrinkles and prominent veins.]

[Image of a person wearing a black wrist brace, which extends from the mid-forearm to the mid-palm, immobilizing the wrist joint. The brace has adjustable straps and a rigid support on the palm side.]

[Image of a diagram illustrating the surgical incision points for open carpal tunnel release. The diagram depicts a hand with three marked lines: the "Mini-open" approach, the "Open" approach, and the "Endoscopic" approach. Each line indicates where the incision would be made on the palm.]

[Image showing a surgical field where carpal tunnel release is being performed. The flexor retinaculum is exposed and being cut with surgical instruments.]

[Image showing a surgical procedure with blood visible, indicating the location of superficial palmar arch injury.]

5.3 **Tendon-related pathology**
Definitions

- Tendinosis: age-related degeneration; can be with pain, but no inflammatory signs (e.g. redness)
- Tendinitis: inflammation of tendon
- Tenosynovitis: inflammation of synovial sheath
- Tenovaginitis: inflammation of fibrous sheath, i.e. pulley

[Detailed illustration of a wrist joint with labels. The illustration highlights the tenosynovium, tendon, synovial cavity, mesotendon, marrow, bone, and periosteum. Six extensor compartments are shown: Compartment 1 contains Extensor pollicis brevis and Abductor pollicis longus; Compartment 2 contains Extensor carpi radialis brevis and Extensor carpi radialis longus; Compartment 3 contains Extensor pollicis longus; Compartment 4 contains Extensor digitorum and Extensor indicis; Compartment 5 contains Extensor digiti minimi; and Compartment 6 contains Extensor carpi ulnaris. The ulna and radius are labeled, and the view is marked as Anterior.]

**De Quervain's tenosynovitis (Gamer's thumbs)**

- Anatomy: 6 extensor compartments on dorsal aspect of wrist, separated by fibrous septa
  - De Quervain's disease: stenosing tenovaginitis/ tenosynovitis within the first extensor compartment of wrist (contain APL & EPB)
- Risk factors
  - Female aged 30-50y
  - Pregnancy
  - Occupation that involves repetitive movement of hand & wrist, e.g. housewife
- Clinical features
  - Pain near the base of thumb + swelling
  - Finkelstein's test: acute pain at radial styloid process and along EPB/APL tendons when thumb is grasped and sharply deviated towards the ulnar side
- Differential diagnosis
  - 1st CMCJ osteoarthritis: Grind test+ (forcefully push thumb against CMC joint with rotation)
  - Wartenberg's syndrome (neuritis of superficial radial nerve): common in those wearing tight watch/ jewelry
  - Intersection syndrome: acute tendinopathy of EPB & APL as they cross over the tendons of 2nd extensor compartment (ECRL & ECRB)
- Investigations: clinical diagnosis; plain hand XR to r/o DDx
- Management:
  - Conservative: lifestyle (avoid repetitive actions), wrist splint
  - Pharmacological: local steroid injection
  - Surgical decompression: percutaneous / endoscopic release → widen the tunnel roof for tendons to move

[Illustration of the Finkelstein Test. Step 1 shows a hand making a fist with the thumb tucked inside. Step 2 shows tilting the hand down.]
Pain felt during the Finkelstein Test is a positive indicator of de Quervain's syndrome.

245

# Trigger finger

- Definition: stenosing tenovaginitis of A1 pulley causing finger clicked / **locked** in flexion, preventing a return to extension
  - Most common: ring finger, middle finger, thumb
- Anatomy: Pulley system prevents flexor tendons from bowstringing
  - Palmar aponeurosis
  - Annular ligaments (x5): A1, A3, A5 overlie MCPJ, PIPJ and DIPJ
  - Cruciate ligaments (x3)
- Pathophysiology
  - **Flexor tenosynovitis** causes local nodal formation distal to pulley, most common A1 pulley (overlie MCP joint)
  - Flexion causes node to move proximal to pulley → fail to pass back
- Risk factors
  - Occupation that involves **prolonged gripping**, e.g. golfer
  - Elderly female
  - Inflammation: DM, RA, gout
- Green's classification
  - Grade I: palm pain and tenderness at A1 pulley
  - Grade II: catching of digit, can actively extend
  - Grade III: locking of digit, passively correctable
  - Grade IV: fixed flexion deformities
- Investigations: clinical diagnosis, bloods
- Management
  - Conservative: splint that holds the finger in extension position at night
  - Pharmacological: local steroid injection (into A1 pulley)
  - Surgical: surgical release of A1 pulley

[Illustration of hand with "Trigger finger" condition. The illustration shows the palmar side of the hand with a finger bent at the proximal interphalangeal joint. The A1 pulley is highlighted in red at the base of the finger. The illustration shows how the flexor tendon can get stuck at this point when the finger tries to extend.]

[Illustration of hand with "Trigger finger" condition. The illustration shows the palmar side of the hand with a finger bent at the proximal interphalangeal joint. The A1 pulley is highlighted in red at the base of the finger. The illustration shows how the flexor tendon can get stuck at this point when the finger tries to extend.]

# Ganglion cyst

- Pathogenesis: periarticular mucoid degeneration after repetitive movement → herniation of dense connective tissue → filled with synovial fluid
- MC soft tissue tumor of hands, occur at any age
- Never becomes malignant and may resolve spontaneously
- Risk factors: **female**, **OA**, previous joint / tendon injury
- Clinical features
  - Site: **dorsal wrist (70%)** from radio-lunate ligament
  - Appearance: solitary **spherical painless** smooth cystic lesion
  - Palpation: non-tender, firm, rubbery, attach to joint capsule / tendon sheath, variable mobility
  - **Transilluminable** due to cystic content
  - Neurological deficit if **nerve impingement**
- Differential diagnoses: tenosynovitis, giant cell tumor (solid fixed mass), lipoma, sarcoma
- Diagnosis: clinical +/- USG (well-defined margins, thick wall with acoustic enhancement)
  - X-ray cannot see ganglions: rule out OA / bone malignancy
- Management:
  - Observe with brace / needle aspiration + immobilization (1st line)
  - Complete excision if persistent

[Two-part image labeled "A" and "B". Image A shows a dorsal view of a hand with a ganglion cyst visible on the wrist. The cyst appears as a smooth, rounded bulge under the skin. Image B shows a lateral view of a hand with a ganglion cyst on the wrist. The cyst is seen as a distinct swelling on the dorsal aspect of the wrist.]

# Tendon sheath infections → Kanavel signs

1. Tenderness over flexor sheath
2. Pain on passive extension
3. Flexed posture of digit
4. Fusiform swelling of digit

5.4 Hand & wrist trauma
Distal radius fracture
Very common (1/4 of all fractures), associated with osteoporosis ("fragility fracture")
| | Colles' fracture (MC, >90%) | Smith fracture |
| :----------------- | :------------------------------------------------ | :-------------------------------------------- |
| MOI | FOOSH forwards → landing on palmar wrist | FOOSH backwards → landing on dorsal wrist |
| Clinical features | Extra-articular fracture* | Extra-articular fracture* |
| | Dinner fork deformities | Garden spade deformities |
| | Low median nerve injury: lateral 3 1/2 finger + palm numbness | |
| Radiological features (x6): | Shortened radius | Shortened radius |
| AP + lateral | Ulnar styloid fracture | Ulnar styloid fracture |
| X-ray wrist | Dorsal angulation + displacement | Volar angulation + displacement |
| | Radial angulation + displacement | Radial angulation + displacement |
| Management | Stable extra-articular fracture: Closed reduction + short arm cast immobilisation x 6 weeks (fig.) | |
| | Unstable fracture^: ORIF with plating / K-wire fixation | |
| | Open fracture: external fixation | |

\*Barton's fracture: intra-articular fracture with associated dislocation of radio-carpal joint

[Detailed illustration of Colles' fracture, Smith fracture, and Barton fracture. The images show the fractures in both dorsal and ventral views, highlighting the displacement and angulation of the bone fragments. The different types of fractures are clearly labeled.]

Radiographic criteria
| Measurement | Normal | Unstable fracture: indicated for ORIF |
| :------------------------- | :------- | :------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Radial height (AP) | 11mm | >5mm shortening |
| Radial inclination (AP) | 22° | Change >5° |
| Articular stepoff (AP) | Congruous| Intraarticular fracture with >2mm stepoff |
| Volar tilt (Lateral) | 11° | Dorsal angulation >5° or >20° difference with contralateral distal radius |
| Others | | Associated ulnar fracture (NOT ulnar styloid #) |
| | | Comminuted fracture |

Frykman classification of Colles' fracture
| Radius fracture | Ulna fracture: absent | Ulna fracture: present |
| :------------------------------------------------------ | :------------------ | :------------------- |
| Extra-articular | I | II |
| Intra-articular (radiocarpal joint) | III | IV |
| Intra-articular (distal radioulnar joint) | V | VI |
| Intra-articular (radiocarpal joint + distal radioulnar joint) | VII | VIII |

Associated complications

- Nerve: must assess all 3 nerves: lower median nerve injury (~CTS + palm numbness) is most common
- Bone: malunion, radial styloid fracture, scaphoid fracture
- Tendon: EPL tendon rupture
- Soft tissue: TFCC injury (triangular fibrocartilage complex), scapholunate lig. injury, lunotriquetral lig. injury
- Joint: Barton's fracture (radiocarpal joint injury), DRUJ injury, secondary OA

Scaphoid fracture
Mechanism of injury

- FOOSH
- Distribution: waist (70%), distal pole (20%), proximal pole (10%, most likely causing AVN) - Blood supply (dorsal branch of radial a.) enters in distal pole and travels retrograde towards proximal
  Clinical features
- Tenderness over anatomical snuffbox
- Pain on axial loading of thumb / palpating scaphoid tubercle
- Complications - Avascular necrosis (AVN) (30%): higher risk if more proximal fracture - Scaphoid non-union advanced collapse (SNAC): progressive arthritis due to prolonged non-union - Scaphoid relies on primary bone healing (scaphoid is mainly surrounded by articular cartilage, which does not provide blood supply for callus formation and consumes callus) → difficult to achieve absolute immobilisation
  Differential diagnosis
- Distal radius fracture
- Fracture of other carpal bones / base of 1st MC
- Wrist sprain
- De Quervain's tenosynovitis
  Investigations
- XR: AP, lateral, scaphoid view (30° wrist extension, 20° ulnar deviation)
- If high clinical suspicion - Thumb splint + repeat XR in 14 days - MRI wrist
  Management
- Non-operative: indicated if undisplaced fracture, normal XR but high clinical suspicion (as above)
  - Immobilisation: thumb spica cast (fig.)
- Operative: indicated if displaced / proximal fracture
  - Percutaneous screw fixation

[Figure 3-(A) Initial AP radiograph showing a subtle linear lucency within the scaphoid (B) more
pronounced lucency observed in repeat imaging after 12 days]

[Image of a hand with a thumb spica cast]

Kienbock's disease

- Definition: avascular necrosis (AVN) of lunate
- Causes: vascular, trauma
- Clinical features: dorsal wrist pain
- Investigations: XR wrist (sclerosis of lunate), MRI wrist
  Mallet finger
- Definition: injury of extensor tendon of terminal phalanx (Zone 1) when an extended finger is forcibly flexed
- Clinical features: flexed DIPJ that cannot be actively extended (passive ROM intact)
- Management: DIPJ extension splint for 6-8 weeks, require operation if type III
- Complications: swan neck deformity

[Image of Classification of mallet finger: Type I: tendon rupture, Type II: bone avulsion, Type III: joint subluxation (usually fracture involve >50% of articular surface or >2mm articular stepping)]

Dupuytren's contracture

- Causes: alcoholism, cirrhosis, DM, HIV, anti-epileptics (phenobarbitone), systemic fibromatosis
- Management: conservative ROM exercise, resection/fasciectomy (if flexion contracture MCPJ/PIPJ >30%), arthrodesis/amputation

[Image of hand with mallet finger splint]

Other finger deformities

- Jersey finger: closed rupture of FDP; failed DIPJ flexion when hold fist (fig.)
- Skier's thumb: ulnar collateral ligament rupture →↑ ROM of thumb at MCPJ
- Boxer's fracture: fracture of 5th metacarpal neck; due to direct trauma to a clenched fist
- Bennett's fracture: fracture of 1st metacarpal base, due to forced abduction of 1st metacarpal in clenched fist

[Image of Boxer's fracture: fifth metacarpal fracture]

6.1 Anatomy
Neurovascular supply of hip joint

- Arterial supply is retrograde:
  - Medial circumflex femoral artery (main) & lateral circumflex femoral artery profunda femoris common femoral a.
  - Ligamentum teres: contain artery to head of femur
  - Nutrient vessels from bone
- Nerve supply: sciatic, femoral, obturator nerves - same innervation to knee joint → hip pain can be referred to knee and vice versa

[Illustration of the hip joint anatomy. The image shows the femoral head, acetabulum, and acetabular labrum. Arrows point to each part with labels. Another illustration depicts the femoral artery and profunda femoris artery, highlighting the adductor hiatus.]

Gluteal muscles

- Superficial muscles: gluteus medius & minimus (abductors; superior gluteal nerve)
- Deep muscles: piriformis (at the exit of sciatic nerve)

Hip muscles
| Muscles | Action | Nerve |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Anterior Quadriceps femoris<br>Sartorius<br>Pectineus<br>Iliopsoas | All except iliopsoas: Femoral<br>knee extension<br>Iliopsoas: hip flexion | Femoral<br>nerve<br>nerve<br>(L2-4) |
| Medial Adductor magnus/<br>longus/ brevis<br>Gracilis<br>Obturator externus | Hip adduction | Obturator<br>nerve<br>(L2-4) |
| Posterior Hamstrings (biceps femoris,<br>semitendinosis,<br>semimembranosus) | Hip extension<br>Knee flexion | Sciatic<br>nerve<br>(L4-S3) |

[Illustration showing the boundaries and contents of the adductor canal. The boundaries are medially (Sartorius), posteriorly (Adductor longus and Adductor magnus), and anterolaterally (Vastus Medialis). The contents are Nerve to vastus medialis, Femoral artery, Femoral vein, and Saphenous nerve]

Hunter's canal (adductor canal)

- Border: vastus medialis (quadriceps), adductor magnus, sartorius
- Femoral artery passes through to form popliteal artery

  6.2 Hip trauma
  Fracture neck of femur (#NOF)
  Definition: fracture between subcapital part of femoral head and 5cm distal to lesser trochanter
  Risk factor: osteoporosis
  Mechanism of injury

- Elderly: slip and fall (low-energy trauma: "fragility fracture")
- Young: road traffic collision (high-energy trauma)

Classification

- Fracture location (fig.)
  - Intracapsular (high AVN risk): head (rare, seen in posterior dislocation of hip), neck (subcapital, transcervical, basicervical)
  - Extracapsular (low AVN risk): intertrochanteric, subtrochanteric (within 5cm of lesser trochanter)

[X-ray image illustrating different types of hip fractures, including Intracapsular fractures (Subcapital, Transcervical, Basicervical) and Extracapsular fractures (Intertrochanteric, Subtrochanteric). The image labels the Capsule and the fracture locations]

Intracapsular #NOF: further classified by [Garden's classification](https://example.com/garden)
| Garden | Description | Prognosis |
| ----------- | ----------- | ----------- |
| Nondisplaced fracture | I | Nondisplaced incomplete fracture | Good → internal fixation |
| | II | Nondisplaced complete fracture | |
| Displaced fracture | III | Incompletely displaced, complete fracture | High risk of AVN (>95%): disruption of blood supply from MCFA |
| | IV | Completely displaced, complete fracture | → ORIF (young), hip replacement (elderly) |

[Image of Garden's classification of femoral neck fractures, showing illustrations and x-ray images of fractures types I-IV. Type I shows a nondisplaced incomplete fracture, Type II shows a nondisplaced complete fracture, Type III shows an incompletely displaced, complete fracture, and Type IV shows a completely displaced, complete fracture.]

Clinical features

- Pain in groin, thigh or referred to knee, exacerbated by **internal rotation** (most sensitive) and axial loading
- **Shortened, abducted and externally rotated** leg (unopposed action of short external rotators, e.g. gluteus medius/ minimus)

Investigation:

- **AP and lateral X-ray hip** +/- CT, MRI or bone scan
- Duplex USG to rule out DVT if delayed presentation
- +/- AP X-ray pelvis and femur (r/o other fractures e.g. pubic ramus, femoral shaft)

Radiological features on X-ray hip

- Externally rotated limb: more prominent lesser trochanter
- Shortened limb: higher lesser trochanter
- **Disrupted Shenton's line** (formed by medial edge of femoral neck and inferior edge of superior pubic ramus) (fig.)
- Displacement & completeness of fracture as in Garden's classification

Management

- Operative management is required for all hip fracture **within 48h** (**young: more urgent**; **old**: optimize medical condition first) to relieve symptoms and restore function
- Factors to consider: Risk of AVN (i.e. intracapsular, displaced fracture), age (<65 vs >65)
- **Surgical options** (need to know!)

|             | Joint replacement                                                           | Open reduction and internal fixation                                      |
| ----------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Indications | **Intracapsular, displaced** fracture (Garden III/IV) **AND elderly >65yo** | Others                                                                    |
| Approaches  | Hemiarthroplasty                                                            | Intracapsular: cannulated hip screws                                      |
|             | Total hip replacement (if OA hip)                                           | Extracapsular: dynamic hip screws / intramedullary nail (e.g. Gamma nail) |

[Image of the anatomy of the hip, labeling structures such as the ischial spine, acetabulum, femoral head, greater trochanter, femoral neck, ischia tuberosity, inferior pubic ramus, superior pubic ramus, lesser trochanter, and femoral shaft. A line is drawn to illustrate a normal Shenton's line.]

- Prevent dislocation: do not squat / cross legs / flex hip>90°, **abduction pillow, high-low chair**
- Post-operative complications:
  - Immediate: bleeding, infection, leg length discrepancies, neurovascular injury
  - Long-term: joint dislocation, **prosthesis infection, AVN**

- Prevention of recurrence
  - **Fall prevention measures**
  - Treatment of osteoporosis: Improve bone mineral content by bisphosphonates and lifestyle modifications

Mechanisms of injury x4

- **Pathological fractures** (e.g. metastatic deposits, osteomalacia)
- **Fragility fractures** (low-energy trauma in elderly)
- **Bisphosphonate-related fractures:** classically transverse # of proximal femur
  Clinical features
- Shortened externally rotated leg
- Complications: nerve injury (pudendal, femoral), haemorrhagic shock (can lose

  | Type 0 | No comminution |
  | --- | --- |
  | Type 1 | Insignificant comminution |
  | Type 2 | >50% cortical contact |
  | Type 3 | <50% cortical contact |
  | Type 4 | No contact between proximal and distal fragment |
  Investigations
- **AP and lateral X-ray** along entire femur (including hip & knee)
  Management: mainstay is **surgery**
- Immediate reduction & immobilisation: traction splinting e.g. **Kendrick traction device** (fig.)
  - Change to skin traction asap to prevent skin necrosis at groin; C/I in hip / pelvic fracture
- Operative (done within 24-48h): **antegrade intramedullary nail** (with closed or open reduction)
- Non-operative: long leg cast (fig.) if non-displaced fracture with multiple comorbidities

[Image of a traction splinting device]

[Image of a person wearing a long leg cast]

Distal femur fracture
Mechanisms of injury

- High-energy trauma in younger patients
- Low-energy trauma in older patients (pathological fracture)
  Clinical features
- Severe pain in distal thigh, inability to bear weight
- **Knee effusion**: indicate intra-articular extension
  Classification
- Type A: extra-articular
- Type B: partial articular
  - Hoffa fracture (fig.): type B with fracture of posterior femoral condyles in coronal plane (require lateral X-ray to pick up)
- Type C: complete articular
  Investigations: AP and lateral X-ray knee and femur
  Management: mainstay is surgery
- Immediate reduction & immobilisation: skin traction
- Operative: retrograde intramedullary nail (simple) / ORIF (complex) / external fixation (open #)
- Peri-prosthetic fractures may require ORIF or distal femoral replacement

Acetabular fracture
Anatomy

- Acetabulum: cup-like depression on inferolateral aspect of pelvis, articulate with head of femur
  Mechanism
- Usually **high-energy injury** (e.g. road traffic accident, fall from height)
  Clinical features
- Pain and inability to weight bear (similar to #NOF)
- Look for open fracture and assess neurovascular status of both limbs
- Assess skin for Morel-Lavallée lesions (fig.): internal degloving injury where skin and subcutaneous tissues are separated from underlying fascia
  Investigations
- Pelvic X-ray: AP + **Judet view** (tilt the patient 45° laterally in both directions - iliac oblique & obturator oblique)
- +/- CT scan
  Classification: Judet-Letournel classification (elementary fractures vs associated fractures)
  Management
- Pelvic binder is usually not indicated
- Undisplaced fractures: conservative management for 6-8 weeks
- Displaced fractures:
  - Young: ORIF to restore anatomy of joint surface and pelvic stability
  - Old: fracture fixation + total hip replacement

Pelvic fracture
Anatomy: pelvic ring formed by ilium, ischium, pubis and sacrum, and their supporting ligaments
Fracture pattern

- AP compression: **open book injury** (PS diastasis + SIJ diastasis)
- Lateral compression : pubic rami fracture
- Avulsion fractures: ASIS (sartorius), AIIS (rectus femoris), ischial tuberosity (hamstring)
- Vertical shear
  Bleeding source: fracture site, tearing of venous plexus, torn arterioles
  Clinical signs
- Tender bony landmarks
- High-riding prostate
- Estimated blood loss: 3-4L
  Investigation: X-ray pelvis (**AP** + **inlet view** + **outlet view**)

[Radiographs of two knees are shown side by side. Image A shows the anterior view of the knee, highlighting the joint space and bone structure. Image B depicts a lateral view of the same knee, demonstrating the alignment of the femur and tibia.]

[A CT scan shows a cross-sectional view of the pelvis, revealing a disruption in the bone structure on the right side, indicative of a fracture. The surrounding soft tissues appear normal.]

Management

- **Pelvic binder:** at the level of greater trochanters (tamponade effect)
- **External fixators:** pins inserted along iliac crests
- Urgent angiogram

# Hip dislocation

Classification

- Congenital dislocation: DDH [Paed ORT]
- Acquired dislocation: **posterior** (90%), anterior (rare), lateral (rare)
- Posterior dislocation
  - Mechanism of injury: dashboard injury (flexed hip & knee against dashboard in RTA)
  - Clinical features
    - Shortened limb that is **adducted, internally rotated and flexed**
    - Associated injury: fracture (femoral head, NOF), sciatic nerve injury
    - Complications: AVN (fracture-dislocation highest risk)
  - Management
    - XR hip: disrupted Shenton's line
    - Closed reduction
    - Post-reduction CT to assess any fracture

## 6.3 OA hip

See [Systemic diseases] for pathology and aetiology

- Secondary OA hip more common in Chinese population
  Clinical features
- Hip pain radiating to knee, aggravated by weight-bearing and improved with rest
- Morning stiffness
- **Externally rotated** limb on supine position
- Antalgic gait
- Painful passive movement with reduced ROM
- End-stage: fixed flexion deformity with Trendelenburg gait
  DDx: fractures, sciatica, trochanteric bursitis, gluteus medius tendinopathy
  Radiological features
- 4 features of OA (fig.)
- Features of underlying cause
  - DDH: hip dislocation, hip dysplasia (inadequate acetabular coverage)
  - AVN: osteopenia, crescent sign
  - AS: fusion of SI joint
    Management
- Non-operative: pain relief, lifestyle modifications (e.g. weight loss, regular exercise, smoking cessation), physiotherapy
- Operative: hemiarthroplasty / total hip replacement
  - Different surgical approaches defined relative to gluteus medius:

| Approach                          | Advantage                                | Disadvantage                                      |
| :-------------------------------- | :--------------------------------------- | :------------------------------------------------ |
| Posterior - most common           | Preserve abductor mechanism →Rapid rehab | Sciatic nerve injuryRisk of hip joint dislocation |
| Anterolateral (modified Hardinge) | Detach abductor mechanism →Good exposure | Superior gluteal nerve injury                     |
| Anterior (Smith-Petersen) - rare  | For open washout of infected hip         |                                                   |

- Specific complications: thromboembolism, dislocation, infection of prosthesis, leg length discrepancy

[Image of a patient lying on an examination table, showcasing the external rotation of the leg from the hip. The right leg is more noticeably rotated outward compared to the left. The image captures the overall body positioning, including the legs and feet, to illustrate the specific presentation of external rotation at the hip.]

[Image of an X-ray of a hip joint. The X-ray reveals signs of osteoarthritis, including joint space narrowing, osteophyte formation (bone spurs), and subchondral sclerosis (increased bone density). The features suggest degenerative changes within the hip joint.]

254
Follow-up after THR: **Harris Hip Score** (full mark: 100)

- Pain (44)
- Function (47)
  - Gait (33): limp, support (none / cane / crutch), distance walked
  - Activity (14): stairs, wear socks/shoes, sitting time, enter public transportation
- ROM (9)

## 6.4 AVN of hip

Definition: cellular death of bone components due to interruption of blood supply
Aetiology

- Trauma
- Long-term steroid use
- Alcohol (amount similar to cirrhosis)
- Inflammatory: SLE
- Infection: osteomyelitis, septic arthritis
- Decompression sickness (Caisson disease/ bends)

Clinical features

- Insidious onset of hip pain
- Physical exam: limited ROM, esp. **abduction** & **internal rotation**

Investigations

- XR: osteopenia → sclerosis (marrow infarct with calcification) → **crescent sign** (subchondral lucency indicating subchondral collapse) → secondary OA changes
- MRI: more sensitive and specific, detect contralateral AVN (high risk)
  - T2W: **double line sign** (outer dark sclerosis, inner bright granulation tissue) (fig.)

[MRI scan showing a hip joint. The image is in grayscale and shows the detailed anatomy of the hip, including the femur and acetabulum. The scan highlights areas of sclerosis and granulation tissue. There is also a scale included.]

[Conventional radiograph of the right femur in the frog-leg position obtained with the patient's thigh abducted and flexed shows subchondral area of hyperlucency (arrows) in the anterolateral aspect of the proximal femoral head]

- Ficat classification: combine plain XR, MRI, bone scan, clinical features to guide treatment & prognosis

| Stage | Features                                                                                      |
| ----- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| 0     | Normal radiographs (silent hip)                                                               |
| I     | Inconspicious abnormality orminor osteopenia changes                                          |
| II    | Sclerotic or cystic lesions                                                                   |
| III   | II a. Focal radiological changes                                                              |
|       | II b. Crescent sign without flattening of the femoral head                                    |
| IV    | Flattening of the femoral head or femoral head collapse, joint space normal                   |
|       | Femoral head collapse and osteoarthritis of the hip (joint spacecollapse, acetabular changes) |

Management

- Non-operative: bed rest, walking aids, bisphosphonates (but associated with ONJ)
- Joint-preserving operation:
  - Core decompression (reduce intraosseous pressure to allow ingrowth of blood vessels)
  - Osteotomy
  - Bone graft (free vascularized fibular graft FVFG)
- Total hip replacement (Ficat stage 3&4)

7 Knee
255

7.1 Anatomy
Knee joint

- Arterial supply: genicular anastomoses (genicular
  branches of femoral & popliteal arteries)
- Articular surface - Tibiofemoral: weight-bearing - Patellofemoral: provide fulcrum to increase
  power of knee extensor (quadriceps femoris) +
  stabiliser of knee joint
- Patella: largest sesamoid bone in the body
- Within tendon of quadriceps femoris
- Attach to patellar ligament

Menisci

- C-shaped fibrocartilage
- Functions: **shock absorbers**, increase stability of knee joint (by deepening the articular surface of tibia)
- Significance: - Medial meniscus attached to MCL → MCL damage causes medial meniscal tear - Lateral meniscus not attached to LCL - Mostly avascular (except outer 1/3): no spontaneous repair
  [Diagram of the knee showing the anterior cruciate ligament, posterior cruciate ligament, lateral meniscus, medial meniscus, lateral collateral ligament and medial collateral ligament.]

Bursae

- Small fluid-filled sac lined by synovial membrane
  [Illustration of a knee showing the location of the suprapatella bursa, prepatella bursa, infrapatella bursa, and semimembranosus bursa. The suprapatella bursa is colored blue, the prepatella bursa is colored green, the infrapatella bursa is colored yellow, and the semimembranosus bursa is colored brown.]

Ligaments

- Collateral ligaments (MCL, LCL): prevent excessive medial or lateral movement
- Cruciate ligaments:

|           | ACL                                                  | PCL                                                   |
| :-------- | :--------------------------------------------------- | :---------------------------------------------------- |
| Insertion | Lateral femoral condyle                              | Medial femoral condyle                                |
|           | Medial tibial condyle                                | Lateral tibial condyle                                |
| Function  | Prevent **anterior translation & rotation** of tibia | Prevent **posterior translation & rotation** of tibia |
|           | Prevent hyperextension of knee                       | Prevent hyperflexion of knee                          |

Pes anserinus

- Conjoint tendons of 3 muscles that insert onto anteromedial aspect of tibia
- Say Grace before Tea: sartorius, gracilis, semitendinosus
- Pes anserinus bursitis is a cause of chronic medial knee pain
  Iliotibial band (ITB)
- Shared aponeurosis of tensor fasciae latae & gluteus maximus, inserted onto anterolateral aspect of tibia (Gerdy's tubercle)
- IT band syndrome (due to repetitive flexion & extension of knee) is a cause of chronic lateral knee pain

  7.2 Soft tissue injuries
  Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tear
  Mechanism of injury

- Contact mechanism: valgus force to knee when foot is fixated to the ground
- Non-contact mechanism (MC): sudden deceleration & pivoting (change of direction)
- Risk factors: weak hip abductors, genu valgus, flatfoot
- Associated injury: - Unhappy triad: ACL tear, MCL tear, medial meniscus injury - Segond fracture (fig.) - avulsion of lateral tibial plateau, pathognomonic of ACL injury
  Clinical features
- Intensive pain + audible "pop" sound
- Immediate joint swelling (haemoarthrosis due to tear of highly vascularised ligament)
- Knee instability ("give way" sensation) and unable to bear weight
- Special tests: Lachman test (more sensitive), anterior drawer test, pivot shift test

Assess severity: Lachman grading
| Transition grade | Endpoint grading |
| --------------------- | ------------------------------------- |
| Grade 0: <2mm translation | Grade A: firm, sudden endpoint |
| Grade 1: 2-5mm translation | Grade B: absent / ill-defined / softened endpoint |
| Grade 2: 5-10mm translation| |
| Grade 3: >10mm translation| |

DDx: fracture, meniscal tear, collateral ligament tear, quadriceps tendon / patellar ligament tear
Investigations

- XR knee: bony avulsion, joint effusion, lipohaemarthrosis (fat from bone + effusion from ligament)
- MRI knee: gold standard, distinguish partial vs complete tear, assess associated soft tissue injuries (e.g. meniscal tear)

Management
Immediate: RICE
Conservative for inactive patients

- Knee brace (fig.): provide stability, but have no effect of reducing risk of OA
- Physiotherapy: quadriceps strengthening
- Lifestyle modification, e.g. avoid contact sports
- Risk: early OA knee, new cartilage/meniscus injury
  Operative for active patients - Arthroscopic ACL reconstruction (NOT repair)
- Indications
  - Concomitant rupture of collateral ligaments
  - Knee instability
  - ADL & functional demands, e.g. professional sports player (that require pivoting motions)
- Timing: after haemothrosis resolves (risk of arthrofibrosis) and regaining ROM - require PT 'prehab'
- Graft choice:
  - Autograft:
    - Patellar tendon graft (harvest at central 1/3 of patella): early healing (bone-tendon-bone graft), anterior knee pain
    - Hamstring graft (harvest at pes anserinus: gracilis + semitendinosus): high tensile strength if use quadrupled stranded graft, but poor initial healing
    - Quadriceps tendon: avoid injury to infrapatellar branch of saphenous nerve (in patellar tendon graft), highest tensile strength
  - Allograft: risk of infection and immunologic reaction
- Complications: Graft failure, OA knee, arthrofibrosis
- Post-op rehabilitation

[X-ray image of a knee with a red circle highlighting a specific area. The bone structure is visible, showing the femur and tibia, with a joint space in between.]

[An image of a knee brace, made of black fabric and plastic supports, is shown. It covers the knee and part of the upper and lower leg, with adjustable straps and hinges.]

[A photograph shows three legs from the mid-thigh to just below the knee. Each leg has a vertical scar on the front of the knee, indicating different types of tendon grafts: Patellar Tendon, Quad Tendon, and Hamstring Tendon. The skin tones vary slightly, and the scars are in slightly different locations.]

257
Posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) tear
Mechanism of injury: less common than ACL tear

- High-energy trauma: direct blow to proximal tibia
- Low-energy trauma: hyperflexion of knee with plantarflexed foot
  Clinical features
- Posterior knee pain + audible "pop" sound
- Knee instability ("give way" sensation) and unable to bear weight
- Special tests: **posterior sag test**, **posterior drawer test**
  Management
- Immediate: RICE
- Mainly **conservative** (knee brace + PT) → surgery if recurrent instability / associated multi-ligament tears

Medial collateral ligament (MCL) tear
MCL is the most commonly injured ligament of the knee.
Mechanism of injury

- Contact: direct blow to _lateral_ aspect of knee → _valgus_ stress
- Non-contact: valgus stress with external rotation (e.g. skiing)
  Clinical features
- Grade I (no loss of MCL integrity): **medial joint line pain**
- Grade II (incomplete tear of MCL): valgus stress test +ve in 30º flexion
- Grade III (complete tear of MCL + capsule injury): valgus stress test +ve in _both_ 30º flexion and full extension
  Investigations
- XR knee: exclude fracture
- MRI: diagnostic + grading of injury
  Management
- Mild (grade I-II): conservative (RICE, analgesics, strengthening exercise, hinged knee brace)
- Severe (grade III): conservative as above, crutches
  - Ligament repair indicated if **distal avulsion** seen on MRI
- Complications: knee instability, **saphenous nerve** injury (MCL)

Meniscal tear
Causes

- Trauma: **twist** their knee while flexed and weight-bearing
- **Degenerative** in older patients
  Classification
- Location: outer 1/3 (vascularised), inner 1/3 (avascularised), middle 1/3 (intermediate)
- Pattern: - **Vertical / Longitudinal (MC)**: associated with ACL tear, progress to bucket-handle tear - Radial: progress to parrot beak tear - Horizontal (parallel to tibial plateau): more common in degenerative, progress to flap tear
  Clinical features
- Intense sudden onset pain
- Delayed swelling (6-12h): lack of vascular supply
- **Locked knee in flexion**: free body from meniscus (most commonly bucket-handle type)
- Special tests: **McMurray test, Apley's grinding test**
  Investigations
- XR knee: rule out fracture
- MRI knee: diagnostic + grading (fig.)

[Image Description: A diagram illustrating different types of meniscus tears. The diagram consists of six images arranged in two rows. The first row shows a longitudinal or vertical tear, a radial tear, and a horizontal tear, each depicted as a crescent-shaped meniscus with a corresponding tear. The second row shows how each type of tear can progress: the longitudinal tear progresses to a bucket handle tear, the radial tear progresses to a parrot beak tear, and the horizontal tear progresses to a flap tear. Each tear is shown in detail within the meniscus.]
