258
Management
Conservative: preferred for <1cm meniscal tear

- RICE
- Analgesics
- Rehabilitation: encourage ROM, muscle strengthening
  Operative: arthroscopic surgery
- Indications: failed conservative treatment, bucket-handle tear, associated ligament injury, locked knee
- Meniscal repair with suture: indicated if outer 1/3 (.'good vascular supply), vertical tear
- Partial meniscectomy: indicated if inner 1/3 (e.g. radial tear, horizontal tear)
- Either one if middle 1/3
  Complications of knee arthroscopy: damage to saphenous nerve and vein, peroneal nerve, popliteal vessels
  Iliotibial band syndrome
  Anatomy of IT band:
- Shared aponeurosis of tensor fasciae latae and gluteus maximus
- Extend from iliac tubercle to anterolateral tubercle of tibia (Gerdy's tubercle)
- IT band syndrome: inflammation → impingement against lateral femoral condyle
  Risk factors:
- Repetitive flexion and extension of knee: e.g. runners, weightlifters, cyclists
- Genu varum
- Hip abductor weakness
  Clinical features:
- Most common cause of lateral knee pain, exacerbated by exercise
- Special tests demonstrate pain over lateral femoral condyle at 30° flexion: Nobles
  test, Renne test
  Investigations: clinical diagnosis, X-ray / MRI to exclude other pathology
  Management:
- Conservative: lifestyle modifications, analgesics, local steroid injections, physiotherapy
- Operative: indicated if failed conservative treatment for 6 months
  - Percutaneous / Open release of iliotibial band

[Illustration of the iliotibial band on the right leg, showing the Tensor fascia lata and the Iliotibial tract.]

7.3 Bone and joint injuries
Patella fracture
Mechanism of injury

- Direct: fall on knee
- Indirect: sudden flexion of knee against contracted quadriceps
  Clinical features
- Inability to extend knee (unable to straight leg raise)
- Immediate swelling + pain
- Visible and palpable patellar defect
  DDx: other fractures (e.g. tibial plateau, distal femur), cruciate / collateral
  ligament injury, quadriceps tendon rupture
  X-ray features (AP, lateral, skyline view - may not be possible due to pain
  inhibiting knee flexion to 30°)
- Fracture type: transverse, polar, comminuted
- Alignment: displaced, undisplaced
- Not to be confused with bipartite patella (congenital condition in 2-
  3% of population)
  Management
- Non-displaced: straight leg immobilisation by hinged knee brace to
  allow early weight bearing in extension, quadriceps strengthening
- Significantly displaced / Disrupted extensor mechanism: ORIF with tension band wiring (fig.) - convert tensile
  force of extensor mechanism into compression force to assist fracture healing
- Comminuted: partial/total patellectomy
  Complication: loss of ROM, patellofemoral joint OA

[An X-ray image of a fractured patella with an arrow pointing to the fracture site.]

[Two X-ray images showing the patella repaired with tension band wiring technique. These images are oriented in the anteroposterior and lateral views.]

259
Patella dislocation
Mechanism of injury

- Sudden contraction of quadriceps when knee is stretched in valgus and external rotation

Clinical features

- Patella apprehension test (upon passive **lateral** translation)
  Risk factors for patellar dislocation (lateral)
- Young obese female
- High riding patella (patella alta)
- Wide Q angle, genu valgus
- Shallow patellofemoral groove
- Weak quadriceps
- Connective tissue disease
  X-ray features (AP, lateral, skyline view)
- **Lateral** displacement of patella^ (pulled towards lateral side as knee is slight valgus)
  Management
- Non-operative (MC): knee immobilisation, progressive weight bearing & quadriceps strengthening

[Radiograph of a knee joint, viewed from the side. A red arrow points towards the patella.]

Tibial plateau fracture
Mechanism of injury

- **High-energy trauma** (e.g. fall from height, RTA) → impaction of femoral condyle
- Usually varus-deforming force → **lateral** tibial plateau more commonly fractured
  Clinical features
- Sudden onset knee pain and unable to bear weight
- Significant swelling: lipohaemarthrosis
- Associated injuries: **popliteal artery** (Cx: compartment syndrome), **common peroneal nerve**
  Investigation: X-ray knee (AP, lateral) + CT
- Schatzker classification
  Management
- Uncomplicated lateral #: **hinged knee brace** x 8-12 weeks, physiotherapy, analgesics
- Complicated / Medial #: **ORIF** + post-op hinged knee brace x 8-12 weeks
- Open #: external fixation → delayed definitive surgery

[Radiograph of a knee, showing a tibial plateau fracture. The image is in black and white, showing the bones and soft tissue of the knee.]

Tibial shaft fracture
Clinical features

- Severe pain and unable to bear weight
- High risk of **open fracture**: lack of significant soft tissue protection (esp. anteromedial side)
- High risk of **compartment syndrome**: 6 Ps, pain exacerbated by passive dorsiflexion of great toe
  Investigation:
- X-ray tibia and fibula (AP, lateral)
- CT scan: indicated if suspected intraarticular extension, spiral fracture (rule out fracture of **posterior malleolus**)
  Acute management
- RICE, analgesics, **reduction + above knee backslab** (anatomical reduction not necessary)
- Monitor for compartment syndrome
  Subsequent management: usually surgical
- Uncomplicated fractures: closed reduction + **intramedullary nail** for early weightbearing
- Proximal / Distal fractures with possible intra-articular extension: **ORIF**
- Open fracture: external fixation before definitive surgery
  Complications: **compartment syndrome, limb ischaemia**, malunion/non-union

  7.4 OA knee
  See [Systemic diseases] for pathology and aetiology

- Pathology: genu varum in normal individuals → **medial** compartment most commonly affected
  Risk factors:
- Genetics
- Constitutional factors: increasing age, **female, obesity**, low bone density
- Local factors: **previous trauma**, occupation, muscle weakness

Clinical features

- **Knee pain:** worse on going downstairs (patella-femoral joint
  involvement)
- Stiffness, locking of joints, instability
- **Reduced ROM with crepitations** - Flexion deformity: extension lag (correctable on
  passive) VS fixed flexion contracture
  Radiological features
- 3 compartments: medial, lateral, patello-femoral
- Views: - **Weightbearing AP:** medial vs lateral compartment - Lateral: anteromedial vs posteromedial (e.g. posterior
  osteophytes) - **Skyline:** patello-femoral joint space - Valgus stress / Varus stress: assess medial / lateral joint space - **Standing scanogram** of bilateral LL: alignment - Tibiofemoral angle (TFA): valgus vs varus - Mechanical axis of LL: pass through medial or lateral side - +/- Schuss view (30° flexion): more sensitive for early OA
- 4 features of OA

Kellgren-Lawrence (KL) classification for OA knee
| Grade | Description |
| ----------- | ----------- |
| Grade 0 | No joint space narrowing (JSN) |
| Grade 1 | Possible osteophytes, doubtful JSN |
| Grade 2 | Definite osteophytes |
| Grade 3 | Definite JSN |
| Grade 4 | Bone-on-bone deformity |

[Image: A line drawing of a right leg from the hip to the foot, showing the bones and some major landmarks. A vertical line runs from the ASIS (anterior superior iliac spine) down the leg. There is an arrow pointing at the location where the tibiofemoral angle is measured, and labels for the "Midpoint of Patella" and "Midpoint Between Two Malleoli". A second image is an X-ray showing a knee joint with severe bone-on-bone arthritis. The joint space is severely narrowed, and there are bony spurs and irregularities visible.]

Management of OA knee:

- Conservative:
  - Lifestyle modifications: weight loss, regular exercise (e.g. bicycle), smoking cessation
  - Adequate pain control: **NSAIDs** have proven benefit
  - Physiotherapy: quadriceps muscle strengthening to slow disease progression and improve biomechanics
  - P&O to relieve medial compartment pressure (controversial): valgus unloading brace, lateral in-sole
- Surgical options - **Total knee replacement (TKR)** - Preferred in: posteromedial OA, lateral OA, PFJ OA, significant
  fixed flexion contracture (≥ 10°), arc of motion ≤110° - **Unicompartmental knee arthroplasty (UKA):** e.g. Oxford implant - High tibial osteotomy: if young (M < 70, F <60)

[Image: A table listing the Oxford partial knee replacement selection criteria, numbered 1 through 5. 1. Medial bone-on-bone, 2. Functionally intact ACL, 3. Functionally intact MCL, 4. Full thickness lateral cartilage, 5. Acceptable patellofemoral joint.]

8 Foot and ankle

8.1 Anatomy
Bones

- Hindfoot: talus, calcaneus
- Midfoot: navicular (insertion of TP), cuboid, cuneiforms
- Forefoot: metatarsals (5th MT = insertion of peroneus brevis), phalanges

[An illustration shows the bones of the ankle and foot. Different bones are colored differently and labelled. The bones are tibia, fibula, talus, calcaneus, navicular, cuboid, and cuneiforms.]

Leg muscles

| Muscles                                                                                              | Main action                                       | Nerve                |
| :--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | :------------------------------------------------ | :------------------- |
| Anterior TA: insert into medial cuneiform and 1st MT EDL, EHL                                        | Inversion & dorsiflexion Extension & dorsiflexion | Deep peroneal        |
| Lateral Peroneal longus: insert into medial cuneiform and 1st MT Peroneal brevis: insert into 5th MT | Eversion of foot                                  | Superficial peroneal |
| Posterior superficial Gastrocnemius Soleus Plantaris                                                 | Plantarflexion of foot                            | Tibial               |
| Posterior deep Popliteus TP: insert at navicular tuberosity and medial cuneiform FDL, FHL            | Pop: unlock knee TP: inversion FDL, FHL: flexion  | Tibial               |

Joints:

- Ankle joint: Talus articulating with mortise (medial malleolus + tibial plafond + lateral malleolus)
- Inversion and eversion mainly occur at:
  - Talocalcaneonavicular joint
  - Subtalar (talocalcaneal) joint
- Ankle ligaments
  - Lateral collateral ligaments: anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL), PTFL, calcaneofibular ligament (CFL)
  - Medial collateral ligament (deltoid): very strong
  - Syndesmosis: anterior inferior tibiofibular ligament (AITFL), PITFL, interosseous membrane
- Sinus tarsi: between talus and calcaneus on lateral side
- Gait cycle:
  - Swing phase
  - Stance phase: Heel strike, foot flat, heel off, toe off
- Physical examination of the ankle
  - Palpate ankle joint line: medial to TA tendon (Dorsiflex to palpate ant. talus, plantarflex to palpate post. talus)
  - Instability: drawer test, talar tilt test
  - Palpate ankle ligaments
  - Palpate Achilles tendon: musculotendinous junction, midshaft, insertion, retrocalcaneal bursa (ant. to tendon)

[An illustration of Talocalcaneonavicular Joint and lower leg structure.
The Talocalcaneonavicular Joint is labeled with Talus, Subtalar joint (posterior talocalcaneum joint), Sustentaculum tali, Navicular, Spring ligament, Calcaneus.
The lower leg structure labeled with Fibula, Tibia, Medial malleolus, Deltoid ligament, Subtalar joint.
The other view of the lower leg structure labeled with Fibula, Tibia, Posterior and anterior inferior tibiofibular ligaments, Anterior talofibular ligament, Calcaneofibular ligament, Subtalar joint.]

Forefoot: hallux valgus, bunion, lesser toes
Midfoot: foot arch
Hindfoot:
valgus (+pes planus) → **tip-toe test**
varus (+pes cavus) → **Coleman block test**
Ankle DF/PF: +/- **Silverskiold test** - Neutralise subtalar joint - Ankle DF ROM at knee flexion > extension (+ve = Gastrocnemius contracture)

261

8.2 F&A deformities
Hallux valgus

- Definition: deformity at 1st MTPJ with medial deviation of 1st metatarsal + lateral deviation of hallux (+/- rotation of hallux) with associated joint subluxation
- Pathophysiology: intrinsic instability of 1st metatarsal → extrinsic tendons become the deforming force once escaped the intrinsic anatomical control → metatarsal head drift medially → reactive exostosis (bunion)

[Image Description:
Two diagrams side by side illustrating the progression of Hallux Valgus. The first diagram on the left shows a foot with normal alignment, labeled with "Medial" and "Lateral" sides. Key anatomical points are marked: EHB at the top, AbH on the medial side, and FHBM and FHBL towards the bottom. An arrow points from left to right towards the second diagram, which depicts a foot with Hallux Valgus. This foot exhibits a visible deviation of the big toe towards the other toes. It also has similar anatomical points labeled as in the first diagram: EHB, AbH, AdH, FHBM and FHBL.]

- Risk factors
  - Female
  - Family history
  - Connective tissue disorders, hypermobility syndrome
  - Anatomical variants: flatfeet, long 1st metatarsal bone
- Clinical features: pain over
  - Bunion (MC)
  - 1st MTPJ (arthritic)
  - Bunionette (5th MTPJ)
  - 2nd & 3rd MTPJ (transfer metatarsalgia)
  - Plantar callosities with without pain
- Physical examination in both non-weightbearing and weightbearing positions
  - Skin over medial prominence: any inflammation / breakdown
  - Range of movement: dorsal & plantar both 5mm, no transverse movement
  - EHL contracture
- Plain AP weight-bearing XR
  [Image Description:
  A black and white medical illustration of a foot skeleton, with lines and labels indicating the angles measured in Hallux Valgus. The angle between the 1st metatarsal and the proximal phalanx is labeled "Hallux Valgus (<15°) Angle". Another angle between the 1st and 2nd metatarsal is labeled "1-2 Intermetatarsal (<9°) Angle".] - Hallux valgus angle (<15°): the angle between the line projected from 1st MT and 1st proximal phalanx on axial view of foot - Mild (15-20°), moderate (21-39°), severe (>40°) - Intermetatarsal angle (<9°): the angle between the 1st and 2nd MT shaft on axial view of foot - OA 1st MTPJ
- Management
  - Conservative:
    - Footwear: side & deep toe boxes (fig.), orthosis for flatfoot
    - Physiotherapy: intrinsic muscle strengthening
  - Surgery: only EBM recommendation
    - Arthritic joint:
      - Arthrodesis (e.g. Lapidus procedure - 1st TMT joint)
      - Keller's procedure (excision arthroplasty + hemiphalangectomy)
    - Non-arthritis joint:
      - Osteotomy (1st MT realignment) e.g. Chevron for mild, Scarf for moderate/severe
      - Soft tissue rebalancing (e.g. McBride)
      - Bunionectomy (e.g. Keller)
- Complications of hallux valgus:
  - Avascular necrosis
  - Non-union
  - Displacement
  - Reduced ROM

[Image Description:
A color photograph showing a pair of feet, each wearing a black brace designed to correct hallux valgus (bunions). The braces are positioned on the medial side of the feet, near the big toes, and appear to provide support and alignment.]

262

263

Pes planus (flat foot)
Definition: collapse of medial longitudinal arch
Aetiology

- Tibialis posterior tendon dysfunction (MC): degenerative, inflammatory, traumatic
- Bone: tarsal coalition
- Ligament: generalised ligament laxity
- Nerve: neuroarthropathy (Charcot's joint)
- Joint: arthritis
  Clinical features
- Associated with hindfoot valgus and forefoot hallux valgus
- Tip-toe test: rigid (bone deformities, e.g. tarsal coalition) if medial arch still not formed & hindfoot valgus still present
  - Windlass mechanism: accentuation of medial arch when MTPJ is hyperextended during tiptoe
- Jack's test: passive dorsiflexion of great toe (to tighten plantar fascia)
- Complications: tenosynovitis of calcaneonavicular ligament (cross PTT) → permanent elongation → rupture → arthritis
  Investigations: XR foot & ankle for **Meary's angle** (talo-1st metatarsal angle) > 4°
  [Image Description: An X-ray image of a foot, illustrating the measurement of Meary's angle. The X-ray highlights the bones of the foot with the Talus and 1st metatarsal bones clearly labeled. Blue and orange lines are superimposed on the X-ray, demonstrating how the angle is measured between these two bones to assess foot alignment.]

Management

- Identify and treat/ refer early
- **Insole**: medial heel wedge

Pes cavus (high-arched foot)
Definition: high arch of foot that does not flatten with weightbearing
Aetiology

- Neuromuscular disease, e.g. muscular dystrophy, CMT disease (weakening of tibialis anterior & peroneus brevis)
- Malunion of calcaneal/ talar fractures
- Residual clubfoot
  Clinical features
- Callosities under metatarsal heads
- Coleman block test (fig.): stand on a 1' wood block under lateral foot (try to offload the 1st MT of the tripod)
  - Corrected: pes cavus is driven by forefoot deformity
  - Uncorrected: both forefoot and hindfoot deformities
    Management
- Conservative: extra-depth shoes, PT
- Surgery: plantar fascia release

Club foot
Congenital fixed deformity (CAVE)

- Cavus
- Adduction of forefoot
- Varus
- Equinus (plantarflexed)
  Management
- Conservative: Ponsenti method (manipulation + casting)
- Operative (if refractory): surgical release
  Ruptured tibialis posterior:
- Flexible hindfoot valgus
- Pes planus
- Cannot stand on heels
- Weakened inversion
- Normal / weakened plantarflexion: partially compensated by Achilles tendon

  8.3 F&A trauma
  Ankle sprain & instability
  Definitions

- Sprain: any painful twisting of a joint causing **ligamentous injury**
- Strain: physical effect of tensile stress involving tearing of some fibres of ligament
- Rupture: complete tear of ligament
  Classification
- **High ankle sprains:** injuries to the syndesmosis
- **Low ankle sprains:** injuries to ATFL, CFL (PTFL very strong → fracture instead of rupture)
  ΜΟΙ
- Inversion injury: forced inversion of plantarflexion of foot
- Eversion injury: forced eversion of foot → Pott's fracture (deltoid ligament very strong)
  Clinical features
- Tenderness, swelling & pain distal to lateral malleolus over affected ligaments
- Difficulty walking & bruising
- Medial ankle joint pain: **osteochondral lesion** (interruption of normal lining of joint surface in which both
  cartilage and the directly underlying bone are affected; most commonly at medial talar dome)
- Signs: **anterior drawer test, talar tilt test**
  Investigations
- XR indicated if meet **Ottawa Ankle rules**:
  Any pain in malleolar region + any one of:
  1. Bone tenderness at distal 6cm of posterior edge of **tibia** / tip of **medial malleolus**
  2. Bone tenderness at distal 6cm of posterior edge of **fibula** / tip of **lateral malleolus**
  3. Inability to bear weight **immediately** + in A&E for **4 steps**
  - View: **AP, lateral, mortise view** (20°
    oblique to allow uniform joint space)
    Management
- Conservative:
  - Ankle sprain: RICE, then early mobilisation
  - Ankle instability: PT for peroneal muscles
    strengthening, braces to prevent recurrent
    sprains
- Surgery for ankle instability
  - Indications: pain & instability despite
    conservative management
  - **Arthroscopic debridement** of impinging
    lesions
  - Reconstruction of lateral ligaments
    (Brostrom-Gould procedure)

[X-ray images of an ankle joint in AP and Mortise views. The AP view shows the ankle from the front, and the Mortise view shows the ankle at a 20-degree oblique angle to allow uniform joint space. Anatomical structures such as the fibula, tibia, talus, and medial malleolus are visible. Red dotted lines indicate areas of concern]

Differential diagnosis of ankle sprain

- Ankle fracture
- Contusion of extensor digitorum brevis: tearing of muscle causes formation of haematoma, with swelling
  anteromedial to lateral malleolus

264

Ankle fracture
Definition: fracture of any malleolus (lateral, medial, posterior [posterior aspect of distal tibia]) **with or without disruption to the syndesmosis**
Pott's fracture: bimalleolar/trimalleolar fracture due to forced eversion of foot
Classification

- By injury pattern: isolated lateral malleolus, isolated medial malleolus, bimalleolar (medial + lateral), trimalleolar (medial + lateral + posterior)
- By level: **Weber classification** for lateral malleolus fracture (higher level = higher chance of ankle instability with syndesmosis diasthesis) - Type A: below syndesmosis - Type B: at level of syndesmosis - Type C: above syndesmosis
  Differential diagnosis: tibial pilon fracture (fracture of tibial plafond)
  Investigations
- Ankle series: **AP, lateral, mortise view** - ankle in full dorsiflexion (or else talus appear to move posteriorly) - Check joint space for uniformity. Ensure no **talar shift**.
  Management
- Non-operative:
  - Indications: non-displaced fracture, Weber A fracture, Weber B fracture without talar shift
  - **Closed reduction, below-knee back slab**, repeat neurovascular exam + XR
- Operative:
  - Indications: bimalleolar/trimalleolar fracture, Weber B fracture with talar shift, Weber C fracture, open #
  - **ORIF** +/- **syndesmotic screw** / **tightrope fixation**

[Illustration depicting ankle fractures labeled A, B, and C. Fracture A shows a fracture below the syndesmosis, labeled as "Type A: below syndesmosis". Fracture B shows a fracture at the level of the syndesmosis, labeled as "Type B: at level of syndesmosis". Fracture C shows a fracture above the syndesmosis, labeled as "Type C: above syndesmosis".]

Tibial pilon fracture (plafond fracture)
Mechanism of injury: high energy axial load (e.g. RTA, fall from height) → **talus punch up** onto tibial plafond
Clinical features:

- Severe ankle pain, inability to bear weight, obvious ankle deformity with significant swelling
- Assess peripheral pulses, nerves (e.g. superficial peroneal, deep peroneal, tibial) and compartment syndrome
  Classification: _Ruedi-Allgower classification_
  Investigations: Ankle series (**AP, lateral, mortise view**) +/- CT scan
  Management
- Non-operative:
  - **Closed reduction + below-knee back slab**, repeat neurovascular exam + XR
- Operative: mainstay - to reconstruct articular surface and restore alignment of ankle mortise
  - Staged approach: temporary external fixator → ORIF after 7-14 days +/- ankle fixation by hindfoot nail

[X-ray images showing severe comminuted fractures of the distal tibia and fibula, representing a tibial pilon fracture (plafond fracture).]

Calcaneal fracture
Most commonly fractured tarsal bone, usually due to **fall from height** (axial loading onto calcaneus)
Classification

- Intra-articular (75%): involve subtalar joint, further classified by Sanders classification
- Extra-articular (25%): usually avulsion fractures e.g. avulsion of calcaneal tuberosity by Achilles tendon
  Clinical features: similar to ankle fracture
- Shortened and widened heel with **varus** deformity
- Assess posterior heel skin integrity – may require emergency surgery
  Investigations: AP, lateral, oblique X-ray foot +/- CT
- **Calcaneal shortening** with **varus** deformity
- Decreased **Bohler's angle** (fig.)
  Management: usually operative (e.g. closed reduction with percutaneous pinning, **ORIF**)
  Complication: subtalar joint OA (if severe may require arthrodesis)

[X-ray image of the foot showing a calcaneal fracture. The Bohler's angle, is measured between two lines drawn on the lateral X-ray view. Line 1 extending from the superior aspect of the posterior calcaneal tuberosity to the superior aspect of the posterior articular facet and Line 2 extending from the superior aspect of the anterior process to the superior aspect of the posterior articular facet. The normal Bohler's angle is between 25 and 40 degrees. The Bohler's angle is labeled on the image.]

Talar fracture
2nd most commonly fractured tarsal bone (after calcaneus)
Pathophysiology:

- Mechanism of injury: ankle forced into **dorsiflexion** → talus press against tibial plafond
- Usually occur at talar neck (~50%)
- Talus is heavily relied on extraosseous arterial supply → High risk of AVN after fracture
  Investigation:
- Ankle series (AP + lateral + mortise) in both **dorsiflexion AND plantarflexion** to differentiate which type
  Classification of talar neck fractures: **Hawkins classification** (predict risk of AVN)
  | Type I | Undisplaced | 0-15% risk |
  | :------- | :------------------------------------------ | :------------- |
  | Type II | Subtalar dislocation | 20-50% risk |
  | Type III | Subtalar + tibiotalar dislocation | 90-100% risk |
  | Type IV | Subtalar + tibiotalar + talonavicular dislocation | 100% risk |

Management:

- Undisplaced (Type I): conservative
- Displaced (Type II-IV): closed reduction + cast in A&E → urgent ORIF

Lisfranc injury
Anatomy of “Lisfranc joint” (tarso-metatarsal joint)

- Base of 2nd MT fit into mortise created by medial and middle cuneiforms
- Supported by interosseous ligaments: e.g. **Lisfranc ligament** (from 2nd MT to medial cuneiform)
  Mechanism of injury:
- Severe torsional force onto **plantarflexed** foot (e.g. RTA, athletic injuries)
  Clinical features
- Swelling and tenderness over midfoot
- **Plantar bruising**
- Piano-key sign: pain on passive dorsiflexion and plantarflexion of toes

Radiological features: order **AP + lateral + oblique X-ray foot**

- Widened interval between base of 1st and 2nd MT
- Fleck sign: bony fragment between 1st and 2nd MT, indicating avulsion of Lisfranc ligament from 2nd MT base
- Dorsal displacement of proximal base of 1st and 2nd MT (on lateral view)
- Look for associated distal MT fractures (fig.)

Hardcastle and Myerson classification (fig.)

Management:

- Immediate: closed reduction (gentle traction to midfoot) + backslab in A&E
- Non-operative if not significantly displaced
  - Cast immobilization / air-cast boot + non-weight-bearing mobilization x 6-12 weeks
- Operative
  - Screw fixation: N-shaped (medial cuneiform to 2nd MT, medial cuneiform to 1st MT, middle cuneiform to 2nd NT) +/- small plates
  - Primary arthrodesis if severely comminuted or displaced

Complication: post-traumatic arthritis, midfoot compartment syndrome

[Illustration showing mechanism of Lisfranc injury. Medial view of the foot. On the left side is a red arrow pointing downwards to the foot representing normal position of the second metatarsal. On the right side, the arrow is curved towards the front of the foot, representing dislocation of the second metatarsal. ]

[Illustration comparing a healthy foot and a foot with Lisfranc injury. Top view with weight bearing. In the healthy foot, the Lisfranc ligament is intact and the space between the metatarsal bones is normal. In the foot with Lisfranc injury, the Lisfranc ligament is torn and the space between the metatarsal bones is widened.]

[X-ray image of foot with lisfranc injury. In the middle of the foot between the first and second metatarsal, there is a small bony fragment indicating Lisfranc injury.]

[X-ray image of foot showing fixation screws. The screws are inserted in the middle of the foot from the medial cuneiform to the second metatarsal.]

8.4 Soft tissue injury
Achilles tendinopathy & rupture
Pathophysiology

- Achilles tendon unites gastrocnemius, soleus & plantaris insert into calcaneus
- Repetitive action of tendon causes microtears, inflammation, fibrosis & potential rupture
  Risk factors
- Stop-and-go sports, e.g. basketball
- Poor footwear choice
- Obese male
- Recent fluoroquinolone use
  Clinical features
- Gradual onset of pain at posterior ankle, worse with movement
- Tenderness over tendon (worse 2-6cm above insertion site)
- Inability to stand / heel raise on single leg
- Tendon rupture: audible popping sound, sudden onset severe pain, Thompson test + (fig.)
- Active ankle plantarflexion still possible: e.g. tibialis posterior, peroneus longus & brevis
  Differential diagnosis: ankle fracture, ankle sprain
  Management
- Tendinopathy: avoid precipitating exercise, NSAID, physiotherapy
- Rupture:
  - Early presentation (< 2 weeks): plaster immobilisation in full equinus (foot plantarflexion + toe extension) x 2 weeks → semi-equinus x 4 weeks → neutral position x 4 weeks
  - Late presentation (> 2 weeks) / Relatively active patient:
    - End-to-end tendon repair +/- FHL graft (if no pre-existing tendinopathy)
    - Achilles tendon reconstruction (if tendinopathy)

Plantar fasciitis
Definition: inflammation of plantar fascia (thick fibrous band of connective tissue, origin at calcaneal tuberosity)

- MC cause of infracalcaneal pain (80%)
  Mechanism
- Repetitive strain injury causing microtears
  Risk factors:
- Anatomical factors: excessive pronation, pes cavus, leg length discrepancy
- Prolonged standing / Excessive running
- Unsupportive footwear
- DM, obesity
  Clinical features
- Dorsiflex great toe → Palpate for tenderness over plantar fascia up to calcaneal tuberosity
- Plantar heel pain with weightbearing, radiate down the arch
- Pain worsens with first few steps in morning (after inactivity) & toe dorsiflexion
  Differential diagnoses: achilles tendonitis, Morton's neuroma, calcaneal fracture
  Investigations: clinical diagnosis, XR to r/o fracture + plantar heel spur (fig.)
  Management:
- Non-operative: pain control, footwear adjustment, PT, shockwave, steroid injection
- Operative: surgical release (plantar fasciotomy)

[Image of Fig. 1.A. Squeezing calf produces plantar flexion of foot when heel cord is intact. and Fig. 1.B. Squeezing calf produces no motion of foot in injured leg. The image shows two simple line drawings depicting the thompson test. In both drawings, the lower leg and foot are visible in profile. In the first drawing, the calf is squeezed, and the foot plantarflexes, indicating a normal test. In the second drawing, the calf is squeezed, but the foot does not move, indicating a positive test for Achilles tendon rupture.]

[Image of an X-ray showing a right foot in profile. The bone spur on the calcaneus is easily identified. The cuneiform, talus, navicular, and calcaneus bones are labeled with arrows. The bone spur is located on the plantar aspect of the calcaneus. Bone spur and calcaneus are clearly visible. Additional parts of the foot visible in the xray include the talus, navicular and cuneiform.]

DDx of heel pain:

- Plantar fasciitis (MC)
- Achilles tendinopathy / rupture
- Retrocalcaneal bursitis
- Posterior ankle impingements (especially FHL)
- Arthritis of ankle joint / subtalar joint

# 8.5 Diabetic foot

## Diabetic foot ulcers

Pathophysiology: neuropathic + ischaemic (less important)
Brodsky classification: depth + degree of ischaemia

[Diagram of the foot showing classification by depth and ischemia. The depth classification starts at the top with a foot labeled 'Grade 0' with 'No break in skin'. The next foot is 'Grade 1' with 'Superficial ulcer'. The next is labeled 'Grade 2' with 'Exposed tendons, joints'. The final foot is 'Grade 3' with 'Exposed bone and/or abscess/osteomyelitis'. The Ischaemia classification begins below. First foot is 'Grade A' with 'No ischaemia'. The next foot is 'Grade B' with 'Ischaemia not gangrenous'. The next foot is 'Grade C' with 'Partial foot gangrene'. The last foot is 'Grade D' with 'Complete gangrene'.]

Investigations

- Transcutaneous O2 pressure (TcPO2): assess wound-healing potential (good if >30mmHg)
  - ABPI not useful in DM due to calcification of vessels
- XR foot & ankle

Management

- Neuropathic component: customised insole
- Vascular component: angioplasty
- Surgical: debridement, below knee amputation

**Charcot arthropathy (neuropathic arthropathy)**
Chronic progressive destructive arthropathy due to loss of pain or proprioception
Causes: classically DM & syphilis

- Peripheral: DM neuropathy, peripheral nerve injury, leprosy
- Central: cauda equina syndrome, syringomyelia, tabes dorsalis
  Clinical features: painless foot & ankle deformities with warmth, redness and oedema
  Investigations:
- Imaging: XR (degenerative changes, subluxation); MRI or bone scan if XR inconclusive
- Joint aspiration to rule out DDx
- Refer occu for proprioception testing
  Management:
- Walking aid to offload foot
- Surgical correction best avoided: high failure rate

# 9 Systemic diseases

## 9.1 Osteoarthritis

Definition

- Chronic wear & tear process involving a joint
- Degeneration only as one of the causes

Aetiology

- Primary (degenerative): more common in elderly > 70y as OA knee
- Secondary: may be seen in young < 50y - must ask about **previous trauma & chronic joint instability**
  - Defective load:
    - Force: obesity, occupational overuse
    - Area: joint dysplasia (e.g. DDH)
  - Defective cartilage:
    - Damage: trauma, haemophilia
    - Diseases: inflammatory (e.g. RA), metabolic (e.g. gout), infection
    - Unsupported: AVN

Clinical features

- Joints affected:
  - **Weight-bearing joints**, e.g. hip, knee, spine
  - UL joints spared, except **1st CMC joint** and IPJ
- Symptoms:
  - **Pain**: aggravated by exertion, relieved by rest - more in **knee**
  - **Morning stiffness**: < 30min after immobility - more in **hip**
  - Swelling: intermittent (effusion) or continuous (capsule thickening)
  - Deformity
  - Loss of function
- Signs:
  - Bony enlargement at affected joints, e.g. Heberden's node (DIPJ), Bouchard's node (PIPJ)
  - Limited ROM with crepitus
  - Small joints: grind test + (axial compression)
  - Joint deformities, e.g. genu varum

Radiological features (LOSS)

- **Loss of joint space** (earliest)
- **Osteophytes**
- **Subchondral cysts**
- **Subchondral sclerosis**

Classification of OA progression: WOMAC (Western Ontario and McMaster Universities Arthritis Index)

Degenerative arthritis vs inflammatory arthritis

|                            | Degenerative                                                                             | Inflammatory                    |
| -------------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------- |
| Joint involvement          | Weight-bearing joints: knee, hip, L spine, C spine Small hand joints: 1st CMC joint, IPJ | Any joint                       |
| Bone density               | Preserved                                                                                | Juxta-articular osteopenia (RA) |
| Periarticular bony erosion | No                                                                                       | Yes (RA)                        |
| Reactive bony changes      | Yes                                                                                      | No (RA)                         |

Management
Conservative

- Relief of weight-bearing: weight reduction, walking aids, muscle strengthening
- Pain relief: analgesics, intra-articular steroid
- Intra-articular hyaluronic acid / platelet-rich plasma (?evidence)
  Operative
- Indications:
  - Patient factor: age, functional status
  - Disease factor: severe impairment to ADL, pain despite conservative treatment
- Options:
  - Arthroplasty for big joints (e.g. hip, knee, shoulder, ankle)
  - Arthrodesis for small joints (e.g. MCP)
  - Realignment surgery e.g. osteotomy
  - Arthroscopic debridement e.g. remove osteophytes

|                                                             | Indications                                                                                | C/I                                                                  | Knee                                                                                                                                   | Hip                                                                        |
| ----------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ | -------------------------------------------------------------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| **Osteotomy:** correct deformity and relieve joint pressure | Young (<60y) with preservation of articular cartilage Pre-requisite: single compartment    | **Severe articular damage** Ligament laxity Severe varus deformities | High tibial osteotomy                                                                                                                  | Hip osteotomy                                                              |
| **Arthroplasty (replacement)**                              | Older with progressive joint destruction Old preferred: reduced chance of revision surgery |                                                                      | [X-ray of a knee with metal implants]TKR Unicompartmental knee arthroplasty (for medial compartment OA, higher revision rate c.f. TKR) | THR Hemiarthroplasty (quicker recovery, high risk of sciatic nerve damage) |

- Specific complications of total replacement
  - Immediate: bone fracture, vascular injury (femoral in THR, popliteal in TKR), nerve (sciatic nerve in THR, CPN in TKR)
  - Early: DVT/ PE, infection (difficult to detect and treat)
  - Late: LLD (must counsel patients beforehand), prosthesis infection, patellar instability
- Post-op:
  - Early mobilisation (1 day after operation)
  - Avoid contact sports, extreme ROM of hip (angle of bed < 45°)
  - Survival of replacement (not requiring revision surgery): 15-20 years
- No evidence: arthroscopic debridement, arthroscopic chondroplasty (drill holes)

# 10 Malignancy

## 10.1 Overview

Overview of bone tumours

| Histology              | Benign                                               | Malignant                   |
| ---------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------- | --------------------------- |
| Osteogenic             | Osteoid osteoma Osteoblastoma                        | Osteosarcoma                |
| Chondrogenic           | Osteochondroma (exostosis) Chondroma Chondroblastoma | Chondrosarcoma              |
| Primitive neural cells |                                                      | Ewing's sarcoma             |
| Unknown                | Giant cell tumour                                    | Malignant giant cell tumour |
| Clinical features      |                                                      |                             |

|                            | Non-aggressive                                   | Aggressive                                                           |
| -------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------ | -------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Age                        | 10-30                                            | Primary: 10-30 Secondary: > 60                                       |
| Onset                      | Slow                                             | Rapid                                                                |
| Symptoms                   | Painless mass                                    | Painful mass, night pain                                             |
| Physical findings          | Well defined, smooth Non-infiltrative Homogenous | Ill-defined Infiltrative (can be fungating) Heterogenous consistency |
| XR findings                | See below                                        | See below                                                            |
| Consistency                | Homogenous                                       | Heterogenous                                                         |
| Margin/ zone of transition | Better defined, narrow                           | More ill-defined, wide                                               |
| Periosteal reaction        | Solid                                            | Onion skin, sunburst or Codman's triangle                            |
| Cortical destruction       | No                                               | Yes                                                                  |
| Soft tissue extension      | Absent                                           | Present                                                              |

Other investigations

- Bloods: LFT (ALP)
- Bone biopsy (CT-guided)
- MRI: soft tissue involvement, neurovascular involvement
- CT thorax: lung metastasis
- Bone scan: skeletal metastasis

Biopsy: principles

- Provide representative sample
- No contamination
- Not compromise definitive Tx
- Excision of biopsy tract in definite Tx

Limb salvage surgery: prerequisites

- Oncological outcome equivalent to amputation
- Reconstructed limb is useful
- Morbidity is acceptable
- Reconstructed limb is durable

Chondrosarcoma

- 40-75 yo
- ChemoRT resistant
- Tx: surgery

Multiple myeloma

- XR: multiple punched-out lesions
- Histology: "clockface" round cells

Bone metastasis

- Most common form of bone malignancy
- Primary site:
  - Adult (paired organ): thyroid, breast, lung, kidney, prostate, MM
    - Osteosclerotic (prostate, SCLC), osteolytic (MM, thyroid, breast, RCC) or mixed
  - Children: neuroblastoma, Wilm's tumour, etc
- Management
  - Pain control
  - Bisphosphonates
  - Stabilisation of impending fracture if high risk (e.g. increasing size, osteolytic)

# 11 Paediatric orthopaedics

## 11.1 Developmental dysplasia of hip

Definition
Abnormal development of hip resulting in a spectrum of disease:

- Dysplasia (shallow acetabulum)
- Subluxation (joint displacement with some contact remaining between articular surfaces)
- Dislocation

Risk factors

- Genetic factors: FHx, female (increased ligament laxity)
- Perinatal factors: firstborn, breech, oligohydramnios

Clinical features

- Neonatal screening: before soft tissue contracture forms
  - Barlow (dislocatable)
  - Ortolani (reducible)

[Image Description: This is a cartoon illustration depicting the Barlow and Ortolani maneuvers used for developmental dysplasia of the hip. The left side shows a doctor examining an infant with the Barlow maneuver, where the hip is being adducted. A small mouse character is explaining, "Examiner adducts the hip while injecting a posterior force on the knee to promote dislocation." Above the doctor and infant, another mouse is saying, "He did it now call Dr. O." The right side shows a different doctor examining another infant with the Ortolani maneuver, where the hip is being abducted. A bunny character is saying, "It's-a back in! Bravo!" Below the doctor and infant, another mouse is explaining, "Examiner abducts the hip while applying an anterior force on the femur to reduce the hip joint."]

- Age 3mo - 1yr: after soft tissue contracture forms
  - Limited hip abduction
  - LLD

- Age 1yr or beyond: after child starts walking
  - Trendelenburg's gait
  - Toe-walking (to compensate LLD)

Investigations

- USG hip: birth to 4 mo
  - Static or dynamic (USG-guided Barlow & Ortolani test)
- XR hip: at 4-6 mo (after femoral head begins to ossify) (fig.)

[Image Description: The image shows two X-ray diagrams side-by-side, illustrating the difference between a "Normal hip" and a "Dysplastic hip". The "Normal hip" diagram shows Perkin's line, Hilgenreiner's line, and Shenton's line which is normal. The Accetabular roof angle is shown to be normal, less than 30 degrees. The "Dysplastic hip" diagram shows Perkin's line, Hilgenreiner's line, and Shenton's line which is abnormal(broken). The Accetabular roof angle is shown to be abnormal, greater than 30 degrees. There are labels pointing to "Normal femoral head located medial to Perkin's line and inferior to Hilgenreiner's line" on the left and "Abnormal femoral head located lateral to Perkin's line and superior to Hilgenreiner's line" on the right.]

- Hip dysplasia: acetabular roof angle
- Hip dislocation:
  - Shenton's line
  - Hilgenreiner's line: horizontal line through triradiate cartilages
  - Perkin's line: vertical line through lateral margin of acetabulum

Management

- Pavlik harness
  [Illustration of a baby wearing a Pavlik harness. The harness consists of several straps: shoulder straps going over the baby's shoulders, a chest strap across the baby's chest, leg straps around the baby's legs, and abduction and flexion straps connecting the chest and leg straps. All these straps combined keeps the baby's legs in a frog like position. The baby is light skinned, bald, and lying on their back, viewed from above. The straps are white with red fasteners. ]
- Indications: < 6 mo
- Mechanism: maintain hip in abduction & flexion to provide early concentric reduction
- Administration: 3 months until stable clinically & in USG
- Complications:
  - AVN: impingement of MCFA; avoid extreme abduction (>60°)
  - Pavlik disease: erosion of pelvis superior to acetabulum due to prolonged positioning
  - Transient femoral nerve palsy
- Closed reduction with hip spica cast
  - Indications: 6-18 mo
  - Avoid extreme abduction (>60°): risk of AVN
- Operative:
  - Indications: >18mo
  - Methods:
    - Open reduction with spica cast
    - Open reduction with femoral osteotomy/ pelvic osteotomy

# 11.2 Scoliosis

Definitions

- 3D torsional deformities of spine affecting all 3 planes with intervertebral changes, defined as Cobb angle > 10°
  Classification
- Structural scoliosis: congenital (failure of vertebrae to form/ segment), **idiopathic**, neuromuscular, syndromic (e.g. NF)
- Non-structural scoliosis: postural scoliosis, LLD, etc
  **Adolescent idiopathic scoliosis**
  Clinical features
- Primary curve: most commonly right thoracic - shoulder tilt, pelvic tilt, trunk shift, prominent scapula
- Secondary curve (compensatory): kyphosis, lordosis
- Adam's forward bending test (FBT): rib hump, asymmetric shoulder height
- Forward bending sitting test: to eliminate LLD as the cause of scoliosis
- Disease course: - 90% do not progress (RF: low BMD - vit D intake) - 10% require treatment - 1% require surgical treatment
  Investigations
- XR (PA + lateral): SLAC (site, location, apical vertebral level, Cobb angle)
- Cobb angle: angle between the lines projected from the most tilted vertebrae at the top & bottom of the curve
  Management

| Cobb angle                | Child | Skeletal maturity         |
| ------------------------- | ----- | ------------------------- |
| Observation               | <25   | <40                       |
| Bracing                   | 25-45 | Progression between 25-40 |
| Operative (spinal fusion) | >45   | >50                       |

[Flowchart titled "School Scoliosis Screening-Hong Kong (1996-)" depicting a screening process. Starting at the top, there are rectangles that contain the words "Grades 5, 7, 9" and "Students screened biennially Grades 5 through 9". These rectangles lead to a diamond labeled "FBT & ATR". Two exits stem from the diamond. The left exit labeled "ATR 5-14" leads to a rectangle labeled "MT". The right exit labeled "ATR ≥ 15" goes to "Student Health Service Centre (SHSC) " which includes bulleted points: "Forward Bending Test (FBT)", "Angle of Trunk Rotation (ATR)". From the MT rectangle there is another diamond labeled "≥ 2 Moiré lines or Clinical signs" that leads to a rectangle labeled X-Ray. From the X-Ray rectangle, there is another diamond labeled "Cobb ≥ 20°" which leads to a rectangle labeled "Specialist Hospitals" which includes the bulleted points: "PWH" and "DKCH". Furthermore, an additional rectangle labeled Special Assessment Centre (SAC) lists the bulleted points: "Moiré Topography (MT)", "Clinical Signs of Scoliosis", and "X-Ray."]

11.3 Hip pain in paediatrics
Hip pain in paediatrics

- Age < 4y: transient synovitis, infection (osteomyelitis, septic arthritis), NAI
- Age 4-10: transient synovitis, Perthes disease, infection (osteomyelitis/ septic arthritis)
- Age 10-16: SCFE, avulsion fracture, infection (osteomyelitis/ septic arthritis), malignancy (osteosarcoma, Ewing's)

SCFE (slipped capital femoral epiphysis)
Definition

- Misnomer: anterolateral displacement of metaphysis relative to epiphysis (which remains in normal position in acetabulum)
- Left hip > right hip (unknown reason)
  Risk factors
- Obese boys aged 10-15y
  Clinical features
- Onset: acute following minor trauma or insidious onset
- Hip pain that may radiate to knee
- Antalgic gait
- Loss of internal rotation, abduction, flexion
- Complications: slipping at contralateral hip, AVN
  Investigations
- XR hip (fig.)
  Management
- Operative: percutaneous in situ fixation +/- prophylactic contralateral hip fixation - despite Salter-Harris type I injury

Perthes disease (Legg-Calve-Perthes disease)

- Definition: idiopathic AVN of proximal femoral epiphysis in children
- Risk factors: boys aged 5-10y
- Clinical features: hip pain, loss of internal rotation and abduction
- XR hip: medial joint space widening, crescent sign
- Management
  - Non-operative (for age < 8y - do not benefit from surgery): PT (ROM exercise), activity restriction (non- weightbearing)
  - Operative (for age > 8y): femoral/ pelvic osteotomy

# SUBSPECIALTY SURGERY

# 1 Anaesthesia and intensive care

1.1 Trauma
Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS)

Airway

- **Immobilize cervical spine** by rigid neck collar
- Signs of airway obstruction (may be absent if complete airway obstruction): cyanosis, stridor, abdominal breathing, accessory muscles, tracheal tug, tachypnea
- Simple airway maneuvers: **jaw thrust**, chin lift, **NO** head tilt (not yet r/o C-spine injury)
- Causes of delayed airway obstruction - obtain **definitive airway** (e.g. tracheal intubation, surgical airway) as soon as possible
  - Sedation
  - Inhalation burns
  - Maxillofacial injury

Breathing
Common problems: **pneumothorax, lung collapse, haemothorax**

Circulation
Check systemic perfusion: **BP/P**, consciousness, urine output

- Shock: **haemorrhagic shock** must be considered
  - Chest: intercostal / rib fracture
  - Abdomen: liver, spleen, mesenteric vessels
  - Pelvic fracture / retroperitoneal haematoma
  - Long bones: e.g. femoral shaft fracture (can cause 1L blood loss per side)

Fluid resuscitation:

- **Isotonic crystalloid** (NS / PlasmaLyte) **10mL/kg bolus** (e.g. IV NS 500mL bolus)
- Reassess BP/P → Give **another bolus**
- Reassess → Consider **blood replacement** / vasopressor / colloids

Disability Glasgow Coma Scale + pupils
(neurological) Table 2. The Glasgow coma scale

[Table Description: A table titled "Table 2. The Glasgow coma scale" displaying the scoring system for the Glasgow Coma Scale, with categories for Eye opening response, Best motor response, and Best verbal response. Each category lists different levels of response and their corresponding numerical scores. For Eye opening response, the options are spontaneously (4), to speech (3), to pain (2), and none (1). For Best motor response, the options are obeys commands (6), localization to painful stimuli (5), normal flexion to painful stimuli (4), abnormal flexion to painful stimuli (3), extension to painful stimuli (2), and none (1). For Best verbal response, the options are orientated (5), confused (4), inappropriate words (3), incomprehensible sounds (2), and none (1). A separate section lists verbal scores for intubated patients: patient appears able to converse (5), patient questionable to converse (3), and generally unresponsive (1).]

Events
AMPLE history

- Allergy
- Medications
- Past health
- Last meal
- Events related to injury

  1.2 Perioperative issues
  Preoperative assessment
  Goals of assessment

- Is this patient fit to proceed to surgery?
- What is the best timing to proceed?
- Are there any anticipated complications that will affect our anesthetic technique and preparation?
- What is the best choice of anesthetic and analgesic technique?
- Are there any investigations and
  treatment that may optimise this
  patient's physiological state prior
  to receiving anesthesia?
- Will the patient need escalation of
  care after surgery?

Fitness for
anaesthesia

- Cardiorespiratory reserve to tolerate anaesthetic drugs and surgical stress
  - Exercise tolerance (FOS)
  - Metabolic equivalents (MET): objective measure of physiological reserve - 1 MET = resting 02 consumption of a 40yo 70kg man = 3.5mL O2/min/kg BW - Role in non-emergency OT: - Low risk of MACE (<1%): proceed to surgery - High risk of MACE (≥1%): assess METS - ≥4 METs (clinically 2 FOS): fit for GA - <4 METs: pharmacologic stress testing (thallium or stress cardiac
    MRI); coronary revascularisation if abnormal
  - Cardiopulmonary exercise testing (CPET): real measure of functional capacity

Medical
history

- Past anesthetic history:
  - Allergy/Anaphylaxis: antibiotics/muscle relaxants / anaesthetic drugs
  - Difficult intubation
  - Poor dentition ("loose tooth alert")
  - Previous post-op n/v (PONV), awareness under GA (rare)
- Family history
  - Suxamethonium apnoea:
    - Pseudocholinesterase deficiency (prevalence: 1/2000) → prolonged paralysis (5-10min to several hours) → post-operative ventilation failure
    - Mx: mechanical ventilation until effect wears off 1-2h later
  - Malignant hyperpyrexia (MHP)
    - Uncontrolled release of intracellular Ca2+ due to defective ryanodine receptor
    - Trigger: suxamethonium, all inhalational agents except nitrous oxide
    - S/S: rigidity, tachycardia, tachpnoea, HT, diaphoresis, unexplained ↑ETCO2, hyperthermia (late), death (80% if untreated, 20% if treated)
    - Management:
      - Stop all trigger agents & change to IV propofol
      - Hyperventilate with 100% O2
      - IV dantrolene 2.5mg/kg Q5min (RyR antagonist)
      - Symptomatic: cooling, treat hyperK and acidosis (e.g. NaHCO3)
- Medical condition (e.g. OSA)
  - PMHx: any medications and S/E, control of chronic diseases, room for optimization
  - Physical examination & check vitals
  - Bloods: Hb, Plt, Na, K, Ur/Cr, clotting
  - CXR/ECG
- Surgical condition: e.g. multiple metastases, UGI tumor with malnutrition, perforated viscus causing sepsis
- Smoking, alcohol, drug Hx (e.g. steroids, antiplatelets, anticoagulants, OCP, HRT, psychiatric)

[Image of a physical exam detailing: Airway: MP3, receding chin +ve, TMD >6cm, removable denture x1, neck extension OK. BP 132/76 mmHg, HR 63/min BW: 52kg Ht: 150cm. CVS: HS dual, no murmur, AF. Chest: clear, no basal crepitations, no ankle edema. Investigations: Hb/Plt: 14.3/215 Na/K/Ur/Cr: 139/4.6/5.5/61. ECG: AF, RBBB. CXR: widened carina, clear lung fields.]

Quantifying American Society of Anaesthesiology classification (**ASA**): Gross predictor of overall outcome, but
anaesthetic not predict mortality
risk

- ASA1: healthy fit, no organic / biochemical / psychiatric disease
- ASA2: mild systemic disease, e.g. controlled T2DM, normal pregnancy, heavy smoker, HBV,
  obese (BMI 30-40)
- ASA3: severe systemic disease that limits normal activity, e.g. poorly controlled DM, CRF
  with regular CAPD, morbid obesity (BMI ≥ 40), stroke with dense hemiplegia
- ASA4: incapacitating disease that poses constant threat to life, e.g. unstable IHD, severe
  COPD requiring ventilation, end-stage cirrhosis
- ASA5: moribund, not expected to survive 24h with or without surgery, e.g. ruptured AAA
- ASA6: declared brain death whose organs are being removed for donation purposes
- Modifiers: Add **"E" for emergency surgery**, **"P" for pregnancy**
- Easy to use compared to other scores; Interobserver variability, cannot account for ≥2 systemic
  diseases of different severity, not take into account age, malignancy

Airway - Inspect jaw profile and oral cavity: e.g. receding chin, tongue fibrosis / tumor, poor dentition
assessment - 3-2-1 rule: difficult intubation if

- Thyromental distance < 3 FB
- Mouth opening < 2FB
- Anterior jaw subluxation < 1FB
- Neck mobility: atlanto-occipital joint (AOJ) extension (normal >35°)
- Mallampati classification (fig.): protrude tongue and say "ah", Class III or above: difficult

[Illustration of Mallampati classification with four classes. Each class depicts the view of the oral cavity when a person protrudes their tongue and says "ah". Class I shows the soft palate, uvula, and pillars being visible. Class II shows the soft palate and the uvula being visible. Class III depicts only the soft palate and the base of the uvula being visible. Class IV depicts only the hard palate being visible.]

- Class I - soft palate, uvula, and pillars are visible
- Class II - when the soft palate and the uvula are visible
- Class III when only the soft palate and base of the uvula are visible
- Class IV when only the hard palate is visible.
- Cormack and Lehane grading (laryngoscopy view): Grade III or above: difficult

[Illustration of Cormack and Lehane grading for laryngoscopy view, with four grades. Grade I shows a full view of the entire glottic aperture. Grade II shows a partial glottic view. Grade III shows a visualization of the epiglottis only. Grade IV shows inability to visualize even the epiglottis.]

- Grade I - full view of the entire glottic aperture
- Grade II - partial glottic view
- Grade III - visualization of the epiglottis only
- Grade IV - inability to visualize even the epiglottis

Aspiration - High risk of aspiration
risk - Unfasted patients: trauma, ruptured AAA

- High intra-abdominal pressure: morbid obesity, pregnancy
- GERD, hiatal hernia
- Delayed gastric emptying: DM with gastroparesis, GOO, IO
- Prevention
  - Pre-operative fasting
  - Antacid prophylaxis (e.g. sodium citrate, H2RA/PPI)
  - Cuffed ET tube
  - Rapid sequence induction with application of cricoid pressure
