# Anaesthetic orders

Medications of anesthetic concern

| Drug class                                                                    | Considerations                                                                                              | Management                                                                                                                                                                                                              |
| ----------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Ongoing treatments: anticonvulsants, antihypertensives, bronchodilators       |                                                                                                             | Often continued + consult medical if change IV                                                                                                                                                                          |
| Antithrombotics: heparin, warfarin, NOAC, aspirin                             | Surgical bleeding Regional anesthetic (e.g. spinal anesthesia) Consequence of cessation of drugs (e.g. AMI) | Refer to [GEN SUR] DAPT: defer elective surgery, stop P2Y12i if emergency OT Warfarin: INR < 1.5 (vit K & FFP if emergency) + heparin bridging NOAC: withhold duration depends on RFT and bleeding risk, usually 2 days |
| Steroids                                                                      | Inadequate cortisol response for surgical stress → Addisonian crisis                                        | IV 100mg hydrocortisone tds (first dose given on induction of anesthesia) → taper to 50mg tds and 25mg tds                                                                                                              |
| Antidiabetic agents                                                           | Glucose fluctuation to fasting and surgical stress Metabolic complications e.g. DKA, HHS                    | Stop OHA / insulin 1 day before OT Dextrose-insulin-potassium (DKI): titrate insulin against H'stix Q6h, target 5-11                                                                                                    |
| Other drugs Bronchodilators for asthma / COPD Anxiolytic for anxious patients |                                                                                                             |                                                                                                                                                                                                                         |

Preoperative fasting - refer to [GEN SUR] for ERAS principles

- No clear fluid for 2h
- No solid food for 6h
- Adult: 2-6-8 rule (clear fluid prohibited within 2h of surgery, solid food/ milk within 6h, heavy meal within 8h)
- Child: 2-4-6-8 rule (clear fluid within 2h, breast milk within 4h, formula milk within 6h, solid food within 8h)

Routine investigations

- CBC, clotting, random glucose, RFT, CXR, ECG
- Blood transfusion:
  - No expected blood loss: omit pre-op T&S
  - Expect some blood loss: pre-op T&S
  - Expect moderate blood loss < 1L: 2 unit packed cells
  - Expect severe blood loss >2L: 4 units packed cells
  - Expect massive blood (> 1 blood volume): 8 units blood + FFP + platelets (stored blood lacks functional platelets and clotting factors)

Post-op destination

- Consider escalation to HDU / ICU: more invasive monitoring & organ support (e.g. mechanical ventilation, inotropes, continuous RRT), high nursing-to-patient ratio

\*Extra: Alternative scores for anesthetic risk

- Cardiovascular: Goldman-Lee score, Revised Cardiac Risk Index (RCRI), NSQIP
- Liver disease: Child-Pugh score
- Head injury: GCS
- Critical care: APACHE I-III, SOFA, RIFLE, Ranson Score

[Image Description: The text "The better known critical care scoring systems are:" is followed by descriptions of APACHE I-III, SOFA, RIFLE, and Ranson Score systems, detailing their purpose, application, and key features. The text is formatted in a paragraph style with some bolded text for emphasis.]

# 1.3 Airway management

Causes of airway obstruction
| | Causes | Management |
| :---------------- | :------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ | :------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
| Upper airway | Functional: - Reduced consciousness level - Neuromuscular abnormalities: bulbar palsy, MG - Recurrent laryngeal nerve problems / cord palsy | Refer to below: Non-definitive airways → Definitive airways |
| | Mechanical: - Inhaled foreign body - Soft tissue swelling: infection (e.g. tonsillitis, epiglottitis), neoplasms, anaphylaxis | Bypass by ETT / tracheostomy Manage underlying causes: drain abscesses, excise neoplasms, stents |
| Lower airway | - Extrinsic tracheal compression - Tracheal stenosis - Severe bronchospasm | |

Ventilation
Rate: 12-15/min
Volume: ~500mL (1/4 of adult resuscitation bag)
Observe chest movement and auscultate for air entry

Methods of supporting airway
Non-definitive airway

- Recovery position (tongue falls forward)
- Airway maneuvers: **head-tilt chin-lift / jaw thrust** (lift up tongue & epiglottis)
- Airway adjuncts:
  - Oropharyngeal airway: in unconscious patients, measure from corner of mouth to angle of mandible
  - Nasopharyngeal airway: in semi-conscious patients, measure from nostrils to angle of mandible, C/I if suspected skull-base fractures
  - Supraglottic devices e.g. laryngeal mask airway (LMA)

[Image of a laryngeal mask airway (LMA). The LMA consists of an oval mask with a cuff that is designed to create a seal around the entrance to the larynx. The mask is connected to an airway tube, which is used to ventilate the patient. The image also shows the different parts of the LMA, including the distal aperture, cuff, mask aperture bars, bowl, inflation line, proximal connector, pilot balloon, and valve. In the bottom right corner of the image, there are descriptions of the numbers shown in the image, that correspond to parts of the device. Number 1 refers to the inflatable cuff (25-30 ml air). Number 2 refers to the stalk with universal (15 mm) connector. Number 3 refers to the pilot balloon (with syringe). Number 4 refers to the fact that the device is disposable or reused.]

- Advantages over ETT: easier to insert (laryngoscopy not required), less traumatic, lower anaesthetic requirement (require only hypnosis + suppression of gag reflex)
- Role:
  - Alternative to intubation in short procedure (but avoid if high risk of aspiration)
  - Rescue device: cannot intubate (ETT), cannot ventilate (BMV)
- Second generation: additional channel for NG tube e.g. ProLeak

Definitive airway (protected)

- Endotracheal tube (ETT)

[Image of an endotracheal tube, labeled with "Murphy eye," "One-way valve," "Inflating tube," "15-mm adapter," "Pilot balloon," "Cap to one-way valve," "Inflated cuff," "Radiopaque line," and "Depth markings."]

- Markings: denote position of **vocal cords**
- Material: PVC (Portex), silicon-coated PVC (Shiley)
- Cuffed vs uncuffed:
  - Cuffed: high volume & low pressure usually
    preferred, aim pressure 20-30 cmH2O
  - Uncuffed: may be used in children to avoid injury
- Single vs double lumen: for one-lung ventilation
- **Fenestrated** vs non-fenestrated: allow phonation
- Inner tube: allow replacement
- Surgical airway: cricothyrotomy (emergency), tracheostomy

Tracheal intubation

- Pre-requisite
  - Suction of mouth and pharynx
  - Pre-oxygenation/denitrogenation: 100% O2 for 3-5 min
- Proper positioning:
  - Sniffing position: flexion of lower C spine + extension of
    upper C spine → oral axis, pharyngeal axis and laryngeal
    axis should be a straight line
  - C/I in suspected C-spine instability/fracture → manual in-
    line immobilisation of head & neck OR awake fiberoptic
    bronchoscopy
- Laryngoscopy
  - Stand at **head** end of patient and hold laryngoscope with
    **left** hand
  - Laryngoscope blade tip placed at **vallecula**
  - BURP maneuver (backward, upward, rightward pressure)
    to facilitate glottis visualization
- Tube insertion:
  - Tip of ETT at least 2cm above carina → ~21-23cm mark (M)/
    19-21cm mark (F) at right corner of mouth
  - _Stylet_ can be inserted through lumen to make it firmer
  - Confirmation of placement:
    - Direct vision + "misting" in endotracheal tube
    - Bilateral chest movement
    - **Auscultate both lungs** for equal breath sounds (to
      prevent transmission of sound over chest) +
      _epigastrium_ for absent breast sounds
    - ETCO2 measured by capnography: observe for 5
      expiratory peaks

[Image of a diagram illustrating the design of an endotracheal tube (ETT). The diagram shows a plastic tube labeled as "Clear, disposable & non-allergy". It includes a cuff with a pilot balloon (5-10 ml air), a seal to keep air in/vomit out, and a connector. The connector is specified as a "Universal size 15 mm". Markings such as size, length, and position are also indicated.]

[Image of a Resuscitation Bag. The bag shows oxygen supply connected here with label of 10L/min. The parts of the bag are labeled as follows: 1. Bag - self-inflating, 2. Valves - unidirectional, 3. Oxygen supply / reservoir, and 4. Face mask.]

[Image of a Macintosh Laryngoscope. The upper scope is in a ready position for use with light switched on, while the lower scope is in the off position. A blue arrow points to a feature on the laryngoscope.]

[Image of a person using a laryngoscope. The text reads "Laryngoscope held in LEFT hand, person intubating stands at head end of patient. Note (a) how the handle is grasped and (b) The orientation of blade in the mouth" Also, a note at the bottom reads: "Too much pressure on upper teeth" and an arrow indicates where the teeth are]

Complications

- Sedative-related
- Laryngoscopy-related: damage to lips, teeth, larynx
- Intubation-related:
  - Oesophageal intubation:
    - Delayed hypoxia for 3-5min (due to pre-oxygenation)
    - Abdominal distension → regurgitation → aspiration
  - Endobronchial intubation: one-lung ventilation → contralateral lung collapse
  - Accidental extubation

289

Modification: Nasal or oral RAE preformed tube (fig.): facilitate H&N surgery

Difficult airway

- Prevention: pre-op assessment (Mallampati score & TMD are most predictive; consider tracheostomy if burns/ maxillofacial trauma), pre-oxygenation
- Management modalities of unsuccessful intubation after induction
  - LMA manages to oxygenate:
    - Gum elastic Bougie (GEB, endotracheal tube introducer)
    - Video laryngoscopy (e.g. Pentex (fig.))
    - Awake fiberoptic bronchoscopy
  - LMA fails to oxygenate: emergency cricothyroidotomy
- Management of predicted unsuccessful intubation before induction
  - LMA (if short procedure)
  - Awake fiberoptic intubation (gold standard): no need of bag-mask ventilation to maintain oxygenation, but uncomfortable and difficult due to gag reflex
  - Awake tracheostomy
    EMERGENCY ACCESS TO TRACHEA

[Diagram showing Cricothyroidotomy and Formal Tracheostomy. On the left side, labeled "Anterior", is a diagram of Cricothyroidotomy. It's annotated with: "Quick, relatively easy stab through cricothyroid membrane. Insert any small round airway such as a biro casing. Anaesthetic not essential. Life saving." Below that is Formal Tracheostomy, with the annotation "Not usually an emergency. Needs full anaesthetic. Ideal for temporary or permanent intubation. Hole cut in 2nd & 3rd tracheal rings, usually after dividing thyroid isthmus. Inferior thyroid veins can be troublesome." On the right side, labeled "Lateral", is another view of the same anatomy.]

[Photograph of a difficult intubation trolley, which is a metal cart with shelves and drawers, holding various medical instruments and supplies. Some of the labeled items are: 1. Blind nasal, 2. Surgical airway* (Tracheostomy, Cricothyroidotomy), 3. Retrograde intubation, 4. Gum Elastic Bougie (GEB), 5. Novel laryngoscope blades (i.e. McCoy), 6. Light Wand, 7. Intubating LMA, 8. Fibre-optic laryngoscope, 9. Video laryngoscope.]

Operating table position
| Position | Features |
| ------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------ |
| Supine | Least likely to sustain injury |
| Lithotomy | Perineal surgery, e.g. anorectal, urologic, gynaecological |
| Lateral | Thoracic Intubation/ line when supine |
| Prone | Back: spine, adrenal Intubation/ line when supine |
| Trendelenburg (head down) | Pelvis (bowel moves proximally) |

1.4 General anaesthesia
Four stages of anaesthesia (ether): analgesia → excitement → surgical anaesthesia (unconscious & still) → respiratory
arrest & cardiovascular collapse

Balanced anaesthesia
Rationales

- Allow lower doses of combination → lower risk
- Improve surgical conditions
- More control on individual drugs
  Components
- Anaesthetics - see [Induction]
- Analgesia
- Neuromuscular blockers

[Illustration of a triangle with the title "Unconsciousness (1)" at the top, "Analgesia (2)" on the left, and "(3) Muscle relaxation" on the right.]

Neuromuscular blockers

[Diagram showing the mechanism of action of neuromuscular blockers. It depicts a synapse with a presynaptic neuron releasing Acetylcholine (ACh) which is then either broken down by Acetylcholinesterase (AChE) into Choline + Acetate, or binds to the Postsynaptic nicotinic ACh receptor. The diagram illustrates the Non-depolarising and Depolarising blocking agents, and their effects on the synapse.]

|            | Suxamethonium                                                                                                                                                                                                 | Rocuronium / Atracurium                                                                                 |
| ---------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| MOA        | **Depolarising**: rapid repeated activation → local accumulation of K+ → inactivation of Na+ channel                                                                                                          | **Non-depolarising** competitive antagonist at nicotinic AChR                                           |
| PK         | Rapid onset (45 sec) - initial fasciculations Short acting (9-10min): metabolized by succinylcholinesterase                                                                                                   | Delayed onset (R: 60-90 sec; A: 3 min) Long acting (up to 1hr)                                          |
| S/E        | Muscle pain Hyperkalaemia: K+ release from increased no. of receptors; higher risk in 3rd degree burns, spinal injury, neuromuscular diseases Increased ICP & IOP Malignant hyperthermia Suxamethonium apnoea | Atracurium: **non-organ elimination** Atracurium: rash, hypotension (histamine) Rocuronium: **minimal** |
| Monitoring | Peripheral nerve stimulation (ulnar nerve) - **train of four (TOF)**: 4 repeated stimuli at 0.5s intervals, usually aim 2 out of 4 twitches, some surgeries (e.g. retinal, CNS) require absolute immobility   |                                                                                                         |

- NMB Reversal
  - Neostigmine (cholinesterase inhibitor) + atropine (block muscarinic S/E of neostigmine)
  - Sugammadex: specific for reversing rocuronium / vecuronium

# Induction

**Equipment required**

- Ventilation: resuscitation bag / anesthetic circuit, face mask
- Airway obstruction: different airways (refer above)
- Intubation: laryngoscope, endotracheal tube (stylet, 10mL syringe), aqueous lubricating jelly
- Confirm tube position: stethoscope, ETCO2 monitor

**Types of induction**

|                      | Routine induction                                                                                                                                                                  | Rapid sequence induction (RSI)                                                                                                                                                                                             |
| :------------------- | :--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | :------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Indications          | Adequately fasted (no liquid x 2h, no solid food x 6h)                                                                                                                             | High risk of aspiration (refer to pre-op assessment)                                                                                                                                                                       |
| Pre-requisite        | Pre-oxygenation with high flow O2 for 3 min (aim to achieve expired O2 conc. >80%)                                                                                                 |                                                                                                                                                                                                                            |
|                      | (Rationale: FRC 2.5L, O2 consumption 250mL/min, CO2 production 200mL/min → pre-oxygenation can fill FRC with 100% O2 and keep the patient oxygenated for 10 min before intubation) |                                                                                                                                                                                                                            |
| Induction &paralysis | Induction anesthetic (**propofol**) + fast-acting opioid (**fentanyl**)                                                                                                            |                                                                                                                                                                                                                            |
|                      | Non-depolarising NMB (e.g. **atracuronium**) after onset of induction agent & ensuring patient is **fully unconscious** by checking eyelash reflex                                 | Depolarising NMB (**suxamethonium**) at the same time (shorter onset) → If C/I: rocuronium (fast onset, but long acting)→ stand-by Sugammadex if failed intubation                                                         |
| Post-induction       | Bag-mask ventilation (± oropharyngeal airway if difficult) x **3 minutes** to allow muscle relaxation                                                                              | Sellick's maneuver: cricoid pressure x **45sec** to allow muscle relaxation (10N before induction, 30N after induction) - only cricoid has a complete ring! Bag-mask ventilation **not done**: increase risk of aspiration |
|                      | Confirm position of ETT                                                                                                                                                            | Laryngoscopy & intubation (+ inflate cuff) Release cricoid pressure **after** ETT position confirmed and secured                                                                                                           |

[Image of a box with RSI: "7 P's" written on top, followed by a list with numbers. 1. P = Preparation 2. P = Preoxygenation 3. P = Pretreatment 4. P = Paralysis with induction 5. P = Protection 6. P = Placement of the tube 7. P = Post-Intubation management]

292
Induction agents
Intravenous agents: fast induction after 1 "arm-brain circulation time"
| | Propofol | Ketamine | Benzodiazepines |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| MOA | Positive modulation at GABAA receptors | NMDA antagonist | Positive modulation at GABA receptors (different site as propofol) |
| Role | Induction (~30sec) | Major trauma | Anxiolysis, sedation, anterograde amnesia |
| | Maintenance (require TCI) | (Not for head injury: increase ICP) | |
| | Total IV anaesthesia (TIVA): In/v | | |
| Caution | Sudden hypotension & bradycardia | Sympathomimetic: increase HR/BP | Respiratory depression |
| Remarks | Anti-emetic effects | Hallucinogenic Potent analgesic | Antagonist: flumazenil 0.2mg IV, repeat Q1min No analgesic effects |

\*Target-controlled infusion pump (TCI, fig.): input desired plasma concentration, and computer
will calculate and control infusion rate
[Image of Target-controlled infusion pump which shows an infusion pump, tubings, and an IV bag. The pump has a digital display showing infusion parameters. A gloved hand is adjusting the pump settings. The background is a sterile medical environment.]
Specific indications for TIVA

- Operation-related: tubeless ENT/ thoracic surgery, neurosurgery (minimise effect on ICP)
- Drug-related: history of severe PONV, long QT syndrome, risk of malignant hyperthermia

Inhalational agents

- Examples:
  - Halothane (less used now due to risk of autoimmune hepatitis)
  - Isoflurane (slower onset → for maintenance)
  - Sevoflurane (non-pungent banana-smelling → for induction)
  - Desflurane (fastest onset and offset, low potency, pungent → not for induction)
  - Xenon (under research)
- S/E:
  - PONV
  - Respiratory depression
  - CVS: hypotension, bradycardia
  - Increased ICP
  - Malignant hyperthermia
- Minimal alveolar concentration (MAC): concentration in inspired air at which 50% of patients have no response to a surgical incision

Depth of sedation
| | Minimal Sedation (Anxiolysis) | Moderate Sedation (Conscious Sedation) | Deep Sedation (Monitored Anaesthetic Care) | General Anesthesia |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Response | Normal response to verbal stimulation | Purposeful* response to verbal or tactile stimulation | Purposeful* response to repeated or painful stimulation | Unarousable, even with painful stimulus |
| Airway | Unaffected | No intervention required | Intervention may be required | Intervention often required |
| Spontaneous Ventilation | Unaffected | Adequate | May be inadequate | Frequently inadequate |
| Cardiovascular Function | Unaffected | Usually maintained | Usually maintained | May be impaired |

- Reflex withdrawal from a painful stimulus is NOT a purposeful response

Monitored Anaesthesia Care (MAC)

- Indicated for ambulatory diagnostic and therapeutic procedures with fast recovery
- Patient remains conscious, maintains own airway and gag reflexes, and responds purposefully
- Anaesthetist administers sedatives and analgesics, and continuously monitors and supports patients
  Contraindications to sedation
- Absolute: risk of aspiration, airway obstruction, respiratory distress, high ICP
- Relative: advanced COPD (T2RF), renal/hepatic dysfunction

Maintenance
Anaesthetic depth

- Clinical: SNS response (HT, tachycardia, sweating), patient movement, blink reflex when eyelashes lightly
  touched
- Machine:
  - Inhalational agents: end-tidal concentration of volatile agent, keep MAC > 0.7
  - Intravenous agents (TIVA): depth of anaesthesia monitoring, e.g. bispectral index (simplified EEG)

[Table with AGENT, MAC, POTENCY, Bispectral index system value and Depth of sedation. The AGENT column has the drugs Methoxy-flurane, Halothane, Isoflurane, Enflurane, Sevoflurane, Desflurane, Nitrous oxide. The MAC column has the values 0.16%, 0.74%, 1.17%, 1.7%, 2.05%, 6.0%, 104%. The POTENCY column contains text which includes Most potent and Least potent. The Bispectral index system value contains the values 0, 0-40, 40-60, 60-90 and 100. The Depth of sedation column contains the text Flat-line EEG, Deep hypnotic state; memory function lost; increasing burst suppression, Recommended range for general anesthesia, Recommended range for sedation, Awake; memory intact]

The lower the MAC- the more potent the agent!

EEG = electroencephalogram

Routine monitoring

- Airway/breathing: pulse oximetry, ETCO2, ventilator function
- Circulation: continuous ECG, non-invasive BP Q3-5min
- Body temperature

Additional monitoring

- Urine output: in all major operations, to prevent overfilling of bladder and post-op bladder dysfunction
- Arterial BP: in critically ill patients where acute changes in BP are possible
- CVP: in patients with poor CV function

Monitoring sedation by midazolam: Ramsay sedation score, Observer's Assessment of Alertness/Sedation (OAA/S)

[Table with Response, Speech, Facial expression, Eyes, Composite score, Sedation Level. The Response column consists of Responds readily to name spoken in normal tone, Lethargic response to name spoken in normal tone, Responds only after name is called loudly or repeatedly, Responds only after mild prodding or shaking, Does not respond to mild prodding or shaking, Does not respond to noxious stimulus. The Speech column consists of Normal, Mild slowing or thickening, Slurring or prominent slowing, Few recognizable words. The Facial expression column consists of Normal, Mild relaxation, Marked relaxation (slack jaw). The Eyes column consists of Clear, no ptosis, Glazed or mild ptosis (less than half the eye), Glazed and marked ptosis (half the eye or more). The Composite score consists of 5, 4, 3, 2, 1, 0. The Sedation Level column consists of Alert, Light, Moderate, Deep, Unconscious, Anaesthesia]

Emergence
General guidelines of extubation

- Suction secretions
- Ensure normal neuromuscular function: nerve stimulator of ulnar nerve (correspond well to respiratory
  muscles function)
- Ensure breathing spontaneously with adequate rate and tidal volume
- Bite block: prevent biting on ETT → might lead to negative pressure pulmonary edema
- Deflate ETT cuff and remove ETT on inspiration (vocal cords abducted)
- Ensure breathing adequately after extubation

Complications

- Early: aspiration, laryngospasm
- Late: transient vocal cord incompetence, oedema, pharyngitis

Aldrete's recovery room score: conscious, activity, respiration, circulation, SpO2

293

1.5 Local anaesthesia
Definitions & mechanism

- Drugs that block the generation and propagation of impulses in excitable tissues near the site of administration
- LA binds to receptors on cytosolic side of Na+ channel

Chemical classifications

- Amide: metabolized by liver
  |Lignocaine|Fast onset (<2min), short acting (~1.5h), max dose **3mg/kg (7mg/kg with adrenaline)**|
  |---|---|
  |Bupivacaine(Marcaine)|Slow onset, **long acting** (3-4h), **more potent, most cardiotoxic, least neurotoxic**, max dose **2mg/kg** (with or without adrenaline), often used for spinal / epidural blocks due to **long action**|
  |RopivacaineLevobupivacaine|Enantiomer of bupivacaine, less potent, **fewer S/E** but longer half life|
  |Prilocaine|Less cardiotoxic thus preferred in **IVLA**, risk of methemoglobinemia; N/A in HK|

- Ester (e.g. cocaine, procaine): metabolized by plasma cholinesterase (shorter halflife), possible metabolism to para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) and cause HSR

Delivery techniques
Topical anaesthetic

- Must be able to penetrate skin or mucous membrane
- EMLA (eutectic mixture of LA): 2.5% lignocaine + 2.5% prilocaine for injection pain
- 10% lignocaine spray: laryngoscopy
- Cocaine: local vasoconstriction in ENT surgery
  Local infiltration

[Extent (Vol LA) x Duration (Conc LA) = Total Dose of LA image, there are mathematical expressions around it.]

- Direct injection of LA into tissues to anesthetize local terminal nerve endings
- Indications: **minor surgery** (e.g. wound suturing, tooth extraction, removal of sebaceous cyst / lipoma)

Risks of local anaesthesia

- Infection
- Injury to nearby vital structures
- Allergic reaction
- **Systemic toxicity**: caused by **overdose, rapid absorption, or accidental IV injection**
  - CNS: perioral numbness, dizziness, tinnitus, visual disturbance, convulsion, respiratory depression
  - CVS: hypotension, arrhythmia (VF), cardiorespiratory arrest
  - Management: resuscitation, diazepam (↑seizure threshold), intralipid 20% (bind LA in circulation), manage arrhythmia

Prevention of systemic toxicity

- Use within max dose
- Frequent aspiration & injection of **small increments** to make sure no blood
- Adrenaline
  - Causes vasoconstriction
    - Reduce bleeding of surgical site
    - Decrease systemic absorption of LA → Limit peak plasma conc. of LA and reduce LA toxicity
    - Increase neuronal uptake → Prolong duration of LA
  - S/E:
    - Local: tissue ischaemia - **avoid end arteries** (ears, nose, fingers/ toes, penis)
    - Systemic: HT, arrhythmia, MI - avoid if taking sympathomimetics (MAOI/TCA)
  - Usual conc.: 1:200,000 (5ug/mL)

[A pyramid-shaped chart showing plasma lidocaine concentration (µg/ml) on the Y-axis, ranging from 0 to 30. The X-axis is unlabeled. Horizontal lines mark the concentration levels, each corresponding to different physiological effects. At 30 µg/ml is labeled "Ventricular arrest". 25 µg/ml marks "Respiratory arrest" and "Cardiac arrhythmias". 20 µg/ml shows "Coma" and "Myocardial depression". 15 µg/ml indicates "Convulsions". 10 µg/ml notes "Unconsciousness", "Muscular twitches", and "Visual disturbance". Lastly, 5 µg/ml describes "Tinnitus", "Lightheadedness", "Numbness of the tongue", and "Circumoral paraesthesia". The chart visually depicts the correlation between lidocaine concentration and associated medical conditions.]

Toxicity: prilocaine < lidocaine < ropivacaine < levobupivacaine < bupivacaine

# 1.6 Regional & obstetrics anaesthesia

Peripheral nerve blocks

- Deposition of LA around target nerve or plexus (within perineural sheath)
- Usage: isolated to avoid GA, or combined with GA
- Examples
  - Distal radius fracture: brachial plexus block
  - Hip fracture: femoral nerve block
  - Hallux valgus: sciatic nerve block / saphenous nerve block
  - Breast surgery: thoracic paravertebral block
- Equipment: 30º short bevel, USG / peripheral nerve stimulator (stimulate nerve and watch for motor response)
- C/I: neurological disease (e.g. ALS, MS), local infection, coagulopathy

Brachial plexus block:
Approaches

- Interscalene (between scalenus anterior & medius)
- Supraclavicular
- Infraclavicular
- Axillary
  Complications (spreading of LA / direct trauma)
- Phrenic nerve block: caution if limited respiratory reserve
- Horner's syndrome (sympathetic trunk)
- Hoarseness (RLN)
- Pneumothorax
- Intravascular injection: subclavian vessels, vertebral a.

[Image of the brachial plexus. The image shows a diagram of the brachial plexus, which is a network of nerves that originates in the neck and shoulder and extends into the arm. The diagram shows the roots, trunks, divisions, cords, and branches of the brachial plexus, as well as the muscles and skin that are innervated by each nerve. Next to the diagram, there is a drawing of a side view of the bones and muscles in the neck and shoulder with the Brachial plexus.]

IV regional anaesthesia (Bier's block)

- Systemic injection of LA localized to upper/ lower limbs
- Indications: surgery below elbow / knee lasting within 1h
- C/I:
  - Procedures ≥ 1h (tourniquet pain)
  - Pre-existing AV shunt/ severe PVD
  - Sickle cell disease
- Components:
  - Double pneumatic tourniquets inflated to 100mmHg above SBP for at least 30min (to prevent systemic toxicity of LA)
  - Exsanguination: elevation + rubber Esmarch bandage
  - IV lignocaine / prilocaine WITHOUT adrenaline
  - After finishing operation: deflate then inflate again x 2 - to ensure no systemic toxicity of LA
- S/E:
  - Drug-related systemic toxicity
  - Equipment-related (tourniquet)
- Alternative: WALANT (wide-awake local anaesthesia no tourniquet) - lignocaine + adrenaline

[Image of a Bier's block procedure. The image shows a patient lying on a bed with a double cuff tourniquet applied to their arm. An IV is inserted into the patient's arm, and medication is being administered. The image also labels: Pressure source, Cotton padding, Esmarch bandage, and 0.5% Lidocaine.]

Paravertebral block

- Tuohy needle advanced into paravertebral space
- Advantages: avoid complications of thoracic epidural block, i.e. hypotension, spinal cord injury

Neuraxial blocks

|                   | Spinal                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              | Epidural                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |
| :---------------- | :-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | :------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Deposition site   | Subarachnoid space Endpoint: free-flow CSF Site: L3/4 (Tuffier's line)                                                                                                                                                                                                                              | Epidural space (potential space between ligamentum flavum & dura) Endpoint: loss of resistance (LOR) with saline/air Sites: depend on site of surgery: high/mid thoracic (thoracic surgery), low thoracic (abdominal surgery), lumbar (LL surgery) |
| Needle            | Pencil point 25-27G                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 | Tuohy 16G                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          |
| Onset             | **Faster** (2-5min)                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 | Slower (10-15min)                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  |
| Specific gravity  | Hyperbaric (higher specific gravity than CSF by mixing with D10) - position of patient important                                                                                                                                                                                                    | Not important                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      |
| Agent             | Bupivacaine^ + opioid (fentanyl / morphine)                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    |
| Dosage            | Single dose → limited duration of operation Smaller dose required (< toxic IV dose): high conc., low volume                                                                                                                                                                                         | Continuous infusion via catheter → unlimited duration of operation Larger dose required (> toxic IV dose): low conc., high volume Give with adrenaline (transient tachycardia if misplaced IV)                                                     |
| Indications       | Surgical anaesthesia below the level of umbilicus for max 3h                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        | Surgical anesthesia Analgesia for labour/ post-op pain relief                                                                                                                                                                                      |

|                   | Post-dural puncture headache (PDPH): - Onset 6h-3d after dural puncture - Postural: worse when sitting or straining - Prevention: pencil point / small gauge needle (25/27G) - Mx: o Conservative: bed rest, hydration o Epidural blood patch (10ml own blood injected into epidural space)         |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    |

[Image of four different types of needles, namely Sprott, Whitacre, Quincke and Atraucan. Each needle has a distinct design and shape at its tip, indicating variations in their cutting or non-cutting mechanisms, which are critical in medical procedures to minimize tissue trauma and prevent post-dural puncture headache.]

^Bupivacaine is used in SA/ EA: not associated with any neurotoxicity & long-acting

- Mechanism of hypotension in high thoracic block

* Reduced TPR (arterial vasodilation), reduced CO (venodilation)
* Mx: Vasopressors used intra-op - Ephedrine (alpha + beta) - Phenylephrine (pure alpha) - Atropine (vagal block)
  Structures penetrated
* Skin
* Subcutaneous fat
* Supraspinous ligament
* Interspinous ligament
* Ligamentum flavum
* Dura + arachnoid (SA only)
  Epidural vs IV analgesia
* ↓Respiratory complications: deep breathing possible
* ↓CV complications: bradycardia → ↓stress to heart
* ↓Thromboembolism: vasodilation
  Obstetrics anaesthesia
* Choice of modality: regional anesthesia is safer (unless very urgent)
  - Spinal anesthesia (first line!)
  - Epidural anesthesia: usually for labour pain relief
  - Combined spinal epidural anaesthesia (CSE) (fig.)
    - Insert spinal needle through Tuohy needle for
      bolus SA, then insert EA catheter for additional
      analgesia prn
  - GA: RSI with propofol + suxamethonium +/- nitrous
    oxide inhalation
* Difficult intubation is 8 times more common than normal patients
  - Weight gain and oedema
  - Pre-existing obstetric disease e.g. pre-eclampsia
  - Increase oxygen demand by 20% & reduced oxygen reserve (FRC drop 20%): less apnea time allowed
  - Delayed gastric emptying and relaxed LES due to progesterone → risk of aspiration even with fasting
* Potential issues
  - Mendelson's syndrome (chemical pneumonitis caused by aspiration of acidic stomach contents during
    anesthesia in childbirth): reduced by RSI and antacids (30mL sodium citrate + H2RA/ PPI)
  - Aortocaval compression (supine hypotension syndrome): reduced by left lateral uterine displacement
    - Placenta bed has no autoregulation to compensate for drop in BP

# 1.7 Postoperative care

Pain management

[Diagram illustrating the recognition, assessment, and treatment (RAT) of pain in the brain. The diagram is divided into location of pain and emotional aspect of pain. Starting from the left at the top, an arrow comes from the somatosensory cortex, the level of the cortex. Below the cortex is the thalamus level. The thalamus has an arrow coming from the VPL. Below that is the midbrain with an arrow from the spinothalamic/spinoreticular tract. Below that is the pons. Below that is the medulla with an arrow from the anterolateral system. Below that is the dorsal horn. At the right, at the level of the cortex, there is the association cortex (insular, cingulate, prefrontal) for the emotional aspect of pain. Below that is centrolateral (intralaminar). Below that is the periaqueductal gray which leads to Opioids on the right edge. From the spinothalamic/spinoreticular tract, an arrow leads to the spino-mesencephalic tract, which feeds into the periaqueductal gray. Also Enkephalin comes from the periaqueductal gray and points to the locus coeruleus. The nucleus raphe magnus is below the locus coeruleus and from it comes 5-HT Enkephalin. An arrow comes from the anterolateral system and points to the nucleus raphe magnus. Underneath that there is a circular diagram. It has Lamina I/V (Substance P Glutamate) and substantia gelatinosa. A dotted line points from lamina I/V to the substantia gelatinosa. Next to that is a red box around NSAID. On the right are A delta and C fibers. At the very bottom right are mechanoreceptors. Finally in the bottom left is a polymodal section with Bradykinin, Adenosine, Histamine and PGs inside of it.]

Peripheral sensitization (inflammatory agents e.g. PG, histamine, substance P) vs central sensitization (NMDA receptor in SC)

Recognition

Definitions

- Nociception: detection & transmission of noxious stimuli
- Pain: perception of nociception; **unpleasant sensory & emotional** experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage (IASP 2020)

Factors affecting postoperative pain

- Surgical factors: site of incision (upper abdomen > thoracotomy > lower abdomen > limbs), complications
- Patient factors: genetics, history of substance abuse, history of chronic pain

Assessment

- Severity of pain
  - Subjective: numerical rating scale (NRS), visual analog scale (VAS)
    - Children: FLACC scale (for 2mo-2yo), faces pain scale (FPS)
    - Elderly: PAINAD scale (for advanced dementia), verbal descriptive scale
  - Objective: behaviour (shallow breathing), physiological (BP, HR, RR)
- Type of pain
  - Onset: Acute (<3mo) vs chronic (>3mo)
  - Etiology: Cancer (lower threshold to start opioids) vs non-cancer
  - Mechanism: can be mixed
    - Nociceptive (physiological): tissue injury, protective function
    - Neuropathic (pathological): no protective function
      - Characteristics: neuroanatomically associated deficits, allodynia, hyperalgesia, electric shock / shooting / burning / tingling sensation
    - Nociplastic (interaction of multiple factors → altered neural pathway)
- Other factors: psychological (e.g. anxiety), cultural, religious, personality, social

299

Treatment
Non-pharmacological treatment

- Physical: RICE, splinting & orthosis, physiotherapy, surgery, radiotherapy, acupuncture & massage
- Psychological: counselling, reassurance
- Placebo (no direct therapeutic value)

WHO analgesic ladder: **step up if chronic pain, step down if acute nociceptive pain, avoid strong opioids for chronic non-cancer pain**

- Paracetamol: mild pain, C/I in hepatectomy (liver impairment)
- NSAID:
  - Act at peripheral chemical mediators of pain
  - C/I in
    - Medical: extreme age, poor RFT, poorly controlled asthma, allergy, bleeding tendency, GIB, APO
    - Surgical: NS/ eye symptoms, difficult haemostasis
- Opioids (fig.): act at periaqueductal grey (midbrain) & dorsal horn (spinal cord)

[Image: A line graph showing the percent of peak effect at the site concentration of different opioids over time. The x-axis represents time in minutes since bolus injection, ranging from 0 to 20. The y-axis represents the percent of peak effect, ranging from 0 to 100. Several lines represent different opioids: Pethidine, Morphine, Fentanyl, Alfentanil, and Remifentanil. Each line has a different curvature, illustrating how quickly each opioid reaches its peak effect and how long it lasts. A key beside the graph shows that Pethidine and Morphine have low lipid solubility and a long half-life (T1/2), Fentanyl has high lipid solubility and a long half-life (T1/2), and Alfentanil and Remifentanil have high lipid solubility and a short half-life (T1/2).]

|                |                                                                                                                                                                          |
| :------------- | :----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Mild opioids   | **Tramadol:** weak µ agonist, also act on 5-HT & NE, 1/5000 affinity of morphine                                                                                         |
|                | **Codeine:** 10% metabolized into morphine by CYP2D6 demethylation (8-10% lack this)                                                                                     |
| Strong opioids | **Morphine:** onset 5-15min, high efficacy, intermediate duration (~4h)                                                                                                  |
|                | - IV (1.5mg Q5min up to 5 doses post-op), IM (Q3h prn), epidural, PCA (see below)                                                                                        |
|                | - PO: only 1/3 can enter circulation                                                                                                                                     |
|                | **Pethidine:** long half life, no histamine effect, but antimuscarinic (tachycardia, dry mouth); neurotoxic metabolites can accumulate and cause generalized convulsions |
|                | **Fentanyl:** early onset (~3-5min), long half life, give with some lignocaine to reduce injection site pain                                                             |
|                | **Remifentanil:** early onset (~1min), **short half life** (give as infusion, often with TIVA)                                                                           |

- Side effects of opioids:
  - Respiratory depression: IV naloxone if RR < 8 or unconscious
  - N/V: IV metoclopramide (Maxolon) 10mg q8h / IV ondansetron 4mg q8h prn
  - Hypotension (histamine): reduce dose
  - Pruritus (histamine): r/o allergy, IV chlorpheniramine 10mg q6h prn
  - Urinary retention
  - Constipation
  - Dysphoria / hallucination
- Toxicity: muscle twitching, pinpoint pupil
- Opioid overdose:
  - S/S: drowsiness, respiratory depression, SaO2 drop (late)
  - Mx:
    - Maintain patent airway
    - Verbal stimulation (ask him to breathe) → pain stimulation (sternum rubbing)
    - High-flow O2 + pulse oximetry
    - Failed above or respiratory depression: IV naloxone 0.4mg (0.1mg if PCA) Q2min to desired reversal, closely monitor as S/S may recur as drug action passes

300

- Other adjuvants for neuropathic pain
  - Antidepressants: e.g. TCA, SNRI
  - Anticonvulsants: Ca channel blocker (e.g. gabapentin, pregabalin), Na channel blocker (e.g. carbamazepine)
  - Local anesthetics: e.g. lignocaine
  - Others: e.g. ketamine, Botox

# Methods of postoperative analgesia

| Routes                                |                                                                 |
| ------------------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------- |
| GI tract                              | PO, feeding tubes (e.g. NG tube), PR                            |
| Parenteral                            | IV (e.g. intermittent bolus PCA\*, continuous infusion), IM, SC |
| Neuroaxial                            | Epidural anesthesia (EA), paravertebral block (PVB)             |
| Peripheral nerve block / plexus block | Brachial plexus block (BPB), femoral block, popliteal block     |
| Topical                               | Transmucosal / transdermal (e.g. fentanyl patch)                |

Example regimens according to severity

- Severe pain (NRS ≥ 8): multimodal e.g. IV PCA, neuro-axial blocks (EA, PVB), plexus blocks
- Moderate pain (NRS 5-7): SC/PO morphine 5-10mg q4h prn, tramadol 50-100mg q8h prn
- Mild pain (NRS ≤ 4): paracetamol 500-1000mg q6h, Voltaran 100mg daily

\*Patient-controlled analgesia (PCA)

- Small injections of IV morphine on demand with measures preventing overdose
- Setting:
  - Bolus dose: morphine 1-2mg (adult), 20µg/kg (paediatric)
  - Lock out time: 5-10min
  - 4h max dose: 30mg
- Assessment: pain score (consider increase if >5/10), PCA usage (exceed 4h limit, consumption in 24h), vitals, S/E
- Advantages: better pain relief, less respiratory depression,

# Postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV)

Risk factors

- Patient: Young female, non-smoker, early pregnancy, previous Hx of PONV / motion sickness, obesity
- Anesthetics: GA > RA, opioids, inhalational agents (→ try to use IV propofol)
- Surgery: Eye, ENT, laparoscopy (abdominal / pelvic)
- Post-op: pain, movement, hypotension

[Diagram illustrating the pathophysiology of vomiting. The diagram is broken up into 4 parts, starting from the left is the stimulus section, then the input section, then the integration section and finally the output section on the right.
Under Stimulus are listed: "Pain, repulsive sights and smells, emotional factors", "Inner ear" and "Motion sickness Labyrinth", "Endogenous toxins, drugs", "Stimuli from pharynx and stomach".
Under Input are listed: "Sensory afferents and CNS pathways" and "Vestibular nuclei (H1 and mACh receptors)" and "Visceral afferents (5-HT3 receptors?)".
Under Integration are listed: "Higher centres", "H1 receptor antagonists, muscarinic receptor antagonists", "Dopamine antagonists, aprepitant, 5-HT3 antagonists", and "CTZ (NK1, D2, and 5-HT3 receptors)" and "Nucleus of the solitary tract (mACh and H1 receptors)".
Under Output are listed: "Nerves to somatic and visceral receptors", "Vomiting centre (mACh receptors)", "Muscarinic receptor antagonists", and "5-HT3 antagonists" and "H1 receptor antagonists".]

| Antiemetics          |                                                                                      |
| -------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
| Antihistamine (H1RA) | Cinnarizine, cyclizine, diphenhydramine                                              |
| Antimuscarinic       | Scopolamine                                                                          |
| D2 antagonist        | Prochlorperazine, metoclopramide (cross BBB → EPSE, also encourage gastric emptying) |
|                      | Domperidone (not cross BBB)                                                          |
| 5HT3 antagonist      | Ondansetron (more effective than metoclopramide), topisetron                         |

# 1.8 Ventilator

Goals of mechanical ventilation

- Adequate oxygenation: FIO2
- Adequate CO2 removal
- Minimize adverse effects of mechanical ventilation

Basic structure

- Circuit: single-limb or dual-limb
  - Single-limb systems contain **expiratory valve**: dysfunction can cause rise in PaCO2 (CO2-rich gas passes down the circuit and is rebreathed)
- Heat-moisture exchanger (HME): placed between Y-piece and ETT
  - Heat and moisture deposited on device by expired gas, and picked up by cold dry inspired gas
  - Role: prevent airway mucosal damage and maintain mucociliary clearance

[Single limb circuit with active exhalation valve. The circuit goes from the Ventilator through a Pressurization line and ends at the Patient with an Active exhalation valve]

[Dual limb circuit: The circuit goes from the Ventilator to the Patient and back to the Ventilator. One line is the inspiration line and the other is the expiration line]

Ventilator settings

- Mode: Volume preset assist-control
  - Each breath is initiated by ventilator or by patient - exactly same tidal volume & duration

| Parameter                    | Usual setting | Remarks                                                                                     |
| ---------------------------- | ------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| FIO2                         | 100%          | **Titrate down** and aim SpO2 >94%                                                          |
| PEEP                         | 5-10 cmH2O    | Prevent alveolar collapse during expiration                                                 |
|                              |               | Higher in pneumonia / pulmonary edema / atelectasis: reduce shunting to improve oxygenation |
| Tidal volume                 | 6-8 mL/kg     | Too high will damage the lungs                                                              |
| RR                           |               | Main determinant of CO2 removal (since tidal volume is quite fixed)                         |
|                              |               | Recommended initial settings (**memorize!**)                                                |
|                              |               | Normal metabolic rate, no cerebral injury                                                   |
|                              |               | 12-16                                                                                       |
|                              |               | Normal metabolic rate, **risk of brain injury**                                             |
|                              |               | 14-18                                                                                       |
|                              |               | High metabolic rate (e.g. severe sepsis)                                                    |
|                              |               | 20-25                                                                                       |
|                              |               | Severe **metabolic acidosis**                                                               |
|                              |               | 25-30                                                                                       |
|                              |               | **Expiratory flow restriction** (asthma, COPD)                                              |
|                              |               | 10-12                                                                                       |
| Inspiratory time (I:E ratio) |               | Inspiratory time = inspiratory flow time + inspiratory pause time                           |
|                              |               |                                                                                             |
|                              |               | I:E ratio                                                                                   |
|                              |               | Inspiratory pause time                                                                      |
|                              |               |                                                                                             |
| COPD / asthma                |               | ≥ 1:3                                                                                       |
|                              |               | 0                                                                                           |
| Other conditions             |               | 1:2                                                                                         |
|                              |               | 10%                                                                                         |
| PaCO2                        | 4-7 kPa       | Must be within range if respiratory acidosis (pH ≤7.2) or high ICP                          |
|                              |               | Not used for titration otherwise, allow hypercarbia if COPD/asthma                          |

- Mode: Pressure support
  - All breaths are triggered by patient, but positive pressure is provided to augment inspiration
  - Advantage: reduce work of breathing, relatively comfortable
  - Settings: similar to volume-control
    - Additional **pressure support** (initially set 6-10 cmH2O, then titrate to achieve TV 6-8mL/kg)
- Switching from volume-preset to pressure support
  - Keep FIO2
  - Original peak airway pressure = new PEEP + new PS

302
Troubleshooting

- High airway pressure alarm: usually set at 40 cmH2O (normal peak airway pressure ~30 cmH2O)
  - Causes: high resistance (e.g. sputum retention), low lung compliance (e.g. APO, ARDS, pleural effusion)
  - Also present as "low tidal volume" in pressure-support mode

[Flowchart describing actions to take in case of High Airway Pressure. First decision is to check that the chest wall is rising with inspiration. If not, consider Medical emergency, e.g. complete ETT obstruction - Ask for help. If yes, disconnect from ventilator and manually bag ventilate. If there is High Resistance, pass suction catheter through ETT. If Resistance is encountered, consider ETT: Blockage by secretions, blood, biting. If Patent, check Symmetrical Chest expansion. If No, consider Reduced Compliance unilaterally: Endobronchial intubation, Lung - pneumonia, collapse, Pleural - pneumothorax, pleural effusion. If Yes, consider Increased resistance: bronchospasm: Reduced lung Compliance: Lung - Hyperinflation (COPD/Asthma, Pneumonia, ARDS Pulmonary edema, Abdominal distension or ascites, Patient- ventilator dysnchrony, coughing. If there is Normal Resistance, consider Ventilator/Circuit problem: Check ventilator settings e.g. machine malfunction, inappropriate settings, Check the circuit for kinking, condensation.]

- Desaturation: Set FIO2 to 100%, rule out ventilator problems, and look for underlying cause

[Flowchart describing actions to take in case of Desaturation. Set FiO2=1.0. If Chest moving? is no, Manually ventilate. If Easy to ventilate? is yes, consider Ventilator problem: Check settings & function. If Easy to ventilate? is No, consider ETT/patient problem, see figure 1. If Chest moving? is Yes, Examine patient, In particular look for: Endobronchial intubation, Pneumothorax, Collapse, Pulmonary oedema, Bronchospasm. Treat cause and adjust ventilator settings.]

- Hypotension:
  - Causes:
    - Pharmacological effects: sedatives → vasodilation & myocardial depression
    - PPV: high intrathoracic pressure → obstruction of venous return to Rt heart
    - Hyperinflation of lungs (e.g. COPD, asthma) → obstruction of venous return to Rt heart
    - Tension pneumothorax
  - Management
    - Fluid resuscitation
    - Disconnect from ventilator to see if hyperinflation is the cause
    - Investigate for other causes

Fluids

Implications of fluid / electrolyte disturbances in anaesthesia:

- Hypovolemia → hemodynamic instability (hypotension, tachyarrhythmias) → **poor tolerance to anaesthetic induction**, exaggerated by PPV / surgical maneuvers
- Hypervolemia → tissue edema → respiratory (pulmonary edema), GI (ileus, anastomotic leak), dilutional coagulopathy, impaired wound healing
- Electrolyte disturbance → arrhythmia, choice of fluid therapy, interaction with anesthetic agents (e.g. suxamethonium-induced hyperK)

Maintenance fluid requirement: 4ml/kg/h x first 10kg + 2ml/kg/h x next 10kg + 1 ml/kg/h x additional weight

[A simple infusion set with a 15 µm in-line filter is depicted on the left. A blood infusion set with a 200 µm filter is depicted on the right.]

Goal-directed fluid management: assess physiological parameters (e.g. BP, CVP, Swan-Ganz catheter for PAWP, echo for IVC size) to guide fluid management

No benefits of using colloids over crystalloids in acute resuscitation

2 Urology
2.1 Common urological complaints
Haematuria
Definitions

- Gross haematuria: red-coloured urine visible to naked eye
- Microscopic haematuria: ≥3 RBC/HPF in 2 out of 3 properly collected urine (freshly voided, clean-catch, mid-
  stream urine processed by centrifugation)
  Differential diagnosis
- Most common cause: UTI (60%)
- Most worrying: malignancy (until proven otherwise)
- Others: stone (10%), GN (5%), BPH, trauma, iatrogenic (e.g. post-TURP, post-FC)
  History taking - highlights
- Blood relative to urine stream: beginning (lower urinary tract), throughout (above bladder), terminal (prostate)
- Any blood clots: urological causes (urokinase in glomerular filtrate prevents formation of blood clots)
- Concomitant frothy urine (GN)
- Associated symptoms:
  - Urologic: irritative symptoms (UTI), obstructive symptoms (prostate), loin pain (colicky: stone, constant: infection), passage of stones
  - Autoimmune:
    - Rash: purpuric rash (HSP, GPA), malar rash (SLE)
    - Arthralgia, myalgia (SLE)
  - Respiratory:
    - Recent URTI (IgA nephropathy)
    - Epistaxis, rhinorrhoea (GPA)
    - Pleuritic chest pain, SOB (SLE)
    - Haemoptysis (pulmonary-renal syndrome)
    - Systemic: fever, weight loss, bleeding tendency
- Risk factors: smoking, occupation (hairdresser, rubber industry)
  Physical examination
- Abdomen: loin tenderness, ballotable kidneys, suprapubic masses
- Scrotum: varicocele (esp. left-sided: RCC obstructing left renal v.)
- DRE: prostate enlargement
  Investigations
  Pearls
- All Hb-positive dipstick should be
  accompanied by urine microscopy to
  differentiate haematuria vs pigmenturia
  - Glomerular disease: dysmorphic RBC
    / RBC casts
  - Urological disease: isomorphic RBC
- Antiplatelet/ anticoagulant use is not a
  satisfactory explanation for haematuria,
  except in warfarin OD
- Urine Ix: microscopy (RBC, WBC, casts),
  C/ST (r/o UTI), cytology x 3 (if malignant
  cells → cystoscopy!)

[A flowchart shows how to determine the cause of blood in the urine. The chart begins with a urine dipstick that tests positive for RBCs. From there, the flowchart splits based on whether the patient is treated for a UTI or receives repeat dipstick testing. If a repeat dipstick also shows RBCs, the patient undergoes urine microscopy and culture. If the urine microscopy reveals dysmorphic RBCs or RBC casts, indicating glomerular disease, the patient is referred for nephrology. However, if the urine microscopy reveals isomorphic RBCs, indicating a urologic disease, the patient undergoes a cystoscopy and CTU scan. If the initial dipstick test is positive for proteinuria or the patient has renal insufficiency, they are referred for nephrology. Finally, if a patient with isolated microscopic hematuria does not have an underlying condition or any abnormalities, they undergo periodic follow-up. If the initial urine dipstick is positive for RBCs but repeat dipstick testing is negative, it means the problem is resolved. The patient then undergoes an evaluation for hemoglobinuria or myoglobinuria. If there are risk factors for CA bladder, the patient undergoes a workup. Otherwise, the workup ends there. ]

308

- Upper tract imaging
  - Plain AXR / KUB: from upper pole of R kidney (T12) to pubic symphysis
  - USG: non-invasive, but cannot visualise the whole ureter
  - CT urogram (recommended): non-contrast phase (detect stones), renal parenchymal phase (detect tumors), excretory phase
  - IVU: not much role, except in trauma (5-minute) or pregnancy (reduced radiation)
- Lower tract imaging: cystoscopy
  - Flexible: performed under LA
  - Rigid: for persistent haematuria - allow washout
- If urological cancer is ruled out, treat as CKD, i.e. monitor RFT & urinalysis yearly

Urinary incontinence
Definition: involuntary leakage of urine
Aetiology

- Stress: intra-abdominal pressure > urethral pressure (e.g. constipation, post-partum, pelvic surgery)
- Urge: overactive bladder syndrome / detrusor hyperactivity causing increased intravesical pressure, e.g. infection, neurogenic, drugs (e.g. cholinesterase inhibitor)
- Overflow: chronic urinary retention, e.g. BPH
- Continuous: anatomical abnormalities (e.g. ectopic ureter), bladder fistula - consider in female
  Investigations
- Urine C/ST
- Bladder diary: urine output, voiding pattern, fluid intake pattern
- Urodynamic study to differentiate type if history not diagnostic
- Cystoscopy
  Management
- Lifestyle: weight loss, reduce caffeine intake, smoking cessation
- Stress UI: pelvic floor muscle training + biofeedback (repeated sets, repetition of contraction and relaxation), tension-free vaginal tape (TVT), fascia lata sling
- Urge UI: bladder training, anti-ACh (e.g. oxybutynin, solifenacin), ẞ3-agonist (mirabegron), Botox injection

Recurrent urinary tract infection (UTI)
Approach

- Check documented culture: urine C/ST if not available
  - Culture -ve: consider stones / TB tumor
  - Rule out treatment failure: resistant strain / incorrect antibiotics / poor compliance to Tx
- True recurrent UTI: check culture pattern

|           | Re-infection (different organism)                                                                | Relapsing (same organism)                              |
| :-------- | :----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | :----------------------------------------------------- |
| Pathology | Failure of defence mechanism                                                                     | Structural causes: large RU, cannot eradicate bacteria |
|           | - Post-coital hygiene problem                                                                    | - Stones                                               |
|           | - Voiding dysfunction → large RU                                                                 | - Diverticulum                                         |
|           | - Diabetes                                                                                       | - Foreign body                                         |
| Workup    | Bladder scan: residual volume                                                                    | Imaging / cystoscopy / uroflowmetry                    |
|           | Rule out DM, check habit                                                                         |                                                        |
| Treatment | Treat underlying cause                                                                           |                                                        |
|           | If failed / no cause: Suppressive antibiotics (Septrin, nitrofurantoin), post-coital prophylaxis |                                                        |

Erectile dysfunction
Causes: psychological, systemic (e.g. hormonal, drug), local (vascular)

- Related to atherosclerosis: Increased risk of developing coronary artery disease in 10 years time
  Management:
- PDE5 inhibitors (Viagra): C/I if nitrate use / poor CV function, separate >6h if taking alpha blockers for HT
- Topical PGE2 analogues (Befar): transurethral / intracavernosal
- Surgery: vascular surgery, penile prosthesis
- Others: vacuum pump, low-energy shockwave therapy, stenting (?)

  2.2 Urological emergencies
  Acute scrotum
  Differential diagnosis

- Infection (bacterial / viral)
- **Testicular torsion**
- Torsion of testicular appendix
- Trauma
- Incarcerated inguinal hernia
  Management
- Doppler USG, surgical exploration if in doubt

Acute retention of urine (AROU)
Definition: sudden painful inability to void despite having a full bladder
Causes

- Mechanical
  - Extraluminal: BPH, CA prostate, constipation (fecal impaction), POP, pelvic/GI masses, pregnancy
  - Intramural: CA bladder neck, urethritis, urethral strictures
  - Intraluminal: stones, clots, foreign body
- Functional - Neurological: spinal cord compression (must r/o), peripheral neuropathy (GBS), stroke/Parki - Drug-induced: - Sympathomimetics: ephedrine, phenylephrine (cough mixture) - Anticholinergics: atropine - Post-operative / Prolonged immobility
  Physical examination
- Vitals
- Abdomen: bladder dull on percussion (>150mL) / palpable (>200mL)
- DRE: prostate size/tenderness, masses, anal tone
- - Neurological exam: sensory level
    Investigations
- CBC, RFT, urine dipstix & C/ST
- USG bladder (confirm diagnosis) + USG kidney/ureter (hydronephrosis/hydroureter)
  Immediate management: urethral catheterization (14Fr Foley) for bladder decompression
- Contraindication: urethral trauma (S/S: blood at urethral meatus, high riding prostate)
- Unable to pass into bladder:

| Situation                             | Likely causes      | Management                                                      |
| :------------------------------------ | :----------------- | :-------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Enlarged prostate                     | BPH                | Thicker catheter (20-22 Fr): stiffer and easier to pass through |
| Catheter stuck proximally, Hx of TURP | Urethral stricture | Thinner catheter (10-12 Fr)                                     |

- Still cannot pass Foley: - Tiemann catheter: curved tip designed for BPH - Cystoscopic-guided Foley insertion - Urethral dilators: for strictures - Suprapubic catheterization (~2 fingers above pubic symphysis): end hole (pass guidewire for changing) instead of side hole
  [Image of a foley catheter with a red balloon at the tip and the other end open with multiple ports]
  Subsequent management
- Treat reversible causes: stop offending drugs, treat constipation (e.g. fleet enema) & UTI
- Prescribe alpha blocker (Xatral) + trial wean-off catheter (TWOC) later:
  - Observe urine output and perform post-void bladder scan
  - Re-cath if BS >400mL → re-TWOC / long-term Foley / clean intermittent self-catheterization (CISC)
  - TWOC is C/I if obstructive uropathy (RFT improve after Foley insertion)
- Manage BPH: elective TURP 4-6 weeks after AROU (lower intra-op risk)
  Complications
- Post-obstructive diuresis (UO >200mL/h for ≥2h): closely monitor urine output and fluid/electrolyte status
- Haemorrhage ex-vacuo (transient haematuria due to mucosal disruption)

309

Foley insertion

- Check patient consent
- Check expiry date of foley set, open the set and open non-sterile covering
- Wash hand and wear sterile gloves
- Test patency of the foley balloon
- Use aqueous hibitane (blue/pink) to cleanse penis
- Set sterile zone
- Soak foley with xylocaine gel
- Insertion of foley (till foley fully inserted) (prevent damage to urethra) → observe for urine output
- inflate balloon by injection of water for injection WFI (10ml)
- Pull out foley catheter until resistance
- Connect foley to urine bag
- - Dispose needle of syringe to sharp box

[Image of a urinary drainage system, featuring three different bag types. On the left is a urinary leg bag, which is smaller and designed to be worn discreetly on the leg. In the middle is a standard urinary bag, which is a larger, more conventional drainage bag. On the right is a urine meter, which is a specialized bag with markings to accurately measure urine output. All three bags are transparent to allow for visual monitoring of the urine.]

Left: urinary leg bag Middle: standard urinary bag Right: urine meter
Hydronephrosis
Definition: imaging evidence of dilated renal pelvis and calyses
Types:

- Obstructive:
  - Unilateral: intraluminal (stone), luminal (stricture), extraluminal (tumour, LN)
  - Bilateral: bladder, prostate, urethra, external compression (e.g. CA cervix, uterine prolapse)
- Reflux, e.g. VUR
- Non-obstructive non-reflux, e.g. massive diuresis (e.g. DI), post-obstructive, severe sepsis
  Acute management
- Foley insertion
- Drainage:
  - Indications: symptomatic, sepsis, deranged RFT
  - Choice: PCN vs JJ

|              | Percutaneous nephrostomy (PCN)   | JJ stent                                    |
| :----------- | :------------------------------- | :------------------------------------------ |
| Size         | Larger calibre (8-10 Fr)         | Smaller calibre (6 Fr)                      |
| Preferred in | Tumor obstruction                | Acute stone obstruction                     |
|              | Infective: drain pus             | Less dilated system: difficult to put PCN   |
|              |                                  | Bleeding tendency                           |
| Advantages   | Quicker access and drainage      | More convenient: no need prone and sedation |
|              | Higher success rate              |                                             |
|              | Monitoring U/O possible          |                                             |
|              | Access for anterograde pyelogram |                                             |
|              | Symptom-free                     | Irritative LUTS                             |

- Drain the side that is: symptomatic, better function, easier to drain
- Monitor for post-obstructive diuresis: osmotic diuresis by accumulated substances, causing dehydration, electrolyte disturbance

Investigate for underlying cause:

- Obstructive cause: CT urogram, cystourethroscopy, MAG3/DTPA scans
- Reflux cause: MCUG

Acute loin pain with sepsis
Acute pyelonephritis
Clinical diagnosis
Rule out obstruction: history, KUB, USG
Antibiotics and reassess with USG in 48h
Acute pyelonephrosis
Antibiotics + Emergency drainage
Renal abscess
Antibiotics + Look for underlying cause (e.g. DM, immunosuppression)
Urological trauma
Kidney
Causes: blunt trauma (usually ESWL), penetrating injury
Mostly mild and managed conservatively: protected by ribs, renal capsule & Gerota's fascia for
tamponade effect
Ix: CT abdomen with contrast
Grading: Surgical exploration if AAST Grade 4/5
American Association for Surgery of Trauma Renal Injury Scale
| Grade | Type | Description |
| :---- | :---------- | :--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| I | Contusion | Microscopic or gross haematuria. Urological studies normal. |
| | Haematoma | Subcapsular, non-expanding without parenchymal laceration. |
| II | Haematoma | Non-expanding peri-renal haematoma confined to renal retroperitoneum |
| | Laceration | <1.0cm parenchymal depth of renal cortex with no urinary extravasation |
| III | Laceration | >1.0cm parenchymal depth of renal cortex w/out collecting system rupture or urinary extravasation. |
| IV | Laceration | Parenchymal laceration extending through renal cortex, medulla & collecting system. |
| | Vascular | Main renal artery or vein injury with contained haemorrhage. |
| V | Laceration | Completely shattered kidney. |
| | Vascular | Avulsion of renal hilum that devascularises kidney. |
Ureter
Causes: iatrogenic (colon, AAA, hysterectomy)
Management: stenting, surgical repair
Bladder
Extraperitoneal: conservative Mx (Foley insertion for a few weeks + antibiotics)
Intraperitoneal (risk of peritonitis and SB herniation into bladder): surgical Mx - drain, repair
Urethra Parts of urethra: prostatic, membranous, bulbar, penile
Causes: direct trauma ("sit on something") (bulbar), pelvic fracture (membranous)
S/S: blood at urethral meatus, high-riding prostate, Hx of trauma, failure to void
Bruising pattern: penile bruising (no rupture of Buck's fascia), butterfly bruising from scrotum up to
clavicle (ruptured Buck's fascia)
Ix: retrograde urethrogram (catheter placed in urethral meatus)
Initial management: avoid catheterisation → suprapubic catheter
