2.3 Urinary stones (Urolithiasis)
Overview

- 10% population
- Recurrence rate: 10% / year

Pathophysiology:

- Formation of crystal: supersaturation
- Retain and aggregate to form stones: inflammation, Randall's plaque (calcium crystal in interstitial space of renal papilla - serve as nidus for stone formation)

Risk factors:

- Old age, male, urinary tract abnormalities (e.g. horseshoe kidney)
- Diet: high oxalate, high protein (acid-producing), high sodium (Na & Ca compete for renal reabsorption), high / low Ca (paradoxical: Ca binds to oxalate in GIT → prevent absorption of free oxalate into blood)
- Dehydration
- HyperPTH, milk-alkali syndrome

Types of urinary stone

|                       | Prevalence | Urine pH     | Mechanism                                                                                                                | XR features  | Prevention                                                                                                                                                                                                                             |
| --------------------- | ---------- | ------------ | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ | ------------ | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Calcium (oxalate/PO4) | 85%        | Oxalate: any | Idiopathic (MC) 1° hyperparathyroidism RTA Medullary sponge kidney Ca oxalate: diet (e.g. spinach), IBD                  | Radio-opaque | Increase fluid intake Limit salt <2g/day Avoid animal protein Avoid oxalate-rich food (spinach, chocolate, coffee) **Normal Ca diet** (promote Ca oxalate binding in gut) **High citrous fruit** Treat underlying cause, e.g. hyperPTH |
| Uric acid             | 5%         | Acidic       | As hyperuricaemia: diet, drugs, ↑cell turnover                                                                           | Radiolucent  | Increase fluid intake Low purine diet Urine alkalinisation: NaHCO3, potassium citrate                                                                                                                                                  |
| Struvite / Staghorn   | 5%         | Alkaline     | Formation of MAP (magnesium ammonium phosphate) by urea-splitting organisms, e.g. Proteus vulgaris, Klebsiella, S aureus | Radio-opaque | Antibiotics x 6 weeks Staghorm stone: ≥ 2 calyces                                                                                                                                                                                      |
| Cystine               | 1%         | Acidic       | Cystinuria (AR)                                                                                                          | Radioopaque  | Increase fluid intake Urine alkalinisation Chelating agents, e.g. penicillamine                                                                                                                                                        |

Rare types: indinavir-induced, xanthine/pyruvate stones
_Hardness: struvite < uric acid < calcium phosphate < calcium oxalate < cysteine_

Anatomy of ureter

- Course in KUB: exit renal pelvis at L1/L2, along tip of transverse processes, in front of SIJ, laterally down pelvic wall towards ischial spine, then curve anteromedially into bladder
- 3 parts: upper 1/3, middle 1/3 (at SI joint), lower 1/3
- **3 common sites of obstruction:** Pelvi-ureteric junction (PUJ), pelvic brim (level of common iliac arteries), vesico-ureteric junction (VUJ)

Clinical features

- Pain: renal colic (colicky pain from loin to groin) +/- n/v (obstruction)
- Loin tenderness (obstruction or infection)
- Haematuria
- Irritative symptoms: FUN, dysuria

Complications

- Infection: pyelonephritis, urosepsis
- Obstruction: hydroureter + hydronephrosis (scarring around stone / post-obstructive effect)
- Acute kidney injury (obstructive nephropathy)

Investigations
Initial evaluation

- Imaging:
  - KUB: may miss radiolucent stones / hydronephrosis
  - Non-contrast CT (gold standard): detect urinary stone, urinary tract obstruction (dilated system, perinephric stranding), determine stone density (>1000 HU is considered hard)
  - Dual energy CT (differentiate stone composition)
  - USG (screening test, or C/I to radiation)
- Urine: pH, microscopy, MSU C/ST (r/o UTI before any definitive Tx)
- Bloods: CBC, clotting (before Tx), RFT, CaPO4, urate, PTH

| KUB vs AXR                 |
| -------------------------- |
| - Must see pubic symphysis |
| - Higher radiation dose    |

Before definitive treatment: CT urogram / IV urogram, ± DMSA / RFT (assess kidney function)
After treatment: stone analysis
High risk for recurrence (Young / bilateral / recurrent): full metabolic work-up with 24h urine collection - rule out hyperPTH, Type 1 RTA, etc.

Management

1. Acute management
2. Definitive management
3. Prevention depending on type of stone

Acute management

- Treat / Rule out urosepsis
- Analgesics: NSAID preferred (also reduce ureteric smooth muscle tone)
- Urgent decompression:
  - Indications: obstruction causing sepsis or obstructive uropathy (AKI)
  - Approach: PCN (1st line) vs JJ stent - refer to [hydronephrosis]
  - Monitor for post-obstructive diuresis: dehydration, electrolyte disturbance

Definitive management
Factors to consider

- Stone factor: site, size, composition, complications
- Patient factor: general medical condition, body build, social status
- Surgeon / institutional factor: availability of expertise and equipment

Conservative

- Increased fluid intake 2-3L/day (until urine is light in colour)
- Dietary modifications: normal Ca, low protein / oxalate / salt
  Medical therapy
- Indications: stone < 5mm without complications
- Medical expulsive therapy (MET): alpha blockers (tamsulosin)
  - Only useful for distal ureteric stones (with alpha receptors)
  - FU 4 weeks with KUB, NCCT
- Medical dissolution: potassium citrate / sodium bicarbonate
  - Useful for uric acid / cysteine stones (urine alkalinization)
    313

Surgical therapy

- Overview: Choice of treatment depends on size & location of stone
  - Kidney: ESWL if < 2cm, PCNL if > 2cm, RIRS as last resort
  - Ureter:
    - Upper ureter: ESWL if <2cm, ESWL (+ JJ stent) / URSL if >2cm
    - Middle / Lower ureter: URSL
  - Bladder: cystolithotripsy, treat outflow obstruction (e.g. BPH)
- Treatment options:

| Modality                                                                                           | Preferred in                                                                                                                                                       | Details                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      |
| :------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | :----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | :------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| 1. Extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL) 體外衝擊波碎石術 → Lower efficacy, but non-invasive | Renal stone <2cm / Upper ureteric stone <1cm (Too large: Steinstrasse - multiple "streak of stones" causing blockage → Insert JJ stent before ESWL if large stone) | - Perform under IV sedation and fluoroscopy (or sometimes USG for radio-lucent stones) - Mechanism: high-energy shock wave - Renal stone: 1.5 Hz, 3000x, Level 6 - Ureteric stone: 1.5 Hz, 4000x, Level 7 - Position: supine (prone if obstructed by pelvic bone) - C/I: pregnancy, UTI, bleeding tendency (should withhold all antithrombotics), angiomyolipoma - Not preferred: obesity (large skin-to-stone distance), hard stones, unfavourable locations (lower pole of kidney, mid/lower ureter) - Complications: bleeding (perinephric haematoma), incomplete stone fragmentation, infection, hypertension, kidney parenchymal injury |
| 2. Percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) - nephroscope 經皮腎鏡取石術                                | Renal stone >2cm Hard / complex stones (e.g. cystine, Ca oxalate, staghorn) Unfavourable locations                                                                 | - Perform under GA, antibiotics on induction, prone position, insertion of nephroscope, lithotripsy by ultrasound, mechanical or laser - ± nephrostomy tube: post-op drainage, access for 2nd look PCNL - Complications: GA risks, bleeding, infection (flush bacteria into bloodstream), kidney rupture, bowel perforation                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  |
| 3. Ureteroscopy with lithotripsy (URSL) - ureteroscope 輸尿管鏡碎石術                              | Middle / lower ureteric stone Coagulopathy (minimally invasive)                                                                                                    | - Perform under GA, semi-rigid ureteroscope, - Small stones extracted by baskets / forceps - Large stones fragmented by ultrasound / mechanical / laser lithotripsy before extraction - Complications: ureteral perforation, flush-back stone (esp. upper ureteric stone) - Flexible URSL                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    |
| Retrograde intrarenal surgery (RIRS)                                                               | Last resort for renal stones (failed PCNL)                                                                                                                         |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              |
| 4. Laparoscopic / Robotic ureterolithotomy                                                         | Large ureteric stones (rarely done)                                                                                                                                |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              |
| 5. Open nephrolithotomy                                                                            | Rare                                                                                                                                                               |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              |

- Bilateral disease: consider - Obstruction side - Individual kidney function: nuclear scan (DMSA) - save better one first, non-functional kidney may be managed conservatively if asymptomatic - Symptomatic side

  2.4 **LUTS & BPH**
  Approach to lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS)
  Traditional LUTS: "FUN" + "DISH"
  | Phase | Symptoms | Details | Causes |
  |--------------|----------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
  | Storage phase | **Irritative** | Frequency 尿频 | Local pathology: stone, UTI, tumor, post-RT, post-op |
  | | | Urgency 尿急 ± urge incontinence | Regional: detrusor overactivity |
  | | | Nocturia 夜尿 | Systemic: increased fluid intake / polyuria (DM, DI) |
  | Voiding phase | **Obstructive** | Dribbling 尿末滴漏 (weakened pelvic floor) | Outflow problem: **BPH, CA prostate**, urethral stricture |
  | | | Intermittent 尿流斷續(residual urine) | |
  | | | Incomplete emptying 尿意未盡 | |
  | | | Straining 谷 (higher bladder pressure needed) | |
  | | | Hesitancy 等尿 | Bladder problem: hypocontractility (nerve, detrusor muscle) |

Other symptoms: pain, haematuria, stone

Physical examination:

- General condition: any neurological cause
- Abdomen: distended bladder
- Genitalia: phimosis
- DRE: anal tone, prostate size

**Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)**
**Overview**
Definition: proliferation of stromal component in transitional zone of prostate
Etiology: unknown

- Prostate starts increase in size at age **40** - usually become symptomatic at ~50 years old
  Pathophysiology
- Obstruction:
  - Static component: stromal hyperplasia mediated by dihydrotestosterone (DHT) via 5a-reductase - 5aRI
  - Dynamic component: **smooth muscle** hypertrophy & contraction by a1 receptors - a1 blockers
- Irritation: detrusor instability causing overactive bladder
- Complications: ↑residual urine, causing infection & stone
  Clinical features
- Typical age: **50-80**
- **LUTS**: both obstructive and irritative Sx (**obstructive** >> irritative)
- Complications:
  - Prostate level: bleeding (ruptured dilated bladder neck veins)
  - Bladder level: **AROU, recurrent UTI, bladder stone**, diverticulum, chronic ROU ± overflow incontinence
  - Upper tract: **Recurrent hydronephrosis**, obstructive uropathy, renal failure
- DRE: smooth enlarged > 3FB, non-tender, median sulcus present, anal tone intact

**Investigations**
Basic investigations:

- **International prostate symptom score (IPSS)**: quantify LUTS (obstructive + irritative + QoL)
- **Voiding diary** / Frequency-volume chart: **at least 3 days**, esp. if frequency / nocturia
- Urine: **urinalysis**, microscopy, C/ST (r/o UTI)
- **Uroflowmetry (fig.)**: to confirm obstruction
  - Volume voided > 150ml to be representative of usual voiding habit
  - Peak urine flow rate (Qmax): diagnostic (<15mL/sec), prognostic (<10mL/sec: better outcome after TURP)
  - Abnormal strain pattern (multiple peaks)
  - Post-void residual volume: <150mL

Other investigations:

- Bloods: RFT, PSA (r/o CA prostate)
- Upper tract imaging: if large residual volume / haematuria / Hx of stone
- TRUS: assess size of prostate (use of 5ARI, surgery planning)
- Cystoscopy / Urodynamic study

BPH" reaches a peak lower than "a. Normal" around Time = 7s and then gradually decreases to 0 around Time = 15s. The graph in "c. Urethral stricture" reaches a peak much lower than "a. Normal" around Time = 10s and then gradually decreases to 0 around Time = 15s.]

316

Management
Indications for treatment:

- IPSS moderate or above (≥8)
- Complications (refer above)
  Conservative Indications: symptoms do not bother patient
  Lifestyle modifications: Avoid caffeine / tea, drinking water few hours before sleep, etc
  Medical α1 adrenergic blockers (MC): relax smooth muscles in prostate & bladder neck (NOT body)
- Non-selective: more orthostatic hypotension, nasal congestion, dizziness, tiredness
  - Prazosin (Minipress), terazosin (Hytrin), doxazosin (Cardura), alfuzosin (Xatral)
- Selective (α1A blockers): more retrograde ejaculation
  - Tamsulosin (Harnal), silodosin (Rapaflo)
- To reduce S/E: slow titration, subtype-selective (α1A), slow-release formulations

[Diagram of the lower urinary tract. It labels Muscarinic receptors (M3 subtype (selective)), a1-Adrenergic receptors, dynamic bladder outlet obstruction, prostate gland, a1-Reductase enzymes (Type 1, Type 2), and Phosphodiesterase enzymes (Type 5) in the inferior gland]

5α reductase inhibitors: reduce DHT → decrease size of prostate + decrease vascularity (less bleeding) + progression prevention

- Drugs: finasteride, dutasteride
- 2nd line / in combination with α1-blockers: slow onset (3-6 months for max effect)
- Preferred for larger glands ≥30-40ml (TRUS) / IPSS ≥ 12
- S/E: erectile dysfunction (10%), gynaecomastia
- 50% decrease in PSA: multiply PSA by 2 when screening for CA prostate

PDE5 inhibitor (tadalafil/ Cialis): avoid if using nitrate

Drugs for OAB: anticholinergics (C/I if RU >150mL due to risk of AROU), beta 3 agonist

Minimally invasive therapy
Thermotherapy: HIFU, TUMT (transurethral microwave therapy)
UroLift: implants to hold different parts of prostate away from prostatic urethra
Steam treatment (Rezum): induce coagulative necrosis
Prostatic artery embolisation (PAE): reduce part of blood supply to prostate

Transurethral
surgery
Others
317
Indications: failed medical therapy, recurrent complications
Modalities:

- Electrocautery: TURP (monopolar / bipolar), EVP (electrovarporization)
- Laser: Holium Laser prostatectomy (HoLRP), PVP (photo-selective vaporisation of prostate
  / Green Laser)
  Long term catheterization: Foley/SPC/CISC
  Metallic stent: temporary for very unfit patients

Transurethral resection of prostate (TURP)

- Procedures: spinal anesthesia, lithotomy position, cystoscopy (1.5% glycine), resection with electric knife
- 3-way Foley post-op to irrigate bladder with NS to avoid clot retention
- Specific complications:
  - Bleeding, infection
  - Perforation: can form fistula
  - TUR syndrome:
    - Patho: dilutional hypoNa + fluid overload + glycine toxicity
    - Risk factors: long OT time, e.g. massive prostate
    - S/S: nausea (1st), confusion, cerebral oedema, visual disturbance
    - Mx: manage as hypoNa (electrolytes, serum osmolality, volume status), hypertonic NS
    - Prevention: use bipolar (NS as irrigating fluid), limit volume < 1L & irrigation pressure <60 mmHg
  - Retrograde ejaculation (70-80% due to resection of bladder neck)
  - Urethral stricture (urethral instrumentation)
  - Incontinence (1%): urge (early) / stress (late)

Irritative LUTS
Approach

- Establish frequency (daytime symptoms +ve) but not pure nocturia
- Perform voiding diary / frequency-volume chart: assess urine output, voiding pattern, fluid intake pattern
  - High urine output: look for cause of polyuria
  - Low urine output: true frequency
    - Detrusor hypersensitivity: nerve problem, local causes, de novo
    - Capacity problem

Overactive bladder syndrome (OAB) if no other causes identified

- Exclude infection / stone / tumor
- Clinical Dx by bladder diary
  - Frequent voiding of small volumes
  - Normal prostate on DRE
  - Good flow rate on uroflowmetry
- Management:
  - Bladder training
  - Anticholinergics: oxybutynin / solifenacin
    - S/E: dry mouth, dry eye, constipation, cognitive impairment
  - Beta-3 agonist: mirabegron
    - S/E: elevated BP (>10%)

318

2.5 Urological neoplasm
Prostate cancer
Overview

- Adenocarcinoma arising in the peripheral zone of the gland
- 3rd MC cancer among males in HK, lifetime risk: 1/26, annual incidence: ~2300
- 1/3 is locally advanced / metastatic upon presentation
  Risk factors:
- Advanced age
- Smoking
- FHx (age & number of FDR)
- Genetics: TMPRSS2-ETS fusion gene (50%)
  Clinical features
- Incidental findings: abnormal DRE, elevated PSA
  - DRE (only 25% palpable): asymmetrically enlarged irregular prostate, hard nodule, midline sulcus lost
- Obstructive LUTS (late findings - cancer arises in peripheral zone)
- Haematuria / haemospermia, new-onset erectile dysfunction
- Metastasis: bone (vertebra: via Batson's venous plexus), liver, adrenal
  Investigations
- PSA (arbitrary cutoff at < 4 ng/mL)
  - Higher level = greater chance of CA prostate & higher risk of advanced disease
- Controversy of PSA
  - Organ-specific but not tumor-specific
  - Function of PSA: liquefy semen coagulum
  - Upper normal limit should be age-related
  - Factors affecting PSA level
    - ↑PSA: CA prostate, BPH, AROU, UTI, vigorous cycling, recent ejaculation <48h, DRE
    - ↓PSA: castration, 5α reductase inhibitors, prostate RT
  - PSA screening:
    - Not for age < 40 or >77 (with life-expectancy < 10 years)
    - May be considered for age 55-77
    - May be considered for age 40-55 with family history
- Prostate health index (PHI) if PSA 4-10 + normal DRE
  - Components: total PSA, free PSA, P2PSA (cancer-specific)
  - > 35: proceed to prostate biopsy
- Prostate biopsy:
  - Indications:
    - Elevated PSA > 10
    - Abnormal DRE
    - PHI > 35
    - Early CA prostate on active surveillance
    - Abnormal MRI prostate (PI-RADS 4-5)
  - Approach: transrectal (with TRUS or MRI), transperineal (TPUS or MRI)
    - "Fusion biopsy": combine MRI image with USG
  - Check MSU 1 week prior to procedure: treat UTI if +ve
  - Take 12-18 random systematic biopsies
  - Complications:
    - Bleeding: haematuria, PR bleed, haemospermia
    - Infection (<0.5% for transperineal, ~5% for transrectal: antibiotic prophylaxis with FQ required)
    - AROU (1-2%): pain and swelling of prostate

[Diagram showing Gleason's Pattern for prostate cancer. It illustrates different patterns based on the arrangement of glands and stroma in a prostate tissue sample, with each pattern corresponding to a grade. The diagram shows 5 different patterns from top to bottom: Pattern 1 shows small, uniform glands. Pattern 2 shows more stroma between the glands. Pattern 3 shows distinctly infiltrative margins. Pattern 4 shows irregular masses of neoplastic glands. Pattern 5 shows only occasional gland formation.]

| Grade group | Gleason score | Gleason pattern  |
| ----------- | ------------- | ---------------- |
| 1           | ≤6            | ≤3+3             |
| 2           | 7             | 3+4              |
| 3           | 7             | 4+3              |
| 4           | 8             | 4+4, 3+5, 5+3    |
| 5           | 9 or 10       | 4+5, 5+4, or 5+5 |

- Grading: Gleason score (1-5, sum of 2 most common histological patterns)
- Further classified into 5 groups for prognostication: higher group = more likely to have non-organ- confined disease
- Multiparametric MRI prostate
  - 3 sequences: T2-weighted, DWI with ADC (apparent diffusion coefficient), DCE (dynamic contrast-enhanced)
  - PI-RADS system: score from 1-5
  - Roles: determine need of biopsy in controversial cases (PI-RADS 4, 5 indicated); local staging

Staging
AJCC 8th edition staging system

- Combined use of TNM, serum PSA level & Gleason group
- T staging
  - T1: clinically undetectable (normal DRE)
  - T2: palpable on DRE but confined to prostate
  - T3: spread beyond prostatic capsule (e.g. T3b = seminal vesicle invasion)
  - T4: invade to pelvic side wall
    Staging workup: depend on risk stratification

| Definition | Low-risk                  | Intermediate-risk        | High-risk                                         |
| :--------- | :------------------------ | :----------------------- | :------------------------------------------------ |
|            | PSA < 10 ng/mL            | PSA 10-20 ng/mL          | PSA > 20 ng/mL                                    |
|            | and GS < 7 (ISUP grade 1) | or GS 7 (ISUP grade 2/3) | any PSA                                           |
|            | and cT1-2a                | or cT2b                  | or GS > 7 (ISUP grade 4/5) any GS (any ISUP grade |
|            | Localised                 |                          | or cT2c                                           |
|            |                           |                          | cT3-4 or cN+                                      |
|            |                           |                          | Locally advanced                                  |

GS = Gleason score; ISUP = International Society for Urological Pathology; PSA = prostate-specific antigen.

- Low risk: Multiparametric MRI prostate
- High risk (e.g. PSA > 20, GS ≥ 8): **PET-CT with PSMA** (prostate-specific membrane antigen), _c.f._ FDG
  - Superior to CT abdomen & pelvis + CXR + bone scan (Technetium-99 bone scintigraphy) - _HA practice_

Management of local disease
Patient factor: age, co-morbidities
Disease factors: PSA, DRE findings, Gleason score

|                                     | Procedures                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           | Preferred in                       | Limitations                                                                                                                                                                                             |
| :---------------------------------- | :------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | :--------------------------------- | :------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
| Active surveillance\*               | Regular FU with **serial DRE, PSA & biopsy for Gleason score** → Offer RP/ RT only if worsen - Avoid early Tx-related complications                                                                                                                                  | Low risk localised disease (T1/T2) | Disease progression Risk associated with repeated biopsy                                                                                                                                                |
| Radical prostatectomy (RP)          | - Robotic-assisted resection of prostate gland + seminal vesicles + ampulla of vas deferens - ± pelvic LN dissection in obturator & iliac regions (only for staging in **high risk**; no benefit in overall survival) - Anastomosis of bladder neck & urethral stump | Young <75y High risk disease       | Early: bleeding, UTI, rectal injury (1%), ureteric injury Late: stress urinary incontinence (10%), erectile dysfunction (50%), anastomotic stricture (urethra, bladder neck), residual tumor/recurrence |
|                                     | [Diagram of bladder and prostate area: The diagram shows the bladder with the connected urethra. The vas deferens connect to the seminal vesicles, which are located behind the prostate gland. A prostate tumor is visible inside the prostate gland.]              |                                    |
| Radiotherapy (EBRT / brachytherapy) | - Avoid risk of surgery & GA, but **equivalent oncological control**                                                                                                                                                                                                 | Older                              | ↓ Stress UI, similar ED c.f. RP ↑Irritative symptoms (FUN), radiation proctitis, radiation cystitis                                                                                                     |

\*Different from watchful waiting (palliative intent, for life expectancy < 10y)

Management of advanced / metastatic disease
Choice of treatment:

- Traditional approach: ADT monotherapy first → add others if CRPC
- New approach: upfront chemohormonal therapy to destroy potential CRPC clones

Options
Androgen
deprivation
therapy (ADT)
Modalities

- Surgical castration: bilateral simple orchidectomy (access via scrotal incision)
- Medical castration: traditionally use estrogens
  | | | |
  | :-------------- | :-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | :----------------------------------- |
  | MoA | LHRH agonist (e.g. goserelin) + short-term antiandrogen cover (e.g. flutamide x 4/52) | LHRH antagonist (e.g. degarelix) |
  | | Downregulate gonadal axis (constant dose to mask normal LHRH pulsatility) | |
  | Dosing | Q3-6m (more convenient) | Q1m |
  | Pros | Cheaper ☺ | Faster onset |
  | | | ? Less CV risk |

S/E: osteoporosis, metabolic syndrome, thromboembolism, erectile dysfunction
Chemotherapy
Add if patient young & fit with good RFT; improve survival if high-volume metastases

- Docetaxel
- Cabazitaxel
  Androgen receptor
  targeted agents
  (ARTA)
  Others
- Abiraterone: CYP17 inhibitor, need maintenance steroids to prevent adrenal crisis
- Enzalutamide: potent multi-targeted AR antagonist
- Apalutamide
- Sipuleucel T: immunotherapy
- Radium 223: with bone-seeking element

Castration-refractory prostate cancer (CRPC)

- Mechanisms:
  - Adrenal production of minor androgens
  - Tumor upregulation of androgen receptors
  - Tumor cells produce ectopic androgens

Bladder cancer
Overview
Types & risk factors (M:F = 3:1)
| Cell type | Prevalence | Risk factors |
| :------------------------------ | :--------- | :--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Transitional cell carcinoma (Urothelial carcinoma) | 98% | Smoking |
| | | Occupational chemical exposure (petrol / rubber / dye) |
| | | Cyclophosphamide |
| | | Concurrent upper tract TCC |
| | | Chronic cystitis (e.g. pelvic RT) |
| Squamous cell carcinoma | Rare | Chronic cystitis: Schistosoma haematobium (TOCC to Egypt), long-term indwelling catheter, bladder stones |
| Adenocarcinoma | Rare | |

Clinical features

- Painless gross haematuria throughout the stream (must rule out malignancy!)
- LUTS: irritative symptoms (in situ) → obstructive symptoms (tumor obstruct ureteric orifice / bladder neck)
- Metastasis: bone pain, RUQ pain / jaundice, SOB
- Constitutional symptoms

321

Investigations

- CBC, LRFT, urinalysis, MSU C/ST, urine cytology (low sensitivity, high specificity)
- Lower urinary tract workup: Flexible cystoscopy (gold standard) ± biopsy (NOT a must → direct TURBT)
- Upper urinary tract workup: CT urogram (delayed phase at 3-5 min to look for filling defects along urinary
  tract; arterial phase to look for LN involvement / metastasis), IV urogram
- Staging work-up: CXR, CT A+P, bone scan

Staging
Concept: Most important is whether it invades muscularis propria

- Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer (NMIBC): Tis / Ta / T1 disease
- Muscle invasive bladder cancer (MIBC): T2 disease or above

[An image showing a diagram of bladder cancer staging. The image shows different stages of bladder cancer, including Tis, Ta, T1, T2a, T2b, T3, and T4. Each stage shows how deeply the cancer has invaded into the layers of the bladder wall. The labels and annotations provide visual information about the disease progression.]

Management: non-muscle invasive bladder cancer
Approach: TURBT + post-op mitomycin C → pathological Dx & staging → non-muscle invasive (± 2nd TURBT /
intravesical BCG / FC surveillance) vs muscle invasive (radical cystectomy & urinary diversion / RT)

Transurethral resection of bladder tumour (TURBT)

- Roles:
  - Diagnostic: Ascertain diagnosis, obtain T-staging (non-muscle invasive vs muscle invasive)
  - Therapeutic: Potential cure if non-muscle-invasive
- Procedures:
  - Piecemeal → no histological proof on resection margins
  - Immediate post-op intravesical mitomycin C (not BCG: risk of infection)
    - Mitomycin C (cytotoxic alkylating agent): reduce recurrence but NOT progression rate (c.f. BCG)
    - Give only if confirmed non-muscle-invasive (reduce recurrence)
    - S/E: chemical cystitis, rash

Pathology confirmed non-muscle invasive cancer

- EAU guideline for risk stratification: - Low risk: Ta & low-grade & solitary & ≤ 3cm - High risk: Tis / T1, high-grade, multiple/recurrent, >3cm
  | 2nd TURBT | High risk Specimen not involving muscle | Detect residual disease in 20-30% cases who had 'complete resection' in 1st TURBT |
  |---|---|---|
  |Intravesical BCG | High risk Carcinoma-in-situ (1\* line Tx) | Reduce recurrence AND progression rate - Immunotherapy: Live-attenuated vaccine (Mycobacterium bovis) that triggers cytokine release against cancer cells Start 3 weeks post-op - PWH regimen: induction (weekly x 6) + maintenance (weekly x 3 at 3mo, x3 at 6mo, x3 at 12mo) - Compliance issues - Troublesome regimens: 15 doses for 1 year in total • S/E: irritative symptoms, infection (anti-TB drugs)|
  |Flexible cystoscopy surveillance | Low risk High risk | 3mo, 12mo, then Q1y x 5 Q3m for 2 years, then Q6m for 3 years, then Qly (can be lifelong) + Qly upper tract imaging (CTU) + cytology|

Management: muscle invasive bladder cancer

- **Radical cystectomy:** bladder + bilateral pelvic LN dissection (external iliac, internal iliac, obturator nodes) + adjacent organs (M: prostate, seminal vesicles, ± urethra; F: HBSO, part of vagina, ± urethra)
  - Pelvic LN dissection offers _survival benefit_ (c.f. CA prostate) because microscopic metastasis is common

[Diagram of Cystectomy in Male, showing the bladder, seminal vesicles (glands), prostate, and urethra with annotations describing that the prostate and seminal vesicles are often removed, and the urethra may also be removed.]

[Diagram of Cystectomy in Female, showing the fallopian tubes, uterus, ovaries, bladder, vagina, and urethra with annotations describing that the urethra, uterus, ovaries, fallopian tubes, and part of the vagina are often removed.]

- Surgical: open, laparoscopic, robotic-assisted laparoscopic
- Complications of cystectomy
  - Anastomotic leakage & stricture: bowel anastomosis, ureteric-enteral anastomosis
  - Lymphocele: pelvic LN dissection
  - **Erectile dysfunction:** consider nerve-sparing surgery if young + early stage low grade disease
  - **Urinary stress incontinence** (removal of prostate)
  - **Bowel injury**
  - Post-operative ileus
  - Residual tumor / recurrence

- Urinary diversion

[Diagram of Ileal conduit, showing the kidneys, ureters, stoma (outside the body), and conduit (inside the body).]

[Diagram of Neobladder (orthoptic bladder substitution), showing the kidneys, ureters, and neobladder.]

[Diagram of Continent pouch, showing the kidney, ureter, continence tunnel which is catheterized to empty urine, catheter, and new bladder or pouch.]

| Type                   | Non-continent                                                                             | Continent (ext. sphincter intact)                                                                                                                        | Continent (submucosal tunnel at oblique angle - act as valve)                                |
| ---------------------- | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Procedures             | Ureters attached to a segment of ileum (~15cm), then brought to surface as a stoma at RLQ | **Artificial bladder** constructed by a length of ileum (detubularized into sheet → reconfigured into reservoir to store urine)                          | Pouch created by appendix Submucosal tunnel for self- catheterization → Opening at umbilicus |
| Limitations            | Non-continent                                                                             | Require **good renal function** (eGFR ≥ 45): waste reabsorption Education: voiding by sphincter relaxation & **Valsalva maneuver**, self-catheterization |                                                                                              |
| Specific complications | Stoma complications (hernia, prolapse, retraction) Less NAGMA & UTI                       | NAGMA (reabsorption of NH4Cl in exchange for HCO3) **Urinary stasis** (SB muscle cannot contract voluntarily): recurrent UTI, AROU, stones               |                                                                                              |

Advantage of using ileum: abundant blood supply, long mesentery, low risk of metabolic Cx, ease of use
Disadvantage of using ileum: reabsorb waste from urine, cannot voluntarily control SB contraction

- Neoadjuvant chemotherapy: often considered for T2+/N+
  - Increase complete resection rate, reduce tumor load
  - Cisplatin/carboplatin-based
- Radiotherapy: for patients not fit for surgery
  - Inferior oncological outcome compared to surgery

Management: metastatic disease

- Chemotherapy: platinum-based
- Immunotherapy
- Palliative surgery: e.g. cystectomy (for symptomatic relief), percutaneous nephrostomy (decompression)

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC)
Overview

- Most common renal neoplasm (only 20% renal masses are benign: e.g. oncocytoma, angiomyolipoma)
- Prevalence of kidney cancers: RCC (MC) >> TCC renal pelvis > nephroblastoma (Wilm's tumor)
  Pathology
- Clear cell carcinoma (85%) - usually found in proximal tubule
- Others: papillary (10%), chromophobe, collecting duct (poor prognosis)
  Risk factors
- Smoking, HT, obesity
- Occupation (petroleum)
- Genetics: von-Hippel-Lindau (VHL), tuberous sclerosis, PKD
- Acquired cystic diseases (long-term HD/PD)
- Renal transplant on immunosuppressants

Clinical features: often asymptomatic until advanced disease

- Incidental finding on imaging (50-60%)
- Classical triad (10-20%): haematuria + flank pain + palpable renal mass
- Regional involvement: uniquely invade into renal vein, IVC, RA
  - Left 2º varicocele: invasion to left renal vein
  - LL edema, ascites, pulmonary embolism
- Metastasis: retroperitoneal LN, lung, bone
- Paraneoplastic syndrome (common, 6-10%)
  - Anemia of chronic disease
  - Endocrine: hypercalcaemia (vit D hydroxylation, PTHrP), polycythaemia (EPO), HT (renin)
  - Non-metastatic liver dysfunction (Stauffer syndrome): abnormal LFT, fever

Investigations

- Diagnostic: **CT abdomen with contrast → nephrectomy for pathology**
  - Classical appearance: renal parenchymal mass with thickened irregular walls and contrast enhancement
  - Role of USG: determine cystic vs solid (e.g. fat-filled - likely AML)
  - Renal mass biopsy is usually NOT indicated: risk of bleeding, tumor seedling, false negative results (20%)
    - Suspected lymphoma
    - Metastatic RCC in poor surgical candidate (guide Tx)
    - Suspected renal abscess
    - Strongly enhancing extrarenal primary lesion (e.g. lung, liver, colon, melanoma)
- Staging: CT T+A+P with contrast / PET-CT scan
- Prognostic: Fuhrman's grading (nuclear size)

TNM staging

- T1: ≤7cm (T1a: ≤4cm, T1b: 4-7cm), within kidney
- T2: > 7cm (T2a: 7-10cm, T2b: >10cm), within kidney
- T3: extend into perinephric tissues or major veins including IVC
- T4: extend beyond Gerota's fascia (fibrous tissue that encapsulates kidney and adrenal gland) and/or into ipsilateral adrenal gland

The right section is an illustration of a kidney, with notations indicating "Gerota's fascia" on the upper right side, "Adrenal gland" and "Vein" slightly below it, "Artery" and "Ureter" further down, and sizes marked at "T1" with less than or equal to 7cm and "T2" with greater than 7cm. The renal capsule, cortex, and medulla are also labeled.]

Management
Resectable tumors: surgery
| | Partial nephrectomy | Radical nephrectomy |
| :-------------------- | :-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | :------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Preferred in | - T1 (<7cm) + **peripherally located** - Bilateral disease / multiple tumors - Solitary functional kidney / poor RFT on contralateral kidney | - Tumors >7cm/ Centrally located - Renal vein / IVC / adrenal gland involvement - LN involvement |
| Procedure | - Temporarily clamp renal vessels to remove tumor, and suture repair the kidney defect - Warm ischemia time <30min: barbed suture (e.g. Stratafix), early arterial unclamping after suturing inner layer, selective arterial clamping - c.f. Cold ischemia time 1-2h: ice pack, inject cold fluid into ureter - Resection margin: limited role, +ve does not necessarily predict recurrence | - Remove kidney with ligation of renal artery, vein and ureter (ligate artery first!) - Dissect external to Gerota's fascia - No need resect ipsil. ureter (c.f. TCC) - + Ipsilateral adrenalectomy (**not** routine, only if suspected invasion) - + retroperitoneal LN dissection - + IVC thrombectomy\* |
| Specific complications | Bleeding, urine leakage, recurrence in ipsilateral kidney | Injury to surrounding organs (R: D2, liver; L: spleen, tail of pancreas) |

Approaches: Open / laparoscopic / robotic-assisted laparoscopic

- Transperitoneal: more spacious operative field (allow triangulation of ports), but risk of post-op ileus
- Retroperitoneal: less manipulation of bowels, allow early ligation of arteries (enter from the back)

[Image of Transperitoneal and Retroperitoneal Surgical Approaches, showing the anatomical differences in accessing the kidney]

\*Grading of cavoatrial involvement
| Level 1: <2cm above renal vein | Simple thrombectomy |
| :----------------------------------------------------------- | :--------------------------------------- |
| Level 2: below intrahepatic IVC | |
| Level 3: involve intrahepatic IVC, below diaphragm | Consider cardiopulmonary bypass |
| Level 4: involve atrium | |

- adjuvant pembrolizumab (if high risk of locoregional recurrence)

* Unfit for surgery:
  - Radiofrequency ablation
  - Cryotherapy
  - Active surveillance for small asymptomatic lesions
* Metastatic disease:
  - RCC is traditionally resistant to chemoRT
  - Targeted therapy
    - TKI: e.g. **sunitinib**, sorafenib
    - Anti-VEGF: bevazicumab
    - mTOR inhibitors: temsirolimus, everolimus
  - Immunotherapy
    - IL-2 high dose
    - Checkpoint inhibitors: e.g. pembrolizumab

# Testicular tumour

## Overview

Most common solid CA in males 15-35 yo
Risk factors: cryptorchidism, Klinefelter syndrome, family
history, infertility

## Types

- Germ cell tumours (95%): malignant, divided into seminoma and NSGCT in 1:1 ratio
- Sex cord-stromal tumours (5%): benign, e.g. Sertoli cell tumor, Leydig cell tumor
- Others: e.g. lymphoma

## Clinical features

- Painless testicular mass, dull discomfort
- Secondary hydrocele
- Abdominal pain / distension: metastasis to **para-aortic LN** (can be very large)
- Gynaecomastia /hyperthyroidism (hCG)

## Investigations

- Tumour markers: **LDH, AFP, HCG** - for diagnosis of NSGCT and monitoring after treatment
- **USG scrotum**: seminoma (well-defined hypoechoic) vs NSGCT (indistinct margins, cystic areas / calcifications)
- Staging: CT **T + A + P** with contrast
- Pathological diagnosis by **radical orchiectomy**
- Do **NOT** do FNAC/biopsy (tumor seedling to scrotal skin → inguinal LN)

## Staging

AJCC TNM-S staging: note that

- T staging: scrotal invasion is cT4, otherwise determined by radical orchidectomy findings (pT staging)
- S staging: serum tumor marker levels
- Overall up to Stage IIIC only, Stage IV does not exist

## Management

- Scrotal exploration + **radical inguinal orchidectomy** (remove testis + spermatic cord) + **retroperitoneal LN dissection**
  - Allow histological diagnosis and staging
  - To prevent tumour seeding along testicular vein
    - **Inguinal** incision instead of scrotal incision (prevent spreading to scrotal skin)
    - Clamp cord before mobilizing testis
- Adjuvant: **RT** (seminoma), **chemotherapy** (both)
- Fertility preservation: e.g. cryopreservation of sperm

| Seminoma         | Non-seminoma GCT (NSGCT)        |
| ---------------- | ------------------------------- |
| 50%              | 50%                             |
| Age 30-40        | Age variable                    |
| Present early    | Present late                    |
| Lymphatic spread | Haematogenous spread            |
| No markers       | LDH, AFP (80-85%), HCG (80-85%) |
| Radiosensitive   | Radioresistant                  |
| 90% curable      | Prognosis varies with subtypes: |
|                  | - Choriocarcinoma               |
|                  | - Yolk sac tumour               |
|                  | - Teratoma                      |
|                  | - Embryonal carcinoma           |
|                  | - Mixed cell type (MC)          |

2.  6 Benign scrotal conditions
    Scrotal exam
    Exposure: groin and external genitalia
    Position: supine / standing

Inspection of penis, scrotum and groin

- Penis: Retract the foreskin to expose glans - look for phimosis, paraphimosis, urethral discharge
- Scrotum and perineum: inspect both anterior and posterior sides, look for surgical incisions along median
  raphe, swellings, pustular discharge
- Groin / spermatic cord: swelling, surgical scars, "bag of worm" appearance

Palpation of penis, scrotum and groin

- Scrotum: testis is anterior (size of testis, any hard nodules, lie of testis); epididymis is posterior
- Groin: LN, masses

If there is a mass, you need to determine:

- Relationship with testis (separable?)
- Consistency (soft / hard)
- Tenderness
- Any cough impulse
- Ability to get above: palpate the superficial inguinal ring 1cm above and lateral to pubic tubercle

Special tests

- Transillumination test for hydrocele
- Valsalva maneuver for varicocele
- Cough impulse for hernia

Acute scrotum

- Testis:
  - **Testicular torsion** (bimodal age: perinatal (_extravaginal_) vs young teens (_intravaginal_))
  - Torsion of testicular appendage (anytime, usually ~11yo)
  - Epididymitis / Epididymo-orchitis (typically 0-6mo)
  - Trauma
  - Testicular rupture (rare)
  - Idiopathic scrotal edema
  - Intra-testicular hematoma
  - Henoch-Schonlein purpura
- Groin: Incarcerated inguinal hernia

Red flags of dehydration

- CR > 2 sec, tachycardia, hypotension
- Decreased urine output (normal: 1 mL/kg/h)
- Irritability / Reduced consciousness / Altered sensorium
- Sunken eyeball / fontanelles
- Dry mucous membranes

Fluid requirements

- Resuscitation: shock (20mL/kg NS or Hartmann), dehydration (10mL/kg NS or Hartmann)
- Maintenance (**must know!**) - Note neonates <D28 have different daily requirements

| ------------------------ | ----------------------- | ----------------------- |
| 100mL/kg/day or 4mL/kg/h | 50mL/kg/day or 2mL/kg/h | 20mL/kg/day or 1mL/kg/h |

- Replacement of ongoing losses: e.g. vomiting, diarrhoea, stoma / drain / fistula losses

3.3 Paediatric surgical abdomen
Acute abdominal pain
Differential diagnosis (selected)

- GI: IO, acute appendicitis, mesenteric adenitis, Meckel's diverticulitis, intussusception, pancreatitis, PPU, omental torsion
- GU: UTI / stone disease, testicular torsion (M), ectopic pregnancy / ovarian cyst torsion / PID (F)
- Vascular: HSP
- Medical: DKA, GE

General management

- Resuscitation: NS 20ml/kg FR
- NG decompression
- Correct electrolytes
- T&S for OT

|                                | Complications - Abscess - Gangrene - Perforation                                                                                                                                                       | - Boys: usually no need imaging unless suspected delayed abscess / unclear diagnosis - Girls: ask LMP, order PT & USG abdomen, do not PV on your own (consult Gynae!!) | Non-operative management (NOM) can be considered in selected patients (no complications, no appendicoliths)                                                                          |
|                                | Differential diagnoses - Mesenteric adenitis: viral illness prodrome, USG detects lymphadenopathy - Meckel's diverticulitis: CT abdomen - Gynaecological causes                                        |                                                                                                                                                                        |                                                                                                                                                                                      |

336
GI bleed
UGIB

- **Esophageal varices**: portal hypertension (e.g. Hx of umbilical vein catheterization, known biliary atresia)
- Peptic ulcer disease
- Mallory-Weiss tear
- Gastritis
- Esophagitis

LGIB

- Anal fissure: **painful** defecation, outlet type, Hx of constipation → Mx: treat underlying constipation
- Colonic polyp: **painless**, 90% juvenile polyps → Mx: bedside suture ligation, endoscopic polypectomy
- Meckel's diverticulum: **painless**, large amount, altered blood
- Intussusception: **painful**, small amount, mucus
- Intestinal duplication cyst
- Inflammatory bowel disease
- Small bowel ischemia e.g. volvulus

Meckel diverticulum

- Definition: **true** congenital diverticulum bulging at the **anti-mesenteric aspect** of small intestine, due to incomplete obliteration of **vitelline duct** (connect midgut to yolk sac in early weeks of gestation)
- Most common congenital anomaly of GI tract

Rule of 2s (**must know!**)

- 2% of the population, 2% symptomatic, often by age of 2
- 2:1 male-to-female ratio
- 2 inches in length, found within 2 feet of the ileocaecal valve
- 2 types of ectopic tissue: gastric (60%), pancreatic (6%) or both

Clinical features

- Haematochezia: **massive painless altered blood** (maroon-coloured stool, due to acid secretion by the ectopic gastric mucosa)
- Abdominal pain (midgut): due to IO or inflammation (mimic appendicitis)
- Intestinal obstruction: due to
  - Recurrent intussusception: Meckel's diverticulum as the lead point
  - Volvulus
  - Littre's hernia: hernia containing Meckel's diverticulum

Investigations

- **Meckel's scan**: Technetium-99m pertechnetate scan
  - Gastric mucosa actively secretes chloride into the intestinal lumen
  - Pertechnetate behaves like chloride ion → actively accumulated in the mucosa → secreted
  - Require pre-med with H2 blockers: inhibit excretion of isotope into bowel lumen
  - False +ve: intestinal duplications
  - False -ve: no/inadequate heterotopic gastric mucosa, rapid bleeding causing dilution of radiotracer

Management in children

- Acute Mx: Resuscitation, IV fluids, H2 blocker infusion
- Stable: Meckel's scan
- Unstable: diagnostic laparoscopy ± bowel resection
  - Narrow base: wedge resection (diverticulum excision and suture at the base)
  - Broad base / ulceration at margin / mesenteric border: segmental bowel resection + primary anastomosis

Duplication cyst
Usually diagnosed in first 2 years of life

Presentation: antenatal USG, abdominal pain / mass, IO, GI bleed (if heterotopic gastric mucosa), volvulus

USG: classical echogenic mucosal lining inside cyst

[Image of an ultrasound with a pink arrow pointing to a region labeled "Echogenic Mucosal lining". There is also a photograph of a resected portion of what appears to be intestinal tissue, laid alongside a ruler.]

# Intestinal obstruction

Surgical causes of SBO

- Incarcerated inguinal hernia (MC)
- Intussusception
- Adhesive IO (previous surgery)
- Pyloric stenosis
- Congenital: bands, duplication cyst, Meckel's diverticulum, malrotation & volvulus
- Foreign body ingestion, i.e. bezoar
- Intra-abdominal sepsis e.g. appendicitis, pancreatitis
  Medical causes: GE, neurological

Umbilical abnormalities

[Close-up photograph of a red umbilical granuloma on a newborn's abdomen. The granuloma is a small, raised bump that is located at the site where the umbilical cord was cut. The surrounding skin is slightly red and inflamed. Some serous fluid present at the base of the lesion.]
Umbilical granuloma

[Photograph of a large umbilical hernia in an infant. The hernia is a bulge in the belly button area. The infant is lying on their back, and the hernia is visible as a soft, round mass. The skin over the hernia is smooth and normal in color.]
Umbilical hernia

True granulation tissue with fibroblasts and abundant capillaries
Size: 1mm - 1cm
Treatment:

- **Cauterization with silver nitrate** until area epithelializes (liquid paraffin on skin to prevent irritation by secretions)
- No response: suspect umbilical polyp / sinus tract → order USG

Umbilicus is surrounded by dense fibromuscular ring (defect in linea alba) - supported by remnants of umbilical vessels, urachus and fascia → Weakened fascia results in hernia
More common in Down's syndrome, VP shunt, premature babies
**Rarely incarcerate <1%**

> 90% close by 3-4yo, but defects >2cm are less likely to close
> Surgical treatment: **Mayo operation** (indicated if >5yo)

3.4 Paediatric urology
Refer to [URO] for testicular / scrotal conditions
Imaging modalities
USG kidney
[Image of ultrasound of a kidney. The kidney appears dark with lighter gray areas within it, suggesting different tissue densities. The image shows a cross-sectional view of the kidney with internal structures visible. It is a medical diagnostic image.]
Can visualize

- Morphological abnormalities: **hydronephrosis**, **hydroureter**, **cortical thinning** (long-standing high-grade obstruction)
- Anatomical abnormalities: Duplex system, absent kidney, ectopic kidney
  Micturating cystourethrogram (MCUG)
  [Image of a micturating cystourethrogram (MCUG). The image shows the bladder filled with a contrast agent, visible as a bright white area. The urethra is also visible as a thin, bright line extending from the bladder. The surrounding tissue appears darker, providing contrast for the urinary tract. This is a diagnostic image used to assess the function and structure of the bladder and urethra.]
  Transurethral injection of contrast under fluoroscopic guidance
  Can visualize
- **Vesicoureteric reflux (VUR)** - gold standard
- Abnormal bladder / urethral contour
- Incomplete emptying
  Mercapto-acetyl-triglycine (MAG3) scan
  [Image of a series of scans illustrating kidney function over time. The scans show the uptake and excretion of a radioactive tracer in the kidneys. The images vary in intensity, reflecting the concentration of the tracer in different regions. Accompanying this set of images is a graph depicting the perfusion and uptake percentages, with specific numerical values (27.03, 30.94, 69.06) displayed. The graph also includes a "Diuretic T1/2" value of 51.99. This imaging technique assesses renal function and identifies any abnormalities.]
  Dynamic isotope scan: MAG3 is filtered & excreted
  Calculate the differential renal function between 2 kidneys during uptake phase
- Normal is 50%:50% - 45-55 regard as symmetrical
- Diuretic t½ > 20 min: indicate significant obstruction (more reliable for PUJO)
  Dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) scan
  [Image of a DMSA scan showing both kidneys. The kidneys appear as bean-shaped structures, with variations in intensity indicating the distribution of the radiotracer. This static image helps assess the structure and function of the renal cortex.]
  Static isotope scan: DMSA is filtered & accumulates in renal cortex
  Gold standard for differential renal function (normal is 50:50, 45-55% still considered symmetrical) - causes:
- Cortical scarring: congenital / acquired (post-UTI)
- Chronic obstruction
- Congenital dysplasia
  Magnetic resonance urogram (MRU)
  [Image of a Magnetic Resonance Urogram (MRU) displaying the urinary tract system. High contrast visuals mark the kidneys, ureters, and bladder. The detailed image is captured through MRI technology, helping to diagnose abnormalities.]
  Good for anatomical details
- Atypical sites for ureteric obstruction
- Duplex system
- Horseshoe kidneys
  Require MAC or even GA for infants / toddlers
  Comparing DMSA vs MAG3 scan:
  | Similarities | MAG3 | DMSA |
  | ----------- | ----------- | ----------- |
  | | Functional assessment: report differential renal function between 2 kidneys | |
  | | Non-invasive but require sedation | |
  | | Low radiation (compared with MCUG and IVU) | |
  | Differences | Dynamic scan: renal tubular excretion | Static scan: cortical uptake |
  | | Detect obstruction | Detect scarring |
  | | Assess etiology of hydronephrosis | Assess complication of UTI |

Upper tract abnormalities

# Hydronephrosis ≠ Obstruction!

[Diagram illustrating Unilateral hydronephrosis, showing the Pelviureteric junction obstruction and Vesicoureteric junction obstruction.]

[Diagram illustrating Bilateral hydronephrosis, showing Bladder neck obstruction and Posterior urethral valves.]

General clinical features

- Antenatal ultrasound: **hydronephrosis**, oligohydramnios
- Infant: **UTI**, loin pain, continuous urinary dribbling after toilet training

Management of antenatal hydronephrosis

- Oral amoxicillin
- Bilateral: postnatal USG on D1-2 → MCUG if hydronephrosis persists
- Unilateral: postnatal USG after BW returns to birth weight (D5-14) → MCUG if hydronephrosis persists

Choice of radiological investigations (**need to know!**)

- Antenatal hydronephrosis: USG + MCUG (micturating cystourethrogram) + MAG3
- Recurrent / atypical UTI: USG + MCUG + DMSA

# Obstruction

| ------------------------------------------ | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Pelvi-ureteric junction obstruction (PUJO) | **MC** cause of obstructive uropathy in children<br>Causes:<br>- Intrinsic obstruction (MC)<br>- Aberrant vessels to lower pole<br>- Horseshoe kidney<br>Investigations:<br>- USG: hydronephrosis, **no dilated ureter**, ± cortical thinning<br>- MAG3: isotope retention in **renal pelvis**, poor drainage despite Lasix (↑t1/2)<br>- + Antegrade pyelogram (if PCN is performed): no drainage to ureter, dilated system<br>Indications for surgical correction<br>- Symptomatic: recurrent loin pain / UTI<br>Initial investigations:<br> o USG: AP diameter > 30mm<br> o MAG3: **differential renal function < 40%**<br>- Follow up scans if not indicated for surgery<br> o Serial USG: progressive dilation<br> o Serial MAG3: persistent/deteriorating obstruction, progressive drop in differential renal function >5%<br>Surgical intervention: **dismembered pyeloplasty** (resection of stenosed PUJ)<br>- Open / Lap / Robotic-assisted lap<br>- Spatulation of ureter to create wider anastomosis<br>- JJ stent in early post-op period |

340
Vesico-ureteric
junction obstruction
(VUJO)

Also known as "obstructing megaureter"
Investigations:

- USG: **dilated ureter**
- MAG3: isotope retention in **distal ureter** (note: diuretic t1/2 is NOT reliable in VUJO)
- MRU: assess any duplex system, better delineate level of obstruction / ectopic ureteric insertion into bladder

Indications for surgical correction: similar to PUJO

Surgical intervention:

- Ureteroneocystostomy + reimplantation + extracorporal excisional tapering of megaureter
- Temporary ureterostomy for drainage if <1 yo

Bladder outlet
obstruction

Anatomical causes

- Congenital: **posterior urethral valve (PUV)** - boys only
- Acquired: large ureterocele, **urethral stricture** (e.g. hypospadias post-op)
  Functional cause: neurogenic bladder dysfunction

Investigations

- USG: **trabeculated bladder** + diverticulum (chronic obstruction)
- MCUG: dilated posterior urethra, **secondary VUR**

Management: **valve ablation**

Vesico-ureteric reflux (VUR)
Primary VUR (physiological bladder pressure): incomplete development of **submucosal tunnel** at VUJ

[Image Description: This is a diagram illustrating vesico-ureteric reflux (VUR). On the left, it shows a normal vesico-ureteric junction (VUJ) where the ureter smoothly enters the bladder. On the right, it depicts a ureter with VUR, indicating the backflow of urine from the bladder into the ureter. Labels indicate "Normal VUJ" and "Ureter with VUR", with arrows indicating the "Length of submucosal tunnel" in each case, with the length of the submucosal tunnel being longer in the Normal VUJ than in the Ureter with VUR.]

Secondary VUR (high bladder pressure):

- Bladder outlet obstruction e.g. **PUV**
- Neurogenic bladder dysfunction

Ix: USG renal system, MCUG (micturating cystourethrogram), DMSA^ (assess renal scarring as UTI common)

Management of primary VUR

- Mild VUR: observe for **spontaneous resolution**, treat UTI if occur
- Severe VUR (grade IV-V) / Renal scarring / Symptomatic: **antibiotic prophylaxis**, **endoscopic injection of Deflux** (bulking agent), ureteric reimplantation (not common)

Duplex system
Definition: abnormal anatomy with duplicated pyelourethral systems

- Incomplete duplex: usually uncomplicated → no need interventions
- Complete duplex can have complications (上塞下 flux)

|              |                                                                                                     |
| ------------ | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Upper moiety | Obstructing ureterocele                                                                             |
|              | Ectopic ureter insertion (fig. 1): infrasphincteric urethra / vagina → continuous urinary dribbling |
|              | Associated with dysplastic upper moiety (can perform heminephroureterectomy)                        |
| Lower moiety | VUR → hydronephrosis: drooping lily sign on MCUG (fig. 2)                                           |

[Image Description: This is an X-ray image depicting the urinary system. The contrast material highlights the kidneys, ureters, and bladder. There is clear visualization of a duplex collecting system, with two separate ureters draining into the bladder from one kidney. The bladder is also filled with contrast. The anatomical details provide visual information about the structure of the urinary tract.]

There are abnormalities with one of the ureters, suggesting vesicoureteral reflux, where urine flows backward from the bladder into the ureter. Genitalia conditions
Phimosis & Paraphimosis
Prepuce: protect the glans and urethral meatus, remain fused to glands for first 3-4 years (physiological phimosis)
| Phimosis | Paraphimosis |
|-----------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Clinical features Inability to retract foreskin (90% retract at 5yo) Cx: balanoposthitis (infection of glans & prepuce) | Entrapment of retracted foreskin behind coronal sulcus → edema of prepuce and glans |
| Management Medical: Retraction exercise, steroid cream (e.g. Betnovate) max 8 weeks Surgical: Circumcision (indicated if BXO / recurrent balanitis / recurrent UTI) Close wound: absorbable material / fall-off bell Post-op: yellow crusts are normal, advise to keep wound clean by regular water/NS irrigation for 2-3 weeks post-op | Manual reduction with analgesia Failed manual reduction: dorsal slit Formal circumcision after reduction |

[Image of scarred prepuce]
scarred prepuce

Balanitis xerotica obliterans (BXO)

- Pathological phimosis (a.k.a. lichen sclerosis et atrophicus)
- Scarred prepuce, often involving glans and meatus
- Management: circumcision (absolute indication!) ± meatoplasty
  Balanitis
  Clinical features: swollen red prepuce, difficulty in voiding, discharge
  Note: smegma (shed skin cells and sebum) is physiological (NOT infection)
  Management:
- Acute: analgesia, local irrigation + oral antibiotics (if severe)
- After acute episode: regular retraction + steroid cream, circumcision if recurrent attacks
  Hypospadias
  Pathology: Arrest in development of ventral structures of penis
  Clinical triad
- Ventrally and proximally located urethral meatus
- Ventral curvature (chordee)
- Dorsal hood: excessive prepuce over dorsal side, absent over ventral side
  Classification (fig.): distal, mid-shaft, proximal
- Defined by intra-op site of corpus spongiosum division: junction of normal urethra & hypoplastic urethra
  Surgical principles
- Functional: restore forward urinary stream
  ○ Correct penile curvature
  ○ Create distally located meatus
- Improve cosmesis
  ○ Correct dorsal skin hood
  ○ Reconstruct glans
  Surgical options
- Distal (less severe chordee): tubularised-incised plate (TIP) urethroplasty
- Proximal (more severe chordee ± scrotal deformities e.g. penoscrotal inversion, bifid scrotum): staged repair
  Complications after repair: higher rate for proximal hypospadias
- Early
  ○ Urethrocutaneous fistula / Neourethral dehiscence
  ○ Meatal stenosis / Neourethral stricture
- Late
  ○ Recurrent chordee

342

Buried penis
Definition: Penis partially or completely concealed within subcutaneous tissue of prepubic region

- E.g. Congenital megaprepuce (preputial bladder, fig.): small preputial opening → trapping of urine
- Excessive redundancy and ballooning of inner prepuce due to ill-defined penopubic & penoscrotal angle
  Anatomical factors
- Non-retractable tight prepuce
- Scarcity of shaft skin compared to penile shaft
- Obesity: Excessive prepubic fat
- Laxity of attachment between base of penile shaft and pubopenile angle
  Surgical principle: reconstruction of pubopenile angle & penoscrotal angle
- Penile shaft coverage by preputial flap e.g. Island flap, inner preputial flap

Disorders for sexual differentiation (DSD) - surgical options
Genitalia reconstruction

- Male
  - Repair of hypospadias and scrotal deformity
  - orchidopexy
- Female
  - reduction clitoroplasty
  - labioplasty
  - augmentation/reconstruction of vagina
    Gonadal management
- Gonadectomy for
  - non-functioning streak gonads
  - dysgenetic gonads not congruent with the assigned gender
- Gonadal biopsy+/-gonadecetomy
  - gonads with high risk of germ cell neoplasm

    Cancers are not common in children, but high mortality

- Leukaemia 30%
- Brain tumours 25%: MC medulloblastoma
- Lymphoma 15%
