# 4 Plastic, Reconstructive & Aesthetic Surgery (PRAS)

## 4.1 Wound healing and reconstruction

"Plastikos" (Greek): to mould or to shape

**Wound healing**

Stages
| | |
|---|---|
| Inflammatory phase (~Day 1-4) | S/S: redness, heat, swelling, pain, loss of function Leucocyte migration and emigration, venodilation, neutrophil chemotaxis, etc. |
| Proliferative phase (~Day 4-42) | Fibroblasts synthesize collagen → gain tensile strength |
| Remodelling phase (after Wk 3) | Maturation by intermolecular cross-linking of collagen |

Types of wound healing
| | |
|---|---|
| Primary intention | Wound closure by direct approximation, pedicle flap or skin graft |
| Secondary intention | Wound left open to heal spontaneously by contraction and epithelialization |
| Tertiary intention | Delayed wound closure after a period of time |

Factors affecting wound healing
| Local factors | General factors |
|---|---|
| - Tissue trauma (kept minimum) - Hematoma - Blood supply - Temperature - Infection | - Steroids - Nutrition - Chemotherapy - Chronic illness |

Wound dressings

Protect the wound from trauma and provide environment for healing

- Antibacterial medications
  - Bacitracin and Neosporin: provide moist environment conducive to epithelialization
  - Silver sulfadiazine (Silvadene) and mafenide acetate (Sulfamylon): burn wounds and penetrate eschar
- Splinting and casting: immobilization to promote healing
- Negative pressure wound therapy: reduce exudate to promote healing

**Reconstruction ladder**

Spectrum of plastic reconstruction techniques that are of increasing complexity

[Illustration of reconstruction ladder: A diagram shows the reconstruction ladder with arrows indicating increasing complexity. The levels from top to bottom are: Free tissue transfer, Distant tissue transfer, Local tissue transfer, Tissue expansion, Skin grafting, Direct wound closure (including healing by primary intention and delayed primary closure), and Healing by secondary intention.]

Skin graft

- Definition: donor skin that is **without blood supply**
- Skin graft survival: graft "takes" by acquiring a blood supply from a healthy recipient bed
  - Plasmatic imbibition
  - Inosculation (~D3)
  - Revascularization (~D5)

[Diagram illustrating Plasmatic imbibition, Inosculation, Revascularization. Three diagrams (A,B,C) show skin graft integration.
Diagram A shows "Plasmatic imbibition" with the graft separated from the recipient area by fluid.
Diagram B shows "Inosculation" with blood vessels growing between graft and recipient area.
Diagram C shows "Revascularization" with established blood flow through the graft.]

- Donor site selection
  - Consider size, colour, hair pattern, texture, skin thickness
  - Avoid infected/necrotic tissues, irradiated tissues, exposed bone without periosteum, tendon without peritendon, cartilage without perichondrium
- Complications: graft failure due to
  - Haematoma/ seroma
  - Infection
  - Mechanical force, e.g. shearing, pressure
- Classification: **split-thickness skin graft (STSG) vs full thickness skin graft (FTSG)**

|            | STSG                                            | FTSG                                                        |
| :--------- | :---------------------------------------------- | :---------------------------------------------------------- |
| Definition | Epidermis + partial dermis                      | Epidermis + full dermis                                     |
| Donor site | More: remaining dermis for re-epithelialisation | Limited: nearby site of similar skin colour and consistency |
| Advantages | More area available: meshing, reharvesting      | Better cosmetics & function: used in face, hands            |
|            | Better survival than FTSG\*                     | Resist secondary contracture                                |

\*The small perforations in FTSG may not be sufficient to drain accumulating fluid → seroma/ haematoma → inhibit adhesion to recipient site

Skin flap

- Definition: donor skin with a **preserved blood supply** through a vascular pedicle → require **micro-anastomosis**
- Indications:
  - Situations where skin grafts will not take, e.g. infected tissue
  - Site of doubtful viability (vascularised donor skin promotes healing)
- Classification:
  - By blood supply to skin: random (unnamed), axial (named)
  - By donor site:
    - **Local**: adjacent to the defect, can be
      - **Rotational** (fig. 1)
      - **Advancement** (fig. 2)
      - **Transposition** (rotational + advancement)
      - Interpolated
    - **Regional**: based on known vascular pedicle
      - Example: _pedicled LD / TRAM flap_
    - **Distant**: non-contiguous anatomic site, can be
      - Pedicled
      - Free (unattached to blood supply, reattached to vessels at recipient site by microsurgical anastomosis): longer OT time, risk of complete flap loss (failure of microvascular anastomosis)

[Diagram of rotational flap. Illustration shows a triangular defect, a curved incision is made extending from one side of the defect, and the skin flap is rotated to cover the defect.]

[Diagram of pedicled flap. Illustration depicts a flap of skin and tissue raised on a vascular pedicle and tunneled under the skin to cover a defect.]

- Complications: **flap failure** due to
  - Haematoma/ seroma
  - Infection
  - Mechanical force
  - Vascular failure
  - Poor flap design

Clinical usage - examples

- Scalp reconstruction with ALT flap
- Mandible reconstruction with fibula flap
- Pharynx reconstruction with ALT flap rolled into tube
- Breast reconstruction: **pedicled TRAM flap / pedicled LD flap**

  4.2 Burns
  Overview
  Definition: wound caused by externally-induced **pathological change** in energy levels within a tissue leading to damage
  Assessment
  History taking

- Causative agents: thermal, chemical, electrical, radiation, cold
- Temperature of agent
- Contact time
- Circumstances of injury: enclosed space, jumping out of buildings
- Associated injury, e.g. fractures
- Any first aid: stop burning process, cooling

Pathophysiology - Jackson's zones

- Zone of hyperemia: reactive vasodilation, recover within 7 days → not included in TBSA measurement
- Zone of stasis: decreased perfusion → cell death in 48h without proper treatment → most salvageable zone
- Zone of coagulation: ischemia → irreversible cell damage

Severity of burns
Surface area (TBSA): Only 2° & 3° burns are counted

- Rule of palm: patient's (NOT your own) closed palm (including fingers) is 1% TBSA; for patchy burns
- Wallace's **Rule of 9s**: inaccurate in children
  - H&N 9%, each UL 9%, front of trunk 18%, back of trunk 18%, each LL 18%, perineum 1%
- Lund-Browder diagram: most accurate, used in burns unit, preferred in children

[Anterior view of a human body with the "Rules of 9" percentages marked on different body parts. The head and neck are marked with 4 1/2%. Each arm is marked with 4 1/2%. The front of the trunk is marked with 18%. Each leg is marked with 9%. The perineum is marked with 1%.]

[Posterior view of a human body with the "Rules of 9" percentages marked on different body parts. The head and neck are marked with 4 1/2%. Each arm is marked with 4 1/2%. The back of the trunk is marked with 18%. Each leg is marked with 9%. The perineum is marked with 1%.]

[Diagram showing the Lund-Browder diagram for estimating burn area in children, including the head, thigh, and leg area marked with percentages. The child has front and back views, with the body divided into area A, area B, and area C.]

Rules of 9

[Cross-sectional diagram of skin layers showing Zones of Thermal Injury. The diagram shows the skin surface, epidermis, dermis with nerves and vessels. Below the epidermis are three marked areas: Zone of hyperemia, Zone of stasis, and Zone of coagulation. Blood vessels and nerves are found in the dermis]

_Figure 16. Zones of thermal injury_

Lund-Browder diagram
Depth

- Factors: temperature of agent, contact time, thickness of skin (extremes of age, anatomical site)

|                    |            | Depth                               | Colour                   | Blister | CR  | Sensation         |
| :----------------- | :--------- | :---------------------------------- | :----------------------- | :------ | :-- | :---------------- |
| Superficial        | 1st degree | Epidermis                           | Pink                     | Nil     | <2s | Very painful      |
| Superficial dermal | 2nd degree | Into superficial dermis             | Pink, wet                | Small   | <2s | Extremely painful |
| Deep dermal        | 2nd degree | Into deep dermis                    | Pale with fixed staining | Big     | >2s | Reduced           |
| Full thickness     | 3rd degree | Complete loss of epidermis & dermis | White, unblanchable Hard | No      | No  | No                |

Management
Resuscitation
Fluid resuscitation (**must know!**)

- Indications: TBSA > **20% (adults)** or **10% (children)**, but no widely accepted limits
- Rationale: increased capillary permeability in burns → net fluid shift from intravascular compartment
- Modified Parkland's formula
  - 3-4ml x weight (kg) x %TBSA (greater than first degree)
  - 50% of fluid given in first **8h** (counted from the moment of injury), remaining 50% in next **16h**
  - Preferred fluid: **Hartmann's solution**
  - For paediatric patient, give additional daily maintenance fluid (100-50-25 per day or 4-2-1 per hr)
  - Monitoring: urine output: insert Foley catheter for all major burn patients
  - Target: **0.5ml/kg/h** in adults, **1ml/kg/h** in children
  - Give **extra fluid** whenever urine output is inadequate
  - Dark urine: consider myoglobinuria
- Additional fluid requirement for
  - Inhalational injury
  - Burns in children
  - Electrical burns: rhabdomyolysis
    Pharmacotherapy
- Analgesia
- Tetanus prophylaxis for burns > 10% TBSA (3 doses in total)

Specific considerations
| Inhalational injury & CO poisoning |
| ----------- |
| - Suspect if - History: fire in enclosed space, **unconscious**, long duration, type of combustible patients - Physical exam: **carbonaceous** sputum, **soot** in oral cavity/ oropharynx, burnt nasal hairs, **HOV/ stridor** (late signs) - S/S of **CO poisoning**: headache, nausea, dizziness, SOB, collapse, LOC - Management: - Airway: consider early intubation - Breathing: **100% O2** (compete with CO binding to Hb, take ~1hr), **hyperbaric O2** (take ~20min), carboxyHb (>5% in non-smokers, >10% in smokers), CXR - Circulation: higher requirement of fluid resuscitation - Diagnosis: fiberoptic bronchoscopy |
| Burns in children |
| - Thin skin → more severe injury - Large surface area-to-weight ratio → - Higher rate of water/ heat loss & metabolic requirement - Rules of 9 not applicable - More prone to hypothermia |
| Circumferential burns |
| - Unique in **full-thickness burn** - act as constricting eschar - Limbs: capillary leak of fluid → skin fails to expand due to loss of elasticity in burned tissues → **compartment syndrome** - Progressive loss of sensation/ power in limbs - Progressive loss of pulses in distal extremity by palpation or Doppler - Intracompartmental pressure (Stryker needle) > 30mmHg (fig.) - Chest: impaired ventilation → **respiratory distress** Management: escharotomy / fasciotomy |

[Image of a medical device, most likely used for measuring pressure. The device is rectangular and made of metal. It has a digital display showing numbers and a connected needle or probe. The image also contains a logo and text indicating it is associated with "EM:RAP".]

346

Types of burn - specific management

- Thermal injury
  - Remove clothing
  - Run effected area under **cold water** (NOT ice: vasoconstriction → less blood supply)
  - Cover with **cling film** (transparent, reduce irritation of skin)
- Electrical injury
  - Surface damage not representative of deeper tissue damage
  - **Arrhythmia**: cardiac monitor
  - **Rhabdomyolysis**:
    - Ix: myoglobinuria (dark urine), CK, RFT
    - Mx: forced diuresis (NS + frusemide +/- NaHCO3), target UO 1-2mL/kg/h
  - **Compartment syndrome**
- Chemical injury
  - Alkali (liquefaction necrosis) worse than acid (coagulation necrosis: eschar stops damage)
  - Exception: HF (liquefaction necrosis) → Mx: Ca gluconate
  - Severity determined by: pH, concentration, length of contact time involved TBSA%
  - Management
    - Remove clothing
    - **Copious irrigation with NS** until neutral pH
    - Document offending agent: test skin with Litmus paper if unknown

Wound care

- Achieve wound closure by **21 days** (↑scar formation afterwards)
  | | |
  | :--------- | :---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
  | Superficial | Analgesia |
  | | Wound dressing that aids skin healing, e.g. Tegaderm |
  | Superficial dermal | Analgesia |
  | | Wound dressing e.g. biological dressing (**amnion**) - accelerates healing |
  | | Prevent wound colonisation: topical antimicrobial agents, e.g. silver sulphadiazine (cannot penetrate eschar) |
  | Deep dermal | **Early wound debridement** |
  | | - Tangential excision up to bleeding tissue |
  | | - Fascial excision |
  | | [Image of a hand with meshed skin graft on it, and a close up of the meshed skin graft before it is placed on the wound. The meshed skin has small diamond shaped holes in it, and is pink in color. The hand with the graft on it shows a large wound with exposed tissue, and the meshed skin is covering the wound.] |
  | Full thickness | **+ Skin grafting**: harvest by skin graft knife at mid-dermis level |
  | | - **Autograft** |
  | | - **Meshed skin** (increase surface area to 1.5x to 6x, allow drainage holes for seroma/hematoma, but poorer cosmesis) |
  | | - **Skin substitutes**, e.g. **Integra** (dermo-matrix: collagen layer to promote neovascularization to create neodermis; silicone layer to protect → later removed and skin graft can be placed) |
  | | If skin grafting cannot be performed immediately: fine mesh gauze + topical antimicrobial agents (escharotomy before application) |

Rehabilitation: management of complications

- Cosmetics: burn scars
- Functional: contractures
- Psychosocial

Prognostic factors

- Age
- TBSA
- Inhalational injury

Criteria for referral to burns centre (reference)

- Requiring resuscitation
- Extremes of age
- Electrical / chemical burns
- Inhalation injury
- Concomitant trauma
- Circumferential burns
- Burns at face / hands / feet / perineum / joints

Management
Non-surgical: multi-modal therapy

- Massage and moisture
- Compression therapy
- Silicone sheet / gel
- Intralesional corticosteroid injection
- Laser
- Cryotherapy

# 4.4 Benign skin conditions

Fitzpatrick skin types
Estimate response to UV light

[Image of The Fitzpatrick Scale showing six skin types, ranging from very light (Type I) to very dark (Type VI). Each type is represented by a skin tone swatch with a corresponding description.]

Benign skin conditions
Seborrheic keratosis
[Image of a seborrheic keratosis, which is a raised, waxy lesion on the skin. The lesion is brown and has a rough surface.]

- Pathology: Benign proliferation of keratinocytes
- Occur in sun-exposed areas, head & trunk
- "Stuck-on" appearance
- NO malignant potential

Actinic keratosis
[Image of an actinic keratosis, which is a rough, scaly patch on the skin. The lesion is pink or red and has an irregular shape.]

- Pathology: Atypia of epidermis that does not involve full-thickness (full-thickness involvement = SCC in-situ)
- Pre-malignant: 20-25% develop into SCC

Bowen's disease
[Image of Bowen's disease, which appears as a red, scaly patch on the skin. The patch is well-defined and slightly raised.]

- Pre-malignant: SCC in-situ
- Very similar to actinic keratosis, but no scaling
- Predominantly in women

349
Keratoacanthoma
[Image Description: a close-up photograph shows a round, raised skin lesion with a central crater-like depression filled with keratinous material. The surrounding skin appears slightly inflamed and uneven.]

- Pathology: keratinizing squamous cells in pilosebaceous follicles
- Fast growing over a few weeks, but spontaneously regresses
- Usually have central keratin plug
- Difficult to differentiate from SCC: require biopsy

Congenital melanocytic naevi
[Image Description: a close-up photograph shows a large, darkly pigmented skin lesion covering a significant portion of an infant's body. The lesion is slightly raised and has an irregular border.]

- Large, hairy, pigmented, verrucous
- "Giant" naevi have ~5% risk of transforming into malignant melanoma (usually within first 5 years of life)
  - Definition: 2% TBSA / ≥20cm in largest diameter
  - Risk reduced but NOT eliminated with excision

Acquired melanocytic naevi
(moles)
Usually do not involve skin appendages
Subtypes: junctional, compound, intradermal

Sebaeceous naevi (of Jadassohn)
[Image Description: a close-up photograph shows a patch of skin with a yellowish-orange, slightly raised, and waxy appearance. The patch is located on the scalp or face.]

- Pathology: hamartoma of sebaceous glands with overlying epidermal hyperplasia
- Typically appears on scalp / face
- 10-15% risk of malignant transformation: BCC (classically), SCC, sebaceous/apocrine carcinomas

Lipoma
[Image Description: a close-up photograph shows a smooth, soft, and slightly raised mass beneath the skin. The skin overlying the mass appears normal.]

- Pathology: benign tumour arising from adipose tissues
- Clinical features: slip sign, soft and rubbery consistency, normal overlying skin
- Investigations (usually not needed): USG/MRI, FNAC
- Management: observation, surgical excision, liposuction

Sebaceous cysts / Epidermoid cysts

- Pathology: inclusion cysts lined by stratified squamous epithelium and filled with keratin - originate from proliferation of epidermal cells from infundibulum of hair follicle
- NOT of sebaceous origin
- Management: excision with inclusion of punctum

Vascular lesions
ISSVA classification: tumor (endothelial proliferation) vs malformation (defective embryonic vasculogenesis)

Haemangioma
[Image Description: a close-up photograph shows a bright red, raised, and well-defined vascular lesion on the skin. The lesion appears superficial and may have a slightly bumpy texture.]
Benign vascular neoplasm, 60% appear on the face
Growth: mostly appear in first few weeks after birth (30% present at birth) → early proliferation in first year → spontaneous involution (50% at 5yo, 90% at 9yo)
May impinge on vital structures

- Obscure visual axis
- Obstruct airway
  Treatment: oral propranolol, oral steroids

Vascular malformations
[Image Description: a photograph shows a skin marking. It is a large, irregularly shaped, purplish-red skin lesion affecting the face. The lesion appears flat and covers a portion of the cheek and around the eye. The eye is covered by a blue marking.]
Errors of vascular development (~8th week)

- High flow (risk of high-output HF): Arterial, AVM, AVF
- Low flow: capillary, venous, lymphatic
  Growth: tend to remain static, but may be associated with soft tissue / bone hypertrophy

Example: port wine stain (fig.) - skin capillary malformation

- Associated with Sturge-Weber syndrome
- Treatment: pulsed dye laser (PDL)

  4.5 Skin cancers
  Prevalence: BCC (75%) > SCC (20%) > melanoma (5%)
  Aggressiveness: melanoma > SCC > BCC

Workup of malignant melanoma:

- Excisional biopsy (2mm margin): Breslow's thickness, histologic ulceration, peripheral & deep margin status, microsatellitosis
- Chest X-ray, staging CT/MRI, PET-CT

\*Gorlin's syndrome (AD): multiple BCC, palmar pits, odontogenic cysts, bifid ribs, calcification of falx cerebri, overdevelopment of supraorbital ridges, learning difficulties
^Xeroderma pigmentosum: deficiency in DNA-repairing enzymes of skin, 100% lifetime risk of skin cancers

# 4.6 Lymphaedema

Definition: obstruction of lymphatic drainage resulting in oedema with high protein content

Aetiology

- Primary:
  - Milroy's syndrome (congenital hereditary lymphedema)
  - Meige disease (lymphedema praecox) (puberty)
  - Lymphoedema tarda (>30yo)
- Secondary:
  - Filariasis (MC worldwide, Wuchereria bancrofti)
  - Malignancy (MC cause in developed countries): 25% after mastectomy, 40% after mastectomy + AD
  - Post-radiation

[Image of the top of a foot with severely thickened, warty, and bumpy skin, primarily affecting the toes. The skin appears rough and irregular, showing signs of significant swelling and deformation.]

Clinical features

- Pitting oedema initially -> **warty & thickened skin** (fig.)
- Stemmer sign: unable to lift skin of 2nd finger or 2nd toe (due to thickened skinfold)

Management

- Conservative: **complete decongestive therapy** - reduce 50% in 8 weeks, but **recur** if stop
  - MLD (manual lymphatic drainage)
  - External compression
  - Exercise
  - Skin / nail care
- Surgical management

| Debulking     | - **Charles procedure** (covered with graft)                                                               |
| :------------ | :--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
|               | - **Homans procedure** (MC performed, only cut the subcutaneous tissue)                                    |
|               | - **Liposuction + compression garments**: chronic lymphoedema associated with fatty infiltration of tissue |
| Physiological | - **Lymph-to-vein** anastomosis (LVA)                                                                      |
|               | - **LN transfer** (lymph nodes can produce VEGF to promote growth of new lymph vessels)                    |

5 Neurosurgery 5. 1 Traumatic brain injury (TBI)
Overview
Epidemiology

- Account for >50% of trauma deaths
- Triple peaks by age: infants to preschooler (0-4yo), teenager to young adults (15-24yo), elderly (≥65yo)
- Causes: falls (MC, esp. children & elderly), road traffic accidents
- Broadly classified into: closed / blunt head injury vs open / penetrating head injury

Assessment
Initial assessment

- ABC
- **Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)**: determine severity of HI
  Table 2. The Glasgow coma scale
  | Eye opening response: | | Best verbal response | |
  | :------------------------ | :-: | :------------------------ | :-: |
  | spontaneously | 4 | orientated | 5 |
  | to speech | 3 | confused | 4 |
  | to pain | 2 | inappropriate words | 3 |
  | none | 1 | incomprehensible sounds | 2 |
  | | | none | 1 |
  | **Best motor response:** | | **In intubated patient, the verbal scores are:** | |
  | obeys commands | 6 | patient appears able to converse | 5 |
  | localization to painful stimuli | 5 | patient questionable to converse | 3 |
  | normal flexion to painful stimuli | 4 | generally unresponsive | 1 |
  | abnormal flexion to painful stimuli | 3 | | |
  | extension to painful stimuli | 2 | | |
  | none | 1 | | |
- Mild TBI (13-15): 30% become disabled
- Moderate TBI (9-12): 40% become disabled
- Severe TBI (≤8): variable; predictors: post-resuscitation GCS & age
- **Focal neurological signs**: pupil, cranial nerves, limbs, posturing, reflexes
- Other relevant signs: e.g. raccoon eyes, CSF rhinorrhoea, ruptured tympanic membrane
- Spinal cord injury: sensory level, motor deficits, anal tone

History taking - pearls

- Mechanism of injury: high-energy vs low-energy
- Precipitating factors: convulsion, syncope, stroke
- Events during HI: duration of LOC, post-traumatic amnesia, lucid interval, convulsions, resuscitations given
- Neurological S/S: headache, vomiting
- Pre-morbid functioning
  Radiological investigations
- Plain CT brain
- Plain CT cervical spine
- ± CTA Circle of Willis: e.g. skull base fracture involving foramen lacerum
- ± CTA vertebral: e.g. C spine injury involving vertebral foramen
- ± MRI for spinal injuries: e.g. spinal epidural hematoma, cord contusions

Prognosis
High risk patients

- High-energy injury: fall from height, road traffic accident
- Advanced age
- On anticoagulants / antiplatelets / alcohol
- S/S of increased ICP: headache, n/v
- S/S of herniation: anisocoria, sluggish pupillary response
- Lucid interval
  [A picture comprised of two images showing "Head injury prognosis" and "CRASH" logo. On the left, there is a clinical tool. The clinical tool is a form with questions that when answered, estimates mortality at 14 days and death and severe disability at six months in patients with traumatic brain injury(TBI). The form questions are listed as: Country, Age, Glasgow Coma Scale score, Pupils react to light, Major extra-cranial injury?, CT scan available?, Presence of petechial hemorrhages, Obliteration of the third ventricle or basal cisterns, Subarachnoid bleeding and Midline shift and Non-evacuated haematoma. The form provides selections to choose a value. The tool has a "Prediction" section that shows the values for Risk of 14 day mortality (95% CI) and Risk of unfavorable outcome at 6 months. On the right is the CRASH logo]

CRASH score (fig.): predict risk of 14-day mortality and unfavourable outcome at 6 months

# Primary brain injuries

- Mechanisms
  - Concussion: trauma-induced alteration in mental state, without CT abnormalities
  - Contusion: brain slide against bony structures
  - **Coup injury**: brain injury at direct impact site
  - **Contre-coup injury**: brain injury opposite to impact site, due to sudden linear velocity changes e.g. acceleration-deceleration
  - Intracranial haematoma (see below)
  - Skull fractures (see below)
  - **Diffuse axonal injury (DAI)**: rotational force, classified by CT findings

| 1   | Normal CT                                        |
| 2   | Midline shift ≤ 5 mm, no parenchymal lesion      |
| 3   | Midline shift > 5 mm, parenchymal lesion ≤ 25 ml |
| 4   | Midline shift > 5 mm, parenchymal lesion > 25 ml |

# Skull fracture

- By fracture lines: linear, comminuted
- By degree of displacement: undisplaced, depressed, open/ compound
- By anatomy: skull vault, skull base

| Linear fracture                                                                                                                  | Depressed fracture                                                                       | Compound/ open fracture                                                                         |
| -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Full-thickness fracture without bone displacement                                                                                | Broken skull displaces inward                                                            | - Fracture that involves skin laceration / extension to paranasal sinus / middle ear structures |
|                                                                                                                                  |                                                                                          | - Increased risk of infection                                                                   |
| [A black and white X-ray image showing a linear fracture of the skull. A thin, bright line is visible on the skull's left side.] | [A CT scan image showing a depressed fracture of the skull. The skull appears indented.] | [A CT scan image showing a compound/open fracture. The bone is broken.]                         |

# Basilar fractures

- Skull fracture at skull base (one of 5 bones, most commonly temporal bone)
- Complications: EDH, **meningitis**, **CSF leak** (halo test, beta-2 transferrin)
- S/S:
  - Anterior cranial fossa fracture: **CSF rhinorrhea**, **raccoon eyes** (periorbital bruise), epistaxis, anosmia (CN I injury)
  - Petrous temporal fracture: **Battle sign** (retroauricular bruise), **CSF otorrhea**, **hemotympanum**, bleeding from ear, CN VII/VIII injury
- CT features: air fluid level in sphenoid sinus / mastoid air cells, fracture lines may not be seen

[A black and white X-ray image showing a basilar skull fracture. The image shows a fracture near the base of the skull.]

Intracranial haematoma

|                                | Patho                                                                     | S/S                                                                                               | Radiological features                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      | Specific management                                                     |
| ------------------------------ | ------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ----------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Epidural haematoma             | Ruptured **middle meningeal artery** (95%) Dural sinus (5%)               | **Lucid interval**, then rapid deterioration Associated with skull fractures                      | [Image of a brain scan showing a lens-shaped hyperdense mass on the right side of the skull. The mass appears bright on the scan, indicating it is denser than the surrounding brain tissue. The lesion abuts the inner table of the skull but is limited by suture lines and it also crosses the midline] | Craniotomy Good outcome if timely evacuation                            |
| Acute subdural haematoma (SDH) | Ruptured subarachnoid bridging veins                                      | Uncal herniation: blown pupil, ipsilateral hemiparesis, LOC Tonsillar herniation: Cushing's triad | [Image of a brain scan showing a crescent-shaped hyperdense mass on the left side of the skull. The mass is bright, suggesting a higher density than the surrounding brain tissue. It follows the contour of the skull and crosses suture lines and it does not cross the midline]                         | Craniotomy Poor outcome: associated with significant parenchymal injury |
| Chronic SDH                    | Ruptured subarachnoid bridging veins                                      | Mild headache Confusion                                                                           | [Image of a brain scan showing a hypodense area in the brain with flattened gyri and thin shallow sulci, indicating brain atrophy.]                                                                                                                                                                        | Burr hole to drain Craniotomy if recur Good outcome with drainage       |
| Diffuse axonal injury          | Multiple focal **white matter lesions** due to shearing /rotational force | Prolonged coma Multiple neurological deficits                                                     | CT can be normal; haemorrhagic lesions in _corpus callosum / dorsal brainstem_ MRI IHC: retraction balls                                                                                                                                                                                                   | Supportive: cerebral oedema, hypoxia etc                                |

Secondary brain injuries

| Extracranial                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 | Intracranial                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       |
| ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
| - Hypoxaemia & hypercapnia: trauma to chest, blood loss - Hypotension - HypoNa: SIADH → may aggravate cerebral edema and cause seizure - Hyper/hypoglycemia - Hyperthermia - Extracranial infections (esp. MRSA): e.g. ventilator-associated pneumonia, aspiration pneumonia | - Delayed haemorrhages: SDH, EDH, SAH, ICH, IVH - **Cerebral edema:** cytotoxic oedema (ischaemia) + vasogenic oedema (BBB disruption) - **Hydrocephalus** - Intracranial infections: e.g. meningitis, brain abscess - Epileptic seizure: early (within 1 week after TBI) vs late - Cerebral diaschisis (reduced cerebral metabolic rate) → reduced cerebral blood flow without autoregulation → prone to ischemia |

- Pathophysiology: Monro-Kellie doctrine
  - (1) Rigidity of skull vault
  - (2) Incompressibility of intracranial constituents: blood, brain parenchyma, CSF
  - → Change in one component (**brain tissue / CSF / blood**) require compensatory change in another component to maintain constant ICP
- CPP = MAP – ICP
- End result of head injury is ↑ICP → may lead to ischemia (drop in CPP) & herniation

[Image of a flowchart illustrating the Monro-Kellie doctrine and its effects on brain physiology after a head injury. The flowchart starts with Intracranial haematoma, Mass effect, and Focal damage. It proceeds to Brain oedema and an upward arrow pointing to Intracranial pressure (ICP). Cerebral Perfusion Pressure (CPP) is indicated as having two paths down, one to Cerebral blood flow (CBF) and then Cerebral ischemia, and the other path to Brain shift, Brain herniation, and Brainstem compression.]

Management of head injury

- ABC
- Scalp wound: **MUST suture** to stop bleeding!
- Skull base fractures: nasal packing, antibiotics, discuss for embolization
- Open fracture: wound debridement and closure, antibiotics, ± Keppra
- **IV Transamine 1g:** within 3 hours if mild-moderate TBI + reactive pupils [CRASH-3 trial]
- CSF fistula: usually heal spontaneously, may require surgical repair if persistent / delayed
- Decide stability for transfer

Management of severe TBI (GCS ≤ 8)

- Treatment targets
  - ICP < 22mmHg, CPP 60-70mmHg
  - SpO2 > 97%, PaO2 > 9 kPa, PCO2 4.5-5kPa, temp <37, avoid hypoglycemia, serum Na >140
- **Endotracheal intubation** for airway protection (± early tracheostomy: better bronchial toileting)
- **Invasive ICP monitoring** with antimicrobial-impregnated EVD catheter
  - Head elevation 30° and loosen any constraints around neck
  - Consider sedation & paralysis
- Nutrition: feeding at least by Day 5
- DVT prophylaxis: graded compression stockings
- Seizure prophylaxis (for 1 week only): decrease incidence of post-traumatic seizure, NO need if sedated
- Antibiotics if open / skull base fractures
- Role of steroids: high-dose MP is contra-indicated [CRASH trial]

ICP management

- Indications for invasive ICP monitoring
  - Severe head injury (GCS ≤ 8)
  - Abnormal CT scan: evidence of mass effect (e.g. hematoma, contusion)
- Types of ICP monitoring
  - Intraventricular (gold standard): burr hole + external ventricular drainage (EVD), telemetric
    ventricular pressure monitoring device
  - Parenchymal: microsensor catheter
  - Subdural / Epidural
  - Non-invasive: optic nerve USG, transcranial Doppler USG
- S/S of impending herniation (**important!**)
  - Fixed and dilated pupils (unilateral/bilateral)
  - Decorticate / decerebrate posturing
  - Cushing triad: hypertension, bradycardia, irregular respiration
- If targets not met, first consider repeat CT brain / recalibrate probes / check catheter position
- Pharmacological approaches
  | Reduce cerebral blood volume | - Head elevation 30° and loosen any constraints around neck |
  | :-------------------------- | :------------------------------------------------------------------- |
  | | - Hyperventilation (PaCO2~30mmHg): cerebral vasoconstriction |
  | | - Sedation & paralysis: reduce metabolic demand of brain |
  | Reduce CSF volume | - Intermittent CSF drainage via EVD |
  | | - Frusemide: might reduce CSF formation |
  | Reduce brain volume | - IV Mannitol 0.25-1g/kg (note: C/I if hypotension) |
  | | - Immediate: improve cerebral blood flow and oxygenation |
  | | - 30min: osmotic effect |
  | | - Hypertonic saline (150mL 3% saline) if hypovolemia |
  | | - Require central line & dilution |

- Surgical approaches
  - Burr hole + external ventricular drainage for ICP monitoring and intermittent CSF drainage
  - Clot evacuation / Contusionectomy
  - Decompressive craniectomy + lobectomy: _NOT recommended for early [DECRA trial], but favourable for late
    [RescueICP trial]_
- Refractory: Barbiturate coma / thiopentone coma with EEG monitoring

# 5.2 Cerebrovascular disease

Refer to [MED] for more details about stroke management
Subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH)
Aetiology
Overall MC: traumatic
Among spontaneous non-traumatic SAH,

- Cerebral aneurysm (85%)
- Other vascular lesions (5%): e.g. AVM, Moyamoya disease
- Non-aneurysmal peri-mesencephalic SAH (10%): no lesion seen on angiography, thought to be venous/capillary in nature, good prognosis

Clinical features

- Headache: sudden onset, severe "thunderclap" / worst headache ever had
- Brief LOC
- Meningism: neck stiffness, photophobia, n/v

Grading:
World Federation of Neurosurgical Societies (WFNS) grading (more common), Hunt and Hess grading
| WFNS Grade | GCS Score | Motor Deficit |
| ----------- | ----------- | ----------- |
| I | 15 | absent |
| II | 14-13 | absent |
| III | 14-13 | present |
| IV | 12-7 | present or absent |
| V | 6-3 | present or absent |

[Image Description: A gray scale CT scan of a human head, axial view, showing the brain inside the skull. The scan shows the cerebral hemispheres, ventricles, and other brain structures. There are varying shades of gray, representing different densities of brain tissue.]

Investigations

- Urgent NCCT brain: hyperdensity in basal cisterns around circle of Willis (65%) or Sylvian fissure (30%)
- LP (2nd line if CTB normal): bloody CSF, xanthochromia (12h to 12d), persistent ↑RBC > 100000, ↑protein
- Non-invasive vascular imaging for cerebral aneurysms: CTA/MRA → DSA

Management

- Resuscitation (ABC)
- Watch out for cervical spine injury and other associated injury: neck collar, CXR, C-spine X ray + CT C spine
- Bed rest, NPOEM, IV fluids, monitor vitals + neuro-obs
- Correct hypoglycemia, temperature / fluid / electrolyte abnormalities
- Symptomatic: analgesics, anticonvulsant, stool softener prn
- Antihypertensive: Nimodipine 60mg Q4h PO/IV (prevent vasospasm, risk of delayed cerebral infarction)
  - Closely monitor BP: target SBP < 160 (note risk of rebleeding vs maintenance of CPP)
- Tranexamic acid: for < 72h or until surgical treatment (risk of thrombosis)
- Early aneurysm occlusion to reduce risk of rebleeding - Endovascular (1st line): DSA + coil embolization of aneurysm; Cx contrast allergy, embolism - New modality: flow diverter (~ EVAR) - Surgical: craniotomy + microsurgical clipping
  Complications (9H)
- Early: haematoma, intracranial HT, systemic HT (compensate ↑ ICP), HF/arrhythmia / neurogenic pulmonary edema
- Late: haemorrhage (re-bleed), hypoperfusion (delayed cerebral ischemia), hydrocephalus, hypovolaemia (CSW), hypoNa (SIADH)

Decreased GC after SAH:

- Hydrocephalus
- Re-bleeding
- Acute ischemic stroke
- Non-convulsive seizure

Delayed cerebral ischemia

- Definition: Focal neurological deficit / decreased GCS x 2 points for at least 1 hour
- Ix: CT perfusion scan + CT angiogram for vasospasm
- Mx: haemodynamic augmentation (increase BP), IA vasodilators (e.g. CCB), angioplasty + stenting

# Intracerebral haemorrhage (ICH)

Aetiology (in order of prevalence)

- **Hypertensive arteriopathy** (rupture of capillary microaneurysms): deep ICH - more central
  - Common sites: **pons, cerebellum, putamen, thalamus**
- **Cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA)**: lobar ICH - more peripheral
- Others: **coagulopathy**, structural vascular lesions (e.g. Berry aneurysms, AVM), drugs (e.g. cocaine)

Investigations

- **Urgent NCCT brain**: size and location of haematoma, any IVH/hydrocephalus, any mass effect
- Indications for vascular imaging: suspected _non-hypertensive_ etiology
  - No HT
  - Age <40-45
  - Atypical location
  - CT abnormality: mass, calcifications

Management

- Resuscitation (ABC)
- Watch out for **cervical spine injury** and other associated injury: neck collar, CXR, C-spine X ray + CT C spine
- Bed rest, NPOEM, IV fluids, monitor vitals + **neuro-obs**
- Antihypertensive: **IV labetalol** (for adequate cerebral perfusion and reduce risk of bleeding)
  - Treat if SBP > 150 (unless evidence of increased ICP)
  - Target SBP <140, but avoid rapid BP reduction (renal complications)
- Reversal of anticoagulation
- Acute hydrocephalus: **burr hole + EVD**

Large territory infarct
Role of neurosurgery: prophylactic decompressive craniectomy and
duroplasty (add synthetic material to dural opening)

- Shown in RCT to reduce disability and mortality in:
  - Malignant MCA syndrome
  - Massive cerebellar infarct

Cerebral venous thrombosis
Epidemiology: F > M - pregnancy, use of COC

- 1% of stroke

Clinical features (require high index of suspicion)

- S/S depends on site:
  - Cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (90%): ↑↑ ICP (headache, papilledema, ↓GCS), seizure, focal neurological deficit
  - Cavernous sinus thrombosis: proptosis, painful ophthalmoplegia, CN 3, 4, 6, V1 involvement
  - Deep cerebral venous thrombosis (10%)

Investigations:

- CT brain: can be normal
- MRI brain + MR venogram for filling defect
  - Empty delta sign: superior sagittal sinus involvement (fig.)

Management:

- Anticoagulation: LMWH (acute) → warfarin or dabigatran for 3 months (chronic)
- Endovascular thrombolysis in selected patients
- ICP management
- Treat seizures

```markdown
5.3 Hydrocephalus
Normal physiology of CSF flow

- Average volume of CSF: 150mL
  - 20% in ventricular system
  - 80% in subarachnoid and cisternal spaces
- Production rate: 480mL/day (i.e. renewed 3x/day)
- Active production:
  - Choroid plexus (75%)
  - Others (25%) e.g. ependymal wall, brain
    parenchyma, interstitial fluid
    [Anatomical drawing of the ventricular system. The ventricles are highlighted in blue. Arrows indicate the flow of cerebrospinal fluid from the lateral ventricles through the interventricular foramen to the third ventricle, then through the cerebral aqueduct to the fourth ventricle, and finally out into the subarachnoid space. The drawing includes labels for: "Lateral ventricles," "Interventricular foramen," "Third Ventricle," "Cerebral aqueduct," "Fourth ventricle", "Central canal" and includes lateral and anterior views.]
- Circulation: lateral ventricles → interventricular foramen (of Monroe) → 3rd ventricle → Sylvian aqueduct →
  4th ventricle → lateral foramina (of Luschka) & medial foramen (of Magendie) → subarachnoid
- Passive absorption: depend on CSF pressure gradient
  - Arachnoid granulations (80%) → Superior sagittal sinus
  - Extracranial lymphatics (20%): via subarachnoid space of exiting CNs, or perivascular (Virchow-Robin) spaces
    Overview
    Definition: accumulation of excess CSF within the cranium
    Etiology: subdivided into

|            | Obstructive: at ventricular system/ aqueduct - ventricular enlargement proximal to block (4th ventricle normal)                                                                                                                                                                | Communicating: at arachnoid villi - all ventricles dilated (4th ventricle enlarged)                                                              |
| ---------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
| Acquired   | - Tumors: CPA tumors (vestibular schwannoma / meningioma), **brain metastasis**, gliomas, craniopharyngioma / pituitary macroadenoma- Vascular: cerebellar infarct, ICH, IVH- Infections: ventriculitis, post-infective aqueductal stenosis, brain abscess, neurocysticercosis | - Tumors: leptomeningeal carcinomatosis- Vascular: SAH, IVH- Infections: basal meningitis (e.g. TB, Cryptococcal)- Normal pressure hydrocephalus |
| Congenital | - Dandy-Walker malformation, Type II Chiari malformation, congenital aqueductal stenosis                                                                                                                                                                                       |                                                                                                                                                  |
|            | - Overproduction of CSF (rare): choroid plexus papilloma                                                                                                                                                                                                                       |                                                                                                                                                  |

Clinical features

- Acute hydrocephalus:, S/S of raised ICP (headache, n/v), sunsetting eyes / Parinaud syndrome, CN 6 palsy, UMN long tract signs
- Chronic hydrocephalus (i.e. NPH): **Adam's triad**
  Investigations
- CT/ MRI:
  - Ventriculomegaly: need to account for physiological increase in ventricular volume with aging ± cerebral atrophy (i.e. "hydrocephalus ex-cavuo")
    - First ventricle to dilate: temporal horn of lateral ventricles
  - Periventricular lucencies: due to transependymal edema
  - Sulci and fissure effacement
  - Midline shift / herniation
- ICP monitoring: LP or external ventricular drain (EVD)
```

Management

- Acute management: burr hole + external ventricular drainage (EVD), diuretics (acetazolamide + frusemide)
- Treat offending cause
- CSF diversion procedures
  - Permanent CSF shunts: ventriculo-peritoneal (VP) shunt, ventriculo-atrial (VA) shunt, lumboperitoneal (LP) shunt
    - Components: ventricular catheter, valve & reservoir, distal catheter
  - Endoscopic third ventriculostomy (ETV): for obstructive hydrocephalus only

Complications of CSF shunt
Ventricular catheter

- Mechanical failure: Shunt blockage (MC), migration, fracture
  - Site: 80% proximal block, 10% valve, 10% distal block
  - Causes: choroid plexus, brain parenchyma, protein, tumor cells
  - Investigations: urgent CT brain, shunt series (plain XR of entire shunt: skull XR, C spine XR, CXR, AXR)
  - Management: consult NS for shunt revision
- Shunt infection (most serious):
  - Pathogens: S. epidermidis, S. aureus
  - S/S: fever, lethargy, meningism, S/S of raised ICP
  - Investigation: contrast CT brain, inspect entire course of shunt for cutaneous erythema
  - Management: antibiotics, consult NS for shunt revision/removal + temporary EVD
- Overshunting:
  - S/S postural headache (worsened with standing/sitting, relieved when lying down)
  - Can lead to subdural hematoma (stretching of bridging veins)
- Distal catheter
  - Inguinal hernia
  - Perforated abdominal viscus / peritonitis
  - Intraperitoneal CSF-filled pseudocyst
  - Tumor seeding

5.  4 Skull base tumours
    Pathology

- Benign: meningioma, schwannoma, pituitary adenoma
- Benign but aggressive growth: chondroma, craniopharyngioma
- Malignant: carcinoma, sarcoma

General management: microscopic / endoscopic skull base surgeries + adjuvant RT / radiosurgery

|                         | Clinical presentation                                                                                                                                                                                                    | Common pathologies                                             |
| :---------------------- | :----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | :------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Anterior cranial fossa  | - Can be asymptomatic- Raised ICP: headache, n/v- Seizure- Anosmia- Visual complaints- Foster-Kennedy syndrome: ipsilateral optic atrophy + contralateral papilledema; classically a/w large olfactory groove meningioma | - Meningioma- Olfactory groove neuroblastoma                   |
| Middle cranial fossa    | - Visual disturbance: optic nerve / chiasm compression- CN palsy: III, IV, V, VI- Hormonal disturbances                                                                                                                  | - Meningioma- Schwannoma- Pituitary adenoma- Craniopharyngioma |
| Posterior cranial fossa | - CN palsy: facial palsy, hearing loss, dysphagia, HoV, tongue atrophy- Obstructive hydrocephalus- Brainstem compression: hemiplegia, sensory loss                                                                       | - Meningioma- Vestibular schwannoma                            |

5.5 Brain tumours
Epidemiology

- 1-2% of all malignancies, 13% of all malignancy-related deaths
  Risk factors
- High-dose ionizing radiation → meningioma & gliomas (the only proven environmental factor!)
- EBV, immunosuppression → primary CNS lymphoma
- Familial syndromes e.g. NF1, NF2, VHL, TSC, MEN1, Turcot syndrome, Li-Fraumeni syndrome
  Classifications
  Distinguish "benign" vs "malignant" ( metastasize outside CNS) is less important for brain tumors
- Histological features: mitosis, invasiveness, vascular proliferation, necrosis
- Anatomical location: risk of fatal / severe neurological consequences
- Possibility of surgical removal: risk of recurrence
  Pathology: Secondary tumors are 6-10x more common

| PRIMARY INTRA-AXIAL                    | PRIMARY EXTRA-AXIAL         | METASTATIC      |
| -------------------------------------- | --------------------------- | --------------- |
| GLIOBLASTOMA (WHO IV) (47%)            | MENINGIOMA (80%)            | LUNG (37-49%)   |
| ANAPLASTIC ASTROCYTOMA (WHO III) (24%) | VESTIBULAR SCHWANNOMA (10%) | BREAST (16-19%) |
| ASTROCYTOMA (WHO II) (15%)             | PITUITARY ADENOMA (7%)      | MELANOMA (16%)  |
| OLIGODENDROGLIOMA (WHO II) (5%)        | OTHER (3%)                  | COLORECTUM (9%) |
| LYMPHOMA (3%)                          |                             | KIDNEY (8%)     |
|                                        |                             | OTHER (11%)     |
| OTHER (7%)                             |                             |                 |

Tumor locations & types: depend on age

- Adults: 70% supra-tentorial - metastatic brain tumours, meningioma, gliomas (e.g. GBM)
- Children 2-12yo: 70% infra-tentorial - medulloblastoma, astrocyotoma, ependymoma, germ cell tumours
- <2yo/ 12-18yo: 50% supra- & infra-tentorial
  [Detailed anatomical drawing of an adult human brain showing the distribution of intracranial tumors. Tumors in the Cerebral hemisphere are shown as: Astrocytoma, anaplastic astrocytoma, glioblastoma multiforme, Meningioma, Metastatic carcinoma, Vascular malformation, Oligodendroglioma, Ependymoma, and Sarcoma. Pineal region tumor: Germ cell neoplasm. Cerebellum tumors: Hemangioblastoma, Metastatic carcinoma, Astrocytoma, and Medulloblastoma. Tumors in the Fourth ventricle are: Ependymoma, Choroid plexus papilloma, Meningioma. Tumors in the Region of the foramen magnum: Meningioma, Schwannoma, Neurofibroma. Tumors in the Cerebellopontine angle: Acoustic schwannoma, Meningioma, Epidermoid cyst, Choroid plexus papilloma, Glomus jugulare tumor. Tumors in the Corpus callosum: Astrocytoma, anaplastic astrocytoma, glioblastoma multiforme, Oligodendroglioma, Lipoma. Tumors in the Region about the third ventricle: Astrocytoma, anaplastic astrocytoma, glioblastoma multiforme, Oligodendroglioma, Ependymoma, Pilocytic astrocytoma. Tumors in the Lateral ventricle: Ependymoma, Meningioma, Subependymoma, Choroid plexus papilloma. Tumors in the Third ventricle: Colloid cyst, Ependymoma. Optic chiasm and nerve tumors: Meningioma, Astrocytoma. Pituitary region tumors: Pituitary adenoma, Craniopharyngioma, Meningioma, Germ cell neoplasm. Brain stem tumors: Astrocytoma, anaplastic astrocytoma, glioblastoma multiforme.]

Pathophysiology and clinical features

- Increased ICP due to
  - Tumour mass effect
  - Vasogenic edema (most apparent on FLAIR MRI): disrupted BBB, tumor-secreting VEGF
  - Hydrocephalus: obstructive / communicating (leptomeningeal carcinomatosis)
  - Obstruction of cerebral venous drainage (e.g. superior sagittal sinus thrombosis)

- Seizures - 50% present as status epilepticus / post-ictal Todd's paralysis
  - Usually associated with **slow-growing** tumours that involve **cortex** e.g. meningioma, low grade glioma

- Focal neurological deficits depending on tumor location
  - Frontal lobe
    - **Motor** disturbances: convulsions, hemiparesis, aphasia
    - **Cognitive impairment** (esp. corpus callosum gliomas)
    - Impaired initiation and spontaneity
    - **Personality changes**: apathy (dorsolateral PFC), disinhibition (orbitofrontal cortex)
    - Urinary incontinence
    - **Anosmia**: esp. olfactory groove meningioma
  - Temporal lobe
    - **Receptive dysphasia**
    - Contralateral superior homonymous quadrantanopia
    - Complex partial seizures
    - Impaired working memory
  - Parietal lobe
    - **Sensory** disturbances: seizures, impaired two-point discrimination / stereognosis
    - Contralateral **inferior** homonymous quadrantanopia
    - **Gerstmann's syndrome** (agraphia, acalculia, finger agnosia) - **dominant side**
    - **Apraxia**, contralateral hemineglect - **non-dominant side**
  - Occipital lobe
    - Contralateral hemianopia (macular-sparing)
    - Visual hallucinations
    - Cortical blindness - if bilateral
  - Cerebellum
    - **Projective vomiting** (area postrema)
    - **Obstructive hydrocephalus**: S/S of raised ICP, CN 6 palsy
    - **Cerebellar signs**: nystagmus, ataxia
    - CN 7 palsy

- Hyperactive function depends on tumor producing other substances
  - Functional pituitary adenomas: Cushing's disease, acromegaly, TSH-secreting (rare)
  - Choroid plexus papillomas (rare): CSF-producing → hydrocephalus

Investigations

- **Gadolinium contrast-enhanced MRI**
- Other MRI imaging: FLAIR, GE/SWI, DWI / DTI, spectroscopy (MRS), perfusion (pMRI)
  - DWI: differentiate cystic intra-axial tumor (facilitated diffusion) vs brain abscess (restricted diffusion)
- Stereotactic biopsy

Management

- Medical: **steroids** to reduce cytotoxic oedema and improve functional outcome
- Surgical treatment: debulking and/or complete excision
- Adjuvant therapy: chemoRT / chemotherapy

5.  6 Spine diseases
    Anatomy
    Spine: Cervical spine (C1-C7), thoracic spine (T1-T12), lumbar spine (L1-L5), sacral spine (S1-S5), coccygeal spine

Nerve roots:

- C8 exits between C7 and T1 (there is no C8 vertebra)
- Above C8: exit on same level of vertebra (e.g. C4 exits between C3/4)
- Below C8: exit on next level of vertebra (e.g. L4 exits between L4/5)

Assessment
Physical examination

- UL:
  - Myelopathy: hyperreflexia, myelopathic hand signs e.g. Hoffmann sign, finger escape sign
  - Radiculopathy: hyporeflexia, dermatomal numbness, Spurling sign
- Trunk: sensory level (T4: nipple; T10: umbilicus)
- LL:
  - Clonus, hyperreflexia, upgoing plantar reflex
  - Straight leg raise test
  - Gait

Investigations

- X-ray spine: dynamic (flexion/extension), sagittal plane to look for any imbalance
- CT spine: bony lesions
- MRI spine: tumours
- Neurophysiological studies: nerve conduction study (NCS), somatosensory
  evoked potential (SSEP)
  Common spinal tumours
  | | | |
  | :------------------- | :-------------- | :--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
  | Intradural extramedullary (IDEM) | Schwannoma | Common at **cervical & lumbar** spine 95% arise from **sensory** nerve root → present as pain Usually sporadic - if multiple, think about NF2 **T1 contrast-enhancing** Mx: surgery (nerve usually can be preserved - separate the diseased rootlet from other rootlets) |
  | | Neurofibroma | Usually **multiple** and associated with **NF1** **Cannot** be separated from nerve fibers within a nerve (c.f. Schwannoma) |
  | | Meningioma | Common at **thoracic** level (80%) Located **lateral** to spinal cord (70%), except at cervical spine (anterior) Well circumscribed with homogenous enhancement and **dural tail sign** Mx: surgery (<10% recurrence) |
  | | Metastasis | |
  | Intradural intramedullary: a/w syringomyelia | Ependymoma | More common **Discrete** from normal cord → Mx by **surgery** Example: myxopapillary ependymoma (WHO Grade 1, at filum terminale) |
  | | Astrocytoma | **Indistinct** from normal cord → Mx by biopsy and **debulking ± adjuvants** |
  | | Hemangioblastoma | |
  | Bony | Hemangioma | |
  | | Metastasis | |

5.7 Deep brain stimulation
Patient selection criteria

- Advanced PD patient >5 years
- Idiopathic PD
- Previous good response to L-DOPA
- Severity: UPDRS motor score >30/108 at off state, Hoehn-and-Yahr grade ≥ 3
- Age ≤ 75
- MMSE ≥ 24/30 with no significant comorbidity, psychiatric problem and dementia
- No structural lesion, severe cerebral atrophy or extensive white matter change

Operative techniques

- Awake / Sedation: can facilitate intra-operative neurological testing (cf. GA)
- Target sites:
  | Parkinson's disease | Subthalamic nucleus (STN) <br> Globus pallidus interna (GPi) |
  | ----------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------ |
  | Essential tremor | Ventral intermediate nucleus of thalamus (VIM) |
  | Medical-refractory epilepsy | Anterior nucleus of thalamus |
  | Tourette's syndrome | Globus pallidus interna (GPi) |

- Pre-op:
  - Measure frame size: fixate at bilateral EAM
  - Assessment by neurologists: withhold anti-Parkinsonism medications to render patient in "off" state
  - Stereotactic CT brain with head frame just before OT → navigation planning (fusion with pre-op MRI)
- Intra-op - Awake technique: facilitate intra-operative neurological testing (cf. GA), but require good pain control, meticulous positioning, thermal control, avoid Foley catheter - Confirm coordinates of frame with intra-op fluoroscopy - Confirm site of implantation: EMG, BIS (bispectral index EEG), micro-electrode recording (MER) - Subcutaneous tunneling under GA

  5.8 Radiology of brain
  Pathology

- Description: size (small, large) + extent (focal, diffuse) + density (hyperdense, isodense, hypodense)
- Localisation: Intraaxial, extraaxial, ventricular, arterial, bone
  Density
- Hypodense: oedema, infarct, old clot/blood\*, abscess (ring-enhancing)
- Hyperdense: new clot/haemorrhage\*, contrast-enhanced blood, calcification, tumour (slightly hyperdense with surrounding hypodense oedema)
- Isodense: choroid plexus
  Mass effect
- Midline shift/ shift of structure
  Cerebral ring-enhancing lesion - MAGIC DR
- M: metastasis
- A: abscess
- G: glioblastoma
- I: infarct (subacute phase)
- C: contusion
- D: demyelinating disease
- R: radiation necrosis or resolving haematoma
